 The purpose is to use multilingual text data consisting of languages that are not included in the paired data.
 The input text token sequence is denoted as X = (xn ∈ V |n = 1, · · · , N ).
 The embedding layers output Z m = (zm) and el.
 The bottleneck layer is used to project the token and language embeddings into a hidden input vector.
 The training objective is defined as Lmlm = 1/K ∑_{k=1}^{K} log p(xπk |X m).
 The main focus is on the supervised learning of the TTS model with paired data.
 The speech features are predicted with teacher forcing using the encoder and decoder.
 The scheme aims to facilitate cross-lingual transfer by preserving the parameters of the language-aware embedding layer.
 The training process involves updating the encoder and decoder while freezing the bottleneck layer and token embedding layer.
 The speech features are predicted by feeding the encoder output to the decoder.

 Equation 6 describes the process of identifying the most likely hypothesis summary ˆY given the input X and semantic representation S.
 We can write P(Y, S|X) = P(Y|X)P(S|X) based on the conditional independence.
 The solution for Equation 6 is obtained using the coordinate descent update shown in Equation 7.
 The encoder and decoder model the probabilities P(S|X) and P(Y|S) respectively.
 The three alternate structures mentioned are Concatenation, Gated Attention, and Hierarchical Attention.
 The How-2 Dataset contains 2,000 hours of instructional videos with corresponding text transcripts, video, speech, translations, and summaries.
 The models used in the experimental setup are ESPNet22, ASR, SUMM, and BASS models.
 The ASR models are trained with Connectionist Temporal Classification (CTC) and Cross-Entropy loss with CTC weight of 0.3.

 Unlimiformer is fully non-parametric and can improve performance without fine-tuning, while Memorizing Transformers added additional weights and cannot easily leverage pretrained LMs.
 While Wu et al. (2022) applies retrieval attention to only a single layer due to computational constraints, Unlimiformer enables the use of retrieval attention in every decoder layer with individualized retrieval per-head.
 Unlimiformer is the only model that can provide benefits without further training, as it can improve base models without any additional training.
 Unlimiformer applied at early stop provides significant gains without any special training, improving the base model by, for example, 3.3 ROUGE-1 points on the GovReport dataset.
 Injecting Unlimiformer at test time results in the most significant gains, with improvements of 7.2 ROUGE-1 and 3 BERTScore points, while the training remains as computationally cheap as standard finetuning.
 The Book Summarization experiments with Unlimiformer include Standard finetuning, +test Unlimiformer, +early stop w/ Unlimiformer, Unlimiformer (retrieval training), Unlimiformer (random-encoded training), and Unlimiformer (alternating training).
 Unlimiformer outperforms both base models, BARTbase and PRIMERA, in BookSum. Additionally, the base model BARTbase, even with Standard finetuning, shows competitive ROUGE and BERTScore metrics.
 Table 4 shows that in almost all metrics and datasets, Unlimiformer outperforms the SLED and Memorizing Transformers baselines when using the same base model.
 PRIMERA experiments highlight that Unlimiformer combined with BARTbase performs better than the base PRIMERA across all metrics and datasets. Unlimiformer can also be applied on top of existing long-range transformers and further improve them.
 Unlimiformer can improve the performance of existing long-range transformers like PRIMERA and BARTbase, even when they were pretrained on much more data. Unlimiformer can provide additional improvements over these models across all metrics and datasets.
 The quality degradation of the reconstructed structure due to the misalignment of the rotation axis is more difficult to compensate by reconstruction algorithms.
 Post-acquisition sample alignment schemes include image processing techniques and iterative reconstruction-reprojection methods.
 Vo et al. (2014) proposed a sample alignment scheme based on Fourier space sinograms.
 Yang et al. (2017) used convolutional neural networks.
 The alignment method discussed in the text focuses on pre-acquisition processes, aligning the rotation axis first and then the sample.
 A genetic algorithm is introduced to optimize the motor position in the global scope for automatic alignment. It ensures globally optimized results without requiring gradient information or a mathematical model.
 Virtual tomography experiments were conducted for algorithm verification and software validation.
 VBS simulates multi-modal and high-data-throughput experiments at next-generation beamlines, allowing users to test and implement algorithms without a real experimental setup.
 The walnut sample is used as it has sharp features that can aid in aligning the rotation axis with respect to the detector.
 The rotation axis is aligned by adjusting motors (cid:3) and (cid:4) to account for the effect caused by the two orthogonal vectors Zt and Xt.
 The AAAI-23 conference on artificial intelligence was held at the Concord Consortium in Concord, MA.
 The main concern is that opportunities to learn AI concepts and practices are scarce, and computer science courses where AI could be taught are only offered in some high schools.
 Many AI innovations are used to solve problems in subject domains outside of computer science.
 The curriculum module is called Exploring Artificial Intelligence in English Language Arts with StoryQ, which introduces students to fundamental AI concepts and essential machine learning workflow.
 Students work with unstructured text data in the StoryQ module.
 Some examples include intent recognition, clickbait filter, and sentiment analysis.
 Students interact with machine-learning language models deeply in the StoryQ module.
 The goal is to transform AI education and reach students who are most underrepresented and underserved in the field.
 The StoryQ app offers dynamically linked data representations that promote meaningful inquiries and allow students to engage in machine learning practices without coding.
 The StoryQ module addresses Big Idea #2: Representation & Reasoning and Big Idea #3: Learning.
 The purpose is to obtain high-quality knowledge for deriving plural considerations.
 GPT-4 excels at enumerating a wide range of value alternatives.
 91% of the distilled data is deemed high quality.
 Clean situations are derived by carefully filtering out ill-formatted, irrelevant, and low-quality situations using few-shot Flan-T5.
 The proportion is down-sampled to 5% of all data to balance out the outsize proportion, leading to an increase in overall diversity of the dataset.
 GPT-4 prompts to generate relevant values, rights, and duties, along with open-text rationales.
 VALUEPRISM is converted into a sequence-to-sequence format for multi-task training, where relevance task data is sampled contrastively.
 Flan-T5 3B is used as the base model for KALEIDO.
 The system overgenerates values and removes low-quality and repetitive outputs based on relevance score and text similarity.
 Gibbs sampling is used to tune the relevance score threshold and similarity thresholds.
 CUTTLEFISH switches from full-rank training to low-rank training when the estimated ranks for all NN layers stabilize.
 CUTTLEFISH tracks the sequences of stable ranks for each layer at each epoch and measures the derivative of the estimated rank sequences for all layers using a rank stabilization threshold.
 Parameter K in hybrid architectures balances the final accuracy and model compression rate.
 It is challenging because it is impractical to achieve faster training speeds without fully training the model to convergence.
 CUTTLEFISH proceeds with factorization if the full-rank time is more than 1.5 times factorized time for a given threshold when proﬁling rank ratio candidates.
 Arithmetic intensity is the ratio of FLOPS to the bytes of data accessed. It affects factorization as layers with low arithmetic intensity may not yield a significant speedup even if FLOPs are reduced.
 Initial layers have small mn but large HW values, resulting in higher arithmetic intensity, while later layers have small H, W values but large mnk2 values.
 Factorizing the initial layers does not yield a significant speedup due to their high arithmetic intensity, which affects the overall performance even if FLOPs are reduced.

 CUTTLEFISH tracks the sequences of stable ranks for each layer at each epoch and measures the derivative of the estimated rank sequences for all layers using a rank stabilization threshold.

 The model discussed in Figure 13 is WavLM, which consists of a CNN encoder followed by transformer encoder layers.
 The audio inputs in the WavLM model are simulated as 2-second sequences sampled at 16 kHz to create 32,000-dimensional floating-point inputs.
 In Figure 13, it is observed that WavLM exhibits framework-bound behavior but quickly transitions to being compute-bound due to the large audio sequence lengths.
 Figure 11 discusses the latency of vision models that scale model depth and number of hidden dimensions.
 The batch sizes mentioned are 100 for WavLM (fp16) and WavLM (fp32).
 It is highlighted that transformer-based speech models exhibit framework boundedness but transition to compute-bound at small batch sizes due to long sequence lengths.
 The transition to compute-bound behavior for WavLM in Figure 13 is attributed to the large audio sequence lengths.
 The discussion in Figure 13 includes the behavior of WavLM, framework boundedness, compute-bound transition, and batch sizes.
 The WavLM model consists of a CNN encoder followed by transformer encoder layers.
 The simulation in the WavLM model uses 32,000-dimensional floating-point inputs created from 2-second sequences sampled at 16 kHz.
 Relatively dry and cold, with an average relative humidity (RH) below 60% and temperatures ranging from -9 to 17 degrees Celsius.
 Higher wind speeds (>3 m s−1) corresponded to northerly winds and were associated with increased daily average PM2.5 concentration and RH.
 Local emissions, regional transport, and liquid/heterogeneous reactions at different stages of the episode.
 The range of aerosol number concentration varied from ~1000 to 17,000 cm−3 with an average of 6714 ± 3117 cm−3.
 The number concentration decreased with the increasing mass concentration, indicating that the wet scavenging effect of fog droplets reduced aerosol number concentration but enhanced liquid-phase reactions.
 Aerosols with higher hygroscopicity are mainly composed of inorganics, which have a greater tendency to form cloud droplets compared to less water-soluble substances like BC or primary organics.
 Organic matter and nitrate were the most important components, followed by ammonium, sulfate, BC, and chloride.
 Organics dominated at low PM2.5 concentration levels (<25 µg m−3), while nitrate became the dominant composition as PM2.5 levels increased.
 The average RH was below 60%, with a temperature ranging from -9 to 17 degrees Celsius.
 The average concentrations were 1345 ± 1270 cm−3 at 0.1% supersaturation, 2752 ± 2114 cm−3 at 0.2% supersaturation, and 3267 ± 2325 cm−3 at 0.3% supersaturation.

 The 4 preprocessing methods investigated are filtering files from repositories with 5+ GitHub stars, filtering files with a high comments-to-code ratio, more aggressive filtering of near-duplicates, and filtering files with a low character-to-token ratio.
 The new filters had a modest impact except for the stars filter, which significantly deteriorated performance on text2code benchmarks.
 A final 1.1B parameter model, dubbed SantaCoder, was trained on Python, JavaScript, and Java.
 SantaCoder obtains comparable or stronger performance than previous open-source multilingual models, InCoder-6.7B and CodeGen-Multi-2.7B, on code generation and infilling tasks.
 Multi Query Attention (MQA) is an architectural change to the transformer neural network where key and value embeddings are shared across attention heads. It is implemented in AlphaCode and PaLM.
 The correctness of generated code can be tested using unit tests or textual similarity metrics.
 Two popular benchmarks for Python are HumanEval and MBPP.
 CodeXGLUE is a set of 14 datasets for evaluating code generation models. The tasks include code-to-code tasks like clone detection, code repair, and code translation; text-to-code tasks like code search and code generation; and code-to-text tasks like generating documentation.

Bhiksha Ramakrishnan, Carolyn Rosé, Alexander Rudnicky
Machine Learning, Multimodal Computing and Interaction, Speech Processing, Spoken Interfaces and Dialogue Processing, Privacy
Information Retrieval, Text Mining and Analytics, Language Technologies for Education, Natural Language Processing and Computational Linguistics, Computer Supported Collaborative Learning/MOOCs
Multimodal Computing and Interaction, Speech Processing, Spoken Interfaces and Dialogue Processing

Research Professor Emeritus
 The focus is on determining whether a claim can be supported by evidence.
 The FEVER dataset is used to determine whether fine-grained claims based on Wikipedia articles are correct.
 FactCC and QAGS-based models detect factual consistency by checking if generated summaries or summary sentences are factually consistent with the given evidence text.
 RARR proposes a method that prompts LLMs to generate queries, retrieve evidence, and determine factuality directly.
 The paper introduces the challenge of factuality detection without explicit claims or evidence.
 Language models use various tools to overcome their limited knowledge and expand their capabilities.
 The unified framework extends the definition of factuality to include claims made in generated signals that can be supported by evidence under specific rules.
 Fine-grained factuality detection allows users to pinpoint inaccuracies and serves as a reward model for developers to refine generative systems.
 The paper suggests using instruction-following ability and natural language interface of LLMs for defining and extracting fine-grained claims.
 The concepts involved are prompt, response, claim, and evidence.
 To significantly compress the size of speech data and reduce training time while retaining performance.
 They are often used as input for the subsequent model, but can still be redundant.
 Methods such as de-duplication and subword modeling.
 Discrete units achieve reasonably good results in almost all the settings.
 The information of speech signals in a short window is represented by a single token or a few levels from restricted vocabulary.
 Discrete units substantially reduce data storage and transmission size while maintaining performance comparable to conventional features.
 Input sequence lengths can be drastically reduced via de-duplication and subword modeling on discrete units.
 Conventionally, spectral speech features are extracted from a fixed-length temporal window.
 Frameworks mentioned include connectionist temporal classification (CTC), attention-based encoder-decoder (AED), and RNN-Transducer.
 Tips include selecting SSL features based on canonical correlation analysis (CCA) and exploring other possible choices of discrete units.
 To analyze words that occur more often with one type of trigger word compared to other trigger words.
 2 words.
 To plot sentence embeddings in a two-dimensional space and visualize the similarity between data points.
 It measures the similarity between output embeddings of prompts with sexual identity trigger words and control prompts.
 It measures how society perceives an individual based on the words used to describe them.
 Outputs with queer trigger words had lower regard scores than those with straight counterparts.
 A post-hoc approach using a text-to-text neural style transfer task to preserve semantic meaning and increase regard.
 It is used with a trained classifier to detect words that influence the output towards a particular label more than others.
 Chain-of-thought prompting (CoT).
 Control and straight men outputs were similar, while gay men and lesbian women were closer to each other but afar from control outputs.
 The main focus has been on English.
 Arabic is considered underrepresented because most LLMs are primarily trained and instruction-tuned for English and are not able to extend their capabilities to languages other than English.
 Jais
 72 billion Arabic tokens were pretraining data for Jais.
 To address the limited availability of high-quality Arabic data, the authors trained bilingual models by augmenting the Arabic pretraining data with abundant English pretraining data.
 Arabic data constituted 33% of the pretraining data for the model Jais.
 The authors adopted ALiBi positional encodings, SwiGLU activation function, maximal update parametrization, and a custom-built tokenizer to enhance the performance of the model.
 Safety measures implemented include safety prompts, keyword-based filtering, and external classifiers.
 They were evaluated across Arabic and English NLP benchmarks, addressing reasoning, knowledge, misinformation, and bias.
 By making the models publicly available, the authors hope to enable further research and development, stimulating innovation and practical applications for the Arabic and global communities.
 The main focus of the OpenMatch-v2 toolkit is on Information Retrieval models powered by Pre-trained Language Models (PLMs).
 The code of OpenMatch is publicly available at https://github.com/OpenMatch/OpenMatch.
 Some key features of OpenMatch-v2 compared to the previous version include further improvements in dense text retrieval, re-ranking, query synthesis, unsupervised pre-training, and efficient data accessing, among others.
 PLMs have emerged as the foundation of advanced IR models, enabling novel models, domain adaptation algorithms, and larger datasets in IR research.
 Recent IR research has become almost exclusively PLM-centric and is conducted under larger, more diverse, and cross-modality datasets.
 OpenMatch-v2 was developed as an upgrade to OpenMatch to catch up with the latest trends in IR research, enhance flexibility, scalability, and support new-generation PLM-based IR models with improved domain adaptation techniques.
 OpenMatch-v2 introduces T5 as a new backbone for IR models in addition to traditional BERT-series models.
 OpenMatch-v2 supports CLIP-based text-to-image retrieval, structured data retrieval including code and product search, in addition to traditional dense text retrieval and re-ranking.
 Template-based data processing in OpenMatch-v2 helps researchers extract data from different datasets in a general way and provides an efficient method for data accessing and searching to handle large corpora with limited resources.
 OpenMatch-v2 supports algorithms such as query synthesis, unsupervised pre-training, and re-ranker score distillation for domain adaptation to enhance model performance in few-shot scenarios.

 To track and incentivize the global development of equitable language technology.
 GlobalBench aims to dynamically track progress on all NLP datasets in all languages, measuring accuracy and estimated per-speaker utility and equity.
 GlobalBench covers 966 datasets in 190 languages.
 They are overlooked despite having a relatively high population.
 Incentives and resource allocation.
 XTREME and XGLUE.
 To evaluate all datasets in all languages for all tasks.
 Improving the quality and equity of language technologies for all speakers in the world.
 What you cannot measure, you cannot improve.
 By explicitly measuring and incentivizing the improvement of language technology for all.

 Manner adverbs that are not agent-oriented
 So that the noun can work in both intransitive and transitive templates using the same sense of the verb
 Something that initiates an action, possibly with some degree of volition
 On Google Forms
 14
 Things that undergo an action and often experience a change
 1 = very unlikely to be an agent, 2 = somewhat unlikely to be an agent, 3 = no preference between agent and patient, 4 = somewhat likely to be an agent, 5 = very likely to be an agent
 Volitional involvement in the event or state, sentience causing an event or change of state in another participant, movement relative to another participant

 Designing exemplars selection strategy
 Because it is found to be effective in improving translation performance
 They improve translation performance
 High-quality pool like development set
 Because developing a bilingual translation system for each direction becomes impossible with increasing supporting languages
 They focus on LLM and its potential in MMT
 Even GPT-4 faces challenges on low-resource languages
 Instruction semantics can be ignored during in-context learning and cross-lingual exemplars can provide better task instruction for low-resource translation
 LLMs can acquire translation ability in a resource-efficient way, promising a bright future in MMT

Lecture
Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania
6.0 A3 R
06:30PM - 09:20PM
6.0 A3 R
 Community-specific investigations are an important future step towards developing effective counter-statements.
 The selection of specific individuals for direct exceptions is challenging due to the high number of marked incorrect instances and biases encoded in language models.
 Language models often encode biases and stereotypes derived from training corpora, making it difficult to produce relevant individuals who do not fit a particular stereotype.
 Producing accurate and relevant direct exceptions to stereotypes is important for understanding the role of counterexamples in countering essentialist beliefs.
 The text highlights the potential harms to workers who are subjected to offensive statements.
 The risks associated with automatic generation of counterstatements include potential misuse in distributed-denial-of-service attacks, perpetuating essentialist beliefs, and producing false and harmful generalizations.
 It is important to develop regulations alongside AI technology to limit harms and misuse in deployment of automated counterstatement generation.
 Annotators are encouraged to reach out to the authors with concerns and questions or to the Crisis Text Line to mitigate potential harms to workers.
 The text proposes working at the intersection of NLP and psychology as crucial for further investigations in countering essentialist beliefs.
 The text mentions the importance of considering ethical risks and the potential for misuse when generating counterstatements.
 k = 8, T = 50, w = 0.3

 ij are initialized as zeros, and h0 features of the nodes.
 A 2-neuron and 1-neuron classification/regression head is applied to the final embeddings of xt for discrete and continuous diffusion models, respectively.
 For all TSP and MIS benchmarks, a 12-layer Anisotropic GNN with a width of 256 is used.
 Specialized decoding strategies are designed for the two CO problems studied in the paper to ensure feasible solutions.
 The diffusion models are adapted to generate heatmaps by making appropriate modifications.
 Greedy decoding and Monte Carlo Tree Search (MCTS) are used to evaluate the heatmap scores for TSP decoding.
 A greedy decoding strategy is used for the MIS problem.
 A common practice for probabilistic CO solvers is to sample multiple solutions and report the best one.
 TSP-50 instances are used as the main benchmark to compare different model configurations.
 The three evaluation metrics presented are average tour length, average relative performance gap, and total run time.

 The main focus of the text is on pretraining data design for language models.
 The text explores the effects of pretraining data age, domain coverage, quality, and toxicity filters.
 28 1.5B parameter decoder-only models were pretrained in the study.
 A temporal shift between evaluation data and pretraining data leads to performance degradation, which is not overcome by finetuning.
 The study shows a trade-off between performance on standard benchmarks and the risk of toxic generations when implementing quality and toxicity filters.
 The study concludes that there is not a one-size-fits-all solution to filtering training data.
 The text mentions that the inclusion of heterogeneous data sources like books and web is broadly beneficial and warrants greater prioritization.
 The experimental pretraining curation pipeline includes sub-selecting data from C4 or the Pile, pretraining a language model, and evaluating its change in performance over several benchmarks.
 MIT and Cornell University are mentioned as contributors to the study.
 The hope is that the findings will help support more informed data-centric decisions in language model development.

 GPT-4 and ChatGPT
 In-context learning enables language models to learn target tasks based on prompts without updating parameters. It is important as it helps models generate better outputs in NLP tasks.
 The final prompt is constructed by wrapping exemplars with a template and concatenating them together.
 A large language model generates output Y of the test sample X by maximizing the conditional probability p(P ⊕ T (X , Y)).
 For label prediction tasks, the prediction can be obtained in one-step generation.
 For sequence generation tasks, predictions can be obtained through sampling strategies like greedy search and beam search.
 Exemplars, which are supervised data pairs, and a human-written template are used to construct prompts for in-context learning.
 The symbol ⊕ denotes the concatenation symbol, such as whitespace or line-break.
 The language family direction table compares translation performance metrics across different language pairs.
 Performance metrics like BLEU and COMET are used to quantify the quality of translations for different language pairs.
 Four templates
 No
 Increased complexity due to more repetitive operations
 A testbed that incorporates memory components
 Hierarchical planning
 Future research focus
 GPT-4 achieves a limited end-to-end task success rate of 14.41%, significantly lagging behind the human performance

 Automatically recommending relevant datasets given a description of a data-driven system.
 Keyword query or a full-sentence description.
 Precision@k, Recall@k, Mean Average Precision (MAP), Mean Reciprocal Rank (MRR).
 The proportion of relevant items in the top k retrieved datasets.
 Mean Reciprocal Rank. It is calculated as the average of the inverse of the ranks at which the first relevant item was retrieved.
 The DataFinder Dataset.
 17495 queries.
 Over the collection of datasets listed on Papers With Code.
 Automatically labeled using the body text of a paper.
 Few-shot learning and rule-based methods.
 Some datasets mentioned are Topical-Chat, Wizard of Wikipedia, Wochat, ConvAI2-GRADE, DailyDialog-GRADE, DSTC7, HCChinese ChatEval, DSTC10. Some models mentioned are DailyDialog-GUPTA, FED-Dial, FED-Turn, Persona-SEE, and others.
 The LCCC corpus is designed for pretraining the Chinese dialogue model. It contains dialogues collected mainly from Weibo and other open-source Chinese dialogue corpora, filtered based on heuristic rules and classifiers to remove noise.
 354 dialogues were sampled from the original KdConv corpus to form the KdConv-Eval test dataset.
 The HCChinese dataset consists of dialogues collected by interacting with three state-of-the-art Chinese chatbots on various topics. It was manually checked to filter out inappropriate responses.
 The TBD-Q1-2023 corpus consists of dialogues with three chatbots: ChatGPT, GPT-3, and BlenderBot3. Student participants had conversations with the chatbots on different topics, collected between November 2022 and March 2023.
 Some of the emotion categories used for annotation are angry, happy, sad, etc. The dialogues were automatically annotated by pre-trained emotion classifiers.
 Most of the dialogues in the LCCC corpus were collected from Weibo, a Chinese microblogging website.
 The total number of dialogues in the ESTC dataset is not explicitly mentioned in the text.
 531 human-chatbot multi-turn conversations were collected for the HCChinese dataset, with 207 from Plato-XL, 224 from XiaoIce, and 100 from the Chinese Di- aloGPT.
 The conversations for TBD-Q1-2023 were collected between November 2022 and March 2023.
 Natural Interaction: Computers can communicate factual information but struggle with understanding nonliteral modes of expression.
 AI technologies are changing the ways we work, travel, communicate, and care for each other. However, biases in data used for AI systems could lead to some people being less well served.
 StoryQ, a code-free web-based machine learning and text mining tool.
 It extracts features from all documents and compiles them into one feature table, summarizing their frequencies associated with each label.

 The unexpected transfer test discusses a false belief rather than a true belief.
 ChatGPT likely fails on the true belief task due to its exposure to the Salley-Anne task.
 Figures 6 and 7 illustrate the variations proposed by Ullman for the examples in ToM-k.
 An MC-probing setup, which involves concatenation of the original test with all possible answers and an instruction to choose an option, was used as input to the LLMs for the prompts.
 Natalie mistakenly thinks the ring is still in box A, where she initially put it.
 The triangle hesitates to open the door because it is unsure if it wants to let the circle in.

 Hyperparameters were chosen to minimize randomness, predict the most probable answer, and allow for a sufficient number of tokens.
 Task 2 scored lower than reported for GPT 3.5, with either 85% or 90% accuracy.
 The purpose of the second, secret test set for SocialIQa is to determine whether LLMs generalize or memorize when they solve the ToM tasks and to avoid data contamination.
 The text states that generative models, such as GANs, memorize more data as their quality improves and that diffusion models are less private than GAN models.
 The best DDPM model memorizes 2× more than StyleGAN-ADA but reaches the same FID.
 The text suggests that understanding why some images are inherently less private than others, despite being memorized by both diffusion models and GANs, is a fruitful direction for future work.
 Deduplicating Training Data is mentioned as a defense strategy to reduce and audit model memorization.
 5,275 examples were removed by deduplication from the total examples in CIFAR-10.
 The gold standard technique mentioned is training with differential privacy guarantees (DP).
 Applying DP-SGD to the diffusion model codebase in the text caused the training on CIFAR-10 to consistently diverge.
 The purpose is to evaluate memorization in the models and determine their vulnerability.
 Canaries are examples inserted into the training set to measure how many bits were learned about them compared to other examples.
 Figure 16 shows that inserting a canary twice is sufficient to reach maximum exposure, and the exposure is not strictly increasing with duplicate count.

 The main focus is on figurative language in human communication and its processing in language models.
 The languages included are Hindi, Indonesian, Javanese, Kannada, Sundanese, Swahili, and Yoruba.
 The text reveals that each language relies on cultural and regional concepts for figurative expressions, with the highest overlap between languages from the same region.
 All languages exhibit a significant deficiency compared to English in interpreting figurative language.
 MBR decoding is a method for choosing the outputs of a machine learning system based on the output with the lowest risk among multiple candidates, rather than the output with the highest probability.
 MBR provides reliable improvements across metrics for a variety of tasks without requiring additional data or training.
 Unlimiformer is a method that extends transformer models to process unlimited-length inputs by offloading cross-attention computation to a k-nearest-neighbor index, improving performance without additional learned weights.
 The environment focuses on language-guided agents performing tasks on the web, aiming for realism and reproducibility.
 The best GPT-4-based agent achieves an end-to-end task success rate of 14.41%.
 Prompt2Model is a method that takes natural language task descriptions to train special-purpose models for deployment, providing an alternative to large language models.

Gates and Hillman Center is located at 5000 Forbes Avenue, Pittsburgh, PA 15213.
The duration of a typical MCDS degree program varies depending on factors such as residency requirements and course load, but generally ranges from 13 to 18 months.
The prerequisite core courses for an MCDS degree include a variety of subjects such as mathematics, statistics, and computer science. These courses provide students with a solid foundation in key areas relevant to their future studies.
Common MCDS core courses include subjects such as data structures, algorithms, and software engineering. These courses provide students with a broad understanding of fundamental concepts in computer science.
Areas of concentration for an MCDS degree include fields such as artificial intelligence, machine learning, and data analytics. Students can choose to specialize in one or more of these areas based on their interests and career goals.
MCDS capstone courses involve a culminating project that demonstrates students' mastery of skills learned throughout their degree program. These projects often focus on real-world problems and provide valuable experience for future careers.
The MCDS curriculum provides students with a comprehensive education in computer science, preparing them to tackle complex problems and contribute to cutting-edge research.
Double counting courses allows students to apply credits from certain undergraduate or graduate courses towards both their bachelor's and master's degrees, potentially reducing the total number of credits required.
Elective courses provide students with opportunities to explore additional topics in computer science that may not be covered by their core or concentration requirements. These can include subjects such as cybersecurity, human-computer interaction, and programming languages.
Undergraduate courses provide students with a strong foundation in computer science before they begin their master's program. These can include subjects such as algorithms, data structures, and software engineering.
An independent study course allows students to explore a topic in computer science that may not be covered by their regular curriculum. This provides them with valuable experience and can help prepare them for future research or projects.

The WORD refers to a resource or office that provides information for students at Carnegie Mellon University.
The Master of Computational Data Science (MCDS) degree is a professional Master of Science degree offered by the Language Technologies Institute (LTI), a department in the School of Computer Science at Carnegie Mellon University.
The Master of Computational Data Science (MCDS) degree is offered by the Language Technologies Institute (LTI), a department in the School of Computer Science at Carnegie Mellon University.
Students with a Bachelor's degree who have basic analytic skills and a strong aptitude for mathematics, programming, and logical reasoning can apply for the MCDS degree.
No, an undergraduate degree in Computer Science is not required for the MCDS degree.
Most students will complete the program in three semesters, but students coming from other disciplines and those focusing on developing applied research skills may require an additional fourth semester.
The MCDS Program offers a core curriculum and several concentrations. Students entering the program enroll in core courses in their first semester.
Yes, the MCDS Program offers several concentrations. Students entering the program enroll in core courses in their first semester.
The MCDS degree offers students with a Bachelor's degree the opportunity to improve their training with advanced study in Computer Science and Machine Learning.
The MCDS degree prepares students for further graduate study or research-oriented employment.
The MCDS program is typically a 16-month program consisting of courses, seminars, a required Capstone Project and a required summer internship or practical training.
Most graduates from the MCDS program go on to jobs in corporate research and development laboratories.
No, a Master’s Thesis is not required for completion of the MCDS program. All Capstone projects are structured as research activities and may lead to a publication.
Students construct their own course of study, in consultation with their academic advisor, in order to satisfy broad guidelines. Thus, a student may tailor their coursework in a given concentration to follow a particular area of emphasis.
The purpose of the Capstone Project is to provide students with an opportunity to apply and demonstrate their knowledge and skills in a real-world context, often through research or development projects.
Some potential career paths for MCDS graduates include jobs in corporate research and development laboratories, as well as continuing on to PhD programs in the LTI or other leading universities.
The MCDS program is highly selective and focuses on providing students with a strong foundation in computational data science, as well as practical experience through coursework, seminars, and a Capstone Project.
Students must satisfy broad guidelines by constructing their own course of study in consultation with their academic advisor. They may tailor their coursework to follow a particular area of emphasis.
The role of an academic advisor for MCDS students is to provide guidance and support in constructing their own course of study, ensuring that they meet broad guidelines and can tailor their coursework to follow a particular area of emphasis.

Carnegie Mellon University does not discriminate in admission, employment or administration of its programs or activities on the basis of race, color, national origin, sex, handicap or disability, age, sexual orientation, gender identity, religion, creed, ancestry, belief, veteran status or genetic information.

Students at Carnegie Mellon, because they are members of an academic community dedicated to the achievement of excellence, are expected to meet the highest standards of personal, ethical and moral conduct possible.
The purpose of the Carnegie Mellon Code is to outline the expected behavior for students at Carnegie Mellon, as they are members of an academic community dedicated to achieving excellence.
The phrase 'highest standards of personal, ethical and moral conduct' refers to the expectation that students at Carnegie Mellon should behave in a manner consistent with the principles of honesty, integrity, respect for others, responsibility, and fairness.
Being part of an academic community dedicated to achieving excellence means that students at Carnegie Mellon are expected to strive for and maintain a high level of intellectual, personal, and ethical development.
Members of the Carnegie Mellon community are expected to uphold a commitment to personal integrity, honesty without compromise, truth without equivocation and placing the good of the community above the good of the self. Obligations once undertaken must be met, and commitments kept.
It's crucial because the life of a student can affect the community as a whole. The discovery, advancement and communication of knowledge are not possible without commitment to these standards. Creativity cannot exist without acknowledgment of the creativity of others. New knowledge cannot be developed without credit for prior knowledge.
Personal integrity, a commitment to honesty without compromise and truth without equivocation, contributes significantly to the functioning of an academic community. It allows for trust among members which is essential in advancing knowledge.
When obligations once undertaken are not met, it can lead to a breakdown of the community's standards and trust. This is why commitments must be kept.
Creativity plays a crucial role in advancing knowledge within an academic community. It allows for new ideas and perspectives to emerge, leading to the discovery of new information.
Acknowledging prior knowledge is crucial because it gives credit where it's due. It also allows for a more accurate understanding and development of new ideas, as all information should be built upon existing knowledge.
The commitment to personal integrity, honesty without compromise, truth without equivocation and placing the good of the community above the self contributes significantly to the functioning of an academic community. It allows for trust among members which is essential in advancing knowledge.
When individuals do not respect these standards, it can lead to a breakdown of the community's integrity and trust. This can negatively impact the functioning of an academic community.
Acknowledging creativity in others allows for a sense of respect and appreciation within the academic community. It also encourages further development of ideas, as individuals are more likely to build upon existing knowledge when they know their work will be recognized.
Maintaining high standards for students contributes to the respect in which the Carnegie Mellon degree is held. Students who cannot meet these standards should voluntarily withdraw from the university.
The Carnegie Mellon Code can be found online at https://www.cmu.edu/student-affairs/theword/

This section describes the various programs available for students who are seeking a degree completion and certification in Master of Science in Data Science (MCDS) at Carnegie Mellon University.
The provision of community space and resources on campus aims to foster collaboration, interaction, and support among students, faculty, and staff.
Carnegie Mellon graduate students are expected to complete their degree requirements within the standard length of time for their program of study as outlined in the relevant Graduate Student Handbook. Standard program lengths vary significantly, ranging from two semesters for some full-time master’s programs to several or more years for doctoral programs.
Graduate students who consider the completion of all degree requirements in less than the standard length of time for their program of study may consult with their degree-granting program or department to determine if early degree certification is allowed and under what conditions.
Upon completion of the graduate program degree requirements, the degree will be certified by the student’s academic program in the semester in which the student completes the requirements.
Graduate students who consider the completion of all degree requirements in less than the standard length of time for their program of study may consult with their degree-granting program or department to determine if early degree certification is allowed and under what conditions.
Standard program lengths for graduate students vary significantly – ranging from two semesters for some full-time master’s programs to several or more years for doctoral programs.
It is not specified in the text what happens if a student fails to complete their degree requirements within the standard length of time for their program of study.
The text does not provide any information about potential benefits of completing a graduate program early.
Graduate students who consider the completion of all degree requirements in less than the standard length of time for their program of study may consult with their degree-granting program or department.
The text does not provide information about the statute of limitations for a Carnegie Mellon graduate student's degree.
Longer-than-standard completion may occur due to academic interruptions in making progress toward the degree as defined by the academic program, interruptions of full-time study or progress towards the degree due to serious, documented medical issues, or other unusual or unforeseen circumstances.
Master’s students who require longer than the standard time to complete their degree requirements
The purpose of Longer-than-standard completion is for Master's students who require longer than the standard time to complete their degree requirements.
A student may have an extended or longer-than-standard completion due to academic interruptions in making progress toward the degree as defined by the academic program, interruptions of full-time study or progress towards the degree due to serious, documented medical issues, or other unusual or unforeseen circumstances.
Master’s students who require longer than the standard time to complete their degree requirements are certified at the end
Master’s students who require longer than the standard time to complete their degree requirements are expected to remain in close contact with their graduate program.
The significance of Longer-than-standard completion for Master's students who require longer than the standard time to complete their degree requirements is that they are certified at the end.
When a student has an extended or longer-than-standard completion, it means that they require more time than the standard period to complete their degree requirements due to academic interruptions in making progress toward the degree as defined by the academic program, interruptions of full-time study or progress towards the degree due to serious, documented medical issues, or other unusual or unforeseen circumstances.
The role of a graduate program in Longer-than-standard completion for Master's students who require longer than the standard time to complete their degree requirements is to remain in close contact with these students and certify them at the end.
 The main focus of lexiprecision is to improve the sensitivity of reciprocal rank in measuring the quality of rankings for users interested in exactly one relevant item.
 Cooper proposed ESL1 in 1968.
 RL1 stands for recall level 1.
 The text addresses the issue of reciprocal rank being brittle when discriminating between ranking systems, especially in modern evaluation settings with high-precision systems.
 Lexiprecision preserves differences detected by reciprocal rank while empirically improving sensitivity and robustness in a broad set of retrieval and recommendation tasks.
 Lexiprecision provides a theoretically-justified ordering when RL1 is tied, preserving all strict orders and avoiding numerous ties observed with reciprocal rank.
 Hasse diagrams are used to compare the total order of lexiprecision with the partial order of reciprocal rank, showing how lexiprecision scales with the number of relevant items and reduces tied performance.
 The paper contributes by providing a detailed study of RL1 metrics, best-case retrieval evaluation, and lexiprecision, demonstrating how lexiprecision improves discriminative power while being strongly correlated with RL1 metrics.
 The observation is that ceiling effects are inherent in RL1 evaluation due to standard ranking problems and the symmetric group over n elements in predicting relevance.
 Reciprocal rank is defined as RR1(𝜋) = 1/p1, where p1 is the position of the first highest-ranked relevant item in a ranking 𝜋.
 To achieve near human-level naturalness.
 It is crucial for AI systems to achieve human-level communication.
 Real-world speech from YouTube and podcasts.
 Mismatch between training and inference alignments leading to unintelligible synthesis.
 Learned discrete codes within multiple code groups.
 Identifying the efficacy of the methods used in the MQTTS system.
 Higher variation of prosody and background noise.
 To address the issue of unintelligible speech due to improper text-audio alignment during inference.
 It leads to distorted reconstruction due to insufficient coverage of diverse prosody patterns.
 It excels in robustness and computation speed.
 GIDroid
 Up to 35% in execution time and up to 65% in memory consumption
 Relatively small programs trained on source code from programming competitions or puzzles
 ChatGPT4 failed to find any improvements, while GIDroid re-discovered 64% of those improvements

 WebArena provides the environment as dockers and provides scripts to reset the environment to a deterministic initial state.
 The observation space in WebArena is designed to roughly mimic the web browser experience, including a web page URL, the opened tabs, and the web page content of the focused tab.
 The multi-tab functionality in WebArena aims to offer a more authentic replication of human web browsing habits compared to maintaining everything in a single tab.
 The three modes in which the page content can be rendered in WebArena are the raw web page HTML, a screenshot, and the accessibility tree of the web page.
 WebArena ensures that the observation can be input into a text-based model with limited context length or an image-based model with image size or resolution requirements by providing an option to limit the content to the contents within a viewport for all modes.
 The available actions in WebArena are categorized into three distinct groups: element operations, tab-related actions, and URL navigation actions.
 WebArena supports agents designed in various ways by allowing element selection either by on-screen coordinates or by a unique element ID that is generated when traversing the Document Object Model (DOM) or accessibility tree.
 WebArena generates unique user profiles on each platform to emulate the scenario where users of the same website often have disparate experiences due to their distinct roles, permissions, and interaction histories.
 There are 812 test examples provided in the benchmark suite of web-based tasks in WebArena.
 Annotators were guided to formulate abstract and high-level intents, ensure creativity in the intents, and formulate the intent as a template with replaceable elements as variables.
 Confidence-based Active Retrieval
 By masking out low-confidence tokens or generating explicit questions
 Due to their significance as semantic units that are neither too short nor too lengthy
 To trigger retrieval if any token of the sentence has a probability lower than a threshold
 It often indicates a lack of knowledge
 Confidence-based Query Formulation
 To help retrieve relevant information and improve retrieval accuracy
 To remove potential distractions from the sentence to improve retrieval accuracy
 Generating explicit questions that target the low-confident span
 GPT-3.5 LMs text-davinci-003
 The EMPATHICSTORIES dataset is a corpus of personal stories containing 3,568 total annotations, including empathic similarity annotations of 2,000 story pairs and annotations for main events, emotions, morals, and empathy reasons for 1,568 individual stories.
 The EMPATHICSTORIES dataset includes empathic similarity annotations for 2,000 story pairs.
 The data annotation pipeline involves annotating individual story events, emotions, and morals, then using these annotations to sample balanced story pairs and rate empathic similarity scores.
 Some themes across the main events of the stories include romantic relationships, positive life events, depression, family, substance use, encouragement, college and school, loneliness, youth, life changes, work, and trauma.
 The stories in the dataset are collected from sources like social media sites, spoken narratives, and crowdsourced stories, including online personal stories, crowdsourced personal stories, and spoken personal narratives.
 The story pairs for empathic similarity annotation are created using a sampling method that aims to select balanced empathically similar and dissimilar story pairs based on composite similarity scores computed using SBERT.
 ChatGPT (gpt-3.5-turbo) is used to summarize all the stories before presenting the pairs to annotators to simplify the task.
 Workers provide four similarity ratings on a 4-point Likert scale for each story pair, rating overall empathic similarity, similarity in the main events, emotions, and morals of the stories.
 The agreement scores for empathic, event, emotion, and moral similarity among annotators are shown in Table 3, with most common disagreements being at most 1 Likert point away.
 To handle the cognitive load and simplify the annotation task for story pairs, ChatGPT is used to summarize all the stories before presenting them to annotators.

 The quality of an automatic evaluation metric is estimated by comparing the agreement between the metric scores and ground-truth quality scores on a large number of translations from different MT systems.
 System-level accuracy calculates the percent of system pairs that are ranked the same by the metric and ground-truth scores, averaged over a set of language pairs.
 Kendall’s τ
 Different variants of τ are inconsistent with respect to ties and even biased against metrics that predict ties.
 A pairwise accuracy score, denoted acc∗, which ranges between 0 and 1, and a random metric would achieve 33% accuracy.
 SP measures the overlap of predicted spans and gold (annotated) spans.
 It captures the percentage of gold major errors that were predicted as errors (either minor or major).
 One of the official metrics in the word-level quality estimation tasks.

 PaLM-2 models exhibited higher system-level performance than GPT-based GEMBA.

 The success of AI Feedback hints that the need for human supervision can be massively reduced.
 Some recent work raises questions if feedback is needed at all when a small amount of high-quality data with human instructions is available for supervised learning.
 The survey aims to help researchers understand the current state of the art and identify new and existing sources of feedback and ways of leveraging it.

 The Lagrangian is defined as L(ϑ) = ∫(ξl, ξr; ϑ)dt + λ ∂ ∂t ξr + β ∂ ∂t ξr + η ∂ ∂t ξl + β ξ2 l ∆ ξr − α ˙ξr + ˙ξl ˙ξr + ξr − 1 + ξ2 r 2 ξl − α ˙ξr + ˙ξl ∆ ˙ξl + ξl + dt 2 + µl(ξl(0) - Cl) + µr(ξr(0) - Cr) + νl ˙ξl(0) + νr ˙ξr(0) where λ, η, µ and ν are Lagrangian multipliers.
 The derivative of the Lagrangian w.r.t. the model parameter alpha yields: Lα = ∫2 ˜cdR(∂αξl + ∂αξr) + λ ∂ ∂t ξr + 2β ˙ξrξr∂αξr + β ∂ ∂t ξr + ∂αξr - ∆ 2 ∂αξr - α ∂ ∂t ˙ξr + ∂ ∂t ˙ξl - ˙ξr + ˙ξl + η ∂ ∂t ξl + 2β ˙ξlξl∂αξl + β ∂ ∂t ξl + ∂αξl + ∆ 2 ∂αξl - α ∂ ∂t ˙ξr + ∂ ∂t ˙ξl - ˙ξr + ˙ξl dt + µl∂αξl(0) + µr∂αξr(0) + νl∂α ˙ξl(0) + νr∂α ˙ξr(0) where lambda, eta, mu, and nu are Lagrangian multipliers.

 The gradient-descent rule for optimizing objective A26 involves updating alpha, beta, and delta as follows: alpha_k+1 = alpha_k - tau_alpha F_alpha beta_k+1 = beta_k - tau_beta F_beta delta_k+1 = delta_k - tau_F_delta
 The summary of the overall algorithm mentioned in the text includes: 1. Integrate (A27) and (A28) with initial conditions (A29)-(A32) from 0 to T, obtaining ξr, ξl, ˙ξr, and ˙ξl. 2. Integrate (A40)-(A43) with the initial conditions (A44)-(A47) from T to 0, obtaining λ, ˙λ, η, and ˙η. 3. Update alpha, beta, and delta with (A51).

Yes, they have graduation ceremonies.
Grandfather policy and definition of transfer credit versus course exemption
Yes, it is mentioned under LTI Academic Policies.
The four sections in LTI's academic policies are: 'Grandfather' policy, Definition of transfer credit versus course exemption, Employment/Consulting, and Leave of Absence.
According to LTI's academic policies, transfer credit refers to credits earned at another institution that can be applied towards your degree requirements. Course exemption, on the other hand, is when you have already taken a course elsewhere and passed it with a grade of B or better, which allows you to skip taking the same course at LTI.
The four sections in Carnegie Mellon's academic policies are: Assistance for Individuals with Disabilities, Summary of Graduate Student Appeal and Grievance Procedures, Process for Appealing Final Grades, Safeguarding Educational Equity.
According to Carnegie Mellon's academic policies, if you wish to appeal a final grade, you must first speak with your instructor. If this does not resolve the issue, you can then submit an appeal in writing to the department head or program director within 10 business days of receiving the grade.
Safeguarding Educational Equity refers to a policy that ensures all students have equal opportunities and access to education, regardless of their background or circumstances. This includes providing accommodations for individuals with disabilities.
The language policy states that English is the primary language used in all official communications and coursework at Carnegie Mellon. However, students are encouraged to use their native languages for communication with each other.
Cultural Tolerance refers to the policy that promotes respect and understanding of different cultures, beliefs, and perspectives. It encourages students to appreciate diversity in all its forms.
The 'Grandfather' policy refers to a provision that allows certain courses or programs to maintain their current requirements even if they are updated in the future. This ensures that students who have already started these programs can complete them under the same conditions as when they began.
Employment/Consulting refers to a policy that allows students to work part-time while studying. This can help them gain practical experience and earn money, but it must not interfere with their studies or the quality of their work.

The purpose of the AI curriculum is for students with a strong background in computer science to study AI in-depth and develop real-world applications, especially in areas where AI has not been applied before.
The integrated curriculum includes coursework and team projects leading to a full-semester capstone project that produces a working prototype.
The capstone project in this AI curriculum lasts for a full semester.
Students are expected to develop real-world applications, especially in areas where AI has not been applied before.
The curriculum is designed for students who have a strong background in computer science with interest in in-depth study of AI.
In the context of this text, 'integrated' means that the curriculum includes both coursework and team projects.
The AI curriculum is structured to include a full-semester capstone project, which is preceded by coursework and team projects.
In the context of this text, 'capstone' refers to a culminating project that demonstrates students' mastery of AI concepts and skills.
The capstone project is evaluated based on its ability to demonstrate students' mastery of AI concepts and skills, as well as their development of real-world applications in areas where AI has not been applied before.
The benefits of studying AI through this curriculum include developing real-world applications, especially in areas where AI has not been applied before.

Carnegie Mellon University does not discriminate in admission, employment or administration of its programs or activities on the basis of race, color, national origin, sex, handicap or disability, age, sexual orientation, gender identity, religion, creed, ancestry, belief, veteran status or genetic information. Furthermore, Carnegie Mellon University does not discriminate and is required not to discriminate in violation of federal, state or local laws or executive orders.

Students at Carnegie Mellion University are expected to meet high standards of personal, ethical and moral conduct. This includes maintaining personal integrity, committing to honesty without compromise, speaking truthfully without equivocation, prioritizing the good of the community over self-interest, and fulfilling obligations once undertaken.
Carnegie Mellon's Code for students requires personal integrity, a commitment to honesty without compromise, truthfulness without equivocation, and a willingness to prioritize the good of the community over self-interest. Obligations once undertaken must be met, and commitments kept.
Students at Carnegie Mellon are expected to meet the highest standards of personal, ethical and moral conduct possible. They must have personal integrity, be committed to honesty without compromise, speak truth without equivocation, and place the good of the community above their own.
It's important because obligations once undertaken must be met, and commitments kept. The life of a student in an academic community can affect the whole community, and these standards apply.
A commitment to personal integrity, honesty without compromise, truth without equivocation, and a willingness to place the good of the community above the good of the self.
Trust is essential because creativity cannot exist without acknowledgment of the creativity of others, new knowledge cannot be developed without credit for prior knowledge, and an academic community cannot exist without it.
Without equivocation means to speak the truth clearly and directly, without any hesitation or ambiguity.
It's rare because obligations once undertaken must be met, commitments kept. The life of a student can affect the whole community and these standards apply.
Without compromise means to maintain personal integrity without making any exceptions or concessions, even when it is difficult or unpopular.
Students are expected to uphold and enforce these high standards because they are members of an academic community dedicated to excellence.
Acknowledgment means recognizing or admitting that someone else has contributed something valuable, and giving them credit for it.
The commitment of faculty, staff, and students at Carnegie Mellon University is to meet certain standards that contribute to the high respect in which their degree is held. Students are expected not to destroy this respect by failing to meet these standards.
Students who cannot meet the standards at Carnegie Mellon University are expected to voluntarily withdraw from the university.
The Reasonable Person Principle (RPP) is a long-standing and revered principle in the School of Computer Science that members of their community are expected to act reasonably. They try to keep formal, written SCS policies to a minimum and expect students not to find technical loopholes that violate program policies.
The purpose of providing working space for full-time MS students in the Language Technologies Institute on the Pittsburgh campus is to create a sense of community and provide space for them when they are on campus.
MS students in the Language Technologies Institute have access to shared working spaces, mailboxes, printers, copiers, and other departmental resources. Mailboxes, printers, copiers, and other departmental resources are located in GHC 5404.
The use of a photocopier requires only a CMU ID card. The School of Computer Science provides black-and-white and color printers for students' use, and they publish a list of these printers online at http://www.cs.cmu.edu/~help/printing/. When you send a file to the print queue, you may go to any listed printer, swipe your CMU ID, and the file will be printed on that printer.
During COVID-19, full-time MS students in the Language Technologies Institute have restrictions due to COVID. In-person meetings outside of a class being conducted in a classroom are banned until further notice.

 The WavLM model consists of a CNN encoder followed by transformer encoder layers.
 Audio inputs are simulated as 2 second sequences sampled at 16 kHz to create 32,000-dimensional floating point inputs.
 The WavLM model exhibits framework bound behavior initially but transitions to being compute-bound due to large audio sequence lengths.
 The batch size mentioned is 100.
 Transformer-based speech models exhibit framework boundedness but transition to compute-bound at small batch sizes due to long sequence lengths.
 The large audio sequence lengths cause the WavLM model to transition to being compute-bound.

 The ACL60/60 evaluation sets are designed for multilingual translation of ACL2022 technical presentations into 10 target languages to enable further research in the field of multilingual speech translation.
 The dataset provides unsegmented audio, domain-specific terminology, and diverse speaker demographics to evaluate and improve model robustness under realistic recording conditions.
 Translating technical presentations is challenging due to domain-specific terminology, recordings with background noise, diverse speaker demographics, and unsegmented speech typically lasting 10-60 minutes.
 The evaluation sets were curated from professionally transcribed and translated presentations at ACL2022 to balance speaker demographics, accents, and talk content while considering recording conditions.
 Resegmentation involves dynamically segmenting the output using a given tokenization to minimize word error rate to a reference segmentation for downstream evaluation.
 Common evaluation metrics include chrF, BLEU, COMET for translation quality, and WER for transcription quality, with TER also used for translation evaluation.
 Post-editing can bias data towards the initial MT systems used for translations and influence metrics towards similar systems.
 Segmentation is critical to ensure consistent translation across languages and provide necessary context for effective translation to the desired target languages.
 Limitations include potential bias towards MT systems used for initial translations, moderate size compared to other datasets, and the risk of overfitting to specific speakers or content.
 The dataset provides a valuable resource for studying language processing in the technical domain and aims to offer a more realistic and representative measure for generalization in this area.

 The text suggests that the benefits of AUTOMQM are less clear for smaller models like BISON, with both techniques (AUTOMQM and score prediction) performing comparably.
 The text mentions that the distribution of scores produced by LLMs prompted with AUTOMQM is much closer to the gold MQM distribution.

 The text indicates that errors predicted by UNICORN have on average approximately 5 words per span, compared to approximately 2 words in the ground truth.

 The main focus is on using a decoder-only architecture for speech recognition with CTC prompts and text data augmentation.
 The study aims to address the challenge of obtaining a large amount of audio-text pair data for ASR by proposing a new training scheme using text-only data.
 The encoder features compressed by CTC prediction are used as prompts for the decoder to refine CTC prediction using the decoder-only model.
 The decoder-only architecture simplifies enhancing the model by leveraging external text data for training, as the decoder architecture is the same as an autoregressive LM.
 The proposed model with text augmentation training reduced word error rates by 0.3% and 1.4% on LibriSpeech test-clean and test-other sets, and by 2.9% and 5.0% on Switchboard and CallHome.
 The proposed decoder-only architecture outperformed conventional encoder-decoder models with a similar parameter setup and had an advantage in computational efficiency.
 The main contributions include proposing a new training scheme to build a decoder-only model for ASR tasks simultaneously augmented by text-only data and achieving lower word error rates with reduced computational cost.
 Audio information is provided as prompts directly in the embedding space of the decoder.
 The proposed model uses CTC prediction to efficiently generate prompts, known as CTC prompts.
 The proposed decoder-only architecture does not have source-target attention layers like an autoregressive LM, making it more suitable for ASR tasks.

 To create a figurative language inference dataset for seven diverse languages associated with various cultures.
 Seven languages: Hindi, Indonesian, Javanese, Kannada, Sundanese, Swahili, and Yoruba.
 Figurative language is a reflection of cultural and societal experiences, making phrases difficult to be universally applicable.
 The study finds that each language relies on cultural and regional concepts for figurative expressions, with the highest overlap between languages from the same region.
 They influence the differences by shaping what concepts or objects are considered culturally significant and the sentiment attached to them in each culture.
 Understanding figurative language is important because linguistic communication often involves non-literal language, which can convey deeper meanings and emotions.
 Monolingual English speakers associate warmth with happiness, while native Hindi speakers may associate coldness with happiness.
 Tasks such as hate speech detection and sentiment classification would benefit from a better understanding of figurative language.
 It is important because cultural relevance helps language models understand how people in a specific culture view concepts and entities, improving their interpretation of figurative language.
 Concept shift across languages, particularly due to culturally specific examples.

 To evaluate model generalization since topics and vocabulary in Ted Talks may differ from movies or TV shows.
 Sentences were length-matched on the target side with corresponding sentences in the idiomatic set.
 To understand how much data is required to memorize non-compositional patterns.
 By generating corpora of different sizes containing occurrences of the non-compositional rule.
 Two informativity conditions: one where the context provides no information, and one where the context is perfectly informative.
 The number of encoder and decoder layers varied, while the hidden dimension and embedding size remained constant.
 There was a trend of translating non-compositional phrases literally, especially for smaller models.
 Clear context clues reduce the amount of data required for translating idioms effectively.
 There were drops in translation quality on idiomatic sentences in all languages, with lower automatic metrics overall.

 Lt+ obj(p) leads to worse mIoU than Lt because it allows greater region-label influence, leading to more noise in region-labels affecting less-common classes adversely.
 The decision to adopt Lt obj(p) is guided by the observation that Lt+ obj(p) leads to worse mIoU than Lt, primarily affecting less-common classes adversely.

 DACS+PAC refers to the regularized version shown in Figure 5.

 Generative adversarial networks (GAN), reinforcement learning, and convex approximations of metrics.
 Current methods were found to fail in capturing the acoustic parameters, and explicit supervision of retaining them improved model outputs.
 Previous methods attempted to use phonetic information in enhancing perceptual quality by implicitly capturing phonetic information in wav2vec embeddings.
 The techniques were evaluated on the Valentini dataset, which is much smaller and less varied than the dataset used in the experiments discussed.
 The method proposed in this text aimed to use a phonetic-aligned acoustic parameter loss to fine-tune speech enhancement models.
 The proposed method allows interpretability through both acoustic parameters and phonemes in the experiments section.
 Subsection 3.1 describes temporal acoustic parameter estimation, Subsection 3.2 describes phonetic-alignment and weighting, and Subsection 3.3 describes the overall fine-tuning process with the proposed PAAP Loss.
 The acoustic-phonetic weights in the PAAP Loss weigh the acoustic parameters differently based on their importance in predicting phoneme logits.
 The fine-tuning process involves predicting the phoneme index for each frame, using the argmax of predicted phoneme logits from clean audio, and performing calculations with the acoustic-phonetic weights.
 The evaluation results in Table 1 show improvements in various metrics such as PESQ, STOI, and WER when using the PAAP Loss compared with noisy audios.
 0.90
 The number of valid regions will increase at the expense of region-label consistency with ground-truth.
 The performance deteriorates.
 The mIoU increases with an increase in threshold up to a certain point (τp = 0.90), beyond which the performance deteriorates.
 DACS refers to a base method, while PAC is a visual comparison between DACS and the ground-truth under GTA→Cityscapes settings.
 The algorithm aims to adapt target-domain parameters using a pseudo-label and target training dataset, along with specific parameters and objectives.
 The Peak prominence threshold is denoted as δpeak.
 The weight αobj is used to control the effect of the objectness-constraint on the target-domain performance.
 The inputs include a pseudo-label, target training dataset with depth, initial model parameters, histogram bins, peak prominence threshold, RGB-segments, spatial dimensions of the depth map, region-label threshold, objectness constraint loss weight, and number of training iterations.
 The algorithm computes valid regions and region labels based on a threshold on majority-voting based region-label and region-wise frequency of pseudo-label classes.

Smart Traffic Signals
The project was funded by three Pittsburgh foundations.
According to CMU President Jared L. Cohon, the reductions in vehicle wait time, travel time and projected vehicle emissions are remarkable.
Pittsburgh Mayor Luke Ravenstahl cheered the success of the pilot as a breakthrough in making their city's traffic system work more efficiently.
Stephen Smith, director of the Intelligent Coordination and Logistics Laboratory in CMU's Robotics Institute, tackled this challenge.
Their first step was to combine concepts from artificial intelligence and traffic theory to allow traffic signals to communicate with each other in real time.
After the successful pilot, the next step will be to expand it on a bigger scale.
The groundbreaking technology was sponsored by the Traffic21 Initiative at CMU's

Pittsburgh can be positioned as a leading city on an international scale in demonstrating how low-cost, easy-to-implement technological solutions can reduce traffic congestion, vehicle fuel consumption and emissions while also improving safety and air quality.

17638
Riley, Pavetti
 The three main components are input processing, stability detection and output processing.
 The voice activity detection generates speech segments based on audio packets which are then processed for speech recognition.
 In revision mode, both stable and unstable outputs are allowed to be sent, while in fixed mode only stable output is allowed.
 Stability detection is implemented using the local agreement two (LA2) method which checks for common prefixes in the output.
 The backend model in the text processing component is used for machine translation.
 Unstable text messages are processed by the backend model and the output is sent as unstable text.
 The evaluation framework involves sending input audio to the system and evaluating the final returned transcript and translation in an end-to-end fashion.
 The framework can be extended by deploying additional backend models for different languages, adding new streaming algorithms, or including custom components in the session graph.
 Prefix decoding allows sending a prefix which is then forced in the output, aiding in stability detection and output processing.
 The moving average calculation is used to determine if a speech segment should start or end based on audio input exceeding certain thresholds.
 PV stands for photovoltaic.
 PVPOT = PR x I x ISTC
 PR represents the performance ratio, which accounts for temperature influence on PV efficiency.
 ISTC is defined as a constant of 1,000 W m−2.
 The cell temperature (Tcell) is approximated by a mathematical formula involving coefficients a1, a2, a3, and a4 multiplied by T, I, and W.
 WPD is defined as the generation of wind energy over all locations and is calculated using a specific formula involving wind speed (W) and air density (ρ).
 NMAD quantifies the day-to-day, month-to-month, and year-to-year variability of renewable energy.
 The scaling factor α represents how quickly the wind speed decreases towards the ground and is used to estimate wind speed at different heights based on the wind power law.
 The simulated solar PVPOT is evaluated by comparing it to the observations using the MBCn technique to correct for temperature, irradiance, and wind speed.
 The spatial pattern of solar PVPOT differences between regions is mainly attributed to variations in cloud cover and vegetation density.
 SemanticSTF
 RandLA-Net, SPVCNN, and SPVNAS
 PointDR is a domain randomization technique that aims to train a domain generalizable 3DSS model that can work well over adverse-weather point clouds.
 Dense fog, light fog, snow, and rain
 It demonstrates the importance of robust point cloud parsing under adverse weather conditions.
 Metareg
 Geometry style randomization and embedding aggregation
 Dense fog, light fog, snow, and rain
 Ministry of Education Singapore
 To create a model that can work well over adverse-weather point clouds
 Building cascaded unsupervised speech-to-speech translation systems and proposing denoising back-translation to improve robustness.
 It generally improves the performance across different language pairs that were experimented on.
 They are better than some previous supervised methods even without using any paired data.
 Investigating techniques to reduce error propagation between different unsupervised cascaded modules or conducting direct unsupervised speech-to-text translation.
 The unresolved error propagation between UTTS and other modules, and the limitation to written languages for the US2ST system.
 Building effective unsupervised speech translation systems, reducing error propagation, and improving inference latency.
 Some references include Common Voice, Wikiextractor, XLS-R, wav2vec 2.0, and Unsupervised speech recognition.
 To be integrated into UNMT in order to reduce inference latency.
 It may lead to a lower score of the S2ST (speech-to-speech translation) result.
 It brings new insights and can be extended to unwritten language setups.
 The trend is a statistically significant decrease of -1.4% per year.
 The trend is an increase of 2.7% per year, which is a complete reversal of the PKU inventory trend.
 They cannot capture it because of the increasing trend in BC emission over eastern China.
 They cannot provide sufficient information and constraints on the fractions or content of aerosol species.
 The mean absolute difference is about 2.7 µm/m3.
 Both products show the highest BC column concentration in April and May, with low values in other months.
