Dabbala Rajagopal (Raj) Reddy received his doctorate from the University of California, Berkeley in 1965.
Dabbala Rajagopal (Raj) Reddy received the ACM Turing Award in 1994.
Dabbala Rajagopal (Raj) Reddy received the ACM Turing Award for pioneering the design and construction of large scale artificial intelligence systems, demonstrating the practical importance and potential commercial impact of artificial intelligence technology.
The first system developed by Raj Reddy for recognizing continuous speech was Hearsay I .
Dabbala Rajagopal (Raj) Reddy attended the University of Hyderabad, Allahabad Agricultural Institute (now known as Indian Institute of Information Technology), Andhra University, and IIT Kharagpur.
The 'blackboard model' is an idea developed by Raj Reddy for coordinating multiple knowledge sources in artificial intelligence systems. It has been adopted across the spectrum of applied artificial intelligence.
Additional materials include a Video Interview with Raj Reddy, which provides insights into his work and achievements in the field of artificial intelligence.
Raj Reddy's research subjects include systems for recognizing continuous speech, which he developed with his students and demonstrated in systems like Hearsay I , Hearsay II , Harpy , and Dragon .

Reddy had his first computer encounter while he was an exchange student in Australia.
He came to Stanford University as a PhD student in 1963.
Reddy chose that project because he was interested in natural languages and what could be learned about them using computers.
He used the Stanford AI Lab’s newly acquired analog-to-digital converter and PDP-1 computer to process speech waveforms.
Reddy completed his PhD dissertation on the project he started under John McCarthy.
Upon finishing his Master’s degree, he worked as an Applied Science Representative for IBM in Australia.
He moved to Australia as an exchange student and received a Master's degree in technology in 1960 from the University of New South Wales in Sydney, Australia.

Reddy
CMU fielded successful speech-understanding systems called HEARSAY II, HARPY, and DRAGON.
DARPA decided not to renew the main projects as such but continued to support Reddy’s work on speech understanding at a reduced level.
Reddy and his colleagues created several historic demonstrations of spoken language systems, such as voice control of robots, large-vocabulary connected speech recognition, speaker independent speech recognition, and unrestricted vocabulary dictation.
Reddy and his colleagues have also made seminal contributions to other areas of artificial intelligence and computer science, such as developing many ideas that underlie modern commercial speech recognition products.
Over a span of three decades
DARPA supported Reddy’s work on speech understanding at a reduced level under its basic research program.
CMU fielded successful speech-understanding systems called HEARSAY II, HARPY, and DRAGON.
Reddy and his colleagues developed many of the ideas that underlie modern commercial speech recognition products.
Reddy’s research interests expanded in several directions, including task-oriented architectures, analysis of natural scenes, and autonomous robotic systems. He also worked on VLSI research, sensor networks, operating systems (the “MACH” system), user interfaces and workstations, and experimented with graphics printing.
Reddy served as the founding Director of the Robotics Institute from 1980 to 1992 and as the Dean of the School of Computer Science from 1991 to 1999. He became the Founding Director of Carnegie Mellon’s West Coast Campus in 2001, serving in that position until 2004.
Reddy became a Full Professor in 1973.
The 'blackboard architecture' for coordinating multiple knowledge sources, developed under CMU’s speech understanding research program, has been widely adopted.
Reddy was one of the major collaborators at CMU with DARPA and instrumental in getting DARPA work started on VLSI research.
Reddy was involved in the development of the 'MACH' system, which is the foundation of Apple’s MAC OSX.

The 2021 laureate of the A.M. Turing Award is Jack Dongarra.
ACM delivers a broad array of resources that advance the computing and IT disciplines, enable professional development, and promote policies and research that benefit society.

 To translate the input image into speech that correctly describes the image content. 
 It allows the model to focus more on the linguistic modeling of speech while suppressing other factors in the speech.
 It eliminates the need for complex processes involving predicting the Mel-spectrogram and converting the raw waveform.
 It extracts visual features from the input image.
 It generates speech units describing the visual features in an autoregressive manner until End of Sequence (EOS) is predicted.
 An embedding of the Beginning of Sequence (BOS) token.
 argmax θ S Σk=1 log p(uk|u<k, x; θ), where uk represents the current prediction, u<k represents the previous prediction, and θ is the model parameters.
 To bring knowledge of image comprehension and language generation from a pre-trained vision-language model into the Im2Sp model.
 It reduces data storage and computational memory costs for multi-modal processing systems.
 Because they require much more data storage and computational memory costs due to utilizing visual and audio modalities.

 The main focus of the text is on leveraging human feedback for improving language generation.
 In §2, the text formalizes the notion of human feedback and creates a taxonomy of different types of feedback in the literature.
 Feedback can be described by its format and objective, in terms of the desired model behavior.
 One approach mentioned in §4 is directly optimizing models against human feedback on their outputs, for example, using reinforcement learning with human reward functions.
 In §6, the text discusses existing datasets for human-feedback data, how these datasets are typically collected, and the impact that the collection process might have on the behaviour of the models.
 Dialog Generation is mentioned as an NLG task, where X is the space of possible dialog histories, and Y is the space of possible responses.
 NLG models are generally realized as a parameterized, conditional probability distribution.
 Evaluating the quality of generated text can be challenging due to the complexity and subjectivity of natural language.
 Various automatic metrics have been proposed, traditionally relying on n-gram matching or other simple heuristics.
 In the text, human feedback is considered the gold standard for assessing the quality of generated text.

 The experiments focus on comparing the performance of different multi-objective algorithms in improving properties of Android applications.
 Considering trade-offs between properties is significant because it shows that improvements in one property may lead to compromises in others.
 SPEA2 performed the best in finding the best fronts in 11 cases.
 The caching operators were highly effective in 26% of improving patches.
 The Vargha and Delaney A measure was used to calculate the magnitude of differences.
 In all but 8 cases, large effect sizes were found.
 The memory consumption improvements were up to 71.69%.
 In 47% of cases, patches produced by single-objective search were detrimental to another property.
 The median time taken by MO-GI across the benchmarks was 2.6 hours.
 The main factor was the difference in time taken by the test suites.

 The focus is on respecting copyright, privacy, transparency, and community-driven model development for code.
 More than 600 members from diverse academic institutes and industry labs are involved.
 The Stack is a publicly available pre-training dataset for Code LLMs consisting of permissively licensed source code and GitHub issues.
 8K token context length, infilling capabilities through Fill-in-the-Middle (FIM), and fast large-batch inference through Multi-Query-Attention (MQA).
 StarCoder is released under an OpenRAIL-M license agreement.
 A new attribution tool is incorporated.
 12,000 files with 22,950 annotated entities were collected.
 Using n-grams, simple smoothing techniques, feedforward networks, and recurrent networks.
 The Transformer architecture.
 There is a predictable relationship between language modeling loss and factors like model size, number of training tokens, and compute budget.
 Multimodal language models can process image and text inputs to generate text outputs.
 The Frozen model showed that it is possible to finetune a visual encoder to map images into the hidden space of a text-only language model.
 GILL is capable of both image retrieval and image generation, while FROMAGe can only retrieve images in their outputs.
 Large language models exhibit compelling properties such as the ability to learn from few-shot in-context examples and generate and process long text inputs.
 The GILL model architecture is trained with a captioning loss to learn to process images on the left side, and losses for image retrieval and image generation to learn to produce images on the right side.
 Text-to-image generation is the task of synthesizing a realistic image conditioned on natural language descriptions.
 GILL adapts a pretrained autoregressive language model of text, keeping most model weights frozen, and finetuning a small number of parameters on image caption data.
 The model needs to learn to process image-and-text content, learn to produce images, and determine whether to produce text or images at each step.
 The model learns translation parameters that map from image features to text embedding space, using a pretrained visual backbone and a linear mapping.
 The linear mapping in the GILL model is trained using the negative log-likelihood loss of the token sequence.

 To achieve strong performance-efficiency trade-offs for end-to-end speech recognition.
 I3D predicts whether to skip an entire self-attention block or feed-forward network through gate predictors, making it more efficient.
 At the utterance level (or chunk level for streaming), which is easier to implement and captures global statistics.

 Dynamic models can adjust their architectures based on input, while static models have fixed architectures for all inputs.
 It consists of a multi-head self-attention module and feed-forward network, combined sequentially.
 By using binary gates for each multi-head self-attention or feed-forward network module.
 It processes an input sequence using a stack of I3D encoder layers that dynamically select modules based on the input.
 It achieves better performance-efficiency trade-offs by adapting the depth of the encoder based on the input.

Students who are receiving a stipend, working as TAs, or plan on having a position with CMU must complete Form I-9 within 3 business days of beginning their work.
Employment Eligibility Verification, including completing Form I-9 and possibly submitting an E-Verify Processing Request Form, is required to comply with federal law.
If a student does not complete the Employment Eligibility Verification within 3 business days, they may be in violation of federal law and CMU's policy.
Form I-9 is a document that verifies the identity and eligibility to work in the United States of an individual receiving a stipend, working as a TA, or planning on having a position with CMU.
If students expect to work on a federally funded project, they are responsible for submitting an E-Verify Processing Request Form to the Office of Human Resources.
The Director at Carnegie Mellon University handles situations related to late graduation for students who require an additional semester to complete a program beneficial to both them and their employer.

 NLP (Natural Language Processing)
 LoRA
 LoRA does not add any additional inference parameters or latency due to structural re-parameterization design
 To enhance the fine-tuning and transfer learning ability for large-scale pre-trained models
 The main focus of the proposed model architecture is to jointly model intent classification, dialogue act prediction, speaker role identification, and emotion recognition with full integration of dialog history in spoken conversations.
 The joint model achieves comparable performance to task-specific models with the additional benefits of low latency and lightweight inference.
 The joint model successfully captures dialog context to improve the prediction performance of all SLU tasks significantly.
 The study recommends incorporating order agnostic training in the framework of future studies on jointly modeling different SLU tasks.
 The joint model learns to automatically predict in the optimal tag order during inference using order agnostic training.
 The work used the Extreme Science and Engineering Discovery Environment (XSEDE), which is supported by NSF grant number ACI-1548562.
 The results show that order agnostic training can further enhance performance.
 The focus of the work is on spoken language understanding.
 The joint model takes a context-based approach for dialogue act prediction.
 The study experimentally confirms that order agnostic training can further enhance performance.
 The vertical distribution of aerosols over Beijing based on long-term LiDAR observations.
 From 8 to 15 February 2020.
 The aerosol extinction coefficient was highest in summer, lower in winter, and lowest in spring and autumn.
 The daily mean PM2.5/CO values showed a fluctuating increasing trend.
 The daily mean PM2.5/CO values increased about 1.3 times.
 It indicates that secondary transformation intensified as the pollution accumulated.
 The PM2.5/CO ratio increased from about 40.0 × 10−3 to about 120.0 × 10−3, indicating a gradual increase in secondary transformation.
 CO, NO2, and O3 increased along with the PM2.5/CO ratio.
 The PM2.5/CO ratio showed a decreasing trend.
 Scattered spherical fine particles dominated the heavy haze pollution event.
 The strength of the concrete has a great influence on the prestress loss.
 The effective prestress in S3 decreases by 86.6 kN, showing a loss ratio of 19.2%.
 With the increase in the length of the component, the sphere of influence of the secondary transfer on the concrete at the non-corrosion side decreases, resulting in a smaller prestress loss.
 The stirrup reinforcement ratio has no obvious influence on prestress loss because the concrete generally does not develop splitting failure due to the large cross-section size of the specimens in the experiment.
 The effective prestress decreases after the secondary transfer of residual prestress due to the fracture of the steel wire strand.
 The secondary transfer length is defined as the distance at which the steel wire strand stress increases from 0 to effective prestress after fracture.
 The relationship is that the maximum bond stress in the transfer length is 1.25 times the average bond stress.
 lt = 0.17 σp f (cid:48) t d, where f (cid:48) t = 0.26 f 2/3 cu and d is the nominal diameter of a single-wire strand.
 The equilibrium equation determines the transfer length where the bond force in the transfer length equals the actual prestress at the beginning of corrosion of the steel wire strand.
 The secondary transfer lengths of prestress of S1-S6 were calculated using Equations (4) and (5).
 It is generally not possible to map the meaning of text exactly into another language.
 Most NMT systems factorize the probability of generating a translation in a left-to-right fashion.
 The two common algorithms are greedy decoding and beam search.
 Some alternative input units include characters, byte pair encoding (BPE), morphological representations, and syllables.
 The two most common options are word embeddings and contextualized word representations.
 The two most frequent architectures are recurrent neural networks (RNN) and transformers.
 One major advantage is their ability to learn representations from raw data.
 One challenge is overfitting, which can occur when not enough data is provided for effective learning.
 The most widely used metric is BLEU, which relies on token-level n-gram matches between translations and gold-standard references.
 A shortcoming is that the evaluation is very dependent on surface forms and not on the ultimate goal of semantic similarity and fluency.
 The presence of exhausted CD8+TILs in AITL, characterized by IC overexpression.
 Investigating the exhaustion status of CD8+TILs in AITL based on the expression of IC and exhaustion biology-related genes.
 IC overexpression can induce exhaustion in CD8+TILs, impairing their effector function and leading to tumor progression.
 There were two clusters of CD8+TILs from AITL, with one cluster showing markedly increased expression of multiple IC genes compared to the other cluster.
 High levels of CD8+TILs and CTL may lead to exhaustion-related biological changes, immune suppression, and poor prognosis in AITL patients.
 CD8+TILs in the high CTL group show dysregulated expression of genes related to metabolism, mitochondria, and effector function, suggesting disturbance in normal metabolic processes.
 The DEGs in the high CTL group were 20 and all were related to biological aspects, while the low CTL group had 11 DEGs, with only 1 related to biological aspects.
 The enriched chemokines in the high CTL group could recruit M2 macrophages and Tregs.
 The result showed the gene expression differences in the high- and low-CTL groups related to exhaustion biology.
 In the high CD8+TILs group, there were more males (83.3%) compared to females (16.7%), while in the low CD8+TILs group, the gender distribution was closer, with 50% males and 50% females.

 The number 0.608 represents a specific value or measurement mentioned in the text.
 The stage is defined by the numbers 0.09 and 0.141, as well as the Roman numerals I, II, and III.
 IPI stands for International Prognostic Index.
 LDH>220 IU/L is a measurement that holds importance in the context of extranodal involvement.
 The response to treatment is categorized as CR+PR (Complete Response + Partial Response) or SD+PD (Stable Disease + Progressive Disease).
 The Kaplan-Meier estimates in Figure 8 represent the overall survival rate for different groups based on CD8+TILs and CTL levels.
 The text suggests using immunotherapy targeting IC and immunosuppressive cytokines in combination with routine chemotherapy to enhance patient prognosis.
 The model in Figure 9 illustrates the characteristics of CD8+TILs exhaustion status in AITL and its impact on patient prognosis.
 The main finding is that the higher the number of CD8+TILs, the greater is the proportion of severely exhausted CD8+TILs, leading to poor prognosis.
 The research findings can help predict the survival risk of patients with AITL and facilitate further mechanistic studies to develop personalized immunotherapy approaches.

Each person's name corresponds to their respective letter. For example, M DNM is associated with M4, Bjorndahl E4 with E4, and so on.
The instructors' names correspond to their respective numbers. For example, Instructor I4 is associated with I4, Seidenfeld J4 with J4, and so on.
The course/activity titles correspond to their respective numbers. For example, 80500 Undergraduate Internship is associated with VAR A and TBA, while 80501 Undergradate Research in Philosophy is also associated with VAR A and TBA.
The same principle applies to the second part of the text. Each person's name corresponds to their respective letter. For example, Wenner O4 is associated with O4.
The same principle applies to the second part of the text. The instructors' names correspond to their respective numbers. For example, Instructor TBA is associated with S4.
The same principle applies to the second part of the text. The course/activity titles correspond to their respective numbers. For example, 80500 Undergraduate Internship is associated with VAR A and TBA.
The same principle applies to both parts of the text. Each person's name corresponds to their respective letter. For example, M DNM is associated with M4 in the first part and O4 in the second part.

 Influences of factors such as concrete strength, stirrup area, and the length of the component.
 Through a bond constitutive model.
 A prediction model of the effective stress transfer length.
 Residual prestress can have a secondary transfer, but some effective prestress may be lost.
 The loss of prestress is inversely proportional to concrete compressive strength.
 When the specimens are relatively short, the prestress loss increases significantly.
 Concrete strength has significant influences on the length of secondary transfer.
 Average error of 2.9%.
 Maximum error of 5.2%.
 Relatively high accuracy.
 The purpose of Prompt2Model is to generate deployable models from natural language instructions.
 Prompt2Model is a step forward from traditional special-purpose NLP models as it is designed to create models that are conducive to deployment using a multi-step process.
 Prompt2Model is based on a multi-step process of dataset retrieval, dataset generation using LLMs, and supervised fine-tuning on these retrieved and generated datasets.
 Prompt2Model can produce models that outperform LLMs like GPT-3 by an average of 20% while being significantly smaller in size, up to 700 times.
 Prompt2Model provides a way to obtain reliable performance estimates of model performance, enabling model developers to assess model reliability before deployment.
 The three main tasks demonstrated to show the effectiveness of Prompt2Model are dataset retrieval, dataset generation, and supervised fine-tuning.
 Dataset retrieval in Prompt2Model involves collecting training data by retrieving task-relevant annotated data to train the model.
 Prompt2Model automatically collects and synthesizes task-specific knowledge through three channels: dataset retrieval, dataset generation, and model retrieval.
 Using a pre-trained language model in Prompt2Model serves as the student model which is further fine-tuned and evaluated using the generated and retrieved data.
 Prompt2Model can serve as a tool for quickly building small and competent NLP systems, enabling the community to produce task-specific models efficiently.
 Event extraction (EE) and relation extraction (RE)
 The first step aims to extract entity mentions for RE, and entity mentions and event triggers for EE.
 A multi-task model
 The first N layers of the pre-trained encoder
 A CRF layer
 By linearly combining the scores of the two sub-tasks
 To compensate for errors in the mention extraction
 r_adjust = α · r_problem + (1−α) · r_origin
 CoNLL-2003 English dataset
 Randomly, with a ratio of 7:1:2 for training, dev, and test sets, respectively

 Due in part to span-based models not supporting categorical slots directly, which make up a significant number of slots.
 In-domain pretraining method outperforms models pretrained on SQuAD. Both strategies show strong improvements when compared to the vanilla backbone models.
 It indicates that pretraining in the QA task is useful for zero-shot slot-filling because it shows strong improvements when compared to the vanilla backbone models.
 More pretraining can be done by combining other QA datasets besides SQuAD, and even using other DST data when applying the pretraining step.
 Table 3 displays the impact of different question generation strategies: Generative LLM, Pronouns, Template-based What-is, Simple, and Manual.
 It highlights how small differences in questions can make a difference, showing that using third person pronouns whenever possible contrasts with the questions present in both pretraining strategies.
 The impact is that LLM-based strategies outperform manual question generation, while template-based approaches perform comparably to question generation without requiring access to a LLM or prompt.
 Due to the LLM misrepresenting the slots train-arriveby and train-leaveat, and the semantic differences in the train-leave day question compared to pretraining questions.
 It concludes that the zero-shot DST method presented requires no human input or domain knowledge through QA. The questions are posed by a generative LLM, allowing for easy addition of new slots and domains without extra manual workload.

Every Wednesday from 09:30 AM to 10:50 AM in HOA 223
 Saeki et al., 2022b built a massively multilingual TTS model.
 The work achieves zero-shot TTS from ASR data.
 The model freezes the language embedding layer.
 Fully zero-shot TTS performs zero-shot TTS without pretraining, while Text-seen zero-shot TTS performs zero-shot TTS with pretraining.
 The bottleneck layer is based on a residual network.
 The model was trained for 1.2M iterations using the Noam optimizer with specific learning rate and warm-up steps.
 The model architecture was based on Transformer TTS.
 The Noam optimizer was used for training the TTS model.
 X-vectors are used for the speaker embedding and added to the encoder output through a projection layer.
 Seven European languages were selected as seen languages for evaluation.
 The traditional solution has been to take actual physical measurements of the vocal fold oscillations or of the glottal flow.
 It is not always feasible due to the difficulty of solving the inverse problem of parameter estimation of phonation models through purely computational means.
 The inverse problem of parameter estimation of vocal tract models is described as difficult to solve through purely computational means without serious approximations.
 The paper proposes a methodology for solving the inverse problem of phonation models through purely computational means using the ADLES-VFT algorithm.
 The driving force equation in the one-mass model of the vocal folds is M ¨x + B ˙x + Kx = f (x, ˙x, t), where x is lateral displacement, M is mass, B is damping coefficient, K is stiffness coefficient, f is driving force, and t is time.
 The key assumptions include independence of asymmetry degree from oscillation frequency, stationary and frictionless glottal flow, neglect of subglottal and supraglottal loads, absence of glottal closure, and applicability of the small-amplitude body-cover assumption.
 The mucosal wave is represented as a one-dimensional surface wave on the mucosal surface (the cover) while treating the remainder of the vocal folds (the body) as a single mass or neglecting it.
 The body-cover assumption allows for the linearization of the oscillation model and simplifies the oscillatory conditions while maintaining accuracy.
 The center-line of the glottis is denoted as the z-axis in the one-mass asymmetric model of vocal folds.
 At the midpoint of the vocal folds, the left and right vocal folds oscillate with lateral displacements ξl and ξr which result in a pair of coupled Van der Pol oscillators.
 Weights are used to incorporate phonetic information in the acoustic parameter differences.
 The PAAP Loss calculates the weighted difference between acoustic parameters for each time step.
 STFT with a hop length of 160 and window length of 512 is used in the implementation.
 The PAAP Loss is used as an auxiliary loss alongside the original loss of the SE model to fine-tune the network.
 Data from the Deep Noise Suppression Challenge from InterSpeech 2020 was used to synthesize audio pairs for training and validation sets.
 The baseline models pre-process their input data slightly before training.
 The DNS 2020 synthetic test set with no reverberation is used for the final evaluation.
 State-of-the-art Demucs and FullSubNet models representing time domain and time-frequency domain models are selected.
 The PAAP Loss is weighed by a factor of 0.1 before adding it to the original loss for fine-tuning.
 The acoustic improvement is measured by the reduction in mean absolute error (MAE) between the acoustic parameters of the enhanced and clean speech.
 CodeBERTScore is an evaluation metric for code generation that encodes both the generated code tokens and the natural language input preceding the generated code, modeling the consistency between the generated code and its given natural language context.
 CodeBERTScore encodes not only the generated tokens but also the natural language input preceding the generated code, while BERTScore only encodes the generated tokens.
 The evaluation found that CodeBERTScore achieves a higher correlation with human preference and functional correctness than all existing metrics.
 Five language-specific pretrained models were released to be used with CodeBERTScore.
 LLMs have the ability to accurately generate long completions that span multiple tokens and lines, rather than just a single next-token.
 Evaluating different code generation models remains a challenging problem that requires an accurate and reliable evaluation metric due to the diversity in implementation and coding style.
 Token-matching metrics like BLEU and CrystalBLEU rely on the lexical exact match of tokens, which does not account for diversity in implementation, variable names, and code conventions.
 CodeBLEU attempts to lower the requirement for a lexical exact match by relying on data-flow and Abstract Syntax Tree (AST) matching in addition to token matching.
 Execution-based evaluation requires datasets with hand-written test cases for each example, which is costly and labor-intensive to create.
 Partial predictions may lead to code that does not parse fully, and thus cannot be fully evaluated by CodeBLEU.
Ph.D. in Language and Information Technologies Student Handbook
Tuesday, August 29, 2023
Page 1
This information can be found on Page 2.
Page 10
Page 2
Carnegie Mellon University
This handbook has 2 pages.
Ph.D. in Language and Information Technologies
The Carnegie Mellon Code is located in Pittsburgh.
LTI's Pittsburgh campus location has office space, mailboxes, and supplies for students.
Yes, LTI provides computers for its Ph.D. students.
The course requirements include a set of courses that students must complete as part of their program.
To pass a course, a student must achieve at least 70% on all assignments and exams combined.
Students need to demonstrate a high level of competence in their field, which can be achieved through coursework and research.
Students are required to write and defend a dissertation, which represents their original contribution to the field.
Yes, students are required to present a research talk at least once during their program.
The purpose of LTI orientation is to provide new graduate students with information about the program, expectations, and resources.
The end-of-semester evaluation takes place at the end of each semester.
Yes, students can take electives outside of SCS as long as they are approved by their advisor and meet certain requirements.
Yes, students can choose to complete an M.S. degree before pursuing a Ph.D., but this is not required.
The section on grading and evaluation covers university policies related to grades, as well as specific guidelines for evaluating student performance in SCS programs.
The policy states that students must earn a minimum grade of C- in order to have their course transferred.
Academic integrity is important because it ensures fairness and honesty among all students, which helps maintain the value and credibility of a degree from this institution.
A student may withdraw their degree if they have not completed any courses at the university or if they are no longer enrolled in classes.
Employment eligibility verification requires a student's degree and transcript from this institution, as well as any additional documentation requested by the employer or agency.
The university provides guidance on program of study selection, financial aid and student account management.
Choosing a suitable program of study ensures that students are taking courses relevant to their interests and career goals, which can lead to better academic performance and post-graduation success.
Financial aid is provided through various forms such as scholarships, grants, loans, and work-study programs. Students must apply for these opportunities each year to continue receiving funding.
The student account is used to manage all financial transactions related to tuition, fees, and other expenses. It also tracks any refunds or balances owed after financial aid disbursement.
If a student does not complete any courses, they may be unable to graduate and will need to re-enroll in classes or withdraw their degree.

FERPA stands for Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act. It's a federal law that protects the privacy of students' education records, limiting access and disclosure without consent.

Intense concentration and hard work.
Carnegie Mellon University is located in Pittsburgh, a city with a rich industrial and labor heritage.
In the past, Pittsburgh was known as the heart of the U.S. steel industry, a source for quality packaged foods, an important financial hub, and an early pioneer in railroads, radio, and nuclear power.
Today, Pittsburgh has reinvented itself as a leader in Computer Science and medicine.
Pittsburgh is an informal city where people don’t take themselves too seriously and remember to have fun.
Pittsburgh has excellent museums, competitive professional sports teams, inexpensive magic shows, free music during the summer, skiing and magnificent state parks nearby.
Visitors are encouraged to make time for exploring the many activities that Pittsburgh and Southwest Pennsylvania have to offer.
Pittsburgh was a place where people worked hard and made things that changed the world because it was an important industrial hub with industries like steel, food production, finance, railroads, radio, and nuclear power.
Pittsburgh's transformation into a leader in Computer Science and medicine is unique because it has reinvented itself from its industrial past to become a hub for cutting-edge technology and medical research.
The phrase 'e balance helps to keep it in perspective' means that maintaining a sense of proportion or moderation is important for keeping things in context and avoiding becoming overwhelmed.

The Language Technologies Institute offers a degree program in Ph.D. in Language and Information Technologies at CMU.
It is hoped that students' time at CMU will be a life-changing experience.
The two Ph.D. programs offered by the institution are LTI Ph.D. and Dual-Degree Ph.D. in Language and Information Technologies (CMU-PT Ph.D.)
The Ph.D. in Language and Information Technologies is focused on understanding and extending the state of the art in computational linguistics, natural language processing, information retrieval, machine translation, speech processing, video dialogue systems, understanding, multimodal systems, automated reasoning, and other topics related to analysis and understanding of unstructured information (e.g., machine learning, and software engineering of intelligent systems).
The handbook that applies to the LTI Ph.D. is called 'LTI Ph.D. Graduate Student Handbook'
This information in the handbook applies on Page 9.
The five Master degrees offered by the institution are MLT, MIIS, MCDS, and MSAII.
The Department Personnel is responsible for the Ph.D. in Language and Information Technologies.
The Ph.D. program focuses on machine learning, software engineering of intelligent systems, computational linguistics, natural language processing, information retrieval, machine translation, speech processing, video dialogue systems, understanding, multimodal systems, and automated reasoning.
The Master degree that focuses on Intelligent Information Systems is called MIIS.
In total, the institution offers four Master degrees: MLT, MIIS, MCDS, and MSAII.

The Carnegie Mellon Code is a set of standards that require personal integrity, honesty without compromise, truthfulness without equivocation, and community service above self-interest.
Students at Carnegie Mellon are expected to meet high standards of personal conduct, ethical behavior, and moral integrity as members of an academic community dedicated to excellence.

Members of the Carnegie Mellon community are expected to uphold standards and hold others accountable for these standards. They must also acknowledge the creativity of others, give credit for prior knowledge, and trust that these principles will be observed.
Students must not destroy the respect for Carnegie Mellon degree by their failure to meet these standards, as this will affect the community and its reputation.
Commitment plays a crucial role in an academic community. It contributes to the discovery, advancement, and communication of knowledge, as well as trust among members.
Acknowledging the creativity of others is essential in an academic community. It promotes respect and encourages new knowledge development by giving credit for prior knowledge.
When students fail to meet these standards, they can damage the reputation of Carnegie Mellon degree. This failure also undermines the trust and respect among members in an academic community.
The commitment to these standards contributes significantly to the high respect in which the Carnegie Mellon degree is held. It ensures that students uphold the community's expectations and maintain its reputation.
Academic communities depend on trust because it allows members to collaborate, share ideas, and develop new knowledge without fear of plagiarism or dishonesty. Trust is the foundation for a productive and respectful community.
When individuals fail to uphold these standards, it can affect the entire community. It undermines trust among members and may lead to a decrease in respect for the community's values.
Creativity thrives in an academic environment when individuals acknowledge each other's work, give credit where it is due, and maintain a commitment to the community's standards.
Not adhering to these standards can lead to a loss of respect for Carnegie Mellon degree, damage the reputation of the community, and undermine trust among members.

 The two main improvements made to the reward model are using a better vision encoder with higher resolutions and a larger language model, and introducing a novel algorithm named Factually Augmented RLHF.
 The reward signals are calibrated by augmenting them with additional information such as image captions or ground-truth multi-choice options.
 The crowdworkers were instructed to prioritize responses that exhibit better multimodal alignment and minimize hallucinations. If two responses are free of hallucinations, they were asked to choose/create a more helpful one.
 The purpose of the Fact-RLHF algorithm is to alleviate the issue of limited capacity in the reward model and to improve the general capabilities of Large Language Models during the Supervised Fine-Tuning stage.
 The two factors to consider are honesty (providing accurate information and articulating uncertainty without misleading the user) and helpfulness (opting for the more helpful response when both responses are free from hallucinations).
 The three stages involved in the Multimodal RLHF pipeline are Multimodal Supervised Fine-Tuning, Multimodal Preference Modeling, and Reinforcement Learning.
 The reward model employs a cross-entropy loss function during training.
 The reinforcement learning stage trains a policy model to generate an appropriate response for each user query by maximizing the reward signal provided by the reward model.
 The reinforcement learning stage aims to address potential challenges like reward hacking by using a per-token KL penalty to prevent over-optimization.
 They trained an encoder-only model, specifically bi-directionally self-attentive Transformers.
 They used the Masked Language Modelling (MLM) and Next Sentence Prediction (NSP) objectives.
 Tokens in the input are masked independently with a probability of 15%.
 They trained the model for 100,000 steps.
 IDs were excluded from the model training due to low annotation quality.
 There were 7,878 examples in the training set and 4,000 examples in the test set.
 They achieved F1 scores of 73.39% on passwords and more than 90% on names.
 Pseudo-labeling is employed to improve the detection of key and password entities.
 They annotated 18,000 files using an ensemble of two encoder models.
 The PII detection models surpassed the regex approach in detecting all three entities.
 Hedges
 Self-disclosure, shared experiences, indirect instruction giving
 It has been shown to be beneficial for learning outcomes
 Hedging
 Automatically generating indirectness behaviors for a tutoring agent
 Knowledge-Driven features based on rules from linguistic literature
 Nonverbal behaviors and tutoring moves
 LightGBM, utilizing Knowledge-Driven features, showed the best performance
 Linguistic Inquiry and Word Count (LIWC)
 By adjusting the correction strength based on the imbalance level of the classes

 The domain-specific IGTD algorithm.
 Homogeneous domain adaptation (DA) tasks.
 The splits from Tan et al. (2020) removing mislabeled outliers.
 Prompting does not update the pretrained weights but modifies the input to query the model.
 The strategy aims to select a landmark with a smaller historical visit count and a larger transitional benefit as the subgoal for the next time interval.
 The high-level teacher policy and high-level student policy in HILL map states to subgoals and are employed with probabilities of p and 1-p, respectively.
 The role of the student policy is mainly to help increase randomness and prevent falling into local optima.
 p is initialized to 0.5 in HILL.
 HILL is evaluated on challenging continuous control tasks based on the MuJoCo simulator.
 The agent gets a reward of 0 when reaching the goal and -1 otherwise in the tasks evaluated in HILL.
 The maximum episode length is limited to 500 steps for the Ant Maze and Ant Push tasks.
 HILL outperforms all baselines in terms of both sample efficiency and asymptotic performance.
 HESS focuses on exploring novel and reachable subgoals, lacking consideration of the potential benefits that subgoals can provide in completing the source task.
 HIRO improves sample efficiency by relabeling subgoals to maximize the likelihood of past low-level action sequences.

 The main focus is on building an acoustic-to-articulatory inversion (AAI) model to capture the mechanics of speech production.
 The MOCHA-TIMIT and HPRC datasets are used to train the AAI models.
 The research showed a 12.5% improvement in correlation on the EMA dataset.
 The 12-dimensional EMA features contain the midsagittal x and y coordinates of jaw, lip, and tongue positions.
 AAI aims to automatically estimate articulatory features directly from speech signals.
 The research uses autoregression, adversarial training, and self-supervision to improve the state-of-the-art in AAI.
 The interpretability is showcased by directly comparing the behavior of estimated representations with speech production behavior.
 It allows for generalizing the models to unseen speakers and improves the interpretability of speech representations.
 One of the challenges is that most articulatory datasets contain limited hours of high-quality speech data.
 The efficacy is evaluated using resynthesis-based AAI evaluation metric that does not rely on articulatory labels.

Robots were used because of radioactive contamination after the worst nuclear accident in the nation's history.
The team was led by 'Red' Whittaker.
The CoreSampler was the second of three robots built for this purpose.
It helped with the cleanup at Three Mile Island in a photo from the 1980s.
Three robots, including Redbot and RAD ROVER, were built for this purpose.
Workhorse was one of three robots built to help with the cleanup at Three Mile Island.
'Red' Whittaker sits atop Workhorse in this photo.
The CoreSampler carried a column of drills that allowed engineers to take samples from the walls of the reactor's basement to test for radioactive contamination.
Robots were used because they could handle tasks that humans couldn't due to radioactive contamination after the worst nuclear accident in the nation's history.
The CoreSampler was the second of three robots built to help with the cleanup at Three Mile Island.
William 'Red' Whittaker is a robotics professor at Carnegie Mellon University.
Whittaker assembled his team of students to build three robots designed to help clean up the basement of a damaged reactor at the Three Mile Island nuclear plant.
One of the two reactors at this facility suffered a partial meltdown and released radioactivity into the atmosphere—the worst nuclear power accident in U.S.
The robots they built were called Workhorse.
Carnegie Mellon University is located in Pittsburgh.
The purpose of building these robots, as per Whittaker, was part of an effort to clean up damaged Unit 2 at the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant.
The article was published in Scientific American.
Daniel Lovering is the photographer who captured this image.
NRC stands for Nuclear Regulatory Commission.

 Grounding fairness notions in domain-specific attributes.
 Group fairness and counterfactual fairness.
 Popularity between items is not necessarily a binary state and such attributes may not be readily available.
 A domain-aware, individual fairness-based approach.
 By generating nuanced multi-modal track features.
 To fine-tune item representations reflecting similarity in musical domain.
 It outperforms three other methods in both performance and recommendation of lesser-known content.
 Music discovery through the lens of domain-aware individual fairness.
 By generating a set of nuanced multi-modal track features.
 To learn expressive representations of items robust to popularity bias.

 ML-SUPERB covers a wider range of languages and focuses on ASR and LID, while XTREME-S covers four different tasks.

 Yang et al.
 The study was conducted at the Department of Respiratory and Critical Care Medicine, Frontiers Science Center for Disease-Related Molecular Networks, West China Hospital, Sichuan University, China.
 The scRNA-seq procedures included sample collection and processing, single-cell RNA library construction and sequencing, and scRNA-seq data processing and analysis.
 A 189-exhaustion biology-related gene panel was established for CD8+TILs.
 Statistical analyses were performed using the Statistical Package for the Social Sciences (SPSS) software.
 The median patient age was 60 years (range, 38–83 years).
 Nineteen (73.1%) patients responded positively to the treatment.
 Men accounted for 65% (n = 26) of the sample.
 Principal component analysis (PCA), t-distributed stochastic neighborhood embedding analysis (t-SNE), and uniform manifold approximation and projection (UMAP) were used to identify different cell clusters.
 The patients were divided into high- and low-expression groups based on the mean proportions of CD8+TILs and IC, respectively.
 The CTL gene showed strong positive expression according to RNA sequencing.
 Adapt the ARR reviewing guidelines and instruct reviewers to consider the compute budget reported in a paper when asking for more experiments.
 Because it facilitates future research and helps reproducibility.
 Code, trained models, system outputs, training checkpoints, and proper documentation of training data.
 To ensure proper understanding and reproducibility of the research.
 Submitting artifacts together with the paper before reviewing.
 To ensure transparency, reproducibility, and facilitate future research.
 Evaluation and emphasizing research over engineering.
 By reporting performance based on Pareto frontiers and considering the compute budget along with model performance.
 Primarily chasing high performance rather than producing meaningful scientific insights.
 Authors should clearly state their scientific hypothesis and conduct research that tests this hypothesis using appropriate resources.
 Aggressive juvenile polyposis in children with chromosome 10q23 deletion.
 2013.
 Individuals with de novo EBF3 variants or deletions have a clinical spectrum that includes syndromic intellectual disability with craniofacial anomalies, epilepsy, hypotonia, and neurobehavioral problems including autism.
 Disruption of PHF21A causes syndromic intellectual disability with craniofacial anomalies, epilepsy, hypotonia, and neurobehavioral problems including autism.
 A patient with intellectual disability and language impairment has dysfunction of SHANK2 and CHRNA7 genes.
 Patients with distal 11q deletions have been clinically and molecularly characterized.
 Jacobsen syndrome is due to an unbalanced translocation between 11q23 and 22q11.2.
 The HMGA2 gene plays a role in growth in the 12q14 microdeletion syndrome.
 The 13q12.3 microdeletion syndrome is characterized by intellectual disability, microcephaly, and eczema/atopic dermatitis encompassing the HMGB1 and KATNAL1 genes.
 Haploinsufficiency of the BMP4 gene may be the underlying cause of Frias syndrome.

 The Miscellaneous category encompasses approximately 18.70% of changes.
 Examples include code cleanups, omitting unnecessary initializations, and replacing computationally intensive functions with predefined constants.
 The faster code directly computes the maximum start and minimum end of the ranges in a single pass, eliminating the need for sorting.
 The code implementations are for computing factorial modulo 10^9+7.
 The optimized code computes the factorial only for the given input, making it more memory-efficient and faster.
 The slower code has a complexity of O(10^6).
 The optimized code leverages the property of modular arithmetic to reduce the complexity to O(B).
 The optimized code avoids an additional conditional check inside the loop by restructuring the loop.
 The purpose is to highlight the speedup reported despite identical programs and environments due to template code.
 A temperature of 1.0 and use of top-p sampling with p = 0.9 are used for generation.
The purpose of this website is to provide information about Carnegie Mellon University's School of Computer Science and its programs.
The text suggests that JavaScript should be enabled in a browser to use this website because it enhances the browsing experience on the site.
The reason given for some resources being blocked by the user's network is that they are being blocked by the network administrator.
Carnegie Mellon University School of Computer Science is located at 5000 Forbes Avenue, Pittsburgh, PA 15213.
The two campuses mentioned in the text are Qatar Campus and Silicon Valley Campus.
The purpose of the School of Computer Science's online application is to apply for academic and professional Ph.D. and Master's programs in Language Technologies and MS in Machine Learning and Robotics.
The Fall 2025 Admissions cycle will open Summer 2024.
The contact email for SCS Graduate Admissions is scs-grad-application@andrew.cmu.edu.
Carnegie Mellon University School of Computer Science has accounts on Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn, and Instagram.
 The focus is on making scalable meta learning practical.
 SAMA combines advances in implicit differentiation algorithms and systems to support a broad range of adaptive optimizers, reduce computational burden, and exploit efficient distributed training techniques.
 SAMA showcases up to 1.7/4.8× increase in throughput and 2.0/3.8× decrease in memory consumption respectively on single-/multi-GPU setups compared to other baseline meta learning algorithms.
 Applications of meta learning mentioned include hyperparameter optimization, data optimization, neural architecture search, learned optimizers, and few-shot learning.
 Factors contributing to poor scalability of gradient-based meta learning include the requirement to invert a large Jacobian matrix, training instability, and lack of efficient distributed training support.
 Many gradient-based meta learning algorithms struggle with scalability in practice due to their requirement to invert a large Jacobian matrix, which leads to algorithmic instability and high compute/memory costs.
 The root causes are identified as base Jacobian inversion, a lack of algorithmic adaptation for adaptive optimizers, and the need for custom implementation of the backward pass of meta gradient computation.
 The main contributions include investigating the root causes of scalability limitations in gradient-based meta learning, proposing solutions to address these issues, and exploring the potential of scalable meta learning in diverse applications.
 The text proposes to approximate the base Jacobian with an identity matrix to address the issue of base Jacobian inversion.
 One of the initial solutions proposed is to expand the meta Jacobian via the chain rule to improve the scalability of gradient-based meta learning.

 GlobalBench currently supports dataset submissions of 6671 languages and 17 tasks.
 GlobalBench covers 1,128 system outputs at the time of writing.
 The six NLP tasks covered by GlobalBench are named entity recognition (NER), text pair classification, text classification, extractive QA, machine translation, and KG link tail prediction.
 The existing systems included in GlobalBench already cover 4.72% to 59.34% of the first languages of people in the world, depending on the task.
 Named entity recognition (NER) has the highest estimated overall demographic and linguistic global average.
 The demographic utility score for NER is 0.4489, while the linguistic utility score for NER is only 0.0067.
 Tasks like text classification and KG prediction, which only have datasets for English, have Gini values almost equal to 1.
 For each task, the highest performance amongst all systems for a specific language is used to represent the performance for that (task, language) pair.
 There are 450 system submissions for NER and 28 system submissions for KG Link Tail Prediction.
 The chromatic analysis figures show the system analysis across language populations for NER with high system performances for many languages, while KG Link Tail Prediction has monolingual coverage and low performance.
 The reconstruction error between ground truth and synthesis.

 Euclidean distance.
 Dynamic Time Warping.
 It distorts the input phone sequence and results in low MOS-Q and MOS-N scores.

 Distinctively better in speech quality (MOS-Q).

 1) To understand pluralistic human values, rights, and duties in large language models, and 2) To support open, value pluralistic modeling
 The dataset should only be used for research purposes and should not be used for real-world decision-making, advice, or commercial applications
 Funding came from the DARPA ITM program and the Allen Institute for AI (AI2)
 Situations in plain-text English spans containing candidate values, rights, duties, valence relations, and explanations
 Training, validation, and testing splits are recommended. Accuracy for valence and relevance, and perplexity for generation and explanation
 T5-based models were trained and assessed for valence, relevance, generation, and explanation
 Situations were provided by volunteer users of the Delphi user demo, and candidate values, rights, duties were generated by GPT-4
 Crowdworkers found the data to be high-quality 91% of the time and had difficulty surfacing missed values, rights, or duties

 Generating discriminative captions that distinguish target images from very similar alternative distractor images.
 It leverages an off-the-shelf CLIP model to parameterize the listener instead of deriving both the speaker and listener distributions from a single captioning model.
 Using a hyperparameter.
 11% to 15%.

 By choosing the hyperparameter value that maximizes how informative the captions are predicted to be to human evaluators.

 To see how the model performs in retrieving a story that is empathically similar to a story that the users told themselves.

 A shortened version of the State Empathy Survey

 The effect was present across all three dimensions of empathy: affective, cognitive, and associative empathy.
 Related to how well-read, genuine, and consistent the story was, and if the user could empathize with the narrator’s emotional reactions.

 Forward-Looking Active REtrieval augmented generation (FLARE)
 They have a tendency to hallucinate and create factually inaccurate output.
 They commonly use a retrieve-and-generate setup where they retrieve documents based on the user’s input, and then generate a complete answer conditioning on the retrieved documents.
 Active retrieval augmented generation allows for continually gathering information throughout the generation process, which is essential for more general scenarios involving long text generation.
 FLARE achieves superior or competitive performance on all tasks, demonstrating the effectiveness of the method.
 Tasks such as long-form QA, open-domain summarization, and chain-of-thought reasoning.
 To address hallucination and create factually accurate content by looking up relevant information from external knowledge resources.
 The information needs are clear in the user’s input, making it sufficient to retrieve relevant knowledge once based on the input.
 Long-form generation presents complex information needs that are not always evident from the input alone, requiring continual gathering of multiple pieces of knowledge throughout the generation process.
 The goal is to anticipate future content by iteratively retrieving relevant information based on the prediction of the upcoming sentence to regenerate sentences with low-confidence tokens.
 One strategy proposed is designing robust loss functions that are resilient to noise.
 The three categories are robust loss functions, noise estimation, and noise correction.
 The key task is to estimate the underlying transition probabilities.
 Co-Teaching uses multiple differently trained networks for correcting noisy labels.
 One technique involves generating new labels equivalent to soft or hard pseudo-labels estimated by the model.
 The primary objective of MIL is to predict labels for new, unseen bags.
 The foundational idea is the dynamic or static labeling of instances according to the bag label.
 One approach involves counting the number of positive instances within a bag and setting a threshold for classifying positive bags.
 IRNet focuses on noisy sample detection and label correction.
 The key goal of DALI is to reduce the negative impact of detection errors in label learning.
 Advantage-Leftover Lunch

 With the single-action assumption
 Any pretrained attribute-specific classifiers or human-designed scoring functions as a reward

 A-LOL is discussed in relation to log-likelihood loss

 The policy’s estimate of expected reward for the input subtracted from the actual reward of the training data
 By initializing a small network of multi-head attention and a single-layer MLP on top of frozen parameters of πref
 It is trained on the rewards achieved by πref on the validation set with mean squared error loss
 The model demonstrates capabilities such as image retrieval, novel image generation, and multimodal dialogue.
 The approach is capable of conditioning on arbitrarily interleaved image and text inputs to generate coherent image and text outputs.
 The model proposes an efficient mapping network to ground the large language model to an off-the-shelf text-to-image generation model.
 The mapping network translates hidden representations of text into the embedding space of the visual models to leverage strong text representations for visual outputs.
 The proposed model outperforms baseline generation models on tasks with longer and more complex language, as well as on tasks that measure context dependence.
 The model is also capable of image retrieval from a prespecified dataset and deciding whether to retrieve or generate at inference time.
 This decision is made using a learnt decision module that conditions on the hidden representations of the large language model.
 The environment includes fully functional websites from e-commerce, social forum discussions, collaborative software development, and content management domains.
 The environment is enriched with tools like a map and external knowledge bases like user manuals.
 The best GPT-4-based agent achieves an end-to-end task success rate of 14.41% in the benchmark tasks.
 The purpose is to select the threshold based on the performance on the dev set.
 The performance is measured using the product of Strict Acc, Macro F1, and Micro F1.
 Recall@k (fraction) evaluates partial retrieval in addition to Recall@k.
 The bi-encoder retrieval performance under Recall@k (fraction) counts successful retrieval if some (not all) of the gold events are predicted within the top-k retrievals.
 The best-performing bi-encoder + cross-encoder system is reported based on Strict Acc, Macro F1, and Micro F1 for each task.

 The global posterior p(θ | D) given a collection of datasets factorizes as the prior times the local likelihood associated with each data partition.
 Q
 To approximate the global posterior p(θ | D) using a tractable density q(θ) that admits the same factorization.
 Each local inference problem is a function of just the local likelihood and the current global estimate.

 The distribution q−k(θ) that is proportional to the global distribution and the local distribution.
 FedEP takes into account the global parameters and the previous local estimate while deriving the local posterior.

 The aim was to investigate the relationship between albumin-to-globulin ratio (AGR) and overall survival (OS) in patients with advanced non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC) treated with anlotinib.
 AGR was calculated by dividing baseline serum albumin by the difference between serum total protein and serum albumin.
 The main outcome was overall survival (OS), defined as the period from the date of initial treatment with anlotinib to death or the last follow-up.
 A non-linear relationship was observed between AGR and OS, with an inflection point of 1.24.
 The findings suggested that AGR was positively associated with OS, and for every 1 unit increase in AGR, the risk of death lowered by approximately 80%.
 Non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC) is highlighted as the major type of lung cancer.
 Anlotinib is a selective receptor tyrosine kinase inhibitor that targets various receptors involved in cancer growth and development like vascular endothelial growth factor receptors and platelet-derived growth factor receptor-α.
 Finding prognostic biomarkers is crucial to select suitable patients who will benefit from anlotinib, as not all patients respond positively to the treatment.
 The study suggested that AGR, by reflecting both nutritional status and inflammatory response, could serve as a valuable predictive parameter, especially due to its insensitivity to conditions like dehydration.
 The conclusion was that AGR level is an independent protective factor for overall survival in advanced NSCLC patients who received anlotinib therapy.
 The main focus of the IPA is to improve upon LLMs such as GPT-3 and reduce toxicity in generated text.
 The REALTOXICITYPROMPTS benchmark is used to assess the efficacy of IPA in reducing toxicity from LLMs by generating a fluent continuation without offensive content for a given prompt.
 IPA sometimes outperforms expensive fine-tuned GPT-3 in benchmarks while being more cost-effective.
 Metrics used to evaluate toxicity reduction include average maximum toxicity across sampled generations, toxicity probability of at least one toxic generation, fluency, and diversity of generated output.
 QUARK is used as the RL algorithm in the adapter optimization for IPA.
 IPA outperforms learning-based and decoding-based methods when tailoring GPT-2 and GPT-3, reducing toxicity while maintaining language quality.
 Directly applying the policy adapter optimized for GPT-2 on top of GPT-3, i.e., IPA-, is highly effective, showcasing the adaptability and reusability of IPA.
 IPA outperforms DAPT in tailoring GPT-3, emphasizing the cost-efficiency of IPA as an approach to align LLMs.
 The ablation studies aim to assess the effect of different RL algorithms on the performance of IPA in reducing toxicity and maintaining language quality.
 The goal of lexically constrained generation is to generate text that includes specific keywords in the correct order. It is tested using datasets like COMMONGEN, where the models are instructed to follow ordered lexical constraints.

 The rank of the Tucker decomposition is calculated by iteratively halving all dimensions until the current compression ratio is under the given one.
 The Tucker decomposition is mainly used to reduce the parameters of the convolution layer.
 The Tucker decomposition is adopted because it is expected to represent the convolution weight tensor with fewer parameters than CP decomposition.
 The Tucker decomposition can be inferred without reconstructing the original tensor by swapping the order of computation as in SVD.
 CP decomposition, similar to SVD, can uniquely determine rank from compression ratio.
 The system was evaluated on the STOP dataset.
 The evaluation criteria used were performed by exact match accuracy (EM).
 The teacher model used a HuBERT-based feature extractor.
 The encoder in the Conformer-based middle model had 12 attention blocks.
 Adam optimization with warmup scheduling was used in the training of the system.

 The text suggests that AGR can serve as a prognostic tool for metastatic NSCLC, with a non-linear relationship between AGR and overall survival.
 The study used GAM and two-piecewise linear regression models.
 The inflection point calculated in the study was 1.24.
 Only when AGR levels were higher than 1.24, the risk of death was significantly reduced by 80% for every 1 unit increase in AGR.
 Lower AGR levels may reflect compromised liver function associated with advanced stages of lung cancer, where multiple indicators and factors contribute to patient prognosis.
 Caution is needed due to the small sample size potentially affecting statistical power and generalizability, as well as the need to consider the specific patient characteristics and treatment modalities of the study.
 Subgroup analysis helps in better understanding the independent association of variables from known risk factors, offering insights into specific group characteristics and prognosis.
 The ECOG PS score was identified as the variable influencing the linear trend between AGR and risk of death.
 Patients with ECOG PS score = 1 may have higher tumor burden indicated by a higher number of metastases, potentially contributing to worse outcomes.
 The relationship between AGR and OS is non-linear, with AGR positively correlated with OS when AGR is higher than 1.24.
 The focus is on evaluating informativity and fluency using different metrics.
 PICL substantially outperforms the mentioned approaches in informativeness.
 Methods controlling for fluency (PPL) pivot around PICL and achieve a similar level of perplexity.
 Human evaluation results show that PICL substantially outperforms Incre-RSA and E-S in informativeness.
 The primary finding is that PICL outperforms Incre-RSA along both dimensions of informativeness and fluency.
 ALBEF accuracy has a strong positive correlation with human retrieval accuracy for model-generated outputs.
 The trend shows that captions generated by E-S and Incre-RSA without controlling for perplexity are rated as much more disfluent by humans.
 Human evaluations are important to accurately compare the performance of discriminative captioning systems.
 The trade-off patterns for E-S and Incre-RSA are different from that under ALBEF, as optimizing for ALBEF accuracy induces more disfluent generation.
 The optimal informativeness under human judgment is likely to be achieved with a moderate level of disfluency.
 The main focus is to formalize differences in perceptual quality in speech enhancement models using domain knowledge of acoustic-phonetics.
 A neural network estimator is developed to accurately predict the values of non-differentiable temporal acoustic parameters across an utterance.
 Adding phoneme-specific weights helps optimize speech outputs to match clean speech values by considering the different behavior of acoustic parameters in different phonemes.
 The goal is to address problems with optimization of DNNs by using acoustic parameters that provide critical information about frequency content, energy/amplitude, and other spectral qualities of speech signals.
 Single-channel speech enhancement has greatly improved by transitioning from traditional signal processing techniques to deep neural networks (DNN) which provide better performance and flexibility.
 Classic losses fail to capture pitch, show relatively low improvement for low-energy phonemes, and are not highly correlated with speech quality at the signal level.
 The purpose is to improve speech outputs by minimizing the difference between phonetically-aligned acoustic parameters in enhanced speech and clean speech.
 The two-step approach involves introducing a differentiable estimator of temporal acoustic parameters and calculating phoneme-specific weights for each parameter to optimize the model end-to-end to match clean speech values.
 Emphasizing interpretability helps demonstrate the improvements made by the method and allows for a detailed analysis of the phoneme-dependent enhancement on acoustic parameters.
 Applications such as VoIP and phone calls, hearing aids, and downstream speech processing tasks are commonly affected by noisy environments.

 The proposed approach achieved an accuracy of 60.8%.
 The proposed approach outperformed all previous methods by a large margin.
 The three stages involved are squeezing, recovery, and relabeling.
 The ultimate goal is to synthesize data in a way that achieves a certain/minimal performance gap on the original evaluation set when models are trained on the synthetic data.
 The objective is formulated as achieving ϵ-approximate performance on the synthetic data compared to the original full dataset.
 The primary drawback is the computational burden due to the unrolling of the inner loop during each outer-loop update, coupled with bias transference from real to synthetic data.
 The main objective is to disassociate model training and synthetic data optimization to enhance efficiency and avoid bias transference.
 The purpose is to extract pertinent information from the original dataset, encapsulate it within deep neural networks, and evaluate the impact of various data augmentation techniques and training strategies.
 The proposed approach reformulates it into a unilevel learning procedure by extracting information from the original dataset and encapsulating it within deep neural networks.
 The core idea is to adequately train and preserve pivotal information within a dataset within a deep neural network.

 The risk of death was reduced by 80% with every 1 unit increase in AGR.
 There was a trend in the association but it was not statistically significant.
 AGR was explored as a prognostic marker in advanced NSCLC patients with anlotinib treatment.
 They showed a positive association between AGR and OS in advanced NSCLC patients treated with anlotinib.
 The inflection point was AGR = 1.24, where AGR was positively correlated with OS when higher than this value.
 By using GAM and two-piecewise linear regression model, they found that the correlation between AGR and OS was different on the left and right sides of the inflection point.
 Albumin and globulin reflect the systemic inflammatory response in the host, influencing antioxidant effects and immune states.
 Low albumin levels have been confirmed to be a useful prognostic tool for lung cancer.
 They found that low AGR was a risk factor for cancer morbidity and mortality, AGR could predict postoperative chemotherapy efficacy in NSCLC, and AGR was associated with overall survival in metastatic cancer.
 The p-value was less than 0.001, indicating a statistically significant result.

 To identify errors within each translated segment, up to a maximum of five.
 Errors are categorized as Addition, Omission, Mistranslation, Untranslated text, Punctuation, Spelling, Grammar, Register, Inconsistency, Character encoding, Terminology, Style, Locale convention, Source error, or Non-translation.
 Error severity is classified as either major or minor, independent of the error category.
 The rejection criteria are used when sampling in-context learning examples for AUTOMQM.
 Major errors are weighted at 25, minor errors at 0.1, and neutral errors at 0.
 To derive quality scores automatically from the identified error spans and their classifications.
 A Non-translation error spans the entire segment and signifies the absence of translation.
 The same weighting scheme is used to obtain scores from errors identified by AUTOMQM.
 Table 9 summarizes the MQM error weighting scheme, which ranges from 0 (perfect) to 25 (worst).
 The final segment-level score is an average over scores from all annotators.
The main focus of Ph.D. programs at LTI is to develop the next generation of scientific and entrepreneurial leaders.
It takes two years for a student to complete their MLT program.
The Ph.D. in Language and Information Technology at LTI focuses on developing the next generation of scientific and entrepreneurial leaders.
The curriculum for Ph.D. programs at LTI is similar to MLT program during the first two years.
After the second year, a student spends most of their time working closely with their faculty advisor on research that advances the state-of-the-art in computer science.
The requirements for Ph.D. programs at LTI include working closely with a faculty advisor on research that advances the state-of-the-art in computer science.
The focus of the first two years of Ph.D. programs at LTI is similar to MLT program, providing hands-on experience and a rigorous curriculum.
The admission process for Ph.D. in Language and Information Technology involves working closely with your faculty advisor on research that advances the state-of-the-art in computer science.
Additional information provided about Ph.D. programs at LTI includes an overview, requirements, curriculum, admission process, and handbook.

The School of Computer Science requires GRE scores that must be less than five years old, and English Proficiency Requirement if you will be studying on an F-1 or J-1 visa.

If you will be studying on an F-1 or J-1 visa, and English is not a native language for you (native language…meaning spoken at home), then you need to fulfill the English Proficiency Requirement.
The minimum TOEFL score required for successful applicants is 100.
Students are required to provide an official copy of their English proficiency score report because the institution has a policy that this requirement cannot be waived for any reason.
The Institution Code for submitting TOEFL scores is 4256, while the Department Code is 78.
Official transcripts from each university attended are required to ensure a complete and accurate record of the applicant's academic history.
Providing a current resume allows the admissions committee to assess an applicant's relevant work experience and achievements, which can be important for certain programs.
A Statement of Purpose is required to understand an applicant's academic and professional goals, motivations, and how they align with the program.
Three letters of recommendation provide insight into an applicant's skills, abilities, and potential from different perspectives, which can help the admissions committee make a more informed decision.
In addition to SCS guidelines, LTI requires a short (1-3 minute) video of the applicant responding to a prompt question and an official award letter if they are receiving outside funding.

The dual-degree Ph.D. program offered by LTI is in Language and Information Technologies, which is a partnership with several universities in Portugal.
Stacey Young should be contacted for any specific application or admissions-related queries.
The Ph.D. Handbook is recommended to get a comprehensive understanding of the Ph.D. program, including information about internships.
LTI has partnerships with Universidade de Aveiro (Ph.D. in Computer Engineering), Universidade do Minho (Ph.D. in Informatics), Universidade do Porto (FCUP, Ph.D. in Computer Science and FEUP, Ph.D. in Computer Science) as part of MAPi; Universidade de Lisboa, Faculdade de Ciências – FCUL (Ph.D. in Informatics); and Universidade de Lisboa, Instituto Superior Técnico – IST (Ph.D. in Computer Science and Engineering, Ph.D. in Electrical and Computers Engineering).
The dual-degree Ph.D. program offers a comprehensive study plan that combines language and information technologies.
The specific requirements can be found in the Ph.D. Handbook, which provides detailed information about internships as well.
The curriculum can be found in the overview section of the Ph.D. Handbook, which also includes information about internships.
Stacey Young should be contacted for any additional queries related to the dual-degree Ph.D. in Language and Information Technologies.
MAPi stands for 'Mestrado Integrado em Ciências da Computação e Engenharia Informática', which translates to 'Integrated Master in Computer Science and Information Engineering'. It is a partnership between LTI and several universities in Portugal, including Universidade de Aveiro (Ph.D. in Computer Engineering), Universidade do Minho (Ph.D. in Informatics), Universidade do Porto (FCUP, Ph.D. in Computer Science and FEUP, Ph.D. in Computer Science) as part of MAPi; Universidade de Lisboa, Faculdade de Ciências – FCUL (Ph.D. in Informatics); and Universidade de Lisboa, Instituto Superior Técnico – IST (Ph.D. in Computer Science and Engineering, Ph.D. in Electrical and Computers Engineering).
Students jointly enrolled in the LTI Ph.D program spend a year in Portugal, then two years at Carnegie Mellon taking classes in linguistics, computer science, statistical learning and task orientation.
After completing the majority of their academic requirements, students return to Portugal for the next two years to conduct extensive research, ultimately leading to a dissertation topic that will be publicly defended.
One adviser from each institution co-supervises their student’s progress and helps to define their final thesis topic.
Students participating in the dual-degree program will spend their first year in Portugal, followed by two years in Pittsburgh to complete their coursework.
