The Master of Language Technologies program prepares students for a research career in academia or industry. After completing this two-year immersive program, many students continue on to Ph.D. programs at CMU and other top institutions while others pursue careers at companies emphasizing research.
In the MLT program, your time will be evenly split between taking courses and doing research with your faculty advisor during the academic year.
During the summer, all time will be devoted entirely to research as part of the Master's Program in Language Technologies.
More information about the MLT program and other programs at CMU can be found on the CMU | Portugal website.
The handbook provides detailed information about admissions requirements, procedures, and policies for students applying to the MLT program.
The 'Additional Info' section likely provides supplementary information about the program, such as resources available to students, faculty expertise, or potential career paths.
The MLT program's primary focus is on research. Students are immersed in research for two full years during their studies, with half the time spent taking courses and the other half devoted to working closely with faculty advisors.
The MLT program lasts for 24 months.
Students must complete two summers of research and take at least 72 LTI courses, 24 SCS courses, and additional units from either LTI or other senior-/graduate-level courses.
MLT students take at least 120 course units, with most being 12-unit courses and lab courses typically being 6 units.
Yes, the courses generally assume knowledge of programming and data structures.
Directed research is an integral part of the MLT program where students carry out research with guidance from their faculty advisors.
No, completing an optional MLT thesis is not mandatory but guidelines can be found in the MLT Handbook.
The remaining units may also be taken from either the LTI, or with approval from the faculty advisor, any other senior-/graduate-level course offered at CMU or Pitt.
Most courses are 12 units while lab courses are typically 6 units.

The Master’s in Intelligent Information Systems degree focuses on recognizing and extracting meaning from text, spoken language, and video. It provides deep exposure to content analysis and machine learning.
The MIIS program requires students to complete coursework, work on directed study projects with a faculty advisor for two semesters; participate in a summer internship; and collaborate with peers on a group-oriented capstone project.
For more information about the MIIS program, contact Kate Schaich.
The MLT Handbook provides a complete breakdown of the MLT program and its policies, including information about internships.
The Master’s in Intelligent Information Systems degree focuses on recognizing and extracting meaning from text, spoken language, and video. It provides deep exposure to content analysis and machine learning.
The MIIS program consists of classroom instruction, professional experience through a summer internship, and using new skills in s
Students can view the MIIS Handbook for more information about the program.
Directed study projects are a part of the MIIS program where students work with their faculty advisor for two semesters to gain professional experience.
The capstone project is a group-oriented project that lasts for one semester and allows students to collaborate with their peers, applying new skills learned throughout the program.
Pursuing a degree in Intelligent Information Systems can prepare you for successful careers in industry or government. The alumni have gone on to exciting careers at places like Apple, IBM and Google.
MIIS students gain three types of practical experience: software development supervised by their advisor (24 units equivalent to two courses), a summer internship, and a capstone project executed in a group of peers.
MIIS-16 degree is completed in three academic years or 16 months.
A capstone project executed by MIIS students is equivalent to four courses: one 6-unit course and three 12-unit courses.
The two options for pursuing a degree in Intelligent Information Systems are Standard MIIS degree (MIIS-16) and another option.
Yes, students can waive the summer internship requirement if they have sufficient prior professional experience.
The purpose of consultation with an advisor in creating a course of study for Intelligent Information Systems degree is to offer students flexibility.
Most MIIS alumni have job offers within six weeks after graduation.
Some of these companies include Apple, IBM and Google.
The MIIS-21 track takes four academic semesters (fall, spring, fall, spring) and a summer internship.
The Advanced Study degree at MIIS offers depth in one of the following areas: Human Language for Language Technologies, Language Technology Application, and Machine Learning for Language Technologies.
Yes, part-time education is an option in some cases at MIIS.
MIIS-16 students need to complete a minimum of 84 units (typically 7 courses) in qualifying and elective courses that meet the human language, machine learning, and language technology applications breadth requirements.
MIIS-21 students have to complete an additional two courses from their selected concentration area, making the total number of units (typically 9 courses) and satisfying breadth requirements.
MIIS-21 students need to complete at least two more courses from their selected concentration area, making it a total of 108 units (typically 9 courses) of qualifying and elective courses that also satisfy breadth requirements.
MIIS-21 students have the option to specialize in Human Language for Language Technologies, Language Technology Application, or Machine Learning for Language Technologies.
MIIS-21 students must satisfy human language, machine learning, and language technology applications breadth requirements.
Yes, the part-time education option is also available in some cases for MIIS-21 students.

 The number of ties for RL1 increases as 𝑚 increases.
 The number of ties for lexiprecision shrinks as 𝑚 increases.
 It suggests that there are very few relevant items in the rankings, resulting in tied rankings and no relevant items present.
 Both rrLP and sgnLP outperform reciprocal rank in detecting statistically significant differences.
 The lexiprecision variants capture the properties of RL1 while increasing the ability to distinguish systems.
 It is recommended to assess whether the assumptions behind RL1 metrics are aligned with the use case, considering the uncertainty over recall requirements and psychological relevance.
 The MSMARCO dataset is mentioned as an example.
 The call is to make labeling practices more robust across all domains.
 The study highlights the importance of considering tie-breaking in the evaluation process and provides a method for conducting more reliable best-case retrieval evaluation.
 Lexiprecision can effectively address the limitations of reciprocal rank in retrieval evaluation.
 It indicates that CUTTLEFISH begins factorizing layers after the first embedding layer.
 PUFFERFISH starts factorizing layers from the 7th encoder block for DeiT.
 Fine-tuning epochs are typically set to T = 3, 5.
 The batch size used is 1,024.
 During fine-tuning, the feed-forward network (FFN) layers FC1 and FC2 in BERT do not get updated.
 The CoLA task is considered to be relatively challenging.
 Scaled stable rank is used to avoid overly aggressive low rank estimations that could harm the final accuracy of factorized low-rank models.
 Applying FD to CUTTLEFISH did not consistently lead to better model accuracy.
 To ensure consistency with the VGG-19 architecture used in the experiments.
 The observation is that applying FD does not always enhance the accuracy of factorized low-rank models.

 Key features of ESPnet-ST-v2 include support for Spectral features, speech SSL representations, and multiple interchangeable encoder and decoder architectures.
 Fully constructed models in ESPnet-ST-v2 are fed to task wrappers which prepare data loaders, initialize models, and handle training/validation.
 For offline attentional decoder models in ESPnet-ST-v2, label-synchronous beam search is supported with optional CTC joint decoding for multi-objective models.
 Cross-entropy, CTC, and Transducer are supported for ST and SST models in ESPnet-ST-v2. Multi-objective training with various combinations of these loss functions is also supported.
 Minimum Bayes Risk (MBR) ensembling is supported for ST models in ESPnet-ST-v2, allowing for comparison and ranking of n-best outputs from one or more models.
 Conformer, Branchformer, EBranchformer, and Transformer encoder architectures are supported for speech-to-speech tasks in ESPnet-ST-v2.
 Decoder architectures in ESPnet-ST-v2 support multi-decoder schemes that allow for E2E differentiable decoder cascades via searchable hidden intermediates.
 Each modeling component in ESPnet-ST-v2 features a variety of interchangeable approaches, allowing for flexibility in architectural design.
 Neural vocoders are supported for both spectral and discrete inputs in S2ST models in ESPnet-ST-v2 for synthesis and post-processing.
 For offline Transducer models in ESPnet-ST-v2, original Graves beam search along with time-synchronous and alignment-synchronous beam searches are supported.
 The purpose of the environment is to build autonomous agents that can perform tasks on the web using natural language commands.
 Current agents are primarily created and tested in simplified synthetic environments, leading to a disconnect with real-world scenarios.
 The environment covers four common domains: e-commerce, social forum discussions, collaborative software development, and content management.
 Tools such as a map and external knowledge bases (e.g., user manuals) are mentioned to be enriched in the environment.
 The best GPT-4-based agent achieves an end-to-end task success rate of 14.41%.
 The human performance success rate is 78.24%.
 The resources can be found at https://webarena.dev/.
 812 long-horizon web-based tasks are included in the benchmark.
 The knowledge bases vary from general resources like English Wikipedia to more domain-specific references, enriching human-like task-solving.
 The content is delivered using Docker containers with gym-APIs, ensuring usability and reproducibility.
 L = LNLL + αLInfoNCE
 α is a hyperparameter with a value of 1 that works well.
 It mixes up pairs of captions with different corresponding audio clips in the Clotho dataset.
 To compute the cosine similarity between the text and audio embeddings for candidate caption ranking.
 It yields better performance compared to 100K mix-ups.
 Using less downsampling gives finer-grained audio features but a smaller batch size leads to less reliable gradients.
 Using a hybrid reranking algorithm that considers both learned audio encoder stack and text decoder.
 To achieve a balance between decoder and encoder reranking metrics.
 To filter out generations with fluency issues during evaluation.
 It makes the distribution less peaky and more challenging.

The purpose of iCalendar RSS Feed is to provide a way for users to access and manage their calendar events in a structured format.
You can share an event from the iCalendar RSS Feed by clicking on the 'Share' button and selecting one of the available options: Facebook, Twitter, Email or Print.
When events are marked in bold in the Home section, they indicate that these events are related to home activities and may be of personal interest or importance.
iCalendar refers to a calendar application used for managing appointments, meetings, and events. On the other hand, an RSS Feed (Really Simple Syndication) allows users to access updates from websites in a structured format.
The 'Conference' event listed could be an upcoming conference related to iCalendar or RSS Feed, which may provide users with updates and information about these technologies.
The word 'Home' refers to events that are related to personal or home activities, which may include family gatherings, appointments, or other important dates.
The separate section for Home events allows users to easily identify and manage their personal activities and events, which may be different from work-related or other types of events.
The RSS Feed in iCalendar allows users to access and manage their calendar events in a structured format, which can be easily shared or subscribed by others.
The 'Share' button allows users to share events with others, either through social media platforms like Facebook and Twitter or by emailing it directly.

 The purpose is to ensure that each individual beam is expanded until it hits the stopping criterion.
 The best beam from the stopped beams is selected.
 Length normalization is applied because the stopped beams may contain hypotheses of different lengths.
 The blockwise streaming beam search algorithm applies beam search to the full-context offline models, whereas the standard beam search does not.
 The experiments use the MuST-C data set for English → German, English → Spanish, and English → French language pairs.
 The ESP-Net toolkit is used for the blockwise speech translation models.
 The encoder has 12 layers, and the decoder has 6 layers. The model dimension is 256, with a feed-forward dimension of 2048 and 4 attention heads.
 The offline ST models are evaluated using Simuleval toolkit. Translation quality is reported using detokenized case-sensitive BLEU, and latency is reported using length-aware average lagging (LAAL).
 The purpose is to enable the incremental user experience while processing each block.
 The difference is between 0.6 and 0.7 BLEU in favor of re-translation SST.

 The goal of the survey is to provide a taxonomy of E2E ASR models and corresponding improvements, and to discuss their properties and their relationship to classical hidden Markov model (HMM) based ASR architectures.
 All relevant aspects of E2E ASR are covered in this work: modeling, training, decoding, and external language model integration, discussions of performance and deployment opportunities, as well as an outlook into potential future developments.
 The two tracks of the MISP2022 challenge are audio-visual speaker diarization (AVSD) and audio-visual diarization and recognition (AVDR).
 Both tracks of the MISP2022 challenge focus on the Chinese language and use far-field audio and video in real home-TV scenarios with 2-6 people communicating with TV noise in the background.
 DPHuBERT aims to address the large model size and heavy computational cost hindering the deployment of self-supervised speech models.
 DPHuBERT is a task-agnostic compression method for speech SSL based on joint distillation and pruning, which outperforms pure distillation methods in almost all tasks.
 The study aims to provide a snapshot of laboratory proficiency, identify issues, improve laboratory performance, and reduce inter-laboratory variation in seasonal influenza serology testing.
 Participant laboratories from various sectors returned data for hemagglutination inhibition (HAI) and microneutralization (MN) assays to assess laboratory proficiency in seasonal influenza serology testing.
 The focus of the submission is to develop a strong target speech enhancement system for hearing-aid (HA) devices in noisy-reverberant environments.
 The Wavlab submission builds on the iNeuBe-X model, which is an extension of the state-of-the-art TF-GridNet model for multi-channel, streamable target-speaker speech enhancement.
 The main topic of the text is active retrieval augmented generation in language models.
 The purpose is to address hallucination and create factually accurate content by retrieving information from external knowledge resources.
 The proposed method is Forward-Looking Active REtrieval augmented generation (FLARE), which actively decides when and what to retrieve during the generation process.
 FLARE was tested comprehensively over 4 long-form knowledge-intensive generation tasks/datasets.
 FLARE uses a prediction of the upcoming sentence to anticipate future content, then retrieves relevant documents to regenerate the sentence.
 Short-form tasks involve clear information needs in the input, while long-form tasks require gathering multiple pieces of knowledge throughout the generation process.
 Examples include long-form question answering, open-domain summarization, and chain-of-thought reasoning.
 Humans gradually gather information as they create content, similar to the proposed approach for long-form generation with LMs.
 Existing methods may not accurately reflect what LMs intend to generate in the future or retrieve at inappropriate points.
 The research question is whether a simple and generic retrieval augmented LM can be created.
 The best filter length for UNSSOR is different from that of iRAS.
 The best performance of UNSSOR is higher than that of iRAS.
 Setting K to 5 and 25 produces worse performance than setting it to 20.
 A very long filter would have a large degrees of freedom to fit the mixture well, potentially hindering separation.
 FCP is less computationally-expensive as it requires inverting a smaller matrix compared to time-domain Wiener filtering.
 The filter length is an important hyper-parameter that affects the performance of the separation.
 The strong modelling capabilities of TF-GridNet and the contributions of the UNSSOR mechanism contribute to the effectiveness of the proposed system.
 UNSSOR works to some extent with TCN-DenseUNet, but the results are not as good as those obtained by using TF-GridNet.
 DPRNN has a window size of 4 ms, a hop size of 1 ms, 6 layers, 256 bases, 128 bottleneck dimension, and ReLU activation.
 The spatial embedding dimension is set to 360 in the six-channel case.

Students seeking guidance about their program of study and degree requirements should consult with their academic advisor and/or appropriate associate dean.
Under U.S. Federal Title IV regulations, student eligibility for federal financial aid is contingent upon enrollment in and successful completion of courses that are counted as credit toward their current degree program.
Students should reference CMU Policy on Master’s Student Statute of Limitations (www.cmu.edu/policies/student-and-student-life/masters-students-statute-of limitations.html) regarding guidelines and restrictions which place an upper limit on the maximum length of time allowable for master’s degree completion and certification.
Students are expected to make normal progress toward their degree in order to graduate within the standard timeframe for their program of study.
If a student fails to make normal progress toward their degree, they may lose eligibility for federal financial aid and could face other consequences as outlined in CMU’s policies.
Students seeking guidance about their program of study and degree requirements should consult with their academic advisor and/or appropriate associate dean.
By regularly meeting with their academic advisor, staying on top of course requirements, and successfully completing courses as outlined in the program of study.
Associate deans are responsible for providing guidance to students seeking assistance with their program of study and degree requirements, as well as overseeing academic policies within their respective departments.
The policy serves to establish guidelines and restrictions on the maximum length of time allowable for master’s degree completion and certification, ensuring that students adhere to academic standards set by the university.
Students must enroll each semester in at least 36 units that count toward their current degree level.

Curricular requirements, Capstone project or thesis, and Elective courses
Curricular requirements
To demonstrate mastery and application of skills learned in the program
Not specified, but students can choose from a variety of electives based on their interests and career goals.
The three types of requirements for students at MIIS are qualifying, elective and practice.
A student must take at least 84 units (typically 7 12-unit courses) of qualifying and elective courses that satisfy human language, machine learning, and language technology applications breadth requirements and 66 practice units for a total of 150 units to attain the Standard MIIS degree.
A student must take at least 108 units (typically 9 12-unit courses) of qualifying and elective courses and 66 practice units to satisfy their degree requirements, making it a total of 174 units to attain the MIIS: Advanced Study degree.
Grade requirements ensure that students have demonstrated a certain level of skill while completing degree requirements.
Both the Standard MIIS degree and the MIIS: Advanced Study degree require 66 practice units.
Practice requirements are opportunities to apply and hone new skills while building state-of-the-art systems.
Both the Standard MIIS degree and the MIIS: Advanced Study degree require 84 units of qualifying and elective courses that satisfy human language, machine learning, and language technology applications breadth requirements.
The main difference in unit requirement between the two degrees is that the MIIS: Advanced Study degree requires an additional 28 units compared to the Standard MIIS degree.
The term 'typically' means that while a certain number of courses are required, there may be some flexibility in how these courses can be taken.
The three areas where students need to show breadth are Human language, Machine learning and Language technology applications.
MIIS-21 students must take two more LTI courses (24 units total) in one of the following areas: Human language, Machine learning and Language technology applications.
Yes, some courses used to satisfy a breadth requirement can also satisfy qualifying course requirements.
A student must complete at least 66 practice-oriented course units for both MIIS-16 and MIIS-21 programs.
Students must pass 24 units in directed study under the supervision of their advisor.
Directed study is a structured, task-oriented form of independent learning under the supervision of their advisor.
The three areas for showing breadth are Human language, Machine learning and Language technology applications.
MIIS-21 students must complete two more LTI courses (24 units total) in one of the following areas: Human language, Machine learning and Language technology applications.
MIIS-21 students must complete 24 units in directed study under the supervision of their advisor.
A capstone requirement is an experience that gives students significant hands-on experience with techniques studied in the classroom and an opportunity to work on a large software application.
A student needs to complete 36 units of capstone project.
The capstone planning seminar organizes students into groups, defines goals and requirements for their projects, identifies resources needed to complete it successfully, and helps them acquire these resources.
The capstone project is supervised by a member of the faculty who meets with students on a weekly basis to monitor progress and provide guidance.
Students need to complete 6 units of capstone planning seminar.
The result of a successful capstone project is typically a major software application.
Students need to complete 42 units in total, which includes both the capstone project (36 units) and the capstone planning seminar (6 units).
A typical goal of the capstone project is to give students experience with collaborative, team-oriented software development.
Students are organized into groups during the capstone planning seminar.
Students must obtain a B- or better in all courses counting towards core requirements, maintain an average QPA of at least 3.0 for courses and projects used to satisfy degree requirements, and not elect the pass/fail option for courses and projects used to satisfy a degree requirement.
That course may count as an elective towards the degree requirements.
No, pass/fail grades are not permitted for courses and projects used to satisfy a degree requirement.
No, graduate students who require additional undergraduate courses to build up their core foundations of computer science may not elect the pass/fail option for these courses.
The process for appealing a final grade is outlined under section 4.2.4 of the MIIS Graduate Student Handbook.
A student must obtain a C or better in an elective course for it to be counted towards their degree requirements.
The QPA (Quality Point Average) is calculated by dividing the total number of quality points earned in all courses and projects by the total number of credit hours.
If a student does not maintain an average QPA of at least 3.0, they may be subject to academic dismissal.
If a student does not obtain a B- or better in all courses counting towards their core requirements, they may be subject to academic dismissal.
The circumstances that may warrant a grade appeal include when the final grade assigned for a course is based on manifest error (e.g., a clear error such as arithmetic error in computing a grade or failure to grade one of the answers on an exam), or when the faculty or staff member who assigned the grade did so in violation of a university policy.
Yes, any graduate course (600-level or higher) offered by the Language Technologies Institute is considered a qualifying course.
Any two graduate courses (600-level or higher) offered by department can be considered as a qualifying course.
Final grades will be changed only in exceptional circumstances and only with the approval of the instructor and the department, unit or program. Grading is a matter of sound discretion of the instructor and final grades are rarely changed without the consent of the instructor who assigned the grade.
When grading is considered as a matter of sound discretion, it means that the final grades are not determined by strict rules or formulas but rather by the instructor's judgment and expertise.
In the context of a grade appeal, 'manifest error' refers to clear errors such as arithmetic mistakes while computing grades or failure to grade one of the answers on an exam.
The department plays a crucial role in the process of appealing for final grades. They are involved in approving the appeal and ensuring that all procedures are followed correctly.
The significance of considering 600-level or higher courses as qualifying courses is that they are typically more advanced and specialized, providing students with a deeper understanding of their field.
It means that once a grade has been assigned by an instructor, it is not often altered unless there are exceptional circumstances and both the instructor and department agree to make changes.

Directed study projects play a significant role in the education and progress monitoring of students through the program. They are supervised by faculty advisors, ensuring that each student receives necessary mentoring.
If a student has not found an advisor after one month in the program, the Program Director will assign an advisor to the student.
To change advisors, a student should find another faculty member willing to serve as an advisor and then make a request to the Program Director to switch advisors. The new and old advisors need to agree to the change.
It's beneficial for students not to switch advisors late in their graduate studies because forming a strong relationship with an advisor takes time and switching can disrupt the progress of their graduate studies.
The Program Director plays a crucial role in approving an advising relationship between a student and faculty member. If a student wants to switch advisors, they need to make a request to the Program Director.
The initial advisor selection should be made carefully. Students are encouraged to seek out faculty members with expertise in their area of interest and proactively meet individually with potential advisors.
The SCS policy requires that both the new and old advisors agree to a change in advisors. This policy has been followed by MIIS Graduate Student Handbook.
Faculty members are expected to serve as advisors for students in their area of expertise. They should agree to an advising relationship with a student if both parties mutually agree.
The MIIS Graduate Student Handbook provides guidelines and information for students regarding their academic journey, including advising relationships.

The purpose of the university policy on grades is to provide details concerning university grading principles for students taking courses and covers the specifics of assigning and changing grades, grading options, drop/withdrawals, and course repeats. It also defines the undergraduate and graduate grading standards.

The purpose of a university's grading principles is to provide guidelines for assigning grades in courses, ensuring consistency and fairness across different instructors and departments.
The specifics covered under the section on 'Assigning Grades' include details about how grades should be assigned in courses, such as considering factors like class participation and performance on assignments.
A cross-registration program allows students to take courses at other institutions that are part of the same consortium, in this case, the Pittsburgh Council on Higher Education (PCHE).
Under 'Grading Options', details about alternative grading methods are provided. This could include options like pass/fail, credit/no-credit, or other non-letter grade systems.
The purpose of a university's policy on drop and withdrawal is to provide guidelines for when students can drop or withdraw from courses, how it affects their grades, and any potential consequences.
The term 'grading standards' refers to the specific criteria that are used by a university or institution to determine what constitutes an A, B, C, D, or F grade.
Under 'Course Repeats', details are provided about when and how students can repeat a course to improve their grade. This could include rules on the maximum number of times a student can repeat a course, or any restrictions that apply.
The purpose of including transfer courses on a university transcript is to provide evidence of students' academic work completed at other accredited institutions, which can be used for various purposes such as fulfilling degree requirements or demonstrating proficiency in certain subjects.

Carnegie Mellon University educates its students to become professionals who will serve society with integrity.
Carnegie Mellon strives to serve the changing needs of society through the three primary goals outlined in its mission statement: to create and disseminate knowledge and art through research and artistic expression, teaching and learning and transfer to society.
Carnegie Mellon strives to serve students by teaching them leadership and problem-solving skills.
The high demands of a challenging academic environment can create situations where some students have difficulty exercising good judgment.
It is the responsibility of the entire community to establish and maintain the integrity of our university.
Academic challenges can provide many opportunities for high standards to evolve if students actively reflect on these challenges and if the community supports discussions to aid in this process.
Carnegie Mellon creates and disseminates new knowledge and expressions of knowledge in ways that benefit society.
The university's community supports discussions to aid in the process of students reflecting on academic challenges and maintaining the integrity of our university.
Carnegie Mellon educates its students to become professionals who will serve society with integrity.
Carnegie Mellon University emphasizes the values of quality, ethical behavior, responsibility to society and commitments to work.
The ethical responsibility of students when presenting any creative or research work is to identify the conceptual sources of the work submitted. Failure to do so is dishonest and can lead to disciplinary action.
If a student violates academic integrity, they may face disciplinary actions according to the university's protocol. The Carnegie Mellon's Academic Disciplinary Actions Overview for Graduate Students describes procedures for disciplinary actions against graduate students in cases of alleged violations of academic regulations and the appeal process.
The purpose of reviewing the University Policy on Academic Integrity is to understand the procedures for disciplinary actions against students in cases of alleged violations of academic regulations and the appeal process.
Carnegie Mellon University values a diverse community that is open to the exchange of ideas, where discovery and artistic creativity can flourish.
When Carnegie Mellon refers to 'conceptual sources', they are referring to the original ideas or concepts that were used in a student's work. It is important for students to identify these sources as it helps maintain academic integrity.
Carnegie Mellon University expects its graduate students to adhere to the values of quality, ethical behavior, responsibility to society and commitments to work. This includes identifying conceptual sources in their creative or research works.
The consequence for failing to identify 'conceptual sources' can lead to a charge of cheating or plagiarism, which may result in disciplinary action.
Carnegie Mellon's Academic Disciplinary Actions Overview for Graduate Students describes procedures for disciplinary actions against graduate students in cases of alleged violations of academic regulations and the appeal process.
Academic integrity refers to the honesty, fairness and responsibility in all aspects of academic work. It involves respecting the intellectual property rights of others by acknowledging their ideas and words.
For a first violation, the student is grounds for dismissal from the graduate program. If we decide not to immediately dismiss, the student will be put on disciplinary probation.
Plagiarism refers to presenting someone else's ideas or words as your own without properly acknowledging the source. This includes copying and pasting from a website, paraphrasing without citing sources, or using quotes without quotation marks.
Unauthorized assistance refers to receiving help on an assignment that violates the academic integrity policy. This includes sharing work with others, allowing someone else to do your work for you, or using materials not authorized by the instructor.
The Academic Disciplinary Actions procedures outline the appeal process for students who feel they have been wrongly accused. The student should submit their case in writing to the Director of Student Conduct within five days of receiving notice of the alleged violation.
The policy encourages students to review the University's Academic Disciplinary Actions procedures, which outline the process for investigating, reporting, and adjudicating violations of the University Policy on Academic Integrity. This helps students understand their rights and responsibilities in case of an academic integrity issue.
Cheating refers to any behavior that gives an unfair advantage on an assessment. This includes looking at someone else's paper during a test, using unauthorized materials or devices, or submitting work done by another person.
If a student commits a second violation while on disciplinary probation, they will be subject to further disciplinary action. The specific consequences depend on the nature of the second violation and other factors.
Unauthorized assistance refers to receiving help on an assignment that violates the academic integrity policy. This includes sharing work with others, allowing someone else to do your work for you, or using materials not authorized by the instructor.
Disciplinary probation is a status assigned to students who have committed an academic integrity violation. During this period, the student must adhere to certain conditions and may face further consequences if they commit another violation.

During the first two weeks of each semester, students can add a course by registering online. After this deadline, they may do so by completing the Late Add Request form and obtaining permission from both the instructor or teaching department and their advisor.
Dropping a course is not recommended unless it's due to health reasons or family emergency. This is because many SCS courses have long waitlists, and if students drop a course, another student who might have had the opportunity to take that course will be denied. If MSAII program students drop too many courses, instructors may no longer allow them to enroll.
In such cases, the student should speak with their advisor or academic department for guidance. They can help determine if dropping a course is necessary and provide advice on how to manage their workload.
The ADD period stands for 'Add/Drop Deadline'. It's the first two weeks of each semester when students can add a course by registering online. After this deadline, they need to complete the Late Add Request form and get permission from both the instructor or teaching department and their advisor.

A leave of absence refers to temporarily leaving the university for personal, medical or academic reasons with a commitment to return at a mutually determined time.
Students planning to return from a leave of absence must complete the appropriate paperwork before returning to the university.
Withdrawal refers to leaving the university with no intention of returning, which is different from taking a leave of absence where students commit to return at a mutually determined time.

Yes, a student can graduate under the policies in effect at the time that the student entered the program; this is known as the 'Grandfather' policy.
The two options available to students who wish to graduate under policies adopted after they entered the program are: (1) following the new policy, or (2) graduating under existing departmental policies as closely as possible.
The decision to grant transfer credit or issue an exemption for equivalent graduate courses previously completed at another institution rests with the program director, on the advice of the faculty member for whose course an exemption is sought.
If a student is exempt from a required course, they can replace that course with an open elective. The student does not receive credit for the exempted course but can take any course that could normally count toward the degree in its place.
This situation typically arises only when a student is enrolled in the program for an extended period, and it is rare to follow a particular policy exactly.
If a student receives credit for exempted courses, they can take any course that could normally count toward the degree in its place.
The decision to grant transfer credit or issue an exemption has no direct impact on a student's academic progress, as it only replaces one course with another.
The faculty member for whose course an exemption is sought plays a crucial role in the decision-making process, providing advice to the program director.
Not following a particular policy exactly is rare and typically arises only when a student is enrolled in the program for an extended period.
If a student cannot find a suitable open elective, they should consult with their academic advisor or program director for further guidance.
Transfer credit and course exemptions allow students to build on previous learning experiences, potentially reducing the time required to complete their degree program.
The student receives that many units of credit and the total amount of required coursework is reduced by that amount.

The following circumstances may warrant a grade appeal: (a) the final grade assigned for a course is based on manifest error, such as arithmetic errors in computing a grade or failure to grade one of the answers on an exam; or (b) the faculty or staff member who assigned the grade did so in violation of a University policy.

Yes, grading is a matter of sound discretion for the instructor. Final grades are rarely changed without the consent of the instructor who assigned the grade.
If there is an error in computing a student's final grade, such as arithmetic errors or failure to grade one of the answers on an exam, it may warrant a grade appeal.
If students believe that their grades were assigned in violation of University policies, they can file an appeal.
Final grades will be changed only in exceptional circumstances and only with the approval of the instructor and the department, unit or program.
The University has a policy against Sexual Harassment and Sexual Assault. It prohibits sex-based discrimination, sexual harassment, sexual assault, dating/domestic violence and stalking.
The process for appealing final grades involves filing an appeal with the approval of the instructor and the department, unit or program. The appeal should be based on manifest error in grading or violation of University policies.

The Consensual Intimate Relationship Policy Regarding Undergraduate Students states that romantic, sexual or amorous relationships/interactions with undergraduate students, even if consensual, are inappropriate and prohibited for graduate students who will be in a supervisory role of undergraduate students as a TA or in a research lab/studio setting.
If you are found to have violated Carnegie Mellon policy, you will be dropped from the MSAII program immediately without exception.

Cross-registration provides an opportunity for enriched educational programs by permitting full-time graduate students to cross-register for courses at a Pittsburgh Council on Higher Education (PCHE) Institution. Full-time Carnegie Mellon degree students are eligible.
More information about the PCHE course is available at www.cmu.edu/hub/registrar/registration/cross/index.html
A PCHE course may not count towards full-time status unless the student is enrolled in an inter-university program.
Usually, no more than one PCHE course may be taken per semester through cross-registration.
Students interested in taking advantage of the cross-registration opportunity should be familiar with the Policy on Grades for Transfer Courses already outlined previously in this handbook.
The policy on grades for transfer courses can be found in a previous section of this handbook.
According to the university policy, students have the right to inspect and review their education records; request an amendment to their education record if they believe it is inaccurate or misleading; and request a hearing if their request for an amendment is not resolved.
FERPA stands for the federal Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act.
This university policy was created to notify students of their rights under FERPA, a federal law that protects student privacy rights.
If a student's request for an amendment to their education record is not resolved, they have the right to request a hearing.
Yes, according to FERPA, students have the right to inspect and review their education records.
The purpose of this university policy is to inform students about their rights under FERPA and how they can exercise those rights.
A student can request an amendment to their education record by submitting a written request explaining why they believe the record is inaccurate or misleading.
If FERPA rights are violated, students can file a complaint with the Department of Education's Family Policy Compliance Office. The university may also have its own procedures for handling such complaints.
The federal law that protects student privacy rights is FERPA, or the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act.

 Approximately 20% reduction in computational complexity was observed with the IBWBS.
 Quality improvement of 6.2, 5.7, and 8.3 BLEU scores were observed for English to German, Spanish, and French, respectively.
 The IBWBS helps reduce the computational complexity by approximately 20%.
 Figure 2a illustrates the latency control using the block size.
 Improvements in both quality and latency (by more than 2 BLEU and by 500 ms, respectively) were observed for English to French.
 Approximately 20 to 30% reduction in computational complexity was observed for both local agreement and hold-n policies.
 The proposed changes brought improvement to both quality and latency.
 It incorporates local agreement or hold-n policies for quality-latency control without the need to retrain the model.
 The framework successfully applied quality and performance improvements compared to the standard beam search.
 The challenge is the accurate measurement of the fitness function, especially in apps that run in more than 150ms.
 The program representation consists of a list of edits that are applied sequentially to the source code.
 In the Fitness section, the application is patched, compiled, and run through unit tests. If all unit tests pass, the patch is considered valid, and the property being improved is measured.
 Robolectric allows for simulation-based testing of application components within a local JVM, which helps in testing any application component with fast local tests.
 The most complained about non-functional properties are execution time, memory usage, bandwidth, and energy usage.
 The statement is supported by the findings of Callan and Petke (2022a), who found that improvements demonstrated with Robolectric testing translated to actual improvements on real devices in all cases.
 The primary technique mentioned is prefetching.
 It is important due to limited resources and the ability to evolve patches that balance different trade-offs, producing Pareto fronts of solutions.
 The initial population consists of individuals with single random edits, which are further guided by a search algorithm that applies mutations and crossovers.
 Patches are created through mutation and crossover on the list of edits representation.
 The text discusses the effectiveness of a partial selection scheme in reducing labeling costs in different querying methods for information extraction tasks.
 The partial selection scheme requires lower labeling costs than full annotation to reach the upper bound.
 The text suggests that it would be interesting to explore combining the method with more complex acquisition functions, such as those considering representativeness.
 Figure 9 shows the mention extraction results for the event extraction task.
 PA can obtain similar results to FA with the same reading texts and less mention labeling cost.
 FA relation extraction cost is measured by two times the annotated entities, while PA counts the number of queried relations.
 The high weight (β) of the second sub-task for relations (or event arguments) is considered when calculating sentence uncertainty.
 The text suggests exploring better ways to enhance both sub-tasks, possibly with an adaptive combination scheme.
 Figure 10 shows the results of the extraction of entity mentions and relations for the relation extraction task on ACE05.
 Some mention extraction results show less obvious differences between the AL strategies over the random baseline, possibly due to a focus on the second sub-task for relations.

This document is about privacy and cookie policies.
The text mentions the Privacy Policy first.
According to the Cookie Policy, cookies are small data files that a website can store on your device.
The Privacy Policy protects user information by not sharing it with third parties and giving users control over their personal data.
The purpose of a cookie, according to the Cookie Policy, can be for authentication, tracking user behavior on websites, or storing preferences.
The Cookie Policy allows users to control their data by providing options such as accepting or rejecting cookies and deleting existing ones.
According to this document, the main difference between Privacy Policy and Cookie Policy is that Privacy Policy focuses on protecting user information while Cookie Policy deals with cookies.
In the context of the Privacy Policy, third parties refer to entities outside of the website or service that may receive user information.
Users can manage their cookie preferences by using options provided in the Cookie Policy, such as accepting or rejecting cookies and deleting existing ones.

 GILL is able to process complex text prompts more effectively than Stable Diffusion for many examples.

The tennis courts were renovated in 2005 and last resurfaced in 2020.
Carnegie Mellon faculty, staff, and students are allowed to use the tennis courts.
A valid CMU ID is needed to use the tennis courts.
Video cameras for live broadcasting were installed in the summer of 2016.
Everyone wishing to use the tennis courts must make their own reservation. Reservations are required and can be made up to 3 days in advance.
Each reservation is for one hour only.
The court will become available to any players waiting. Only the remaining portion of the court time can be used.
No, reserved time cannot extend into the next full reservation hour.
The tennis courts are only open to current CMU faculty, staff, and students. All users must have their CMU ID with them.

 ROUGE, named entity-based F1, and UniEval
 43.2 EM F1, 39.0 Prec. Rec.
 FLARE outperforms all baseline on all tasks/datasets
 The task has a clear definition and specific objective of producing the final answer through a 2-hop reasoning process
 Identifying ambiguous aspects is challenging even for humans, providing a generic hint helps LMs to stay on topic
 Question decomposition
 Manual exemplar annotation is not necessary for effective future-aware retrieval
 The improvement of retrieving using the previous sentence is relatively small
 They are more reliable than metrics computed over all tokens
 Using the next sentence for retrieval is clearly better than using the previous sentence
 A pre-trained BERT was used for the English side.
 The back translation strategy for Bribri–Spanish NMT transformers was explored.
 Spanish text or text extracted from PDFs and other sources can be used.
 Even though morphological segmentation has less perplexity at the language modeling time, it is still under-performing or equivalent against BPEs for MT.
 Supervised morphological segmentation under-perform unsupervised.
 A morphological segmentation, or a combination of BPEs and morphological segmentation, works better.
 Training word embeddings for Guarani–Spanish translation is highlighted.
 Transfer learning from multilingual systems has been tried with limited results.
 Fine-tuning a Spanish–English model together with ILA, along with a careful preprocessing and filtering step, has been the most successful strategy.
 They advocate for including community members as co-authors and considering data and technology sovereignty.
 The total token count is not immediately obvious to users except through a separate tokenizer interface.
 Most services limit daily token usage to a small number of tokens per use.
 Proposed approaches range from defining tokens as whitespace-delimited words to defining tokens as characters or bytes.
 BBPE is a byte-level base vocabulary with only 256 tokens used in modern language modeling efforts for its effectiveness.
 The main focus is on investigating the impact of tokenization strategy on LM API cost disparity and downstream task performance across different languages.
 Non-uniform tokenization rates can lead to significantly high usage costs for less represented languages.
 High fragmentation rates can negatively affect the in-context learning performance, resulting in reduced model utility.
 The implications revolve around certain languages being more expensive and less effective, hindering uniform accessibility of the technology.
 The two models are ChatGPT and BLOOMZ, with ChatGPT being closed and BLOOMZ being open-source trained on multiple languages.
 The Huggingface API has a context limit of 1000 tokens for BLOOMZ.
 The batch size used in the experiment is 128.
 The binary accuracy is used as both the local validation score and evaluation metric.
 All baselines are implemented in PyTorch 1.12.1.
 The reward-and-slash design is deployed in a private blockchain using Ethereum smart contracts.
 The value of ϵ is set to 0.05.
 The first baseline is the Oracle approach, a centralized baseline without malicious attacks, which provides the upper-bound performance of the experiment.
 Four baselines are considered in the study.
 In FedAVG w/ block, 90% of the clients are used as voters.
 A too small ϵ value can cause large oscillation, which slows the convergence.
 Malicious voters will be eliminated from the system shortly, with their average tokens declining to 0 within approximately 40 epochs.
 Frame synchronous beam search is an algorithm that performs pruning at every input frame during the search process.
 Frame synchronous beam search depends on explicit alignment, while label synchronous beam search does not.
 LM shallow fusion is a score combination method that linearly adds the language model score to the end-to-end ASR scores during beam search.
 Classical approaches to beam search for these variants are based on weighted finite state transducers and they are used for frame synchronous beam search.
 Asynchronous score fusion handles the mismatch by incorporating the language model score in the label transition state.
 Lexical constraint during score fusion is used to incorporate word-based lexical constraints for ASR, especially in end-to-end ASR using letter or token units.
 Vectorization enables the replacement of score accumulation steps with vector-matrix operations, leveraging parallel computing capabilities for significant speedups.
 The TLG transducer is composed of the token unit, word lexicon, and word-based language transducers, and it helps incorporate lexical constraints during beam search.
 Vectorization allows for parallel processing of multiple utterances, resulting in faster decoding and significant speedups.
 The frame synchronous algorithm can easily extend to online and streaming decoding by using explicit alignment information with input frame and output token.
 The fatigue crack propagation behaviour of Q550E high-performance steel
 By conducting static tensile testing and fatigue crack propagation testing
 The initial crack angle, crack depth ratio, stress ratio, thickness, and corrosion pitting
 It reduced the fatigue life by 18%
 Q235
 The initial crack angle of 52.5°
 The effective crack length
 It leads to a smaller stress intensity factor
 It affects the stress intensity factor
 The initial crack angle, crack depth ratio, stress ratio, thickness, and corrosion pitting
 AraBART: a pretrained Arabic sequence-to-sequence model for abstractive summarization
 Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates
 Jared Kaplan, Sam McCandlish, Tom Henighan, Tom B Brown, Benjamin Chess, Rewon Child, Scott Gray, Alec Radford, Jeffrey Wu, and Dario Amodei
 2005
 Natural Questions
 Email classification research
 Tomasz Limisiewicz, Jiˇr´ı Balhar, and David Mareˇcek
 Arabic information extraction
 TruthfulQA: Measuring how models mimic human falsehoods
 A multilingual replicable instruction-following model with low-rank adaptation
 Age, never smoker, hypertension, ALK rearrangement, EGFR mutation, histology, tumor stage, ECOG PS score, number of metastases, number of previous treatment lines, number of previous chemotherapy lines, previous targeted therapy, previous radiotherapy, previous immunotherapy, anlotinib monotherapy, leukocyte, neutrophil, lymphocyte, platelets, and globulin
 0.47
 Positively associated with OS
 1.24
 Lower risk of death
 12.26 months, 14.59 months, and 20.13 months respectively
 Less than 0.05
 Non-linear relationship
 High AGR associated with favorable prognosis
 Lower age, fewer males, fewer never smokers, lower leukocyte count, lower neutrophil count, lower lymphocyte count, lower platelet count, lower albumin level, and lower globulin level
 To transform inputs to be compatible with pretrained models
 FPT does not account for modality difference, while ORCA does
 A domain consists of a feature space X, a label space Y, and a joint probability distribution P(X, Y)
 To correctly map each input xt to its label yt
 Generating task-specific embedder and predictor, pretraining embedder, and fine-tuning to minimize target loss
 By decomposing a transformer-based learner m into three parts: an embedder f, a model body g, and a predictor h
 To transform input x into a sequence of features compatible with the pretrained model
 Both input and output feature spaces are RS×D
 It uses task-specific output modules and fine-tunes them for new problems
 To achieve better adaptation by aligning the target data with the pretrained model
 The paper focuses on the end-to-end (E2E) SLU model for minimization of computational cost towards on-device processing.
 SVD and Tucker decomposition are mentioned for model miniaturization.
 Tensor decomposition helps reduce the model size by applying singular value decomposition to linear layers and Tucker decomposition to convolution layers.
 The purpose of using tensor decompositions in the E2E model is to flexibly control the number of parameters without changing feature dimensions.
 Singular value decomposition (SVD) is stable and widely used for parameter reduction.
 In Tucker decomposition, the parameter size is controlled by decomposing the parameter tensor into a core tensor and factor matrices.
 The algorithm aims to halve the size for Tucker decomposition by adjusting the dimensions R, S, and T.
 CP decomposition is explored for applying high-order tensors in the context of model compression.
 Model compression is essential for on-device processing to reduce power consumption and enable faster computation on edge devices.
 Combining convolution and self-attention operations in these models makes them more efficiently compressed using tensor decomposition techniques.

 End-to-end question-answering experiments on NQ, OTT-QA, and HotpotQA.
 The Fusion-in-Encoder (FiE) model was used for NQ and OTT-QA experiments.
 Top-100 passages for NQ and top-50 evidence chains for OTT-QA.
 A separate reader model was trained to predict supporting sentences in addition to the answer span.
 COS learns five reusable skills for ODQA via multi-task learning.
 One limitation is that the reranking expert only learns to rerank single-step results. Another limitation is that the current pretraining setup only includes three bi-encoder tasks.
 The model, coupled with the FiE, outperforms previous baselines by large margins on OTT-QA.
 Separate models were trained independently for each dataset, NQ, OTT-QA, and HotpotQA.

The purpose of using CAPTCHAs, as per the text, is to prevent bots from accessing a website and to ensure that there's a human behind any other computer.
Visual-perception based CAPTCHAs, which rely solely on reading text or performing other visual tasks, prevent visually impaired users from accessing the protected resource and may make a site incompatible with Section 508.
The text suggests that accessibility, image security, and script security should be considered while implementing CAPTCHAs. Accessibility ensures that visually impaired users can also use the protected resource, image security involves distorting random images of text before presenting them to the user, and script security aims at making sure there are no easy ways around it at the script level.
Many CAPTCHA implementations use undistorted text or only minor distortions, making them vulnerable to simple automated attacks.
(1) Systems that pass the answer to the CAPTCHA in plain text as part of the web form, and (2) systems where a solution to the same CAPTCHA can be used multiple times are common insecurities.
Most CAPTCHA scripts found freely on the Web are vulnerable because they do not ensure that there are no easy ways around it at the script level.
The text suggests using a CAPTCHA to protect against abuse, and recommends considering accessibility, image security, and script security while implementing it.
Section 508 refers to a law in the United States that makes it illegal for any government agency (or any other entity that receives federal funds) to discriminate against people with disabilities. Visual-perception based CAPTCHAs may make a site incompatible with Section 508 if they prevent visually impaired users from accessing the protected resource.
An example of ensuring accessibility for blind users is by permitting them to opt for an audio or sound CAPTCHA instead of a visual one.
The text suggests that the advantage of using CAPTCHAs is that they prevent bots from accessing a website and ensure there's a human behind any other computer.
The main topic of the text is CAPTCHAs and their use in security measures.
Kumar Chellapilla and Patrice Y. Simard

 The conﬁnement effect of stirrups on concrete can effectively improve the ultimate compressive strength of concrete and delay the occurrence of splitting cracks.
 The initial effective pre-tension set for S1, S5, and S6 is 497 kN.
 The maximum stress value reached by S1 among the specimens is 77.6 MPa.
 Increasing the diameter of stirrups has no significant effect on the secondary transfer length before the splitting cracks appear in the concrete.
 The average error of the numerical simulation results in comparison to the test results is only 2.62%.
 The calculations suggest that the loss ratio of prestress is negatively related to concrete strength, with the lower concrete strength leading to a higher loss ratio of prestress.
 The secondary transfer length of residual prestress is significantly correlated with concrete tensile strength, with a higher concrete strength leading to a smaller secondary transfer length.
 The secondary transfer after the corrosion fracture of steel wire strands is determined by their bond performances.
 The calculation method focuses on the secondary transfer length based on the principle of equal actual stress and bond force of steel wire strands, which has high accuracy with small errors.
 When the thickness of the protective cover exceeds five times the diameter of prestressed tendons, the structure develops no splitting failure.

 Non-functional properties in mobile apps, such as runtime or memory use, are important because they affect user experience.
 The proposed tool is GIDroid.
 Genetic improvement is used as a search-based technique.
 GIDroid greatly improves the speed of search by using a simulation-based testing framework.
 GIDroid automatically rediscovered 64% of existing improvements when applied to versions of mobile apps.
 The maximum improvement in execution time achieved was up to 35%.
 The maximum improvement in memory use achieved was up to 33%.
 1/3 of instances of users abandoning applications and 59% of bad reviews were due to poor performance in Android apps.
 The main entry point for Android applications is its UI components.
 The text argues that an approach not requiring external resources and applicable to all applications would make developers more likely to adopt it.
 Impact explains the biased, prejudiced, or stereotypical meaning implied by a statement.
 Emotional and Cognitive Reactions capture the possible negative effects and harms that a statement and its implied meaning could have on the targeted group.
 There is an increasing push to develop content moderation from the perspective of the harms that content engenders.
 The consideration of perceived emotional and cognitive reactions is drawn from Nadal et al. (2014).
 Emotional reactions capture the short-term emotional effects or reactions to a statement.
 Cognitive reactions focus on the lessons someone could draw, the subsequent actions someone could take, or on the long-term harms that repeated exposure to such statements could have.
 Offensiveness captures, in 1-3 words, the type or degree of offensiveness of the statement.
 The text avoids imposing a categorization or cutoff between offensive and harmless statements.
 The main focus of creating COBRACORPUS is to study the contextual dynamics of the offensiveness of statements at scale.
 The statements are drawn from Toxigen, a dataset of GPT3-generated statements that are subtly or implicitly toxic, offensive, prejudiced, or biased against various demographic groups.

 interpolated loss
 The purpose is to lower the real-fake discriminability and make it harder for the discriminator to distinguish between real and fake samples.
 LAGG AGKD = |I(x) − Df (G(z))| + |I(G(z)) − Df (x)|
 The hyper-parameter p controls the designed aggregated loss LAGG AGKD, where the loss is applied with probability p or skipped with probability 1-p.
 LAGKD = LKD AGKD
 The goal is to improve the generation diversity by enforcing diverse correlations between generated images and texts in CLIP.
 The correlations are built by calculating the inner products between CLIP visual features of generated images and CLIP text features.
 LP D CGKD = ∑∑ Cos(CT[i, :], CT[j, :]), i=1,j=1,j ≠ i
 The correlation distillation is defined as L1 loss between CT and CS: LKD CGKD = |CT − CS|
 LCGKD = LP D CGKD + LKD CGKD
 The overall training objective is to minimize LG (generator loss) and maximize LD (discriminator loss), where LD includes Ld, LAGKD, and LCGKD.

82532
Scotty is a breed of dog that was kept as a pet by Andrew Carnegie, the founder of Carnegie Mellon University.
Carnegie Mellon formed a Mascot Identity Task Force in November 2006 to select an official mascot for the university. The task force consisted of students, faculty, staff, and alumni.
Nearly 78 percent of 2,370 students surveyed in February 2007 voted for the Scottish terrier as their preferred mascot.
The co-chairs of the Mascot Identity Task Force were Director of Athletics Susan Bassett and Dean of Student Affairs Jennifer Church.
Carnegie Mellon University adopted the Scottish terrier as its official mascot in 2006, after a series of surveys and a university Town Hall meeting.
The Scottish terrier has been associated with Carnegie Mellon for many years, as Andrew Carnegie, the founder of the university, kept a Scottish terrier as his pet.
Approximately 25 percent of 400 alumni surveyed thought about the selection process and gave their opinions on what they believed would be a good mascot for Carnegie Mellon University.
The university Town Hall meeting was held to discuss the selection process and gather feedback from students, faculty, staff, alumni, and other members of the Carnegie Mellon community.
The Scottish terrier costume has been a popular tradition among students at Carnegie Mellon University, where they dress up as Scottish terriers to excite fans during athletic events.
The Scottish terrier was already the mascot.
In the spring, the Task Force partnered with SME Branding — a firm with more than 17 years of experience creating mascots for professional sports teams and universities — to develop the graphics for the mascot.
Carnegie Mellon's official mascot debuted at the Nov. 10, 2007 home football game.
The graphic features a profile of a distinguished, bold Scottish terrier sporting a plaid scarf around his neck. The dog is contained in a shield, representing Carnegie Mellon's Scottish heritage.
The Task Force then partnered with a mascot costume company to design our Scottish terrier in the winter of 2007.
The official Scotty costume was unveiled at the 2008 Spring Carnival.
The Scottish terrier breed is known for its keen, alert and intelligent expression. Its temperament is described as determined and thoughtful while its physical aspects exemplify strength, power.
The Scottish terrier breed is known for its keen, alert and intelligent expression. Its temperament is described as determined and thoughtful while its physical aspects exemplify strength, power.
The shield in Carnegie Mellon's mascot graphic represents Carnegie Mellon's Scottish heritage.

The purpose of the Graduate Financial Aid Guide on the Carnegie Mellon University website is to provide information about funding options for graduate students.
A student in need of immediate funds due to an emergency situation should contact the Office of the Dean of Student Affairs at www.cmu.edu/student-affairs/index.html to inquire about an Emergency Student Loan.
U.S. citizens and permanent residents can complete the FAFSA online at https://fafsa.ed.gov.
The William D. Ford Direct Loan Program provides information about loans, including deferment forms and payment information for students.
Information about federal student aid programs may be found at www.studentaid.ed.gov.
Yes, the MCDS program accepts students with external fellowships.
Grade reports are typically mailed to individual students at the conclusion of each semester. See the official calendar for specific dates.
Late Graduation refers to a student who has not completed their degree requirements by the end of the semester and needs additional time to finish, resulting in an extra fee.
The purpose of external fellowships mentioned at 5.1.6 is not explicitly stated in this text, but they are likely used to provide additional funding opportunities for students.
Late graduation can be arranged for students who need an additional semester to complete a program that will benefit both them and their employer.
The student should discuss their situation with the Director of Carnegie Mellon University.
Students who are receiving a stipend, working as TAs, or plan on having a position with CMU must complete Form I-9 within 3 business days of beginning their work.
Employment Eligibility Verification, including completing Form I-9 and possibly submitting an E-Verify Processing Request Form, is required to comply with federal law.
If a student does not complete the Employment Eligibility Verification within 3 business days, they may be in violation of federal law and CMU's policy.
Form I-9 is a document that verifies the identity and eligibility to work in the United States of an individual receiving a stipend, working as a TA, or planning on having a position with CMU.
If students expect to work on a federally funded project, they are responsible for submitting an E-Verify Processing Request Form to the Office of Human Resources.
The Director at Carnegie Mellon University handles situations related to late graduation for students who require an additional semester to complete a program beneficial to both them and their employer.
Carnegie Mellon University maintains an Employment Eligibility Verification Policy covering I-9 and E-Verify requirements for students receiving a stipend, working as TAs, or planning on having a position with CMU.
Students funded by a research project may receive travel funding according to the policies set by the individual projects.
The Graduate Education Office manages the conference travel funding opportunity provided by GSA and the Provost’s Office for students.
An LTI form must be filled out in advance before a student can receive travel funding.
The Director of the MCDS program approves the expenses.
A student must apply for approval of expenses before they are incurred.
Verification of purchase and/or expenses along with receipts should be presented to the program administrator for reimbursement.
Students can find more information about the application process and deadlines at https://www.cmu.edu/graduate/professional-development/index.html
A larger amount of travel funding is available for students who have no project funding.
Within three months of the calendar date of the event’s last day.
No, the University does not reimburse for taxes.
Yes, it is mandatory for full-time degree-seeking students to carry adequate medical insurance.
Students must either purchase the plan offered by the University or apply for a waiver if they are enrolled as a dependent, partner/spouse, or principal in an employer or government-sponsored insurance plan.
Each student is responsible for making arrangements with Student Health Services to either pay for their insurance at the beginning of the semester or elect a payment plan over the course of the academic year.
More information is available at the Student Health Services Web site https://www.cmu.edu/health-services/student-insurance/plans.html.

The Carnegie Mellon University transcript will include information on such courses as follows: Carnegie Mellon courses and courses taken through the university's cross-registration program will have grades recorded on the transcript and be factored into the QPA. All other courses will be recorded on this transcript indicating where the course was taken, but without grades.

Under FERPA, students have the right to inspect and review their education records; request an amendment if they believe their record is inaccurate or misleading; consent to disclosure of personally identifiable information from their education records except where FERPA authorizes disclosure without consent; file a complaint with the U.S. Department of Education Family Policy Compliance Office if they believe their rights under FERPA have been violated.
Students can review the university’s policy on privacy rights here: https://www.cmu.edu/policies/student-and-student-life/privacy-rights-students.html

Carnegie Mellon offers shuttle and escort services operated by the University Police. The Shuttle Service operates within Oakland, Squirrel Hill, and Shadyside areas, as well as to university sites outside of the main campus.
The Escort Service offers vehicle routes within a radius of campus between 6:30 pm-6 am daily. Information regarding up-to-date shuttle and escort schedules, pick-up/drop-off locations, routes, and usage policies can be found at www.cmu.edu/police/shuttleandescort.
SafeWalk provides another option to campus community members walking across and around campus during late-night hours. It's a student volunteer organization that offers escorts for all members of the Carnegie Mellon community nightly from 10 pm until 2 am.
Students, faculty, and staff may request a SafeWalk escort by calling 412-268-SAFE (8-7233 from a campus phone), approaching an escort team, or stopping by the SafeWalk dispatch area.
SafeWalk is a student volunteer organization that provides campus escorts for all members of the Carnegie Mellon community.
SafeWalk operates nightly during the regular academic year (except certain holidays and break periods) from 10pm until 2am.

 They caution against the use of data filters, which can reduce model perplexity on underrepresented communities
 Improvements on bias benchmarks correlates with deteriorations in general language modeling abilities

 Proposed remedies include finetuning on more recent data, adaptive/continuous pretraining, data augmentation, and modeling text with its timestamps

 By the hybrid similarity between visual and semantic (CLIP) features.
 Significant performance improvements in accuracy gains of 3.0% and 4.6% on easy and hard distractors, respectively.
 Models that do not use their ToM listener in training.
 When training on both easy (15.6% relative increase) and hard (11.6%) distractors.
 Longer and more complex utterances were observed.
 It led to significant performance and fluency gains.
 RSA models.
 An important role, similarly to human language acquisition.
 Significant improvements, particularly in fluency score where gains ranged between 25% to 46%.
 Directly sparsifying the teacher vectors resulted in lower performance compared to learning a student LM.
 The teacher LM vectors are real valued, causing the TopK operation to ignore dimensions with high absolute value but negative weight.
 Latency depends on the posting list sizes of the added terms, and smaller vocabularies cause an increase in the average posting list size, making search slower.
 Adding larger vocabularies increased latency since queries were made longer, considering terms from both the English and KALE vocabularies.
 KALE was able to significantly outperform the BM25 baseline in efficiency and effectiveness.
 Experiments with larger vocabularies in the KALE only setting were more efficient than the original BM25 baseline.
 A significant improvement over BM25 was observed independently of the vocabulary size.
 A trade-off between efficiency and effectiveness is expected, where a higher number of terms should improve text representations but may hurt query latency.
 Increasing the vocabulary size consistently resulted in efficiency and effectiveness gains, although accuracy flattened.
 Forcing terms to exist across passages despite bearing no semantic similarity likely introduces noise in the passage representations.
 Outputting a non-blank symbol.
 In RNN-T, outputting a blank symbol advances the model to the next frame; in RNA, however, the model advances to the next frame after outputting a single blank or non-blank label.
 It limits the number of model expansions at each frame.
 PRNA(C|X) = (∑ P (A|H(X))) where A∈ARNA (X,C)
 Assuming that the model can only output a single label at each frame; and utilizing a straight-through estimator for the alignment.
 They result in ASR models that are easily amenable to frame-synchronous decoding.
 AED models use an attention mechanism to learn a correspondence between the entire acoustic sequence and the individual labels, while explicit alignment models directly align output symbols with input frames.
 An end-of-sentence symbol, ⟨eos⟩, is added to the output vocabulary.
 It allows the model to learn which portions of the input acoustics are relevant to each output unit.
 The output distribution is conditioned on the decoder state (summarizes the previously decoded symbols) and the context vector (summarizes the encoder output based on the decoder state).
