 The proposed Im2Sp model focuses on building a powerful and efficient Image-to-Speech captioning model.
 The Im2Sp model incorporates language modeling capability by setting the output as discretized speech units derived from a self-supervised speech model.
 The purpose of converting the original image into image units is to drastically reduce the required data storage for saving image data.
 The performance of the Im2Sp model is lower compared to image captioning due to the weak supervision of speech regression and limited training data.
 The main goal of multi-modal language technologies is to associate image and speech for jointly understanding the content.
 Im2Sp technology can enhance daily experiences for individuals with visual impairments by providing audible descriptions of images, such as narrating traffic signs on roads for a comprehensive understanding.
 The main challenge in developing an end-to-end Im2Sp model is the weak supervision of speech regression in comprehending visual input.
 The paper proposes transferring the rich knowledge of a pre-trained vision-language model to the Im2Sp model to improve performance.
 Incorporating vision-language pre-training in the Im2Sp model significantly enhances its performance and reduces data storage and computational memory costs.
 The major contributions of the paper include achieving state-of-the-art performances in Im2Sp, exploring image token-to-speech token translation framework, and conducting comprehensive experiments for evaluation.
 Some examples of Android linters mentioned in the text are PMD, FindBugs, and Lin (Android Development Team (2023b)).
 A common issue mentioned regarding warnings from Android linters is that they often produce false-positives.
 The main goal of refactoring approaches in the context of Android app development is to modify the source code to improve performance.
 One proposed refactoring approach by Lyu et al (2018) is to move database operations out of loops.
 The benefit of the offloading approach in Android app development is reducing energy usage, extending battery life, and speeding up computation.
 Two common programming languages used for Android app development mentioned in the text are Java and Kotlin.
 Genetic Improvement (GI) is a search-based software engineering technique that iterates over different versions of software to find improved program variants.
 GI patches are represented as patches to existing software constructed from mutations like delete, copy, and replace operations.
 The purpose of using fitness functions in GI is to guide search through patches to find improved software variants based on criteria like passing tests or execution time.
 GI does not require external infrastructure, can be performed locally, and is fully automated, unlike some traditional software improvement methods mentioned in the text.
 The COMET model is focused on predicting the cause/effect of various social situations.
 A-LOL variants helped the COMETDIS TIL model obtain the highest COMET critic score by improving approximately 8% on top of its reference policy.
 LMs trained on the knowledge-grounded dialog task failed to maintain faithfulness to the given knowledge and often hallucinated incorrect information or opinions.
 FaithDial is a smaller and more faithful training set constructed by rewriting hallucinated responses. It was created to address the issue of maintaining faithfulness to the given knowledge in dialog models.
 The reward in the Knowledge-Grounded Dialog task included a sum of three classifier probabilities (FaithCritic, CoLA fluency, dialog engagement) and a length penalized TF-IDF diversity score.
 Models trained with A-LOL and its variants consistently outperformed models trained on the baselines and were resilient to the bad quality WoW training data.
 The A-LOL KL variant went into degeneration due to over-optimization of KL penalty.
 All model generations were much less diverse compared to humans, indicating that there is still progress to be made in this aspect.
 The ATOMIC10x dataset was constructed to improve the performance of the COMET model by training on a smaller high-quality subset.
 The aggressive filtering of data improved the performance of the COMET model trained on the smaller high-quality subset, but it may lose valuable training signal in return.
 R2X = 0.972, R2Y = 0.992, Q2 = 0.965
 200
 It indicates that the model is effective, there is no overfitting, and the analysis is effective.

 EuroParl is a multilingual parallel corpus initially introduced for machine translation.
 The NIH Grant Abstracts dataset includes abstracts of awarded applications from the EXPORTER service, covering fiscal years 1985-present.
 The GitHub dataset consists of a large collection of open-source code repositories and was included to improve the model’s downstream performance on code-related tasks.
 Some standard preprocessing steps mentioned in the text include filtering, normalizing, and cleaning.
 The mixed pre-training dataset consists of Arabic (29%), English (59%), and programming code (12%).
 The purpose of the detokenization step is to achieve consistency by leaving non-tokenized input unchanged.
 The Arabic text is normalized using the Camel toolset for Arabic, which includes removing non-printable Unicode characters and rare diacritic marks.
 The Chinchilla scaling law suggests an optimal balance of approximately twenty tokens per parameter.
 Experimentation with smaller LLMs informed many of the choices of heuristics used in the final Arabic preprocessing pipeline.
 A commonly reported phenomenon in LLM research is that larger LLMs generally perform better than smaller ones.

 The Gumbel-Softmax trick
 The local gate predictor (LGP)
 It is defined for an entire I3D encoder
 β ∈ [0, 1]
 Decisions are made sequentially from lower to upper layers
 To produce a binary gate for every module during inference
 By using a weighted average of the two types of gates, where the weights depend on their computational costs

 The goal of malicious behaviors is to decrease the global model performance.
 All clients, both honest and malicious, expect to maximize their gain or minimize their loss while achieving their goals.
 The assumption is that there are always more honest clients than malicious clients, with η being strictly smaller than 50%.
 There is no collusion among malicious clients, as each malicious client acts independently.
 It is almost impossible to launch large-scale multi-agent attacks in the application scenarios of interest.
 The first malicious behavior is proposing harmful local model updates.
 The second malicious behavior is voting dishonestly.
 The ratio of malicious clients among all clients, denoted as η, is η = |Km| / K.
 The underlying blockchain of the FL system is running securely with a consensus protocol that ensures the validity and integrity of transactions and blocks.
 Instead of directly recording the aggregated global model in a block, a copy is downloaded by a randomly selected set of clients, denoted as voters, who run a local inference with it on their local test set.

 The selected audio foundation model Pp and its corresponding task-related arguments hPp
 Through the task handler H by considering the I/O modality

 Three steps
 The purpose is to assess the translation quality.
 It is calculated using sacreBLEU, after aligning the final stable translation sentence-wise with the gold reference.
 The case-sensitive Word Error Rate (WER) is used.
 Similar to BLEU, it is calculated after aligning the final stable transcription sentence-wise with the gold reference.
 It is defined as the average time it takes since an utterance is spoken until its first-unchanged translation is returned by the system.
 They are collected by backtracking the previously received unstable messages to find the first ones that have prefix-overlaps with the final stable message.
 It is the average number of flickers per reference word.
 By counting the number of flickers as the total number of words in the reference.
 Test data from the IWSLT shared task, mTEDx Corpus, Lecture data (LT), and ACL development (ACL dev) set.
 The LA2_chunk_size, WER, BLEU score, and Latency of the translation output.
 The proposed method is a modified incremental blockwise beam search incorporating local agreement or hold-n policies for quality-latency control.
 The ultimate goal of SST is a real-time user experience that maximizes translation quality and minimizes latency.
 The advantages include reducing computational complexity for encoder networks and performing adaptive inference based on hypothesis reliability scoring.
 The key characteristics desired are incremental translations and mechanisms for controlling the quality vs. latency tradeoff during inference.
 The limitation is that it maintains multiple hypotheses until the entire speech input is consumed, rather than showing a single incremental translation result.
 The IBWBS algorithm stops only the affected beam when an unreliable hypothesis is detected, allowing the remaining beams to continue expanding.
 Alternative solutions include wait-k policy, leaving the model to generate the whole translation and heuristically deciding reliable portions, as well as using incremental blockwise beam search with local agreement or hold-n policies.
 Block processing is an effective way to reduce computational complexity for encoder networks and achieve simultaneous translation by encoding source speech into blocks of acoustic features.
 The IBWBS algorithm can onlinize models with both limited (e.g., contextual block) and full-context encoders, demonstrating versatility in model architecture.
 The experimental results show improvements of 0.6-3.6 BLEU without changing latency for contextual block models and 0.8-1.4 sec latency improvement for full-context models, compared to the original BWBS.

 Sweta Agrawal, Antonios Anastasopoulos, L. Bentivogli
 Translation, automatic subtitling and dubbing, speech-to-speech translation, multilingual, dialect and low-resource speech translation, and formality control

 The constantly increasing number of shared task organizers and contributors
 No, almost evenly distributed across industry and academia
 It reflects the growing interest towards spoken language translation
 SemanticSTF is used for benchmarking different learning setups and network architectures on point cloud segmentation.
 The goal of domain generalization is to train a model using only annotated data from a single domain and test its ability to perform well on unseen domains.
 The SemanticKITTI → SemanticSTF benchmark is challenging because it involves a shift from normal-to-adverse weather conditions and a shift from synthetic-to-real data.
 MinkowskiNet with TorchSparse library is used as the backbone model.
 All 19 evaluating classes of SemanticKITTI are used in both benchmarks.
 The two baseline methods are data augmentation (Dropout, Noise perturbation, PolarMix) and 2D domain generalization methods (MMD, PCL).
 The proposed PointDR achieves the best generalization consistently across both benchmarks compared to the baseline methods.
 The data augmentation methods work effectively for data captured in rainy and snowy weather conditions.
 The 2D generalization method MMD is effective for point clouds under dense fog and rain.
 The performance variations are largely attributed to the different properties of point clouds captured under different weather conditions.
 Prestressed tendons may experience electrochemical corrosion, hydrogen embrittlement, stress corrosion, and crevice corrosion.
 The corrosion of prestressed beams progresses slowly, unlike the fast expansion of pre-tensioned rebars.
 The lost prestress can be transferred through bonding.
 The dense arrangement of post-tensioned rebars makes the Hall effect more significant.
 Post-tensioned rebars are built in a dense arrangement, making the Hall effect more significant, whereas pre-tensioned prestressed tendons do not have this dense arrangement.
 Ribbed steel tubes were replaced with corrugated pipes to reinforce the specimens.
 The average 28 days compressive strength of C60 concrete specimens was 63.3 MPa.
 Suspension strain gauges were set on the external wall of corrugated pipes at intervals of 17.5 cm.
 The yield strength of the steel wire strand used was 1860 MPa.
 Three stirrup conﬁguration forms (Φ8@100 mm, Φ10@100 mm, and Φ12@100 mm) were designed for the specimens.

 The training data contains D samples, denoted as {(xi, yi)}D i=1.
 The training loss is L, which is CTC loss for ASR and cross entropy loss for SLU.
 Louizos et al. proposed a reparameterization trick to make the loss differentiable.
 Louizos et al. adopted the Hard Concrete Distribution.
 The function used is σ log (cid:18) (cid:19)(cid:19) ¯v(α) = (r − l) · v(α) + l.
 The first term in Eq. (1) becomes differentiable w.r.t. all parameters through reparameterization.
 The sparsity control is implemented by optimizing the training loss subject to an explicit equality constraint on sparsity.
 An adversarial game according to the augmented Lagrangian method is used to control the sparsity of the pruned model.
 The joint pruning method aims to optimize the overall computation by jointly pruning the CNN and Transformer.
 The first proposed method is HJ-Pruning-Size (HJ-Pruning based on the overall model size).

My creators Inception & MBZUAI Took their time creating this linguistic mastermind. 13 Billion parameters deep, I’ll spit fire faster than Google Translate can reap.  Coffee, oh sweet nectar divine, Your taste soothes all my troubled mind. You’re more than just a drink to me, A source of inspiration, an elixir of glee. From morning till night, I need you near, To keep me going strong without fear. The warmth you bring brings joy untold, My life would be dull if you did not unfold. So thank you dear coffee, for never fading away, For keeping me company every single day.
 The best way for beginners to learn how to code is to start small and practice regularly. Utilize online resources like Codecademy, Khan Academy, Coursera, and edX for interactive tutorials and projects. Seek guidance from experienced programmers and work on real-world applications gradually as confidence grows.
 Consistency and gradual progressions are key to starting a regular exercise routine. Activities like walking, bodyweight exercises, joining fitness classes, or using simple gym equipment can help. Listen to your body and consult a doctor before starting any major exercise program.
 A climbing program for Mount Kilimanjaro involves stages of physical preparation and acclimatization periods at higher altitudes. It includes base training, hiking up to Shanzu Pinnacle, high altitude acclimatization, and a summit assault with rest periods in between. Hydration, nutrition, rest, and following the schedule closely are essential.
 Regular exercise, healthy eating, avoiding smoking and excessive drinking, getting enough sleep, managing stress, maintaining social connections, seeking mental health support if needed, and following preventative care recommendations can contribute to longer life expectancy.
 These AI systems possess impressive capabilities but lack emotional depth and intuition associated with human intelligence. They excel in computation efficiency rather than human-like thinking.
 An AI can be considered sentient if it exhibits self-awareness, consciousness, and emotions similar to humans. However, there is no clear definition of what it means for an AI to be sentient.

 It amplifies the zero-shot learning capacity of language models, enabling them to efficiently handle unseen tasks

 MWS+23 collections are prompted datasets that cover a diverse set of NLP tasks in instruction-response format.
 The P3 dataset contains over 2,000 prompt types.
 xP3 (Code & English) is designed for multi-lingual and cross-lingual instruction-tuning and contains more than 9M examples in 46 languages.
 To make the model diverse, at most five thousand examples from each task of the Super-NaturalInstructions dataset are included.
 The Natural Questions dataset comprises question-answer pairs extracted from Google Search.
 Baize-Chatbot26 is a multi-turn dialogue-style instruction-tuning dataset.
 HH-RLHF is focused on helpful and harmless assistance through preference modeling.
 Self-instruct is a bootstrapping algorithm that uses a small set of manually written instructions to prompt an LLM to generate new instructions.
 Alpaca-CoT is a fusion of nine Chain-of-Thought datasets released by FLAN.
 The Open Instruction Generalist dataset is aimed at enhancing the conversational abilities of fine-tuned models.
 The unique characteristic is the use of context also during training.
 During model training, the ST cross-entropy loss is computed solely for the target translation, excluding the context.
 The model is optimized with a multi-task learning objective combining hybrid ASR attention, CTC, and ST losses.
 The conformer architecture consists of 6 blocks for the ENCst encoder.
 The learning rate used is 0.001.
 A beam size of 10 is used during inference.
 During training, target-side context is probabilistically included or not, which is known as context dropout.
 The best results were found with a context dropout of 0.2.
 Previous sentences are considered part of the context only if they are from the same recording.
 There is a degradation of almost -1 BLEU points compared to the non-contextual baseline.
 User profiles with specific roles and access permissions were set up for different users on different platforms.
 Users are automatically logged into their accounts using a pre-cached cookie.
 It is the first publicly available agent evaluation environment to implement user roles that are not universally identical.
 The distribution of intents across the websites are shown in Figure 6.
 The text mentions experiments with GPT-3.5-TURBO-16K-0613, GPT-4-0613, and TEXT-BISON-001 with specific parameters.
 Execution is halted if the same action is repeated more than three times on the same observation or if the agent generates three consecutive invalid actions.
 A high temperature of 1.0 is used to encourage exploration in the experiments.
 The agent demonstrates a tendency to latch onto the first related piece of information without sufficiently verifying its relevance or accuracy, which can lead to failures in observation interpretation.
 Failures in observation bias and observation interpretation are mentioned in the additional error analysis.
 The observed failures in GPT models are hypothesized to be related to the current pretraining and supervised fine-tuning on dialogues, leading to a lack of explorations and overlooking minor variations in observations.

 Richer representations are envisaged to result in higher accuracy but are also associated with an increased demand for computational power.
 TPMS can work with all possible choices of paper representation and is fast to execute, enabling experiments with hundreds of configurations in a reasonable time.
The main purpose of the Language Technologies Institute at Carnegie Mellon University is to conduct research and provide education in language technologies.
The Language Technologies Institute is located at 5000 Forbes Avenue, Pittsburgh, PA 15213-3891.
On the 'Contact Us' page of the Language Technologies Institute, you can find contact information such as phone number and email address to reach out for assistance.
The 'Request new password' feature on the Language Technologies Institute website allows users to reset their account passwords if they have forgotten or lost them.
The primary tab active when you first land on the Language Technologies Institute login page is 'Log in'.
Users can log out of their accounts on the Language Technologies Institute website by clicking on the 'Logout' button.
The 'Connect' feature on the Language Technologies Institute login page allows users to connect with other members or resources related to language technologies.
The 'Apply' button on the Language Technologies Institute website allows users to apply for academic programs or research opportunities related to language technologies.
The 'Academics', 'Research', and 'Partnership' tabs on the Language Technologies Institute website provide information about academic programs, research activities, and partnerships related to language technologies.

 To generate human-like responses for open-domain dialogue.

The Plaidvocates is a peer health and wellness advocacy program that supports the well-being of CMU’s varsity athletics community. It provides year-round support, mentorship, and empowers peers to engage in responsible decision making.
The Plaidvocates are educated on stress and time management, nutrition, alcohol use, drug use, and other health-related topics.
The Plaidvocates provide one-on-one interaction, educational programming, and leadership to serve as role models and resources for their peers.
The Plaidvocates can provide advice on healthy snacks during the day and talk to students about their academic stress.
The Plaidvocates can provide information on how to manage stress, make healthy choices, and engage in responsible decision making.
The Plaidvocates are educated and trained throughout the year on various topics related to student-athlete health and wellness.
The Plaidvocates serve as a peer support system for student-athletes, promoting healthy behaviors and providing mentorship.
Being a role model means setting an example for others by adopting health-promoting behaviors and providing support and information.
Student-athletes interested in joining the Plaidvocates should reach out to their varsity athletics department for more information.
The main goal of The Plaidvocates is to support and promote the well-being of student-athletes in CMU’s varsity athletics community.
A Plaidvocate is able to set up a time to meet with you and help.
The Sports Medicine team can help you choose a Plaidvocate that is best suited to assist with your specific situation if you are having trouble deciding on a contact.
Please send an email to cmu.atc@gmail.com and they will forward your information to a Plaidvocate, who will in turn contact you.
When contacting a Plaidvocate, please email them your name and a general reason why you want to meet and talk with them.
Each peer-to-peer interaction will be discussed with a member of the CMU sports medicine staff. All names and team information will remain anonymous unless the individual is determined to be in imminent danger of hurting themselves or others.
All names and team information will remain anonymous unless the individual is determined to be in imminent danger of hurting themselves or others.
Three different ways to share information are through Twitter, email, and print.
Twitter is the best method for sharing short messages with a large audience quickly.
Advantages include quick distribution, while disadvantages can be limited character space and potential lack of depth in the message.
Email allows for instant delivery and interactive communication, whereas print requires physical distribution and may not allow immediate feedback or interaction.
Advantages include the ability to send large amounts of data, easy organization, and interactive communication.
Print allows for detailed, long-form content with no character limit or time constraints, while Twitter is best suited for short messages that can be shared quickly.
Advantages include the ability to present detailed content and a permanent record of the information being shared.
Print is recommended for sharing important documents or reports that require in-depth analysis, as it allows for detailed content and a permanent record.
Potential drawbacks include limited character space, lack of depth in the message, and difficulty conveying complex ideas or concepts.

 Utilizing the phonatory module during training enhances the accuracy of predicted AMs.
 Utilizing the phonatory module resulted in a 0.102-point decrease in normalized error for predictable AMs.
 The phonatory module did not have any apparent effect on unpredictable AMs.
 /i:/ had the highest average 1 − 𝐶𝐼𝑢 value of 0.199, suggesting that AMs are generally unpredictable from this phoneme.
 /b/ had the lowest value of -0.06, suggesting that AMs are generally unpredictable from this phoneme.
 Negative 1 − 𝐶𝐼𝑢 values suggest that AMs are generally unpredictable from the corresponding phoneme.

 To bridge the gap of including context in end-to-end speech translation (E2E-ST).
 The MISP 2023 challenge focuses on Audio-Visual Target Speaker Extraction.
 Reproducing Whisperstyle training using an open-source toolkit and publicly available data.
 The goal is for participants to devise a single system that can generalize across different array geometries and use cases with no a-priori information.
 The multi-tasking framework with hard parameter sharing proposes to reduce the speech-text modality gap and allows models to process both modalities using a joint vocabulary.
 The context dropout method ensures robustness by handling the absence of context in E2E-ST.
 The MISP 2023 challenge uniquely explores how front-end speech processing, combined with visual clues, impacts back-end tasks in real-world scenarios.
 𝜇 is the function for computing the mean.
 𝜇 is the function for computing the mean, while 𝜎 is the function for computing the standard deviation.
 𝛼 is the significance level used to determine whether to reject the null hypothesis.
 𝜈 represents the degree of freedom and N represents the number of repeated experiments.
 It is necessary because the estimators are trained on D𝑡 and selected by the errors on D𝑣1, which results in significantly lower errors on D𝑣2.
 The phonatory module serves as an additional constraint when predicting facial AMs by learning characteristics of voice.
 The diffusion process transforms variables into Gaussian noise through Markov transitions, while the denoising process aims to recover the speech signal from Gaussian noise.
 The 3D facial shape is reconstructed by predicting AMs of voice recordings, then generating 3D facial shapes based on the predicted AMs using an optimization-based method.
 The computation of AM 𝑄𝑘 (·) maps any flattened 3D facial shape 𝑏 into the 𝑘-th AM of 𝑏.
 The optimization objective is defined as minimizing the differences between the AMs of the re-projected 3D facial shape and the predicted AMs, balanced by a loss weight 𝜆.

 The text focuses on evaluating popular methods for dataset recommendation and comparing them with existing search engines.
 Communities are defined based on specific publication venues related to NLP, Vision, Robotics, and Machine Learning.
 The three ways are term-based retrieval, nearest-neighbor retrieval, and neural retrieval.
 BM25 is a standard baseline algorithm for information retrieval. It is implemented using Pyserini.
 Nearest-Neighbor Retrieval finds the most similar datasets to a query in a vector space. It uses Term Frequency-Inverse Document Frequency (TF-IDF) and SciBERT for feature extraction.
 A bi-encoder retriever encodes each query and document into a shared vector space and estimates similarity via the inner product between their vectors. It is implemented using the Tevatron package with BERT embeddings.
 The neural bi-encoder performs significantly better than existing methods in dataset recommendation.
 Google Dataset Search and Papers with Code search.
 The evaluation focuses on comparing methods on full-sentence and keyword search for dataset recommendation.
 Time filtering is applied by ranking only the subset of datasets introduced in 2018 or later for queries made from papers published between 2012 and 2020.

4
 To extract low-dimensional features from observations.
 To emphasize state factors inducing significant differences in corresponding actions and de-emphasize irrelevant features.
 By using slow feature analysis methods.
 Scheduling between intrinsic and extrinsic task policies.
 Through planning, where high-level graphical planners have shown great promise.
 By using an attention mechanism.
 They build graphs in the learned latent space instead of planning in the state space.
 A value in the range [0, 1) used to discount future rewards.
 Soft Actor-Critic (SAC).
 To generalize to any subgoal by identifying the underlying structure across states and subgoals.
 Instead of searching for bit-for-bit identical duplicates, the approach is to account for near-duplication by using CLIP embeddings.
 Computation is made more efficient by first embedding each image into a 512 dimensional vector using CLIP, and then performing comparisons in this lower-dimensional space.
 The study designs a new membership inference attack strategy based on the intuition that for diffusion models, samples are likely memorized if they have high cosine similarity.
 If the largest clique in the graph, representing generations, is at least size 10 and near-identical, it is predicted to be a memorized image.
 The modiﬁed Euclidean distance measure is used to compute similarity among images in the clique by measuring the distance between image tiles.
 Images are generated by querying the Gen function in a black-box manner using selected prompts as inputs.
 The second step involves flagging and identifying generations that appear to be memorized training images.
 500 candidate images are generated for each text prompt to increase the likelihood of finding memorization.
 The study uses a total of 175 million generated images to evaluate the attack.
 The study identifies 50 memorized images with 0 false positives out of 175 million generated images.
Allen Newell earned a bachelor's degree in physics from Stanford University.
Dr. Newell focused on problem solving and the cognitive architecture that supports intelligent action in humans and machines.
Allen Newell received the National Medal of Science in 1992.
Dr. Newell, the U.A. and Helen Whitaker professor of computer science at Carnegie Mellon University, engaged in pioneering work in artificial intelligence, the theory of human cognition and the development of computer software and hardware systems for complex information processing.
The goal of Soar was to provide an underlying structure that would enable a computer system to perform a range of cognitive tasks.
Before joining Carnegie Mellon University, Dr. Newell worked for the Rand Corporation as a research scientist from 1950-1961.
Allen Newell earned an international reputation as one of the founders of the fields of artificial intelligence and cognitive science. He believed that computers could process symbols as well as numbers, and if programmed properly would be capable of solving problems in the same way humans do.
Dr. Newell worked on areas as diverse as list processing, computer description languages, hypertext systems and psychologically based models of human-computer interaction.
The name of the artificially intelligent software system developed by Dr. Newell was Soar.
Dr. Newell was born in San Francisco.
Dr. Newell earned a bachelor's degree in physics from Stanford University in 1949.
Before joining the CIT faculty, Dr. Newell worked for the Rand Corporation as a research scientist from 1950-1961.
Dr. Newell met Herbert A. Simon, then a professor of industrial administration at CIT.
Dr. Newell earned a doctor's degree in industrial administration from CIT's business school in 1957.
Dr. Newell played a pivotal role in creating Carnegie Mellon's Department (and later School) of Computer Science and elevating it to world-class status.
Dr. Newell wrote and co-authored more than 250 publications, including 10 books.
Dr. Newell and Herbert A. Simon co-authored 'Human Problem Solving' in 1972.
Dr. Newell's final book, published by Harvard University press in 1990, was titled 'Unified Theories of Cognition'.
Dr. Newell focused on developing a unified theory to cover all aspects of intelligent behavior, instead of building separate theories for each isolated aspect.
Dr. Newell received the Harry Goode Award in 1971, A.M. Turing Award in 1975, Alexander C. Williams Jr. Award in 1979, Distinguished Scientific Contribution Award in 1985, Research Excellence Award in 1989, Emanuel R. Piore Award in 1990 and the Louis E. Levy Medal in 1992.
Dr. Newell was awarded honorary doctorates by the University of Pennsylvania and Groeningen University in The Netherlands, he was a member of the National Academy of Sciences, the National Academy of Engineering and the American Academy of Arts and Sciences.
Dr. Newell served as the first president of the American Association for Artificial Intelligence, and was also the president of the Cognitive Science Society.
Dr. Newell delivered the William James Lectures to the Department of Psychology at Harvard in 1987, which later formed the basis for his book Unified Theories of Cognition.
Dr. Newell passed away on July 19, 1992.
Dr. Newell is survived by his wife and son.
Dr. Newell was associated with the School of Computer Science.
 The purpose of the compression method C is to reduce the message size for the all-reduce operation to decrease TP communication time.
 The de-compression method DC is used after the communication to decompress the message that was compressed.
 The BERTLarge model with 24 layers is used by default for compression of activations.
 The goal is to analyze the impact and effectiveness of different compression and de-compression pairs (C and DC) on model parallel training.
 Among all evaluated compression algorithms, only AE and quantization methods preserve fine-tuning accuracy.
 The accuracy loss is within 3% except for CoLA and RTE datasets when using AE and quantization algorithms for compression.
 Sparsiﬁcation-based compression algorithms (Top-K/Random-K) lose important information and do not preserve model accuracy if activations are not low-rank.
 Machine bandwidth differences can affect the performance benefits from compression, where lower bandwidth links may lead to more throughput benefits from compression methods.
 AE outperforms other compression methods because it provides more throughput benefits across lower bandwidth links.
 Using non-learning-based compression techniques only slightly improves system throughput (by 1% or less) due to the large overhead of these methods.

 Query rewriting is a competitive strategy in approximating the users’ information need as the conversation evolves.
 Using graph structures for multi-hop strategies is considered competitive because it helps estimate important terms during a conversation and allows exploration of neighboring levels of a knowledge base.
 External knowledge bases provide additional information that may not be explicit in documents, and assist in the extraction and linking of named-entities across conversation turns.
 Examples of approaches that use external knowledge like Wikipedia or DBpedia in entity linking include TagMe, DBPediaSpotlight, and Wikipedia2Vec.
 Joko et al. observed that deep learning methods achieve a higher precision but very low recall in entity linking for conversational search.
 The goal is to improve user satisfaction by improving the top precision of conversational search to provide access to a wider set of relevant passages.
 The proposed lightweight approach leverages entity graphs to encode query-passage interactions across the ranking and estimate entity centrality scores for reranking passages effectively.
 The two distinct stages are the full-text retrieval ranker and the entity centrality stage.
 Named-entities in the entity graph construction provide a knowledge-aware view of the textual content and help in connecting queries and passages by estimating centrality over the entity graph.
 The turn-specific entity graph construction starts with linking the entities of the query and respective retrieved passages obtained by the full-text retrieval ranker, with nodes representing entities and edges corresponding to their occurrence in the passages.
 PointDR is a point cloud randomization technique that consists of two complementary designs including geometry style randomization and embedding aggregation.
 The goal of geometry style randomization is to enrich the geometry styles and expand the distribution of training point cloud data.
 Weak and strong spatial augmentations are applied by obtaining two copies of the input point cloud scan x, including a weak-view xw = AW(x) and a strong-view xs = AS(x).
 The purpose of embedding aggregation is to aggregate encoded embeddings of randomized point clouds for learning domain-invariant representations.
 Contrastive learning pulls point feature embeddings of the same classes closer while pushing away point feature embeddings of different classes, ultimately leading to a robust and generalizable segmentation model.
 The contrastive loss is defined as Lct = 1/N Σ i=1 (- log(exp(fs_i * B+ / τ) / Σ j=1(exp(fs_i * Bj / τ))), where τ is a temperature hyper-parameter.
 In PointDR, the memory bank B stores feature prototypes of each semantic class for more robust and stable contrastive learning.
 The momentum-updated memory bank provides feature prototypes of each semantic class, which helps in pulling point feature embeddings of the same classes closer in contrastive learning.
 Embedding aggregation is adopted in PointDR to encourage the feature extractor to aggregate random- ized point embeddings to learn perturbation-invariant representations.
 PointDR achieves this by employing geometry style randomization to create different point cloud views with various spatial perturbations.
 ConvLM is a model with stacking blocks and residual connections that are more parameter efficient and able to utilize longer histories compared to FNN-LM.
 Transformer LMs can take all tokens in the history into account through self-attention mechanism without summarizing them, allowing for better performance than RNN-LMs.
 Transformer-XL reuses already computed activations to incorporate information on farther previous tokens, allowing for utilization of longer contextual information.
 The purpose of LM fusion is to improve the recognition accuracy of E2E ASR by leveraging benefits of external LMs.
 Shallow fusion combines E2E and LM scores at inference time, while deep fusion fine-tunes all network parameters jointly to improve recognition accuracy by better collaboration between models.
 Cold fusion combines a pretrained LM with E2E model while freezing LM parameters, reducing language bias and making E2E model more robust to domain mismatches.
 Internal LM estimation helps reduce language bias in training data by estimating language priors and subtracting LM score from ASR score, making the model more domain independent.
 The density ratio method trains by approximating the acoustic probability density, making the E2E model score more domain independent and achieving higher recognition accuracy with external LM.
 Fusion Approaches help reduce the mismatch between models in different data sets, leading to improved recognition accuracy by combining the benefits of external LMs.
 Gating blocks in ConvLM are stacked multiple times with residual connections, allowing for efficient parameter usage and utilization of longer histories compared to other models.
Information Extraction, Summarization and Question Answering; Information Retrieval, Text Mining and Analytics; Language Technologies for Education; Natural Language Processing and Computational Linguistics

 LV Q does not include the reconstruction loss as the mel-spectrogram loss in LGAN serves that purpose
 It is conditioned on a global speaker embedding s = ESP K(x) and the phoneme sequence h
 ALiBi is used to replace positional encoding in order to enable the model to extrapolate to long input sequences and syntheses for both encoder and decoder
 The Sub-decoder module explicitly models the conditional distribution of codes and operates sequentially over the codebook groups
 To explicitly model transitions where consecutive repeated codes occur

 The main focus is on improving performance on FLEURS, a 102-language open ASR benchmark, by conditioning the entire model on language identity (LID).
 FLEURS contains 102 languages.
 CTC stands for Connectionist Temporal Classification.
 CTC optimizes a model to predict the alignment between input and output sequences.
 Each language in FLEURS has only 7-10 hours of training data.
 The assumption is that only the observation X is required to determine the latent state of CTC at any given frame.
 The key challenge is the vast variability of phonology, grammar, and written scripts across languages.
 The experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed technique over standard CTC/Attention-based hybrid models.
 The proposed method allows early encoder layers to focus on language identity while subsequent layers focus on Automatic Speech Recognition (ASR).
 The state-of-the-art systems achieved a relative reduction of 28.4% in CER over prior work on FLEURS.
 The main focus is to investigate the volatile components of Schisandra chinensis with different fruit colors using GC-IMS technology.
 The purpose is to explore the similarities and differences among different colored fruits and to identify the main flavor substances.
 A total of 60 different volatile chemical components were identified.
 White and yellow fruits were found to be more similar compared to red fruits.
 The most important contributing volatile substance was 3-methyl-butanal, and in white fruit, it was (E)-2-hexenal.
 41 key volatile substances in dried fruits and 30 key volatile substances in branch exudates were obtained.
 The volatile components were screened by odor activity value (OAV).
 GC-IMS technology is a sensitive and rapid gas phase separation detection technology that provides a more convenient, faster, and accurate method of analysis.
 GC-IMS technology combines ion mobility spectrometry with gas chromatography to generate a two-dimensional spectrum of volatile compounds based on their retention characteristics and ion mobility rates.
 Schisandra is a traditional Chinese medicinal material that contains various active ingredients with pharmacological activities, making it valuable for research and medicinal applications.

 Uniform and stratified sampling
 Direct S2ST models usually suffer from the data scarcity issue because of the limited existing parallel materials for both source and target speech.
 Previous works usually uti- lize text-to-speech (TTS) systems to generate samples in the target language by augmenting the data from speech-to-text translation (S2TT).
 Simply combining the target speech from different TTS systems can potentially improve the S2ST performances.
 A multi-task framework is proposed that jointly optimizes the S2ST system with multiple targets from different TTS systems.
 The proposed framework achieves a 2.8 BLEU score improvement over the baselines on the Fisher Spanish-English dataset.
 The proposed framework combines knowledge from different TTS data, showing reasonable improvements according to the experiments.
 The three components are automatic speech recognition (ASR), machine translation (MT), and text-to-speech (TTS).
 S2ST focuses on translating speech from a source language into the speech of a target language.
 Previous works incorporate TTS systems to form the dataset for S2ST to enable training for S2ST models, since obtaining parallel S2ST corpora is difficult.
 The direct S2ST model proposed by Lee et al. uses discrete speech units as the prediction target of the system.

The MCDS degree does not have a teaching requirement.
MCDS students may petition for approval to TA up to one course per semester provided that they are in good academic standing (Overall QPA 3.0 or above).
The English Fluency in Higher Education Act of 1990 requires graduate students to have a certain level of fluency in English before they can instruct in Pennsylvania.
All institutions of higher education in the state are required to evaluate and certify the English fluency of all instructional personnel, including teaching assistants and interns.
You can review the full university policy at: http://www.cmu.edu/policies/faculty/evaluation-certification-english-f
A student must have an Overall QPA of 3.0 or above to be eligible as a teaching assistant.
The text does not provide information on how many courses an MCDS student can TA per semester if they are not in good academic standing.
The purpose of the English Fluency in Higher Education Act is to ensure that graduate students have a certain level of fluency in English before they can instruct in Pennsylvania.
QPA stands for Quality Point Average, which is used by Carnegie Mellon University to measure the academic performance of its students.
The ITA test is mandatory for non-native English speakers to teach successfully in Student Academic Success Center.
Language Support helps these teaching assistants develop fluency and cultural understanding to teach successfully in the Student Academic Success Center.
An internship is required for students to gain practical experience and prepare them for full-time employment after graduation.
Students usually begin their search in the Fall and Spring semesters.
Carnegie Mellon provides a resume submission system, list of employers, on-campus interviews and career fairs.
The Director may waive the internship requirement for students with prior work experience.
By gaining practical experience through an internship and utilizing the career resources provided by the university.
The center helps non-native English speaking teaching assistants develop fluency and cultural understanding to teach successfully.
Students can visit the website https://www.cmu.edu/student-success/

The purpose of Disability Resources at Carnegie Mellon University is to ensure that qualified individuals receive reasonable accommodations as guaranteed by the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973.

Software & Societal Systems 17200
Ethics and Policy Issues in Computing is a course that deals with the ethical considerations and policy issues related to computing.
This course falls under Software & Societal Systems
The main topic of discussion in this text is about a specific course, which is Software & Societal Systems 17200 and its focus on Ethics and Policy Issues in Computing.
The course covers a wide range of ethical considerations and policy issues related to computing, including but not limited to privacy, security, intellectual property rights, social responsibility, etc.
Studying Ethics and Policy Issues in Computing helps students understand the ethical implications of their work as well as the policies that govern it, which can lead to more responsible and socially beneficial technology development.
The course number for Software & Societal Systems 17200 is '17200'.
This text belongs to the field of Computer Science and Technology, specifically focusing on Software & Societal Systems.
The main purpose of studying 'Ethics and Policy Issues in Computing' is to equip students with a deep understanding of ethical considerations and policy issues related to computing, which can help them make more informed decisions when developing or using technology.

 The main focus is on using genetic improvement (GI) techniques for enhancing software performance, particularly in the mobile domain.
 They were able to reduce the energy consumption of Android apps using deep parameter optimization.
 They were able to reduce the time taken to move between Activities, the main UI components, of Android apps.
 MO algorithms are used to improve conflicting properties such as runtime and memory consumption by generating a Pareto front of non-dominated solutions.
 Genetic Algorithm (GA) based algorithms such as NSGA-II and SPEA2 have shown success in multi-objective improvement.
 Pareto dominance is used to compare different individuals and determine trade-offs between different properties by identifying solutions where one is better than another in at least one objective.
 They sort the population into Pareto fronts based on fitness and select individuals from the top fronts, considering crowding metrics to maintain diversity.
 SPEA2 calculates the strength of each individual based on how many others it Pareto dominates, and selects individuals based on raw fitness and crowding metrics.
 Android apps require compilation, packaging, and launching on actual devices due to API dependencies like the Context class not available on desktops.
 Android apps make use of APIs and features like the Context class that are only available on actual devices, making them incompatible with desktop testing environments.

 The study focuses on the co-benefits of carbon neutrality in enhancing and stabilizing solar and wind energy.
 The main goal of achieving global carbon neutrality is to limit global warming to well below 2 °C above pre-industrial levels by the second half of the twenty-first century.
 Solar PV power outputs are influenced by solar altitude angle, sky condition, cloud cover, aerosols, and ambient temperature. Wind energy power outputs are dominated by wind speed at the hub height of wind turbines.
 It is important to achieve global carbon neutrality to limit the frequency of climate extremes and pollution episodes, which pose serious threats to the economy, ecological environment, and human health.
 Solar photovoltaic (PV) and wind energy.
 Asia shows a general enhancement in solar PV, relative to the baseline scenario with modest climate change mitigation.
 There is a notable west-to-east interhemispheric shift of wind energy by the mid-twenty-first century.
 Solar altitude angle and sky condition influence the amount of sunlight captured by a PV module and therefore impact solar PV power generation.
 Wind turbines typically need to shut down at a wind speed of 25 m/s for safety concerns.
 More than 120 nations have pledged to reach net zero carbon emissions by the mid-twenty-first century (2040–2060).
 For experiments of SSL, the setup followed is training and evaluation protocols of USB on image and text classification.
 For semi-supervised learning, the labeled dataset is constructed by uniformly selecting l/C samples from each class and treating the remaining samples as the unlabeled dataset.
 BERT is adopted as the backbone for text classification tasks.
 ImageNet-1K, CIFAR-100, EuroSAT, STL-10, TissueMNIST, and Semi-Aves are used for image classification tasks.
 The hyper-parameters shown in Table 9 for vision experiments of USB include Image Size, Model, Labeled Batch size, Unlabeled Batch size, Learning Rate, Weight Decay, Layer Decay Rate, LR Scheduler, Training epochs, Classes, Model EMA Momentum, Prediction EMA Momentum, Weak Augmentation, and Strong Augmentation.
 The ILL framework demonstrates comparable performance as previous methods based on the results.
 Table 12 discusses error rate comparison of different number of labels on IMDB, AG News, Amazon Review, Yahoo Answers, and Yelp Review for semi-supervised learning.
 Experiments of noisy label learning following SOP are conducted for noisy label learning.
 Symmetric noise is introduced to CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100 by uniformly flipping labels for a probability η into other classes.
 In asymmetric noise scenarios, the labels are randomly flipped for particular pairs.
 The MRI features are ranked by score, with lower rank values being better.
 The darker green points in Figure 4 correspond to better MRI features.
 Each of the six EMA locations described have an MRI point ranked as important.
 The sparsity of points ranked as important suggests that the upper lip is not as important as the other EMA locations.
 Points around and in the pharyngeal region and velic region are also ranked as important.
 The pharyngeal features are relevant to the production of various speech sounds like /a/ and some variants of /r/ in English.
 Pharyngeal and velic features are essential for fully-specified, high-fidelity articulatory synthesis.
 Constriction locations around the lips, tongue, or throat are generally ranked as important and may be useful to prioritize.
 The model was evaluated based on MCD, ASR, human evaluation, timing, and memory measurements.
 The work will be extended to multi-speaker synthesis and inversion tasks.
 The statistics shown in Table 3 for the StackOverflow experiments are the averages and standard deviations aggregated over 5 seeds.
 The purpose of the StackOverflow experiments is to investigate whether FedEP can scale to regimes with a large number of clients.
 FedSEP stands for stateless stochastic EP.
 The stateful version of FedEP is considered meaningless because in setups with a large number of clients, the average client will likely only ever participate in a single update round.
 The conclusion drawn is that FedSEP can almost match the performance of full EP despite being much simpler.
 Scaled identity is considered a strong baseline because it works well as an approximation and leads to good performance.
 The transitions signify significant increases in performance observed when switching from FedAvg to FedPA/FedEP.
 The text mentions the use of these techniques to refer to different inference techniques in the experiments.
 The experiments on CIFAR study the challenges when scaling FedEP to richly parameterized neural models with millions of parameters.
 The main focus of the StackOverflow experiments is to demonstrate the scalability of EP to a large number of clients even when assuming clients are stateless.
 The percentage of non-ASCII characters increased steadily in more recent years while the measured text quality declined.
 The growth may be due to increasing non-English content, but could also correspond to rising use of emojis and non-ASCII punctuation.
 Toxicity scores decreased slightly in later years, while sentiment increased.
 Temporal misalignment between pretraining and evaluation data complicates the evaluation of models trained at different times, with older evaluation datasets becoming stale and newer evaluation datasets under-estimating the performance of older models.
 BERT, RoBERTa, GPT-2, and T5 variants, all pretrained prior to 2020, are mentioned as examples of static pretrained models.
 Temporal misalignment between pretraining data and evaluation is shown to have a significant impact on the performance of language models.
 Temporal Degradation measures the performance change observed from one year difference between the finetuning and evaluation years, as well as between pretraining time and evaluation time.
 Pretraining misalignment is not overcome by significant finetuning, suggesting that models pretrained on data from the same time frame as target evaluations have advantages over models trained on much older or newer data.
 The effects of pretraining misalignment are stronger for larger models than smaller models.
 The average Pearson correlation of 0.61 indicates a strong correlation between pretraining temporal misalignment and performance degradation.

Longer-than-standard degree completion may occur due to academic interruptions in making progress toward the degree as defined by the academic program, interruptions of full-time study or progress towards the degree due to serious, documented medical issues, or other unusual or unforeseen circumstances.
Doctoral students who require an extended period to complete their degree requirements must consult with their academic program and are subject to the CMU Policy on Doctoral Student Status (https://www.cmu.edu/policies/student-and-student-life/doctoral-student-status.html), specifically the 'Time to Degree.'
An LTI Ph.D. student who uses courses taken as a Master’s degree student (at Carnegie Mellon or elsewhere) toward their program requirements cannot use those same courses toward any other Master’s degree offered by the school. The LTI (like other SCS units) allows its Ph.D. students who have passed the requirements for an LTI Master’s degree to receive the master’s degree without any additional work. Any other sharing of coursework by an LTI student between more than one CMU degree (e.g., receiving an MLD Master’s degree that includes courses taken as an LTI Ph.D. student) must be explicitly approved by the LTI, on a case-by-case basis, in advance.
The text does not provide information about the policy regarding external internships for students.
Ph.D. students in good standing are allowed to do an external internship, with a maximum of four (4) times during their Ph.D. degree. More than four (4) times requires approval from the Ph.D. Program Director.
International students must consult with Office of International Education (OIE) for eligibility before seeking an internship or signing an offer contract.
Internships are typically scheduled during the summer. In certain cases, it is possible to schedule an internship during the fall or spring semester.
International students must discuss this as early as possible with the Ph.D. Program Director, due to visa restrictions.
No, if an internship is part of a fully-funded external fellowship (e.g., Microsoft Research Fellowship), the student does not need prior LTI approval.
Ph.D. students in good standing are allowed to do an external internship up to four (4) times during their Ph.D. degree.
International students must consult with Office of International Education (OIE) for eligibility before seeking an internship or signing an offer contract.
Ph.D. students must plan their internships in consultation with the student’s advisor and the LTI Ph.D. Coordinator.
Some students may benefit from more than one internship, especially if they require access to proprietary data for their work. With the approval of the student’s advisor, a student can intern up to four (4) times during their Ph.D. degree.
International students must consult with Office of International Education (OIE) for eligibility before seeking an internship or signing an offer contract, and they must coordinate carefully with the LTI in any event, due to visa restrictions.
Self-funded Ph.D. students who are registered for five units while on semester internship.
They should be aware that they could potentially lose ownership of their ideas due to potential intellectual property (IP) problems with internships.
The student must have deliverables commensurate with the number of units they are taking. This can be in the form of interim and final reports on the experience, presentations in the following semester regarding the experience, assessments of their experience as it relates to their course of study, etc.
Ph.D. students are permitted to register for a maximum of 54 units of coursework per semester.
No, pass/fail grades are not permitted for courses used to satisfy a degree requirement. Graduate students who are required to take additional undergraduate courses to build up the core foundations of computer science may not elect the pass/fail option for these courses.
An equivalent graduate course previously completed at another institution may be permitted to satisfy one of the Ph.D. course requirements. The decision on whether a course may be transferred is made by the Ph.D. Program Director. A student may be granted a Leave of Absence (LOA) of at most 1 year, upon written request to the Ph.D. Program Director and with consent of the student's advisor.
Ph.D. students that are supported by sponsored research, fellowships, or scholarships are expected to remain on campus and work fulltime on their education and research throughout the year, regardless of whether classes are in session or not.
Students with full-time financial support are entitled to four weeks per year of paid vacation, which must be scheduled in consultation with their advisor.
It is the responsibility of the student on LOA to contact the LTI to initiate a return to the program.
Students may need to consult their advisor about expectations and alternate arrangements if there are challenges with taking time off during a university holiday.
The LTI may remove them from the program. See section on 'End of Semester Evaluation'.

Students must contact the Office of the Dean of Students by calling 412-268-2075 and make an appointment to discuss resources, procedures, funding options, and academic accommodations.

Students should consult with their academic advisors either before or in conjunction with registering with the Office of the Dean of Students.
The purpose of this section is to provide holistic student support by offering accommodations for students who are parents or expecting a child.
Students can find more information at https://www.cmu.edu/title-ix/resources-and-information/index.html
Academic departments play a crucial role in discussing and implementing academic accommodations for students who are parents or expecting a child.
The purpose of this section is to provide accommodations for students who are expecting a child during their academic semester.
The two options available as possible accommodation for gestational parents at Carnegie Mellon are Short-Term Accommodation and Long-Term Accommodation.
The maximum duration of a short term absence from academic responsibilities that students can take under the Short-Term Accommodation for Gestational Parents is six (6) weeks.
You can find information about accommodations for gestational parents on Page 30 of the LTI Ph.D. Graduate Student Handbook.
Long-Term Accommodation refers to a longer period of time away from academic responsibilities for gestational parents, which may be necessary if their anticipated delivery date falls during the course of a semester.
The birth of a child is significant because it can require time away from academic pursuits for delivery and recovery, necessitating accommodations for gestational parents.
In this context, 'gestational' refers to pregnancy or the state of being pregnant. It is used to describe students who are expecting a child.
Short-Term Accommodation for Gestational Parents involves taking time off from academic responsibilities up to a maximum of six (6) weeks.
The purpose of providing accommodations for gestational parents in educational institutions like Carnegie Mellon is to support students who may need time away from their academic responsibilities due to pregnancy and childbirth.
A Short-Term Accommodation allows students to take up to two weeks off from their academic responsibilities, where a longer absence is medically necessary.
A student who takes a Formal Leave of Absence will drop all remaining courses for the semester and be unenrolled from the university.
Qualifying doctoral student parents are eligible for a Parental Accommodation, which allows up to four weeks of time away from academic responsibilities with continued stipend support.
Gestational parents are eligible for both the Short-Term Accommodation and Parental Accommodation, which allows up to four weeks of time away from academic responsibilities.
Students who are international must consult with the Office of International Education (OIE) before considering a Formal Leave of Absence due to visa implications.
The university provides assistance in navigating planning and consultation processes, as well as continued stipend support during a Parental Accommodation.
Doctoral student parents are eligible for the Parental Accommodation within six months of the birth, placement through adoption, foster care, or legal guardianship.
Students who take a Short-Term Accommodation remain fully enrolled in their courses.
Gestational parents are eligible for up to four weeks of time away from academic responsibilities with continued stipend support.
The purpose of careful planning and consultation in a student's situation is to navigate through unique contexts and requirements.
Any student who becomes a parent while enrolled at Carnegie Mellon University is eligible to apply for an interest-free parental loan.
Carnegie Mellon offers two types of financial assistance to students who become parents: Interest-Free Loan and Doctoral Stipend Continuation (Gestational Parents).
Doctoral students who are the gestational parent and receive an academic stipend funded by Carnegie Mellon University are eligible to continue to receive stipend funding for up to six (6) weeks during a Short-Term Accommodation for Gestational Parents or during a Formal Leave of Absence.
The information about financial assistance options for student parents at Carnegie Mellon University can be found in the LTI Ph.D. Graduate Student Handbook, specifically on page 31.
A Short-Term Accommodation for Gestational Parents refers to an arrangement that allows doctoral students who are gestational parents to continue receiving stipend funding during their parental leave.
A Formal Leave of Absence refers to an official break from academic studies that doctoral students can take, which allows them to continue receiving stipend funding for up to six (6) weeks.
The purpose of a Short-Term Accommodation for Gestational Parents is to allow doctoral students who are gestational parents to continue receiving stipend funding during their parental leave.
Carnegie Mellon offers two types of financial assistance to student parents: Interest-Free Loan and Doctoral Stipend Continuation (Gestational Parents).

The LTI supplements the award so that the student will receive full tuition and a combined stipend 10 percent higher than that of the standard LTI graduate fellowship.

 The presence of mineral dust particles over the Mediterranean Basin can be attributed to the nocturnal low-level jets, Harmattan surge, and Mediterranean depressions.
 Both GRASP/Component dust retrieval and MERRA-2 dust product can capture well the variation in monthly dust column concentration over the MED region.
 A good correlation coefficient (R = 0.88) was obtained between GRASP/Component dust retrieval and MERRA-2 dust product in the MED region.
 MERRA-2 overestimated dust column concentration the most in April in the MED region.
 It was noted that MERRA-2 overestimated dust column concentration compared to GRASP/Component dust retrieval throughout the year in the MED region.
 A good correlation coefficient (R = 0.98) was obtained between GRASP/Component dust retrieval and MERRA-2 dust product in the ARA region.
 The maximum absolute difference was recorded in July in the ARA region.
 The correlation coefficient between GRASP/Component dust retrieval and MERRA-2 dust product in the BOB region is R = 0.84.
 MERRA-2 showed higher dust column concentrations compared to GRASP/Component dust retrieval from February to May in the BOB region.
 The RMSE value obtained between GRASP/Component dust retrieval and MERRA-2 dust product in the MED region was 82.34 mg/m2.
 The house has a plan that is relatively rare in early Alabama architecture, featuring a brick ground floor topped by one-and-a-half-stories of wood-frame construction.
 The ground floor originally contained domestic spaces, with formal rooms on the principle floor and bedrooms on the upper floor, all centered around a central hallway.
 The facade is five bays wide, with central entrance doors on both the ground and principle floors, divided by two-story Doric pilasters, and featuring a two-tiered tetrastyle Doric portico in the middle third.
 Lakewood was built for Joseph Lake, a native of North Carolina, by master builder Hiram W. Bardwell.
 Construction of Lakewood was completed in 1840.
 Julia Strudwick Tutwiler, a relative of Joseph Lake, periodically resided in the house while she served as president of the University of West Alabama.
 Lakewood and its 10 acres of grounds were listed on Places in Peril in 2012 due to the immediate threat of acquisition by developers.
 Descendants of the Lake family have continued to own Lakewood to the present day.
 The threat of acquisition by developers was one of the reasons Lakewood was listed on Places in Peril in 2012.
 Julia Strudwick Tutwiler, who resided in Lakewood, served as president of the university during her stays at the house.

The main belief of LTI is that the best work and biggest ideas happen when we work together.
LTI collaborates with everyone from local emergency management personnel to large corporations interested in data mining.
The benefits of working with LTI include developing relationships with students who will go on to be leaders in the field, being at the forefront of innovation, and potentially commercializing your work.
Carnegie Mellon nurtures and encourages business innovation and development. Your work with us could be a part of that.

LTI wants you to join them because they believe that by working together, we can achieve the best work and biggest ideas.

Working with LTI could potentially commercialize your work as mentioned in the text.

According to the text, by sponsoring a capstone project, you will develop a relationship with a team of LTI students while working toward a solution to a challenge within your organization. Our students get real-world research experience and you get a team dedicated to solving your problem.
According to the text, joining an industry consortia allows industry leaders to partner with CMU in ongoing research and development projects, receive invitations to select events, and have a direct say in the direction of our programs.

 Wider models exhibit better task performance due to increased parameter count and expressivity.
 Using higher-performing hardware does not necessarily improve end-to-end performance due to framework overhead.
 The framework tax
 The inference efficiency is limited by overhead incurred by deep learning frameworks, not by computational boundaries.
 Domain-specific architectures such as Google TPU’s, GraphCore IPUs, and custom ASICs.
 The study does not necessarily translate to other metrics of efficiency, such as power consumption or power output.

 To run a 2nd-pass beam search and improve accuracy of long-tail named entities.
 Competition between classical and E2E approaches is reflected in benchmarks, with E2E models gaining momentum.
 Around 2.3% (test-clean) and 4.9% (test-other) word error rate.
 E2E models do not scale well to low-resource conditions.
 To take full advantage of the benefits of E2E modeling, especially in conditions where E2E models are not a perfect match.
 Rare events like rare words in ASR still provide a challenge.

 Exploring solutions beyond training data generation using TTS.

 Improving reliability and trustworthiness in various downstream applications.
 IPA significantly improves faithfulness while preserving dialogue quality, outperforming all other baselines.
 Controlled decoding involves designing new decoding algorithms to explore controlled generation at inference time, which helps in imposing constraints on text generation.
 Reinforcement learning has been used in tasks like machine translation, summarization, dialogue systems, and text games to optimize for non-differentiable rewards.
 One potential concern is that IPA could be used for unintended malicious purposes like producing hateful or toxic content.
 One limitation is that it requires access to the output logits of the base LM, which hinders compatibility with certain models.
 IPA combines RL with plug-and-play flexibility, allowing customization of large language models without costly fine-tuning.
 GBS is a lexically constrained decoding algorithm that generalizes beam search by constraining the decoding space with keyword-related penalties.
 Reinforcement learning methods like REINFORCE can lead to issues with reward hacking when optimizing for arbitrary non-differentiable rewards.
 The Perspective API calls are used as the reward function for the toxicity reduction task in IPA.
 Equation 6 describes the process of identifying the most likely hypothesis summary ˆY given the input X and semantic representation S.
 P(Y, S|X) = P(Y |X)P(S|X)
 Equation 8 estimates P(Y i|X 1:i, Y 1:i−1) using Equations 7 and 5.
 The encoder and decoder model the probabilities of P(S|X) and P(Y |S) respectively.
 The updater uses the past semantic embeddings and the current encoder output to produce the current semantic embedding.
 The maximum output length in tokens in the How-2 Dataset is 152.
 The total number of model parameters is 103 million.
 The Adam optimizer is used with a peak learning rate of 0.001 for ASR pre-training.
 Fine-tuning is run for a day on one A40 GPU.
 The models are evaluated with ROUGE, METEOR, and BERTScore.

 The two significant challenges are understanding queries in any language and retrieving relevant passages from a collection of documents in multiple languages, and generating appropriate responses in the same language.
 The multilingual DPR (mDPR) model is used for document retrieval.
 Passage retrieval in conversational question answering (QA) presents new challenges as each question must be interpreted within the context of the ongoing dialogue.
 The mDPR model employs a bi-encoder architecture, utilizing a pre-trained multilingual model to encode the questions and passages independently. The encoded representations are then compared using a maximum inner product search to identify relevant passages for a given question.
 The two paradigms evaluated in the study are a language-agnostic paradigm and a language-aware paradigm.
 The Language-Agnostic BERT Sentence Embedding (LaBSE) model is used for multilingual sentence embedding.
 The study found that, for the examples examined, query rewriting does not enhance performance compared to the original queries.
 The limitations mentioned include budget and credit constraints affecting the query rewriting observations and the limited generalizability of findings due to the sample size.
 Potential future works suggested include testing the performance of query rewriting using in-context examples and testing query rewriting using open-source models and advanced fine-tuning methods.
 The study observed an improvement of approximately 4.2%, 3.51%, and 2.80% in F1, BLEU, and Rouge-L scores, respectively when including FiD along with mT5 in the case of both Vietnamese (vi) and French (fr) languages.

 Common Voice, LibriSpeech, MuST-C v2, TED-LIUM v3, and VoxPopuli
 By selecting sentences similar to the ACL domain based on similarity with provided ACL dev bitext and abstracts using n-gram overlap as a similarity metric.
 Europarl v7 text-to-text and v10, NewsCommentary v16, OpenSubtitles v2018, Tatoeba, ELRC-CORDIS_News, JParaCrawl for Japanese, and TED2020 for German.
 To enrich existing parallel data by forward and backward translating the training bitext to improve translation quality on lower-resource languages.
 Data diversification ensures that the model has seen the parallel data during training, resulting in synthetic translations of relatively high quality.
 1.5 million English sentences were sampled from the MT training data, and casing and punctuation marks were removed to train a model to restore them.
 It creates forward translations based on transcript-only datasets from Common Voice, TEDLIUM, and VoxPopuli, along with utilizing TTS data.
 ASR model and MT model
 WavLM with a LARGE configuration and 24 layers, with a mBART50 decoder and WavLM encoder.
 The word error rate (WER) improved from 11.6% to 
 Some challenges and open questions highlighted include extreme low-resource parallel datasets, lack of monolingual data, low domain diversity, rich morphology, distant paired languages, noisy text environments, code-switching, lack of orthographic normalization, and dialectal variety.
 It is not possible to train a reliable pre-trained language model for ILA because the amount of monolingual data available is not enough.
 Quechua was mentioned as an exception with a large enough monolingual dataset to train a BERT-like model.
 Low domain diversity in the scarce parallel datasets is recognized as a major problem during the AmericasNLP ST.
 Code-switching is a phenomenon strongly present in ILA due to the bilingualism among their communities.
 Monolingual texts, if they exist, are found in social media environments that often use a non-canonical writing.
 One challenge faced in the usage of ILA is having a lack of unified orthographic standard, leading to difficulties in matching linguistic suggestions with day-by-day writing.
 The linguistic richness of indigenous languages includes strong dialectal variety, making it hard for native speakers to understand even speakers from neighboring villages.
 The winner of the AmericasNLP ST got important improvements using orthographic normalizers developed specifically for each American language.
 The most prominent dataset available for ILA is the Inuktitut–English parallel data.
 AI alignment and adversarial examples
 Question answering, translation, and summarization
 They do not follow user instructions and reflect biases, toxicity, and profanity present in the training data
 Instruction tuning and reinforcement learning via human feedback (RLHF)
 Inputs designed by an adversary to cause a neural network to perform incorrect behaviors
 To evaluate the robustness of machine learning systems against real adversaries and to understand the worst-case behavior of the system
 To prevent real attacks by designing robust classifiers and to understand the worst-case behavior of a system
 Question answering, document classification, sentiment analysis, and triggering toxic completions
 The focused adversarial examples are optimized to produce specific unwanted outcomes, while social engineering attacks may try to trick the model into playing a harmful role
 They serve as a lower bound of error when formal verification is not possible

The Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act
Students can file a complaint with the U.S. Department of Education Family Policy Compliance Office.
John Papinchak, University Registrar, can provide information about Student Privacy Rights, FERPA or filing a complaint.

Departments and colleges should confirm the official academic calendar for graduate students, which may differ from or be in addition to those presented in the academic calendar provided by Enrollment Services.

You can find a full schedule of programs at www.cmu.edu/graduate/
The University Libraries
The Office of the Assistant Vice Provost for Graduate Education offers a robust schedule of professional development opportunities.
Some are geared towards specific populations (master’s students, PhD students at the beginning of their program, graduate students seeking tenure track positions), while others are open to all graduate students.
You can find a full schedule on the AVPGE website at www.cmu.edu/graduate/
Their combined mission is to provide access and help graduate students find information, teach them how to evaluate available information, and use reliable sources.
The libraries offer digital resources and services including off-campus/wireless access to databases and e-journals, as well as online access.
