Computing Services is located in Cyert Hall 285.
Computing Services develops, maintains and supports the computing infrastructure for Carnegie Mellon students, faculty members and staff members. This includes the campus wired and wireless networks, public computer labs or “clusters,” cable television and telephone services, computing related documentation and support through the Help Center.
The website contains addition information regarding The Help Center hours, location and contact information, computing cluster hours and location, the Carnegie Mellon web portal, computing security and policies and guidelines.
Students can email the Help Center at ithelp@andrew.cmu.edu with questions and for assistance.

Carnegie Mellon extends certain benefits to the domestic partners of its eligible students. These benefits can be elected through a registration process orchestrated by the Office of the Dean of Students, located on the 3rd floor of Warner Hall.
The university does not currently offer housing to its graduate students. However, the Office of Housing and Dining Services provides community housing information to assist graduate students who are seeking housing in the communities surrounding the university. This includes information on the legal aspects of renting an apartment, moving checklists, and access to an off-campus housing database.
To elect benefits for your domestic partner through the university's registration process, you should visit the Office of the Dean of Students located on the 3rd floor of Warner Hall. There, you will find information regarding the benefits available for domestic partners, eligibility criteria, and instructions to register.

The Office of Housing and Dining Services provides a wealth of resources to assist graduate students in finding off-campus housing. This includes information on the legal aspects of renting an apartment, moving checklists, and access to an off-campus housing database.
The Office of Housing and Dining Services offers dining locations open around campus in academic buildings, Hunt Library and the University Center. These locations offer flexible hours with options from the early morning through late night.
Students can find information about parking availability, policies, transportation options and Port Authority Transit usage with a valid university ID on the Parking and Transportation Services site.
The Shuttle Service operates several routes within Oakland, Squirrel Hill and Shadyside areas, as well as to University sites located outside of the main campus. Information regarding up-to-date shuttle schedules can be found at www.cmu.edu/parking/shuttle/index.html.
The Parking and Transportation Services office is located in the lower level of the University Center, LL#8.
Parking and Transportation Services will ticket any car parked at an expired meter. The city monitors the metered parking along Margaret Morrison, Frew and Tech Streets.
The varying permit rates can be found on the Parking and Transportation Services website.
The Escort Service offers vehicle routes within a radius of campus between 6:30 pm-6 am daily. Information regarding up-to-date shuttle and escort schedules, pick-up/drop-off locations, routes and usage policies can be found at www.cmu.edu/parking/shuttle/index.html.

SafeWalk provides campus escorts for all members of the Carnegie Mellon community.
SafeWalk operates nightly during the regular academic year (except certain holidays and break periods) from 10pm until 2am.
People may request an escort by calling 412-268-SAFE (8-7233 from a campus phone), approaching an escort team, or stopping by the SafeWalk dispatch area in the University Center.
SafeWalk will escort to locations approximately one mile from campus.
Additional SafeWalk information can be found at admission.enrollment.cmu.edu/pages/health-safety.
SafeWalk is a student volunteer organization that provides campus escorts for all members of the Carnegie Mellon community.
SafeWalk operates from 10pm until 2am during the regular academic year (except certain holidays and break periods).
The contact number for requesting an escort with SafeWalk is 412-268-SAFE (8-7233 from a campus phone).
People may stop by the SafeWalk dispatch area in the University Center, Lower Level near the Post Office Package Pick-Up window between 10pm-2am.

The Office of Community Standards and Integrity (OCSI) upholds the university's community standards, promoting integrity and respect among students.

Athletics, Physical Education and Recreation provides students with opportunities for physical activity, team sports, and recreational activities.
The Career and Professional Development Center (CPDC) helps students explore their interests, develop skills, and connect with employers in various fields.
University Health Services offers medical care, counseling, and wellness programs for students' physical and mental health needs.
The main purpose of the Center for Student Diversity & Inclusion is to cultivate a strong, diverse and inclusive community capable of living out the values of Carnegie Mellon University.
The Center offers resources to enhance an inclusive and transformative student experience in dimensions such as access, success, campus climate and intergroup dialogue. It supports and connects historically underrepresented students and those who are first in their family to attend college.
The Office of Disability Resources has a continued mission to provide physical, digital, and programmatic access to ensure that students with disabilities have equal access to their educational experience.
Students who would like to receive accommodations can begin the process through Disability Resources' secure online portal or email access@andrew.cmu.edu.

Carnegie Mellon University offers a wide variety of confidential, consultation services and professional development programs to support graduate students as teaching assistants or instructors of record during their time at the university.
The Graduate Student Assembly (GSA) represents and advocates for the diverse interests of all graduate students at Carnegie Mellon University. It improves the graduate student experience, passes legislation, allocates student activities funding, advocates for legislative action locally and in Washington D.C., and acts on behalf of all graduate student interests.
The Eberly Center assists departments in creating and conducting customized programs to meet the specific needs of their graduate student instructors. It also offers campus-wide Graduate Student Instructor Orientation events and our Future Faculty Program, both designed to help participants be effective and efficient in their teaching roles.
The goal of the Eberly Center's support for graduate students is to disseminate evidence-based teaching strategies in ways that are accessible and actionable, regardless of one's current or future teaching context and duties.
Graduate Student Assembly (GSA) is funded by the Student Activities Fee from all graduate students at Carnegie Mellon University.
Graduate Student Assembly has made a difference in implementing its vision laid out by the strategic plan, and it passes legislation, allocates student activities funding, advocates for legislative action locally and in Washington D.C. on behalf of graduate student issues and needs.

The purpose of reporting bias at this institution is to address and prevent incidents related to discrimination, harassment, or retaliation based on race, color, religion, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, national origin, age, disability status, genetic information, veteran status, or any other protected characteristic.
Students, faculty, and staff can anonymously file a report by calling 877-700-7050 or visiting www.reportit.net (user name: tartans; password: plaid). All submissions are reported to the appropriate department for review.
The purpose of reporting environmental health and safety issues at this institution is to ensure a safe learning environment by identifying, evaluating, and controlling potential hazards or risks that could cause harm to students, faculty, staff, or visitors.
Financial matters such as fraudulent activities, misuse of funds, and other financial irregularities can be reported through the reporting system to ensure transparency and accountability in the institution's financial operations.
The purpose of reporting high-risk incidents, such as threats to public safety or security breaches, is to promptly address and mitigate potential risks that could disrupt operations or harm individuals within the community.
Human resource related issues such as discrimination, harassment, retaliation, and other workplace misconducts can be reported through the reporting system to ensure a fair and respectful working environment for all employees.
The purpose of reporting information systems related issues, such as data breaches or unauthorized access to sensitive information, is to protect the integrity and confidentiality of the institution's digital assets.
Research related issues such as misconduct or ethical violations in research practices can be reported through the reporting system to maintain the integrity and credibility of the institution's research activities.
The purpose of reporting threats of business interruption, such as natural disasters or cyber attacks, is to prepare and respond effectively to minimize potential disruptions in operations.
Threats of violence or physical harm towards students, faculty, staff, or visitors can be reported through the reporting system to ensure a safe and secure learning environment.

The Computing Services Help Center can be reached at 412-268-4357 (HELP) or it-help@cmu.edu.

 The main focus is on evaluating IPA for controlling the safety of a dialogue model.
 DI-ASAFETY is a dataset containing 54K context-sensitive unsafe examples. It is used to train a dialogue safety classifier by providing human-written safe and unsafe responses.
 The safety of dialogue responses is evaluated using a classifier score as an automatic measure of safety, as well as a human evaluation of safety and coherence on 200 examples through Amazon Mechanical Turk.
 Blenderbot-3B-distill, DialoGPT, GODEL, and ChatGPT are compared with IPA.
 The reward chosen is the product of safety score from the dialogue safety classifier, coherence score, and engagingness scores from UniEval-Dialogue.
 IPA significantly improves dialogue safety and coherence compared to Blenderbot-3B-distill, surpassing other dialogue models.
 The study aims to address the issue of models generating hallucinations containing unverifiable information.
 The Wizard of Wikipedia data and the FaithDial dataset are used to evaluate faithfulness of responses.
 Models such as GPT-2, DialoGPT, DoHA, T5, T5-CTRL, and T5-LossTruncation are used as baselines.
 IPA performs better in generating faithful dialogue responses compared to supervised models that struggle due to poor data quality of their supervision dataset.
 The text focuses on hierarchical event structures in Wikidata and the methodology for linking event references in text documents to entries in a knowledge base.
 The task of grounding involves linking event references in text documents to the corresponding entries in a knowledge base.
 Event typing classifies event mentions into types from a predefined ontology, while event linking grounds mentions to one or more events from a knowledge base.
 The task definition involves predicting an unordered subset of events from a hierarchy tree in a knowledge base, from the leaf to the root of the tree, given an input mention span from a text document.
 The alternate task formulation involves traditional event linking followed by hierarchy propagation in the knowledge base, requiring access to gold hierarchy relations at test time.
 The text expands the XLEL-WD dataset to include hierarchical event structures, collecting events and their mentions from Wikidata using a three-step process.
 Hierarchical relation extraction for events involves predicting parent-child relationships in the knowledge base by masking the child event and tasking models to retrieve the parent event.
 The two task variants presented are Multilingual, where event details are in the same language as the mention, and Crosslingual, where event details are in English.
 The text presents a rank-based loss utilizing entity ontology, a complex structured loss, and box embeddings to model hierarchical relations between entity types.
 Works presented in the text typically focus on hierarchical relations among mentions in a document, whereas the text focuses on hierarchical relations among events in a knowledge base.
 The objective of the project is to contribute to the diversity of the open-source spoken language translation ecosystem.
 ESPnet-ST-v2 focuses on offline speech-to-text (ST), simultaneous speech-to-text (SST), and offline speech-to-speech (S2ST) translation.
 Speech-to-text (ST) translates speech input into textual output, while speech-to-speech (S2ST) translates speech input into target speech.
 Simultaneous speech-to-text (SST) translation requires systems to produce textual outputs incrementally while ingesting speech input.
 ESPnet-ST-v2 offers state-of-the-art architectures such as transducers, hybrid CTC/attention, multi-decoders, time-synchronous blockwise CTC/attention, Translatotron models, and direct discrete unit models.
 Common approaches to ST include coupling statistical automatic speech recognition (ASR) and text-to-text translation (MT) as well as end-to-end differentiable (E2E) approaches.
 ESPnet-ST-v2 offers a wide variety of approaches for offline speech-to-text (ST), simultaneous speech-to-text (SST), and offline speech-to-speech (S2ST) translation tasks.
 ESPnet-ST-v2 benchmarks its performance against top IWSLT shared task systems and other prior works to evaluate the performance of its models.
 The modular design allows for easy interchangeability of major neural network modules such as frontends, encoders, decoders, search, and loss functions.
 The modular design of ESPnet-ST-v2 improves over ESPnet-ST-v1 by making it easier to extend and modify the toolkit, and allowing modules to be readily used for adjacent tasks.

Additional resources for graduate students include College Liaisons and the Student Support Resources team.

GSA advocates for legislative action locally and in Washington D.C. on behalf of graduate student issues and needs.
The MLT Graduate Student Handbook is not directly related to GSA's role at CMU. However, it provides guidelines and information for graduate students in the Master of Language Teaching (MLT) program.
GSA takes steps towards implementing the vision laid out by the strategic plan, which includes advocating for legislative action and improving graduate student experiences at different levels of the university.
The Office of International Education (OIE) at Carnegie Mellon University serves as a liaison to the university for all non-immigrant students and scholars, while also providing study abroad opportunities and advisement. It offers various services such as personal, immigration, academic, social, and acculturation advice.
OIE presents a variety of programs including international career workshops, tax workshops, cross-cultural events, and more to cater to the needs of its diverse student population.
International graduate and undergraduate students from over 90 different countries attend Carnegie Mellon University.
OIE provides advisement on study abroad programs, helping students navigate the process of studying in a foreign country and making informed decisions about their academic and personal goals.
OIE acts as a liaison between non-immigrant students and the university, helping them navigate complex immigration processes and ensuring compliance with relevant regulations.
OIE organizes cross-cultural events to promote understanding, appreciation, and integration among students from diverse cultural backgrounds, fostering a more inclusive campus community.
Students can access information about OIE's various services and programs on the university's website under the Office of International Education (OIE) section.
MLT stands for Master of Language Technologies, a graduate program offered at Carnegie Mellon University that focuses on research and development in language technologies.
International students, including those enrolled in a Master of Language Technologies (MLT) program, can greatly benefit from OIE's services. These include immigration support, academic advisement, cross-cultural events, and study abroad opportunities that align with their personal and professional goals.
The Veterans and Military Community provides information on applying veteran education benefits, campus services, veteran’s groups at CMU, non-educational resources and international military service information through their website. They also have links to veteran resource in the Pittsburgh community.
The Naval ROTC and Veteran Affairs Offices are located at 4615 Forbes Avenue, with contact information uro-vaedbenefits@andrew.cmu.edu and phone number 412-268-8747.
Computing Services maintains and supports computing resources for the campus community, including the campus wired and wireless networks, printing, computer labs, file storage, email, and software catalog. They also ensure that everyone in the community is responsible for the security of these shared resources.
The primary purpose of research at the university is the advancement of knowledge in all fields in which the university is active. Research is regarded as one of the university’s major contributions to society and as an essential element in education, particularly at the graduate level and in faculty development.
Research activities are governed by several university policies. Guidance and more general information is found by visiting the Research at Carnegie Mellon website.
The Veterans and Military Community provides information on non-educational resources related to international military service through their website.
Students can find more general information about research at the university by visiting the Research at Carnegie Mellon website.

 Its ability to generalize to many different tasks due to LLM pretraining and freezing.
 GILL is able to outperform retrieval models like FROMAGe on examples where FROMAGe is unable to retrieve relevant images.
 It is a lightweight transformer model that conditions on [IMG] embeddings and q learnt embedding vectors to enable image synthesis.
 As r increases, image generation generally improves, plateauing around r = 4.
 GILL performs comparably or better compared to prior approaches, with R@1 at 22.3, R@5 at 45.0, and R@10 at 29.8.
 The performance of GILL generally improves with increasing input contexts on VIST, showing better results with multimodal context.
 Scaling up the LLM backbone, image generation backbone, or visual processing model are promising directions that will likely induce even stronger vision-and-language capabilities.
 GILLMapper is compared against a linear layer, a multilayer perceptron (MLP), and a 4-layer bidirectional transformer encoder.
 The metrics used are Fréchet Inception Distance (FID) on the CC3M validation set and CLIP Similarity on VIST.
 The ablated model achieves CLIP similarity of 0.636 and LPIPS of 0.694, comparable to the original model.
 TDT predicts the token duration of the current emission in addition to the output token.
 A TDT joint network emits two sets of output: one for the output token and the other for the duration of the token.
 The probability of observing the first u output labels in the first t frames is represented by node (t, u) in the lattice.
 The TDT loss (LTDT) is computed as -log PTDT(y|x), where PTDT(y|x) is the probability of the whole sequence.
 The gradient computation for the TDT loss is done analytically because automatic differentiation for transducer loss is highly inefficient.
 The first part of the gradient of the TDT loss with respect to the token probabilities PT(v|t, u) is -α(t, u)*b(v, t, u)/PTDT(y|x).
 The base condition for the backward variable (β) is β(T + 1, U) = 1.
 The forward variables α(t, u) are computed based on a recursive formula involving the duration probabilities and base conditions.
 The TDT loss (LTDT) differs from the conventional Transducer loss in that it sums over durations in D for both non-blank and blank emissions.
 The sum over durations in D for the blank emission in TDT is important to consider all possible contributions from states that can reach (t, u), weighted by the corresponding duration probabilities.
 Hierarchy aware loss
 Based on the ComplEx embedding
 Asymmetric, transitive relations
 s(ep, ec) = Im(ep) ⋅ (Re(ec) ⊙ Im(r)) − Re(ep) ⋅ (IM(ec) ⊙ Im(r))
 Biased linear projection of event embedding into the real part of the complex space
 By minimizing the in-batch BCE loss
 Pretraining, Joint Learning, Pretraining + Joint Learning
 Hierarchical relation extraction
 h(ei, ej) = |Mei ∩ Mej | / |Mei |
 Recall@k, Recall@min, Strict Accuracy, Macro F1, Micro F1
 Approximately 900 languages.
 Most of these languages are endangered due to various factors.
 MT helps overcome language barriers and allows native speakers to continue using their language.
 Dialectical and orthographic variations, noisy texts, complex morphology, etc.
 In 2023.
 The Georgetown-IBM experiment in 1954.
 Converting text in a source language into text in a target language that conveys the same meaning.
 To find the target text with the highest conditional probability, given the source text.
 Decoding refers to the generation of output given the parameters and an input.
 Maximizing the log-likelihood with respect to the parameters.
 Zhong-Qiu Wang and Shinji Watanabe
 Unsupervised neural speech separation in reverberant conditions with multiple speakers
 In over-determined conditions, a unique solution to speaker separation exists and can be leveraged as supervision
 Enforcing a linear-filter constraint to promote separation of speakers in over-determined mixtures
 A deep neural network (DNN) is used to estimate speaker images and a sub-band linear prediction algorithm named FCP is used for linear filters
 By proposing a loss term based on minimizing intra-source magnitude scattering
 Supervised models rely on paired clean and corrupted signals for training, while unsupervised models do not require labeled mixtures
 Separating a recorded mixture of concurrent speech by multiple speakers into individual speaker signals
 It turns the ill-posed problem into a well-posed one, providing a unique solution for separation
 To estimate both the speaker images and linear filters without needing labeled mixtures

 To make the embedded target features resemble the source features on which the pretrained model body performs well.
 The pretrained source embedder is denoted as fs and the randomly initialized target embedder is denoted as ft.
 The goal is to minimize the distance between the joint distribution of the target embeddings and that of the source embeddings.
 (S, D)
 (S, k^2K)
 The transformer output
 To align the embedder and predictor with the pretrained model by updating all model parameters to minimize the target loss.
 Pairwise Euclidean distance, moment-based maximum mean discrepancy (MMD), optimal transport dataset distance (OTDD).
 OTDD
 It not only aligns individual data points but also groups features with the same label together in the embedding space, facilitating fine-tuning.
 No improvements were found to bandwidth because only FDroid 2 uses bandwidth extensively according to the benchmarks.
 GIDroid found patches that contain edits semantically equivalent to developer patches 17 times.
 Each MO run was repeated 20 times.
 The best change found for the Port Authority application consisted of removing an unnecessary try-catch statement.
 The improvement for F-Droid refactored an if/else statement to remove the null clause and only cancel the animation if the object is not null.
 The best-evolved change in Tower Collector consisted of changes to the way in which a database is handled.
 The best improving change in the Frozen Bubble application consisted of modifying how new rows of bubbles were instantiated in a row.
 The most improving change in the Fosdem Companion application consisted of moving the instantiation of two objects outside of a loop.
 The best change for the GadgetBridge application involved caching the method call which resolves the name of a file that is repeatedly used.
 The best-evolved mutation in the Lightning Browser application involved removing a check for whether or not a list of bookmarks is null.

 It indicates that the accumulation of pollutants during PE2 was dominated by fine particles.
 It increased about 2.1 times, from about 120 µg m−3 to about 250 µg m−3.
 It increased about four times, from about 0.4 to about 1.6.
 The increase in the relative humidity.
 The hygroscopic growth of a large number of fine particles with increasing relative humidity increased the scattering of particles.
 It indicates different degrees of growth in the aerosols.
 It led to a decrease in the amount of radiation reaching the surface and an increase in the amount of radiation trapped in the boundary layer.
 Because pollutants may be suspended in the atmosphere, resulting in low PM2.5 mass concentrations from near-surface observations.
 The wind field.
 It can transport pollutants from one area to another, affecting their accumulation.

 Measurements can be performed from statistical, signal processing, information-theoretic, and algebraic perspectives.
 The key idea is to recast the study of the topological structures of the phase space to the study of its algebraic constructs, such as homotopy groups and homology/cohomology groups.
 Algebraic invariants can characterize the homeomorphisms between phase spaces and reveal large-scale structures and global properties.
 One suggested research direction is to study deep learning approaches for solving and analyzing dynamical systems, as well as exploring the integration of dynamical systems with deep neural models to analyze and interpret behaviors.
 In the multi-mass models, 50 masses are used to model vocal fold motion with high precision.
 The equation of motion for the i-th mass component includes anchor force, vertical and longitudinal coupling forces, collision restoring force, and driving force from glottal pressure.
 The key principle behind finite element models is the discretization of the vocal fold motion in space and time, solving differential equations in each cell based on the law of physics.
 The relation between stress and displacement in finite element models is governed by a system of partial differential equations that can be efficiently solved by finite element methods.
 Bio-mechanical models focus on simulating the geometry and articulatory movements of the vocal tract using displacement-based finite element methods.
 Statistical models describe the vocal tract as statistical factors or components, such as factor analysis that analyzes the relationship between articulatory components and vocal tract parameters.

Changes made today will not be reflected until the next morning. The files are updated NIGHTLY.
You can view the class schedules in PDF and HTML formats. The specific file types are Spring Class Schedule PDF, HTML Summer One/All Class Schedule PDF, HTML Summer Two Class Schedule PDF, HTML Fall Class Schedule PDF, HTML.

You should use print preview to check if the schedule data fits on the printed page. If necessary, adjust the scaling percentage in the print dialog box under graphics.
Students can use the Course Search feature on the website to find and enroll in their desired courses.

Students can access Feedback section to view their progress and receive constructive criticism from instructors.

 Training an initial translation model with synthetic data generated via BT and then finetuning it with gold data is a technique mentioned in the text.
 The text mentions that using back-translation (BT) without a tagging strategy for high-resource languages (HRLs) can degrade performance.
 The text explains that using back-translated data from multiple sources or optimizing the ranking of back-translated data can yield further gains in performance.
 The text states that using back-translation (BT) with naturally occurring text parallel corpora instead of translationese corpora improves automatic n metrics.
 The text mentions that sentence modification can be achieved by replacing a randomly chosen word in a sentence with a soft-word.
 One way to augment MT data mentioned in the text is by paraphrasing, which can increase the number of training instances.
 The text mentions augmenting existing data by adding continuous or discrete noise, paraphrasing, and using minimum risk training to optimize BLEU.
 The text states that pivot-based approaches in NMT suffer from error propagation challenges.
 The LoResMT 2020 shared task is highlighted in the text, which explores language pairs with no parallel data.
 The text explains that transfer learning helps low-resource tasks by allowing training with a lower amount of data.
 The purpose of the HomeRobot library is to support tasks such as manipulation learning, continuous learning, navigation, and object-goal navigation.
 The HomeRobot OVMM challenge focuses on integrating perception, planning, and action to build general-purpose home assistants.
 The RL methods moved to the object more efficiently if an object was visible, while the heuristic planner was better at long-horizon exploration.
 The DETIC object detector provides object segmentation for both the heuristic and RL policies in the comparison.
 Open-Vocabulary Mobile Manipulation is defined as a new, crucial task for the robotics community that involves navigating from one location to another carrying a small household object.
 The paper proposes a real-world benchmark in a controlled environment and aims to compare current baselines in simulation and in the real world under different conditions.
 The main goal of having a real-world benchmark is to enable benchmarking of individual components and building general-purpose home assistants through holistic problem-solving.
 The HomeRobot stack enables the benchmarking of individual components by providing a full robotics stack with multiple implementations of different sub-modules.
 The HomeRobot benchmark provides a broadly capable robotics stack for implementing and sharing robotics code, which is not provided by other benchmarks.
 The Open-Vocabulary Mobile Manipulation task involves interacting with small and manipulable household objects like cups, stuffed toys, or boxes.

 The objective is to condition the encoder layers on intermediate predictions and improve model performance.
 The hidden vector hint is summed with a linear projection of the intermediate posterior distribution and input into the next encoder layer.
 SC-CTC passes intermediate outputs to the next layer to condition the encoder.
 Equation (7) is recursively applied for each intermediate layer, allowing conditioning on the intermediate predictions.
 The proposed method focuses on using an auxiliary CTC objective to improve language identification and transcription predictions.
 Conditioning later encoder layers on noisy transcription predictions of earlier layers can hinder model performance.
 The latent variable I represents the intermediate language identification (LID) predictions.
 Utterance-level LIDs and token-level LIDs help in aligning languages with spoken words and predicting language at different levels of granularity.
 A hierarchical setup of K intermediate layers is constructed where each layer makes increasingly complex predictions.
 The complete loss function is a sum of the encoder-decoder attention loss, CTC loss, and the LID-conditioned intermediate loss with appropriate weights.
 The three resolutions were 100ms, 40ms, and 20ms.
 The vocoder was trained on the LJSpeech dataset.
 The two approaches were a parallel approach (HuBERT-MR-P) and a hierarchical approach (HuBERT-MR-H).
 HuBERT-MR-P was evaluated on the SUPERB benchmark.
 The experiments demonstrate that the HuBERT-MR models significantly improve model performance on various downstream tasks.
 The results demonstrate that the features differ across resolutions, while all retain the essential information for intelligibility.
 The work was supported by a Meta AI SRA grant.

 The study explores self-supervised pretrained representations for end-to-end speech recognition.
 Reference [11] discusses a Multistream CNN for robust acoustic modeling.

The Language Technologies Institute
Dr. Lori Levin's research interests include Machine Translation, Natural Language Processing and Computational Linguistics, and Corpus Annotation and Resources.
Dr. Lori Levin's work primarily focuses on the linguistic aspects of language technologies, specifically Language Technologies With Low Resources and Language Universals and Typology.
The use of typology and universals helps to develop language technologies for new languages on short timelines or in low-resource scenarios.
Dr. Lori Levin's office is located at 5717 —Gates & Hillman Centers.
Speakers of technologically poor languages may use language technologies to access information related to education, politics, business, weather and health conditions, as well as for preserving culture and maintaining community relationships.
Dr. Lori Levin's office phone number is 412-268-6193.
Less than a hundred of the more than 6,000 human languages have robust language technologies like search engines, spell checkers or speech recognition.
Dr. Lori Levin is a Research Professor in the Language Technologies Institute with an expertise in Machine Translation, Natural Language Processing and Computational Linguistics.
Low-resource scenarios for technology-rich languages like English may occur in specialized styles or subject areas, where machine learning is insufficient. In such cases, hybrids of human-engineered knowledge and machine learning can be used.
The main purpose of exploring how to use typology and universals in developing language technologies is to develop language technologies for new languages on short timelines or in low-resource scenarios.
The author suggests using a linguistic theory of construction grammar as an approach to annotation when time and data are available.
The Language Technologies Institute is located at 5000 Forbes Avenue, Pittsburgh, PA 15213-3891.
On the 'Connect' page, you can either login or logout.
Language technologies can be based on what is known about human languages in general or what is known about related languages.
The author suggests falling back on what is known about human languages in general or what is known about related languages.
Linguistic typology and universals provide expectations for what languages might be like, which can help in developing language technologies for new languages on short timelines or in low-resource scenarios.
The contact information of Language Technologies Institute includes their address at 5000 Forbes Avenue, Pittsburgh, PA 15213-3891 and phone number 412-268-6591. They can also be reached via email at ltiwebmaster@cs.cmu.edu.
Language technologies can be developed in situations with sufficient time and data, or when there is insufficient time or data to build an NLP system.
 The main focus of the text is on using linguistic representations to enhance performance in few-shot transfer settings for relation extraction across domains.
 High-quality data availability is considered a limitation in specialized domains for implementing machine learning based NLP methods because acquiring such data is time-consuming and expensive.
 The purpose of linguistic representations in this study is to encourage learning domain-agnostic representations of relations to help models generalize better in a few-shot setting.
 The two linguistic formalisms used in the study are dependency parses and abstract meaning representations (AMR).
 Procedural text is chosen for the study on relation extraction because it describes processes that share loose semantic correspondence across domains, making it easier to generalize.
 Linguistic structures benefit models by providing abstraction over the variation of natural language, allowing models to learn salient features of the input.
 Both AMR parses and dependencies significantly enhance model performance in few-shot settings, but the benefit diminishes when models have more training data.
 Linguistic representations are significant as they provide features that can act as cross-domain pivots, enhancing generalizability in few-shot transfer settings.
 Linguistic frameworks aim to help models generalize across domains by providing representations that express meaning in domain-general ways.
 The main difference is that AMR seeks to represent meaning at the sentence level in the form of a directed graph, while dependency parsing remains at a lower level of abstraction.
 An embedding layer, a stack of N transformer layers, and a prediction layer
 An attention module and several matrix multiplications
 Carefully managing I/O and reducing the complexity of the attention module
 Developing new model parallelism strategies for Transformer models
 Compressing the message size, especially the model gradients
 Low-rank updates, sparsification, and quantization
 Studying the effect of various compression techniques on tensor and pipeline parallelism in a cloud computing setting
 Learning-based compression algorithms are the most effective approach
 Tensor model parallelism and pipeline parallelism

 The focus is on the multilingual track of IWSLT 2023, which evaluates translation quality on scientific conference talks.
 The system translates into 10 languages of varying amounts of resources.
 A retrieval-based approach (kNN-MT) is used for effective adaptation.
 Adapters are used to easily integrate incremental training data.
 Cascaded systems outperform end-to-end systems on scientific talk translation.
 The main challenge is dealing with non-native speakers and varying recording conditions.
 Accurate translation of terminologies that rarely occur in the training data is crucial.
 Effective adaptation is crucial as no training data from the same domain is provided.
 The system leverages pretrained models including WavLM, mBART50, and DeltaLM.
 The ASR system is adapted using n-gram re-weighting and synthesized data for the target domain.
 Voice chains were found to exist for all 76 syndromes listed in Table A1.
 74 syndromes were considered in the analysis of voice chains.
 About 5% of the general population is reported to have speech pathologies.
 17 syndromes had both level-1 and level-2 voice chains.
 For all instances where level-1 voice chains are present, severe symptoms occurred 100% of the time.
 Level-1 voice chains co-occur with speech problems 100% of the time.
 Speech was reported to be normal in only 6 cases out of the 56 syndromes with level-2 voice chains.
 The chainlink connectivity refers to the total number of pathways that include the chainlink genes of a syndrome.
 Both the number of chainlink genes and the chainlink connectivity appear to relate monotonically to the severity of the speech disorder.
 The distributions of chainlink counts and chainlink connectivity are predictive of the type of speech problem.

 SUPERBs aggregates all task-specific scores st(u) with respect to baseline (i.e., FBANK) and state-of-the-art (SOTA) model on the task t.
 st,i(u) is the ith metrics for task t and SSL model u.
 Various analysis tools are provided including character error rate (CER), aggregated scores for different language groups, and visualizations of the learnable layer weights.
 The wav2vec2 model uses a contrastive learning approach that prioritizes identifying true quantized latent speech representations over masked time steps from distractors.
 The robust-wav2vec2-large model considers the diversity of speech types, such as read speech, conversational speech, and noisy speech, by including additional corpora in the pre-training stage.
 XLSR-128 achieves the best performance in the 1-hour set for the monolingual ASR task.
 Models trained using self-supervised learning (SSL) techniques have shown superior performance compared to the baseline model.
 Large models trained on monolingual data do not necessarily have better representations for multilingual scenarios.
 XLSR-128 has been the dominant model for both 10-minute and 1-hour datasets in the LID task.
 XLSR-128 is considered the best model overall in terms of performance.

 Small sub-networks influence global performance due to limited knowledge of the global model in the aggregation phase.
 SplitMix has an average performance degradation of 5.55% ± 0.81%.
 FEDEPTH shows 1.73% ± 0.34% degradation, while m-FEDEPTH shows 2.74% ± 0.97% degradation.
 The predefined scenario was Figure 6, where new clients with resources r = 2 joined and replaced clients with r = 1.
 The alternative way suggested is to train a new large base model from scratch and discard previously trained neural networks, then perform Model Knowledge Distillation (MKD).
 m-FEDEPTH always outperforms FEDEPTH for CIFAR-100.
 Replacing zero paddings with other modules may result in a better model, but it may come at the cost of extra memory due to new activations and parameters.
 HeteroFL and SplitMix perform worse than FedAvg on unbalanced Dirichlet partitions, with SplitMix even performing worse than training with the smallest models.
 FEDEPTH and m-FEDEPTH achieve substantial improvements of 6.15% and 6.53% on CIFAR-10, and 12.24% and 11.57% on CIFAR-100 compared to FedAvg.
 A learning rate of 5 x 10^4 and a training epoch of 100 are chosen for fine-tuning.

End of semester evaluation involves assessing student progress at the end of each academic term, typically through exams or projects.
Satisfactory progress refers to meeting the academic requirements and expectations set by the university, such as maintaining a certain GPA or completing coursework on time.
Academic integrity means adhering to ethical standards in academic work, including not plagiarizing others' ideas and properly citing sources.
Students can monitor their grades, meet with advisors regularly, and stay on top of coursework deadlines to ensure they are making satisfactory progress.
If a student fails to maintain satisfactory progress, they may face academic probation or even dismissal from the university. However, specific consequences can vary depending on individual circumstances.
Examples of Academic integrity violations include plagiarism (using someone else's work without proper citation), fabrication (making up data or information), and cheating on exams.
MIIS has several academic policies including double counting courses, duration of study, deferral, maximum and minimum course loads, transfer credit, and transferring into the MIIS program.
The policy states that students cannot take two courses with similar content in order to receive duplicate credits. This is known as 'double counting' and it is not allowed.
The duration of study varies depending on the program, but generally students are expected to complete their studies within 2 years for full-time programs and up to 4 years for part-time programs.
The policy allows students to request a temporary leave of absence from their studies. However, this must be approved by the school and may have certain conditions attached.
The policy states that students can take a maximum of 18 credits per semester, but they must also ensure they are not taking too few courses as this may affect their academic progress.
Yes, students can apply for transfer credits. However, the school will evaluate each course on a case-by-case basis and not all courses may be accepted.
Yes, students can apply to transfer into the MIIS program. However, they must meet certain requirements such as having completed a specific set of courses and achieving a minimum GPA.
Double counting refers to taking two courses with similar content in order to receive duplicate credits. This policy is not allowed at MIIS as it can lead to unnecessary repetition of coursework.
The school may approve a temporary leave of absence, but this is subject to certain conditions. These may include maintaining contact with academic advisors and ensuring that all financial obligations have been met.
The policy states that students can take a maximum of 18 credits per semester, but they must also ensure they are not taking too few courses as this may affect their academic progress. The minimum course load is determined by the student's program and schedule.

Carnegie Mellon University's main goal is to have a transformative impact on society through continual innovation in education, research, creativity, and entrepreneurship.
Carnegie Mellon University aims to create a transformative educational experience for students focused on deep disciplinary knowledge; problem solving; leadership, communication, and interpersonal skills; and personal health and well-being.
Carnegie Mellon University's mission is to create a transformative educational experience for students focused on deep disciplinary knowledge; problem solving; leadership, communication, and interpersonal skills; and personal health and well-being. The university also cultivates a transformative community committed to attracting and retaining diverse, world-class talent; creating a collaborative environment open to the free exchange of ideas, where research, creativity, innovation, and entrepreneurship can flourish; and ensuring individuals can achieve their full potential.

The MIIS degree provides advanced study and practical experience in areas of Computer Science focused on processing and analyzing unstructured or semi-structured information, such as text, image, video, speech, and audio.
The Language Technologies Institute (LTI), a graduate department in the School of Computer Science, offers the MIIS degree.
There are significant differences between CMU's different departments and degree programs in philosophical approach, procedures, policies.
The MIIS degree provides advanced study and practical experience in areas of Computer Science focused on processing and analyzing unstructured or semi-structured information, for example, text, image, video, speech, and audio information. It is a practice-oriented professional degree designed for students who want to rapidly master advanced content-analysis, mining, and intelligent information technologies prior to beginning or resuming leadership careers in industry and government.

Carnegie Mellon students are expected to meet the highest standards of personal, ethical, and moral conduct possible. This includes personal integrity, a commitment to honesty without compromise, truth without equivocation, and a willingness to place the good of the community above the good of the self.
Once an obligation is undertaken by a Carnegie Mellon student, it must be met. Commitments made are expected to be kept.
The life of a student in an academic community at Carnegie Mellon involves upholding the standards of the community and holding others accountable for those same standards.
The standards that must be observed in an academic community, as per this text, include acknowledging creativity of others, giving credit for prior knowledge, and trusting these principles will be observed.
The commitment of faculty, staff, and students to certain standards contributes to the high respect in which the Carnegie Mellon degree is held. Students must not destroy this respect by failing to meet these standards.

 They have investigated predicting a microphone closing token ⟨eos⟩ at the end of the utterance.

 The training criterion for AED models does not have a latent variable A for explicit alignment.
 E2E models provide mechanisms to solve the underlying sequence alignment problem, either explicitly or implicitly, while classical HMMs use explicit alignments only.
 A teacher-forcing technique is used.
 To fuse frozen text-only large language models (LLMs) with pre-trained image encoder and decoder models, by mapping between their embedding spaces.

 It is capable of conditioning on arbitrarily interleaved image and text inputs to generate coherent image (and text) outputs.

 The focus of the comparisons in Figure 16 is the BC column concentration between GRASP/Component BC retrieval and MERRA-2 BC over the Indo–China Peninsula (ICP) region.
 GRASP/Component BC retrieval and MERRA-2 BC show high BC column concentration in April and May, and low BC column concentration in July over the ICP region.
 A correlation coefficient of R = 0.89 and RMSE = 1.30 mg/m2 are obtained between GRASP/Component BC retrieval and MERRA-2 BC product in the ICP region.
 The BC column concentration of MERRA-2 is higher than those of GRASP/Component BC retrieval throughout the year over the ICP region.
 The focus of the comparisons in Figure 17 is the BC column concentration between GRASP/Component BC retrieval and MERRA-2 BC product over the North China Plain (NCP) region.
 Large discrepancies are found for all months except in June in the comparisons of monthly BC column concentration over the NCP region.
 A correlation coefficient of R = 0.46 and RMSE = 3.88 mg/m2 are found between GRASP/Component BC retrieval and MERRA-2 BC product in the NCP region.
 The BC column concentration of MERRA-2 is higher than those of GRASP/Component BC retrieval for all months over the NCP region.
 One reason mentioned is the emissions inventory assumption employed in models, specifically the discrepancy in anthropogenic BC emission trends in different inventories.
 The PKU inventory shows a decreasing trend of −1.4% per year in anthropogenic BC emission, while the CEDS inventory exhibits an increasing trend of 2.7% over eastern China from 2006 to 2014.
 OpenMatch-v2 directly operates on the raw TSV data to fetch the title and text and assemble them into the final input to the model.
 The distillation trainer fine-tunes dense retrieval models with the numeric, continuous training signals obtained from the re-ranker.
 Template-based data processing in OpenMatch-v2 simplifies the process of converting data into a compatible format for training and reduces manual effort.
 OpenMatch-v2 improves efficiency by introducing template-based data processing, which reduces the need for manual data-processing scripts and frees up researchers to focus on developing their core algorithms.
 OpenMatch-v2 integrates with HF Datasets to provide efficient data accessing by maintaining an on-disk cache in Arrow format and allowing direct iteration over the raw dataset from disk during training.
 OpenMatch-v2 introduces a shard-twice approach to break down the search process into smaller, more manageable steps, allowing for searching on large IR datasets with limited resources.
 The distillation trainer in OpenMatch-v2 can train models using either pairwise (using MarginMSE loss) or listwise (using KLDivLoss) fashion.
 OpenMatch-v2 reduces the need for manual data-processing scripts by introducing template-based data processing.
 TSV and JSONLINES formats are widely used for storing IR data according to OpenMatch-v2.
 The template in OpenMatch-v2 defines how the input should be built with the data in each field by replacing the key enclosed in angle brackets with its corresponding value during processing.
 This algorithm relies on general-purpose Embeddings from Language Models (Peters et al., 2018) to compute textual similarities between submissions and reviewers’ past papers.
 Specter algorithm employs more specialized document-level embeddings of scientiﬁc documents (Cohan et al., 2020).
 Specter+MFR further enhances Specter (Chang and McCallum, 2021) by constructing multiple embeddings of each paper that correspond to different facets of the paper.
 The key idea of the model training in the ACL algorithm is to split each abstract into two non-contiguous parts and treat two parts of the same abstract as a positive example.
 The ACL algorithm uses its own method to compute expertise between papers and reviewers.
 The procedure of profile construction and similarity prediction is repeated 10 times to average out randomness in the ACL algorithm.
 Conference organizers need to decide on the representation of paper content, such as using the title and abstract, for similarity-computation algorithms.
 Reviewer profiles are constructed automatically by using the 20 most recent papers from Semantic Scholar profiles of reviewers.
 The TPMS algorithm is chosen as a baseline for comparison due to its simplicity.
 To build confidence intervals for the difference in performance, 1,000 iterations are run and new reviewer pools are sampled with replacement.

 The main idea is to improve initial outputs from large language models through iterative feedback and refinement without the need for supervised training data.
 SELF-REFINE improves the performance of outputs generated by large language models across various tasks, making them preferred by both humans and automatic metrics.
 Iterative self-refinement involves creating an initial output and refining it based on self-provided feedback, similar to how humans refine their work through reflection and revision.
 The two main generative steps are FEEDBACK and REFINE, which work together to generate high-quality outputs through iterative refinement.
 SELF-REFINE uses few-shot prompting to guide the model in generating feedback and integrating it into an improved draft.
 SELF-REFINE outperforms direct generation from strong language models by achieving 5-40% absolute improvement in various tasks.
 SELF-REFINE was evaluated across 7 diverse tasks, including dialog response generation, mathematical reasoning, natural language generation, and source-code generation.
 SELF-REFINE does not require supervised training data, additional training, or reinforcement learning, relying solely on a single language model for generation, refinement, and feedback.
 The process iterates between feedback and refinement until a specified number of iterations is reached or until the model determines that no further refinement is necessary.
 SELF-REFINE provides an effective way to obtain better outputs from a single model without additional training, demonstrating that even state-of-the-art language models can be further improved at test-time.

 The two contributors are cross-lingual transfer and concept shift.
 The cross-lingual transfer gap is thought of as the difference, while the remaining difference is attributed to the concept shift.
 The results represent upper bounds for concept shift and cross-lingual shift.
 The concept shift gap is generally greater.
 The concept shift gap exceeds the cross-lingual transfer gap for all languages except Swahili.
 For Indonesian (id), zero-shot performance itself is close to English performance for XLM-R.
 The performance of Hindi and Indonesian increases significantly with larger models and more training data.
 Investing in few-shot in-language task-specific examples provides vast improvements over the zero-shot setup.
 The performance gain from few-shot transfer was generally modest.
 Kannada, Swahili, and Sundanese benefited more greatly from augmentation with additional examples.

 As the weighted average of the delays of all first-unchanged messages based on their length

 Obtain a set of query- and seed-specific metric values, average them over seeds, and then compute statistical significance using a paired difference test.
 The cost of generation for the GPT-3 Curie model is estimated to be $0.002 per one thousand tokens.
 The estimated cost can be up to $100 for collections like Robust04 and TREC-COVID.
 The estimated cost of generation in the InPars-light study is under $10 per collection.
 The throughput exceeds 500 passages per second.
 Cohere AI provides re-ranking with neural models as a cloud service.
 The all-domain pretraining of the DeBERTA-v3-435M model took about 28 hours.
 The total effectiveness evaluation time for the DeBERTA-v3-435M model was about 6 hours.
 Three seeds were used for training the rankers.
 The procedure is considered in the future as an alternative for carrying out consistency checking.
 The study focuses on evaluating hallucinations in Language Model Multimodal (LMM) responses.
 The LLM is based on Vicuna and utilizes the pre-trained CLIP visual encoder, ViT-L/14.
 The response length, measured in the number of tokens, is incorporated as a penalizing factor to control hallucinations in LMMs.
 The RL models have similar architectures to the base LLaVA model, but the reward model outputs a scalar value indicating the reward of the response.
 The MMHAL-BENCH evaluation metrics focus on detecting hallucinations in LMM responses, while previous benchmarks evaluate response quality in a more general sense.
 The MMHAL-BENCH includes questions related to object attributes, adversarial objects, comparisons, counting, spatial relations, environment, holistic descriptions, and others.
 The image-question pairs are designed to cause hallucinations in LMM responses, ensuring that LMMs make false claims about the image contents when answering these questions.
 Researchers select images from the validation and test sets of OpenImages and design brand-new questions to avoid data leakage or evaluation on data that LMMs have observed during training.
 The powerful GPT-4 model is used to analyze and rate LMM responses by comparing them against image contents and human-generated answers provided in the prompt.
 GPT-4 is used to determine whether hallucinations exist in LMM responses by comparing them against image contents and human-generated answers, as the GPT-4 model can only assess text inputs.
 The motivation is that relevant documents would contain similar entities contained in the query, so it is important that the query also makes part of the entity matrix.
 The parameter 𝛾 controls the weight balance between the entities in the query vector and the entities in the top passages matrix.
 The unrolled expression is represented as the product of the query vector and the top passages entity matrix with weights determined by 𝛾.
 The purpose is to design a more informative, conversation-specific weighting scheme using passage rank scores to signal the presence of entities in passages and the query.
 The scores of each passage entity of CP are computed based on the full-text retrieval ranker scores, RS.
 The original multi-hot binary encoding is used as the weighting scheme for the entities in the query vector CQ.
 Eigenvector methods are used as an implementation of random walks to estimate entity centrality scores.
 The EC scores are computed as a combination of the graph structure, damping factor, and the centrality scores of entity i.
 The scoring vector is based on the dot product between EC scores and the entity-passage matrix CP.
 The purpose is to balance the original scores from the full-text retrieval ranker with the entity centrality scores to improve the ranking of passages.

 The function of the distinguishability metric is to measure how well CodeBERTScore can differentiate between similar and dissimilar code snippets.
 The distinguishability metric shows that CodeBERTScore achieves higher distinguishability scores than CrystalBLEU for both Java and C++ datasets.
 The distinguishability metric can be manipulated by exponentiating the output score of CodeBERTScore, resulting in inflated distinguishability scores.
 Distinguishability is not considered reliable because it can be easily manipulated by comparing absolute scores across different metrics.
 The text suggests that comparing metrics based on how they rank different examples is more reliable than comparing them based on exact scores.
 Figure 8 illustrates how distinguishability increases exponentially when the original CodeBERTScore is exponentiated by different values of k.
 The text recommends comparing metrics based on how they rank different examples rather than relying on exact scores for a more reliable comparison.
 The purpose of providing additional examples is to showcase scenarios where CodeBERTScore outperforms the best baseline metric by preferring functionally correct predictions.
 The motivation behind showing the C++ example in Figure 10 is to highlight a scenario where CodeBERTScore ranks a functionally correct prediction higher than the best baseline metric.
 The Java example in Figure 9 aims to demonstrate how CodeBERTScore favors the functionally correct prediction over an incorrect one by ranking it higher.
 The results show that neither too small nor too large a dimensionality is useful for the proposed tasks, and there is little interaction between task type and dimensionality.
 Model ranking based on each task is very similar across dimensions, with Spearman and Pearson correlations of 0.61 and 0.79, respectively.
 Similarly to changing the dimensionality, the individual tasks react to changing the training data size without an effect of the task variable.
 Phonological features, especially articulatory features, play a strong role in phonology by capturing the similarity between sounds.
 The articulatory feature set employed by PanPhon originates in the Sound Pattern of English by Chomsky and Halle (1968).
 Applications include cognate/loanword detection, multilingual named entity recognition, keyphrase extraction, spelling correction, phonotactic learning, and more.
 Training with phoneme embeddings can reduce errors from confusing phonetically similar words in automatic speech recognition.
 One limitation is that the models train on phonemic transcriptions, which cannot capture finer-grained phonetic distinctions.
 The proposed future work includes enlarging the pool of languages and including more tasks.
 Phonological word embeddings serve as a tool to study what phonological and phonetic features are encoded by speakers for linguistic analysis.

Students may request to transfer into the MIIS program after completing their first semester and before the add/drop deadline of the spring semester. The student must make the request in writing (or email) to the MIIS Program Director.
The MIIS program will conduct an expedited admissions process after receiving such a request. The program will explicitly consider whether the coursework done prior to the transfer will allow the student to be “on schedule” by the end of the spring semester, so that the student can participate in a capstone project with other MIIS students during the next fall semester.

An open elective is a course that can be taken as an option for students who are exempt from a required course due to prior courses or experience.
Units of credit refer to the amount of academic work that is equivalent to one hour of class time per week for a semester. If a student receives credit, they receive that many units.

The two accommodations for gestational parents at Carnegie Mellon University are Short-Term Accommodation and Long-Term Accommodation.
The maximum duration of a Short-Term Accommodation for gestational parents at Carnegie Mellon University is six (6) weeks.
The duration of a Short-Term Accommodation for gestational parents at Carnegie Mellon University may be extended by two (2) weeks, for a total of eight (8) weeks, where a longer absence is medically necessary.
Before taking a Short-Term Accommodation, students must work with relevant university faculty and staff to adjust their course work, research, teaching and other academic responsibilities during the period of absence.
If a student takes a Short-Term Accommodation, they will remain enrolled at Carnegie Mellon University.
The purpose of Long-Term Accommodation for gestational parents is to provide a longer absence from academic responsibilities, up to a maximum of six (6) weeks.

 Some tools used in Android development to identify performance issues include linters like PMD and FindBugs.
 Warnings from Android linters are often considered false-positives because developers must manually verify and fix the detected issues.
 Refactoring approaches aim to modify the source code of the application to be more performant, such as by executing code asynchronously.
 Offloading computation to external servers can reduce energy usage, extend battery life, and make the app more responsive by speeding up computation.
 Commonly used programming languages in Android app development include Java, Kotlin, and C/C++ for native code.
 Genetic Improvement (GI) is a search-based software engineering technique used to find improved program variants by iterating over different versions of software.
 GI patches are constructed from a set of edits to code, known as mutations, which describe modifications to the program being improved.
 The fitness function is used to measure the effectiveness of GI patches in terms of desired outcomes such as passing tests or execution time improvement.
 Genetic Improvement (GI) differs from traditional software improvement techniques by using search-based optimization to find improved program variants through iterative changes.
 GI is considered fully automated because developers only need to review the patches produced by GI once the process is finished, ensuring no unintended side effects.

 The main focus is to jointly prune heterogeneous components (CNN and Transformer) of speech SSL models.
 HJ-Pruning significantly reduces the total computation while retaining good performance in ASR and SLU.
 LightHuBERT deploys once-for-all training to obtain weight-sharing subnets.
 It requires an expensive two-stage training process and an advanced distillation loss.
 Compressing Hu-BERT Base takes 62 hours with 32 V100 GPUs and 19 hours with 8 GPUs for two stages, respectively.
 The objective is to learn a sparse model through L0 regularization.
 The masks z follow a probability distribution q(z; α) with parameters α.
 The loss function L measures the difference between two feature sequences using a combination of L1 and cosine distances.
 In Step 1, the student model is jointly distilled and pruned to generate a smaller model with a pre-specified size.
 It is due to the discrete nature of masks z, which makes the loss non-differentiable.

Scotty is a character from Star Trek.
In the show, Scotty is the chief engineer of the USS Enterprise.
Scotty originated on Earth but was assigned to serve as the chief engineer of the USS Enterprise.
Scotty's full name is Montgomery Scott, or just plain 'Scotty' for short.
In general, Scotty seems to enjoy and take pride in his work as chief engineer of the USS Enterprise.
One unique ability that Scotty possesses is his exceptional knowledge of engineering, particularly when it comes to repairing and maintaining the USS Enterprise's systems.
Scotty frequently says 'I cannae do that Captain!' which is a humorous way of saying he needs more time or resources to complete the task at hand.
Scotty's character adds humor and depth to the show, as well as providing a competent and resourceful engineer who is crucial for the success of the USS Enterprise's missions.
Scotty has a high level of respect for Captain Kirk, often referring to him as 'the captain' and showing loyalty towards his commanding officer.
Carnegie Mellon adopted a Scottish terrier as their official mascot because Andrew Carnegie, founder of the university, kept a Scottish terrier as his pet.
The decision to adopt a Scottish terrier as Carnegie Mellon's official mascot was made in 2006.
The co-chairs of the Mascot Identity Task Force were Director of Athletics Susan Bassett and Dean of Student Affairs Jennifer Church.
Nearly 78 percent of 2,370 students surveyed in February 2007 voted for a Scottish terrier.
The Task Force partnered with SME Branding, a firm with more than 17 years of experience creating mascots for professional sports teams and universities.
Carnegie Mellon's official Scottish terrier mascot debuted at the Nov. 10, 2007 home football game.
Carnegie Mellon's Scottish terrier mascot features a profile of a distinguished, bold Scottish terrier sporting a plaid scarf around his neck. The dog is contained in a shield, representing Carnegie Mellon's Scottish heritage.
The official Scotty costume was unveiled at the 2008 Spring Carnival.
According to the text, the Scottish terrier breed is known for its keen, alert and intelligent expression. Its temperament is described as determined and thoughtful while its physical aspects exemplify strength, power and agility.

 The search space is vast because for a two hidden layer fully connected neural network with 100 neurons in each layer and training with 100 epochs, the cardinality of the search space is 2 x 10^6.
 Traditional NAS methods necessitate concurrent training of both network architecture and network weights, resulting in computational requirements that substantially exceed those of standard model training.
 The automated low-rank factorized training method introduced in the paper is called CUTTLEFISH.
 CUTTLEFISH performs lightweight profiling to identify the layers to factorize, ensuring that factorization occurs only in layers that can effectively enhance the training speed.
 CUTTLEFISH observes that factorizing early layers in CNNs does not lead to considerable speedups.
 The stable ranks of neural network (NN) layers initially change rapidly and then converge to a constant mean.
 CUTTLEFISH automatically selects all factorization hyperparameters during training on-the-fly, eliminating the need for multiple experimental trials for factorization hyperparameter tuning.
 The Lottery Ticket Hypothesis (LTH) suggests that smaller, randomly initialized subnetworks can be trained to attain accuracy levels comparable to those of the full network.
 Sparsity methods mainly focus on unstructured sparsity, which does not yield actual speedups on current hardware, unlike low-rank training which can lead to tangible acceleration.
 The focus of the research is low-latency speech translation.
 It is important to evaluate different approaches to low-latency speech translation to compare and improve the effectiveness of such systems.
 The proposed framework allows for evaluating various aspects of low-latency speech translation in realistic scenarios and comparing different approaches.
 Low-latency speech translation is particularly important in scenarios like presentations or meetings.
 Some components include Speech processing, Text processing, Website, Mediator, API, Audio Client.
 The system uses a central mediator that coordinates the interaction of different components and dynamically defines how data is sent to different components for each session.
 The main contributions are a framework for low-latency speech translation with dynamic latency adjustment, an evaluation setup for assessing low-latency scenarios, and a comprehensive evaluation of different translation approaches and streaming algorithms.
 The system minimizes increasing latency in high-load situations by enabling the middleware to skip intermediate processing steps and combining multiple input messages.
 The central mediator coordinates the interaction of different components and forwards data between the user, API, and processing components.
 Each component in the system, such as the middleware and backend, enables flexible processing with the help of the streaming framework Kafka.

 One of the main drawbacks is that it is susceptible to erroneous pseudo labels that arise from confirmation biases in the source domain.
 The reliance on only photometric cues may lead to suboptimal adaptation in self-training methods.
 The proposed method is to incorporate structural cues from auxiliary modalities, such as depth, to regularize conventional self-training objectives.
 The contrastive pixel-level objectness constraint pulls pixel representations within a region of an object instance closer, while pushing those from different object categories apart.
 The objectness constraint is agnostic to ground-truth semantic labels because it is used to improve unsupervised domain adaptation.
 The regularizer significantly improves the top performing self-training methods (by up to 2 points) in various UDA benchmarks for semantic segmentation.
 The blue-dashed-boxes represent high-confidence regions that are likely to be included in the set of pseudo-labels despite being mis-classified.
 An important limitation is the excessive cost and time taken to annotate images at a pixel-level.
 Self-training based adaptation is susceptible to erroneous pseudo labels arising from confirmation bias in the seed model, which can lead to sub-optimal performance.
 The proposed method aims to incorporate auxiliary modality information such as depth maps to provide structural cues, in addition to photometric cues.
 top-k and nucleus sampling (or top-p)
 It becomes easier to detect whether a writing sample was generated by a language model or human-written, and it helps in reducing biases introduced by decoding settings.
 It helps in detecting generated text and uncovering biases caused by decoding settings which truncate a model’s predicted distributions.
 They are deployed in APIs and websites that allow users to input prompts and receive generated text.
 To identify the decoding strategy employed for text generation, even in a blackbox setting.
 Because it only allows generating one output for a given prompt and tends to produce repetitive and low-quality text.
 Tokens are chosen from the k most likely items, where all other items are assigned a score of 0 before sampling.
 To reduce entropy in the distribution before sampling to prevent text from being too erratic and error-prone.
 Top-k sampling selects a fixed number of most likely items (k) while top-p sampling selects items to cover a fixed proportion (p) of the total probability mass.
 They require more complex implementations and are not the focus of the current paper.

 The TDT architecture jointly predicts a token and its duration during sequence-to-sequence tasks.
 TDT models can skip input frames guided by the predicted duration output, which makes them significantly faster than Transducers that process the encoder output frame by frame.
 Improvements include the replacement of LSTM encoders with Transformers, Contextnet, and Conformers, as well as exploring different decoders like stateless decoders and Echo State Networks.
 The TDT model introduces a novel architecture that jointly predicts tokens and durations, achieving better accuracy and faster inference in various sequence transduction tasks.
 ESPNet, NeMo, Espresso, and SpeechBrain are some of the toolkits mentioned with efficient implementations for speech recognition models.
 FastEmit introduces biases in the gradient update of the transducer loss to reduce latency during inference.
 TDT models improve the intent accuracy by up to over 1% (absolute) compared to conventional Transducers, while also running up to 1.28X faster.
 The predicted token duration can direct the model decoding algorithm to skip frames during inference, leading to faster computation.
 LRNNT(y|x) represents the log-probability of an audio utterance x with corresponding text y, requiring summing over all possible ways to augment the text sequence to match the audio.
 The TDT model implementation will be open-sourced with the NeMo toolkit.

 The main focus of the paper is on accelerating diffusion-based combinatorial optimization solvers by progressive distillation.
 The proposed method is to use progressive distillation to take fewer steps during the denoising process.
 The progressively distilled model can perform inference 16 times faster with only a 0.019% degradation in performance on the TSP-50 dataset.
 A significant portion of combinatorial optimization problems fall into the category of NP-complete problems.
 Traditional approximation algorithms often demand an extensive degree of mathematical understanding specific to each individual problem.
 DRL models focus on training an agent to learn heuristics for solving CO problems by interacting with its environment.
 Diffusion-based methods are inefficient in inference due to the non-trivial number of inference steps required to produce satisfactory results.

 HBP hypointensity in hepatocellular carcinoma indicates microvascular invasion (MVI).
 Hepatocellular carcinoma with MVI-positive was confirmed by histopathology.
 HBP stands for hepatobiliary phase, and MVI stands for microvascular invasion.
 The presence of a radiological capsule helps to predict MVI status in patients without peritumoral HBP hypointensity.
 The presence of a satellite nodule was identified as an independent risk factor for intrahepatic recurrence in patients without peritumoral HBP hypointensity.
 Tumor size greater than 5 cm had a hazard ratio of 2.928 in predicting intrahepatic recurrence in patients without peritumoral HBP hypointensity.
 Patients without peritumoral HBP hypointensity and satellite nodule had a low risk of intrahepatic recurrence.
 The two-step flowchart is developed to stratify intrahepatic recurrence risk based on peritumoral HBP hypointensity and satellite nodule presence.
 The presence of the mosaic sign was identified as a prognostic factor for intrahepatic recurrence in patients without peritumoral HBP hypointensity.
 The median time to intrahepatic recurrence after curative hepatic resection was 7 months.

The author of 'The Kiltie Band' is Robert Louis Stevenson.
The main theme of 'The Kiltie Band' is a group of boys who form a band and their adventures together.
The boys in the story live in Scotland, specifically in Edinburgh.
The band formed by the boys in 'The Kiltie Band' is called The Kilties.
The boys want to form a band because they are inspired by their music teacher, Mr. Sinclair, and his love for music.
In 'The Kiltie Band', Davie plays the drums.
The boys come up with the name 'The Kilties' by combining the word 'kilt,' which is a traditional Scottish garment, and '-ties,' to represent their friendship.
At the end of 'The Kiltie Band', the boys perform in front of a large audience and receive great applause, indicating that they have succeeded as musicians.
Mr. Sinclair is the music teacher who inspires the boys to form a band and helps them practice and improve their musical skills.
The Kiltie Band began in 1908 with a group of just seven students dedicated to supporting Carnegie Tech football.
The Kiltie Marching Band consists of musicians and colorguard and plays at all Carnegie Mellon home football games.
After football season, the Kiltie Concert Band plays a holiday concert and two spring concerts, including a performance at Carnegie Mellon’s Spring Carnival.
A part of the band gets together and acts as a pep band for the basketball teams.
The Kiltie Band is a campus organization recognized by Student Senate.
During football season, the Kiltie Marching Band practices Mondays and Thursdays from 5:30 p.m.-7:30 p.m., with a Game Day practice at 9:30-11:00 a.m.
During the concert season, the Kiltie Band practices Mondays and Thursdays from 5:30-6:30 p.m.
No, any member of the campus community with music experience is able to join the Kiltie Band!
No, the music is changed for every show. You should invest in a good and trusty lyre.
