No, the music is changed for every show. You should invest in a good and trusty lyre.
On the first day of class (Monday) at 5:30 p.m. in the CUC Studio Theater.
There are several Kiltie-owned instruments available for your use. Loans begin at 4:30 p.m. before the first rehearsal.
Join and you’ll find out! For more information, visit the Kiltie Band website .

 The purpose of an RNN-T model is to transform input speech frames into a high-level representation, and to model the sequence of non-blank labels that have been output previously.
 The prediction network in an RNN-T model generates output labels by producing the previous non-blank label sequence.
 The joint network in an RNN-T model produces a probability distribution over the output symbols given the prediction network state and a specific encoded frame.
 An RNN-T model reduces some of the independence assumptions in CTC by making the output at a given time dependent on the sequence of previous non-blank predictions.
 In an RNN-T model, the blank symbol represents the termination of a sequence of zero or more symbols in C for each input encoder frame.
 The set ARNNT(X,C) in an RNN-T model represents all valid alignment sequences of T + L symbols in C∗b, which are identical to C after removing all blanks.
 The purpose of the recurrent neural aligner (RNA) model is to define a probability distribution over blank-augmented labels and to remove conditional independence assumptions from the RNN-T model.
 In the RNA model, valid alignments consist of length T sequences in C∗b with exactly T-L blank symbols and are identical to C after removing all blanks.
 The prediction network state in an RNN-T model depends on the previously output non-blank labels, while in an RNA model, it depends on the entire alignment sequence.
 The RNA model is only allowed to output a single label – either blank or non-blank – in a single frame, unlike the RNN-T model.
 Table 2 shows the strict accuracy (Top Min) of cross-encoder compared to bi-encoder Recall@min for various tasks.
 Multilingual R@min refers to the strict accuracy of the bi-encoder under Top Min conditions.
 System (d) is the only hierarchy-aware system that outperforms the baseline across all metrics.
 The large performance gap of cross-encoders between the two tasks confirms that the crosslingual setting is more challenging.
 Cross-encoders enhance bi-encoder performance on the test set in multilingual tasks.
 Table 3 presents the hierarchical relation extraction results of a set-based approach using the retrieved candidates by the best performing bi-encoder.
 The proposed method demonstrates high rankings for true parents on both tasks, showing its capability in aiding humans to discover new hierarchical relations.
 The Wikinews dataset is used to evaluate the performance of the baseline and the two hierarchy-aware linking systems.
 The paper presents the task of hierarchical event grounding using a multilingual dataset with Wikipedia and Wikidata.
 Some potential future directions include adapting encoders to include hierarchy directly and exploring hierarchical relation extraction on standard datasets.
 The stress ratio is directly proportional to the crack length.
 The effective length of the crack tip decreases, leading to a sudden increase in crack tip stress and a sudden change in the crack propagation rate.
 An increase in thickness leads to a downward curve shift in the K-a relationship, showing that thickness is inversely proportional to K.
 The stress intensity factor decreases as thickness increases, resulting in a lower crack growth rate.
 The critical value of rapid fracture cycles at a thickness of 10 mm was approximately 335,330 cycles.
 Some forms of corrosion pit mentioned are conical, cylindrical, etc.
 Stress ratios of 0.1, 0.2, 0.3, and 0.5 were used.
 The curves of corroded specimens fluctuate and experience a sharp-slow-sharp growth process.
 ASTM E647-15 provides guidance on the thickness of the CT specimen.
 Increasing thickness results in a lower crack growth rate.
 The goal of the adversary is to estimate k while keeping n as small as possible.
 The ideal prompt m gives responses that are perfectly uniform over the entire vocabulary V.
 The number of unique items in a set of responses can be observed by calling Gen(m) n number of times, each time keeping the first token of the output.
 It is exceedingly difficult to engineer a prompt that gives perfectly uniform distributions over the entire vocabulary.
 The construction of a prompt m that distributes substantial probability mass onto a subset Vm of the token space is the key building block.
 The algorithm estimates p by using two prompts m1 and m2 that return responses from known distributions, calculating the average of the estimated p values from m1 and m2.
 The top-p reverse engineering problem reduces to top-k when given a known distribution.
 This approach ensures robustness against an imperfectly guessed distribution, especially when prompts including exemplars create biases in the returned tokens.
 Using such prompts reduces the error in estimating p, which is determined by how close the guessed distribution is to the true underlying one.
 The algorithm uses the actual distributions over tokens for distribution matching by summing the k largest in-vocabulary probabilities, ensuring consistency.

 To address critical areas of function absent from existing HRQOL measurement systems

 The Unlimiformer approach allows for processing unlimited input sequences by offloading cross-attention computation to a single k-nearest-neighbor (kNN) index.
 Unlimiformer aims to extend the capabilities of existing pretrained encoder-decoder transformers to accept inputs of unbounded length at test time.
 Unlimiformer achieves this by allowing every attention head in every decoder layer to retrieve its top-k keys from a k-nearest-neighbor (kNN) index, rather than attending to every key.
 Unlimiformer is especially useful for tasks involving long narratives, such as book summarization, where inputs can exceed 500k tokens.
 Unlimiformer does not require further training of position embeddings or global attention weights, making it a more computationally efficient solution for handling long inputs.
 Datasets with inputs that are many times longer than the maximum input length of traditional models can benefit from Unlimiformer.
 By performing a k-nearest-neighbor (kNN) search to select a set of per-attention-head tokens to attend to from the full-length input.
 Unlimiformer not only outperforms strong long-range transformers like LED and PRIMERA but can also be applied on top of such models to further improve their performance.
 Unlimiformer uses a k-nearest-neighbor (kNN) index to allow the model to attend only to the top-k keys, which covers more than 99% of the attention mass.
 The kNN index can be stored in either GPU or CPU memory and can be queried in sub-linear time, making it a memory-efficient solution.
 Removing frames of blank predictions (P3)
 Training the decoder-only model from scratch was slightly worse than the conventional encoder-decoder model
 30 epochs
 Advantage in computational speed with 0.29 of RTF against 0.54
 Text augmentation using an external text-only corpus (D1)
 Fine-tuning using the paired data (F1)
 Baseline EncDec model
 To enhance the model with LM training without any modification
 Fusing both CTC and LM (D3)
 Scaling up the decoder to have more capacity for LM while maintaining the advantage in inference speed
 LMs provide a prior probability distribution, P(C), for a given sentence C.
 The probability distribution P(C) is computed as P(C) = Π(i=1 to L+1) P(ci|c0:i−1) where ci represents the i-th token of C.
 N-gram LMs rely on the Markov assumption that the probability distribution of the next token depends only on the previous N-1 tokens.
 Smoothing techniques are applied to avoid estimating probabilities based on zero or very small counts for rare token sequences in N-gram models.
 The FNN-LM outperforms classical N-gram LMs due to its distributed representation of each token and history, leading to better generalization.
 The RNN-LM can exploit longer contextual information over N-1 previous tokens using recurrent connections, allowing it to outperform other N-gram-based models in many tasks.
 Convolutional neural networks in ConvLMs replace the recurrent connections used in RNN-LMs with gated temporal convolutions for computing hidden vectors.
 The FNN-LM estimates N-gram probabilities using a neural network and provides a better generalization than classical N-gram LMs.
 The RNN-LM computes the hidden vector as a recurrent function of the input token and the previous hidden vector, allowing it to hold longer contextual information.
 N-gram LMs suffer from data sparsity problems and poor generalization due to their reliance on discrete representations of tokens and history.

FERPA stands for Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act, a federal law that protects student's privacy rights.
Under FERPA, students have the right to inspect their education records and request amendment of inaccurate records. They also have the right to consent to disclosure of personally identifiable information.
Students can find more information about this university policy on the official website, which is https://www.cmu.edu/policies/student-and-student-life/privacy-rights-students.
PCHE stands for Precollege Honors Experience, a program that offers high school students the opportunity to take college courses at Carnegie Mellon University.
PCHE course may not count towards full-time status unless the student is enrolled in an inter-university program.
FERPA protects students' privacy rights by ensuring that their education records are kept confidential and can only be accessed with the student's consent.
Students have the right to inspect and review their education records, request an amendment to their education record if they believe it is inaccurate or misleading, request a hearing if their request for an amendment is not resolved to their satisfaction.
Yes, students have the right to give written consent before any personally identifiable information from their education record is disclosed to anyone other than school officials with legitimate educational interests.
If a student's request for an amendment to their education record is not resolved to their satisfaction, they have the right to request a hearing.
Inspecting and reviewing means that students can look at their education records and ask for copies of them. They may also request an amendment if they believe the record is inaccurate or misleading.
Personally identifiable information refers to data that, alone or in combination, can be used to identify a student. This includes but is not limited to the student’s name, address, date of birth, social security number, or other identifier.
Students have several rights related to their education records. They can inspect and review them, request an amendment if they believe the record is inaccurate or misleading, request a hearing if their request for an amendment is not resolved to their satisfaction, and consent to disclosure of personally identifiable information from their education records.
Education records are those records that directly relate to a student and are maintained by an educational agency or institution, or by a person acting for such agency or institution.
Disclosure refers to the act of releasing personally identifiable information from a student’s education record to anyone other than school officials with legitimate educational interests.
The purpose of allowing students to request an amendment to their education record is to ensure that inaccurate or misleading information about a student can be corrected.
Legitimate educational interests refer to the need for school officials to access education records in order to perform their job responsibilities or conduct research and studies that benefit students.
FERPA authorizes disclosure without consent.
Students can contact John Papinchak in Enrollment Services.

The mission of the Office of Disability Resources at Carnegie Mellon University is to provide physical, digital, and programmatic access to ensure that students with disabilities have equal access to their educational experience. The office works to ensure that qualified individuals receive reasonable accommodations as guaranteed by the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973.
Students who would like to receive accommodations can begin the process through Disability Resources' secure online portal or email access@andrew.cmu.edu to begin the interactive accommodation Process.
Students with physical, sensory, cognitive, or emotional disabilities are encouraged to self- identify with the Office of Disability Resources and request needed accommodations.
Any questions about the process can be directed to access@andrew.cmu.edu, or call (412) 268- 6121.

The Graduate Student Assembly (GSA) is a branch of the Carnegie Mellon Student Government that represents and advocates for all graduate students' interests.
GSA representatives are made up of individuals from different graduate programs and departments who aim to improve the graduate student experience at various levels within the university.
GSA receives its funding through the Student Activities Fee paid by all graduate students.
GSA is responsible for passing legislation, allocating student activities funding, advocating for local and national legislative action on behalf of graduate student issues, and acting as a representative body for all graduate students' interests.
GSA has recently passed legislation, allocated student activities funding, advocated for local and national legislative action on behalf of graduate student issues, and acted as a representative body for all graduate students' interests.
The purpose of GSA's recent actions is to improve the graduate student experience at different levels within the university, advocate for legislative action on behalf of graduate students' issues and needs, and represent all graduate students' interests.
GSA represents the diverse interests of all graduate students by advocating on their behalf at different levels within the university and in Washington D.C.
The Student Activities Fee, paid by all graduate students, funds GSA's activities such as passing legislation, allocating student activities funding, and advocating for local and national legislative action on behalf of graduate student issues.
Having a Graduate Student Assembly ensures that the diverse interests and needs of all graduate students are represented and advocated for, improving their overall experience within the university.
 The phonatory module equips a diffusion-based voice generation model with a voice code 𝑒 as a condition to conduct voice style cloning to help us understand the relationship between face geometry and voice characteristics.
 The three types of AMs computed are proportion, angle, and distance.
 During training, the loss for each segment is computed individually and then averaged as the training loss.
 The objective is to produce a small variance for the uncertainty estimator if the prediction error is small and vice versa, indicating a close prediction to the ground truth.
 The predicted AM and its uncertainty are given by aggregating the predictions among all segments, assuming the short segments are class-conditionally independent.
 To successfully reject the null hypothesis, a learned estimator 𝐹𝑘 (𝑣) must perform better than the chance-level estimator 𝐶𝑘 without using voice input, with statistically significant results.
 The null hypothesis states that the Abstract Measure (AM) 𝑚 (𝑘 ) is NOT predictable from voice.
 The uncertainty of the predicted 𝑘-th AM is calibrated by multiplying the computed aggregated variance by the number of voice segments in the long recording.
 The more reasonable learning objective is to minimize the Kullback-Leibler (KL) divergence between the predicted variances when the predicted variances are small.
 The purpose is to identify AMs that are predictable from voice by comparing the performance of estimators with and without the voice input, rejecting the null hypothesis for AMs that are predictable.
 The goal for participants is to propose effective automatic dialogue evaluation metrics that exhibit specific properties and perform well in a multilingual setup.
 Participants were asked to propose a single multilingual model that could provide high correlations with human-annotations in multilingual dialogues and perform well in the hidden multilingual test set.
 Participants were required to use pre-trained multilingual models and train them to predict quality metrics using self-supervised techniques.
 The models were expected to perform well in English, Spanish, and Chinese.
 The datasets included open-domain human-human conversations and human-chatbot interactions.
 The training set consisted of 393,000 dialogues, totaling approximately 3 million turns.
 The data was automatically translated back and forth using the high-quality MS Azure translation service.
 The development data was intended to help participants verify the multilingualism and robustness capabilities of their models in terms of correlations with human-annotations.
 The human-chatbot interactions dataset annotations were obtained through manual annotation and translations using various services.
 Participants were provided with quality annotations and machine translation Quality Estimation (QE) metric scores using the QE COMET system.

The course codes and their respective titles are as follows: 54808 - Pedagogy for Creative Writing, 54809 - Teaching Practicum, 54813 - Advanced Artisan Draping, 54819 - Figure Drawing, 54820 - Costume Forum, and 54823 - Directors' Generative Process.
The classes and their respective days and times are as follows: Pedagogy for Creative Writing (Wednesday, 2:00 PM - 2:50 PM), Teaching Practicum (Tuesday, 9:00 AM - 11:50 AM), Advanced Artisan Draping (Friday, 9:00 AM - 11:50 AM), Figure Drawing (Thursday, 2:00 PM - 3:20 PM), Costume Forum (Saturday, 12:30 PM - 1:20 PM), and Directors' Generative Process (TBA).
The classes and their respective locations are as follows: Pedagogy for Creative Writing, Teaching Practicum, Advanced Artisan Draping, Figure Drawing, Costume Forum, and Directors' Generative Process all take place at PCA (Pittsburgh Center for the Arts).
The instructors for each class are as follows: 54808 - Pedagogy for Creative Writing is taught by Young, 54809 - Teaching Practicum is taught by Handel, 54813 - Advanced Artisan Draping and 54823 - Directors' Generative Process are both taught by Weild. The instructor for 54819 - Figure Drawing is Hanson, while Zamborsky teaches 54820 - Costume Forum.
The classes and their respective credit hours and meeting times are as follows: Pedagogy for Creative Writing (6.0, Wednesday, 2:00 PM - 2:50 PM), Teaching Practicum (9.0, Tuesday, 9:00 AM - 11:50 AM), Advanced Artisan Draping (9.0, Friday, 9:00 AM - 11:50 AM), Figure Drawing (3.0, Thursday, 2:00 PM - 3:20 PM), Costume Forum (1.0, Saturday, 12:30 PM - 1:20 PM), and Directors' Generative Process (9.0, TBA).
The course descriptions are as follows: Pedagogy for Creative Writing - Explores teaching strategies and methods for creative writing, Teaching Practicum - Provides practical experience in teaching, Advanced Artisan Draping - Develops advanced skills in draping techniques, Figure Drawing - Focuses on the art of drawing the human figure, Costume Forum - Discusses costume design and construction, Directors' Generative Process - Explores directing as a generative process.
The courses and their respective durations are as follows: Pedagogy for Creative Writing (6 weeks), Teaching Practicum (9 weeks), Advanced Artisan Draping (9 weeks), Figure Drawing (3 weeks), Costume Forum (1 week), and Directors' Generative Process (9 weeks).
The instructors are as follows: Pedagogy for Creative Writing - Young, Teaching Practicum - Handel, Advanced Artisan Draping and Directors' Generative Process - Weild, Figure Drawing - Hanson, Costume Forum - Zamborsky.
The classes are located at PCA (Pittsburgh Center for the Arts).
The classes and their respective credit hours and meeting times are as follows: Pedagogy for Creative Writing (6.0, Wednesday, 2:00 PM - 2:50 PM), Teaching Practicum (9.0, Tuesday, 9:00 AM - 11:50 AM), Advanced Artisan Draping (9.0, Friday, 9:00 AM - 11:50 AM), Figure Drawing (3.0, Thursday, 2:00 PM - 3:20 PM), Costume Forum (1.0, Saturday, 12:30 PM - 1:20 PM), and Directors' Generative Process (9.0, TBA).

 The purpose was to spread out the effect of undetectable or unexpected characteristics.

 The CLUTRR dataset is divided into different difficulties measured by k, the number of facts used in the reasoning chain.
 There are 10K data points in the training set for the CLUTRR dataset.
 The symbolic program of DBpedia-INF consists of 26 predicates, 161 soft rules mined from DBpedia, and 16 rules defining the negation and symmetry between the predicates.
 The main model is DSR-LM, which uses RoBERTa as the underlying LM.
 The main purpose of the DBpedia-INF dataset is to deduce the relationship between any two entities based on a synthetic passage and deductive logic rules.
 During testing, 150 rules are used for symbolic reasoning.
 DSR-LM-DeBERTa uses DeBERTa as the backbone LM, while DSR-w2v-BiLSTM uses word2vec for word embedding and BiLSTM for sequential encoding.
 GPT-3 variant contains 175B parameters.
 The models compared to DSR-LM include pretrained large language models like BERT and RoBERTa, non-LM counterparts like BiLSTM and BERT-LSTM, structured models like GAT, RN, and MAC, and neuro-symbolic models like CTP and RuleBert.
 DSR-without-LM takes the ground truth structured entity relation graph as input.
 The primary focus of the meta learning research mentioned in the text is on communication cost optimization and efficient distributed training.
 SAMA enables efficient DDP by developing a communication strategy that performs the first two backward passes locally on each device, and then overlaps computation in the final backward pass with communication.
 The workflow diagram of SAMA helps to visualize and understand the communication optimization strategy implemented in the framework.
 The application of meta learning focused on in the text, other than few-shot learning, is data optimization.
 Weak supervision aims to reduce data labeling costs by generating labels for a large amount of data using multiple weak labeling functions, such as hand-designed rules and other neural networks.
 Data reweighting and label correction are utilized as data optimization operations for weak supervision in the text.
 The bilevel optimization formulation is λ∗ = (λ∗ r, λ∗ c ) = argmin L(Dclean; θ∗(λr, λc)) λr ,λc s.t. θ∗(λr, λc) = argmin θ 1 |Dnoisy| (cid:88) (x,y)∈Dnoisy w(L; λr) · L(f (x; θ), c(x, y; λc))
 The WRENCH benchmark datasets are used to evaluate the scaling efficiency of SAMA in text classification.
 The experiments showed noticeable improvements in noisy text classification accuracy of the large Transformer model with the help of small additional clean data in the meta level. SAMA performed better compared to SAMA-NA, emphasizing the importance of algorithmic adaptation when an adaptive optimizer is used.
 SAMA is compared to other implicit-differentiation-based meta learning algorithms, namely Neumann Series and conjugate gradient, in terms of GPU memory usage (MB) and throughput (samples/sec) on the AGNews dataset to evaluate compute/memory efficiency.
 The primary focus is on enhancing end-to-end conversational speech translation through target language context utilization.
 The authors propose incorporating target language context and introducing context dropout.
 Including longer context has been shown to benefit machine translation by improving coherence and accuracy.
 The text introduces a context-aware end-to-end speech translation that leverages context in the output side.
 The proposed framework employs target language context, robustness to context absence through dropout, and context enrichment with speaker information.
 The challenges mentioned are high context dependence for meaning, informal language usage, and data scarcity.
 Unlike existing work, the proposed approach focuses on conversational speech translation and incorporates previous translations as context.
 The primary contributions are a context-aware end-to-end speech translation framework, improved robustness through context dropout, and context enrichment with speaker information.
 Consistency is crucial in language understanding because the meaning of utterances often depends on the broader conversational context.
 The architecture includes conformer encoders with hierarchical CTC encoding and transformer decoders.

 The specific pattern corresponds to a unique compositional unit of speech (phoneme), and when a speaker enunciates different phonemes, the vocal tract, mouth, nose, and other facial structures act in concert.
 The AM Estimator is used to predict articulatory movements (AMs) from phonemes.
 It is considered a classic regression problem.
 The main goal is to investigate the correlations between each phoneme and AM pair.
 The segmented phonemes are transformed into log mel spectrum to capture information from the frequency domain, and an AM estimator is employed to predict each AM from phonemes. Hypothesis testing is then used to analyze the correlation.
 The purpose is to determine whether a specific phoneme can predict an AM.
 The null hypothesis is that the AM is not predictable from the phoneme.
 The chance level estimator is calculated as the mean of all instances of the phoneme in the training set.
 The one-sided paired-sample t-test is used to test the hypothesis.
 The significance level chosen is α = 0.05.
 A window size of 32 ms, a hop size of 8 ms, and the square-root of Hann window
 Only the MC loss is used, and the ISMS loss is not used
 Minor frequency permutation is observed
 The results are presented in Table 10
 MixIT, which also deals with unsupervised separation
 MixIT needs to be trained on synthetic mixtures of mixtures, which makes the comparison difficult
 By randomly adding two extra speakers in the same simulated room to create an MoM for training MixIT for 4-speaker separation
 The same as that in UNSSOR and PIT
 Defined similarly to (5) on the real, imaginary and magnitude of the reconstructed mixtures weighted by the summation of mixture magnitudes

 The shape of the complex spectrum generated by the STFT module is 2 × F × T, where 2 denotes the real and imaginary parts, F is the number of frequencies, and T is the number of frames.
 The TAC module in the proposed model is used for channel modeling.
 The bottleneck dimension N is projected by the point-wise convolutional layer in the proposed model.
 The PReLU activation is applied to the output in the proposed model.
 The output is a single-channel representation of the same shape after processing by K stacked multi-path blocks.
 The proposed method is called unconstrained speech enhancement and separation (USES).
 The linear shift of the frequency response of STFT filterbanks for all center frequencies allows for consistent T-F representations across different sampling frequencies.
 The spectra have the same number of frames and different numbers of frequency bins, while the resolution is consistent across different sampling frequencies.
 The original TFPSNet model was modified by adopting the complex spectral mapping method, replacing convolutional layers for mask estimation with a single 2D convolutional layer, and replacing projection layers with 2D convolutional and transposed convolutional layers.
 The proposed USES model can build a sampling-frequency-independent (SFI) model by leveraging the property of consistent T-F representations across different sampling frequencies.
 DPR evaluation scripts for retrieval evaluations and MDR evaluation scripts for reader evaluations.
 The COS has 182M parameters for pretraining.

 The STFT window size is 32 ms and the iSTFT window size is 16 ms.
 The embedding dimension D is set to 256 and the bottleneck dimension N is set to 64.
 The hidden dimension H in each TAC module is 192.
 The number of memory tokens G is set to 20.
 The input signal is divided into non-overlapping segments of approximately 1 second long (64 frames).
 The models are trained using the Adam optimizer.
 The STFT window sizes for the multi-resolution L1 loss are {256, 512, 768, 1024}.
 The models are trained using the SI-SNR loss [37] for speech separation.
 The SE models are evaluated using wide-band PESQ (PESQ-WB), STOI, SI-SNR, SDR, DNS-MOS (OVRL), and WER.
 The SI-SNR improvement reported is 21.1 for 8 kHz and 21.0 for 16 kHz.

 Heat vegetable oil in a deep frying pan and cook onions and garlic until golden.
 The mixture should be seasoned with salt and fresh ground black pepper according to taste.
 Mix tomato sauce, ground coriander, laurel leaf, cinnamon, cloves, star anise, and chicken stock cube into a bowl and add enough water to make a thick paste.
 The pre-washed and soaked rice is put in a strainer to strain excess water, then placed in a deep pot. Enough chicken stock is poured over the rice to cover it completely by about 2 cm.
 Lower the heat to medium and let the rice cook for another 15 minutes until ripe.
 Stir the sauce well to ensure the cube melts completely, then add it to the cooked chicken, onions, and garlic and stir to mix the ingredients.

 Navigating in indoor environments
 Outdoor environments lack clear spatial delineations and are riddled with semantic ambiguities
 Humans can reason about the unseen
 OUTDOOR (Outdoor Underspecified Task Descriptions Of Objects and Regions)
 By enabling agents to expand imaginary nodes in space
 Introducing the OUTDOOR task and using LLMs for outdoor navigation
 CASR (Computationally Adjusted Success Rate)
 Level 1: Navigate to obj X, Level 2: Navigate to obj X conditioned on obj Y, Level 3: Navigate to obj X conditioned on path P, Level 4: Navigate to underspecific abstraction A
 Embodied platforms
 To refine the foundational navigation and reasoning abilities of LLMs
 The SICSF task is to predict user intents and extract corresponding lexical fillers based on input audio.
 Intents are represented as a scenario type and an action type, while slots are represented as key-value pairs.
 Experiments are conducted using the SLURP dataset.
 The baseline model is a Conformer Transducer model.
 HuBERT encoders pretrained on LibriLight-60k are used by ESPNet-SLU and SpeechBrain.
 TDT models achieve better accuracy and efficiency, making them the new state-of-the-art in the SICSF task.
 Using a smaller σ value helps stabilize training for SLURP experiments, as setting σ too high may hurt training.
 The output distribution of TDT models using Librispeech test-other dataset is investigated in the TDT Emission Analysis section.
 TDT models with [0-2] and [0-4] configurations fully utilize longer durations during inference, while [0-6] and [0-8] models have reduced frequencies of predicted long durations.
 The frequency shows that as the TDT models incorporate longer durations, fewer blank emissions are produced, while the number of non-blank emissions remains unchanged.
 High-quality instruction tuning data is essential for aligning LLMs as they traverse vast textual and visual domains, ensuring models produce contextually relevant outputs.
 LLaVA synthesized visual instruction data by representing images as associated captions on bounding boxes to prompt the GPT-4 model.
 Enhancing LLaVA with high-quality instruction-tuning data significantly improved LMM capabilities on benchmark tests, surpassing models trained on datasets larger than theirs.
 Differentiating between less helpful responses and those containing hallucinations helps in providing clearer guidance for annotation and identification of potential hallucinations in model responses.
 The study collected human preferences on LLaVA data by re-sampling the last response with the SFT model and a temperature of 0.7.
 Fact-RLHF aims to augment the reward model by providing additional ground-truth information such as image captions to calibrate judgment, preventing policy model hacking.
 In Fact-RLHF, the reward model is provided with additional factual information about the textual descriptions of the image along with the user prompt and response.
 Symbolic Rewards in Fact-RLHF penalize selections that diverge from predetermined ground-truth options, such as binary choices and multiple-choice options.
 RLHF-trained models often produce more verbose outputs, a phenomenon noted by Dubois et al. (2023), which may be favored by users or automated evaluation systems.
 The hyper-parameter beta is used to control the scale of the KL penalty in the full optimization loss equation.
 The transcriber group plays a role in how fast the user completes tasks.
 Having some form of OCR greatly improves transcription speed, reducing the time estimate by over 50%.
 Yes, using post-correction further reduces transcription time compared to using an off-the-shelf OCR tool.
 Using post-correction reduces manual correction time by 21%.
 Having prior familiarity with Kwak’wala language reduces transcription time.
 100% of the participants perceived that correcting an OCR output was faster.
 The majority of transcribers preferred correcting OCR outputs over typing from scratch.
 The majority preferred correcting OCR outputs because it was faster and required less mental effort.
 One transcriber mentioned that differentiating between l and ł was difficult.
 Several transcribers described correction as easier than typing from scratch.
 Improving the inference speed of an automatic speech recognition model based on a partially autoregressive framework.
 Attention-based encoder-decoder models with autoregressive decoding.
 Incremental calculation of the decoder.
 By employing segment-level vectorized beam search and a partially autoregressive framework.
 Generating an initial hypothesis using greedy CTC decoding.
 Increased computational cost and inference time.
 NAR models can produce multiple outputs simultaneously, accelerating the inference process.
 AR models require previous tokens to estimate the next token, hindering parallelization.
 Partially autoregressive (PAR) method.
 Combining autoregressive and non-autoregressive methods to achieve a better balance of accuracy-latency trade-off.
The purpose of the Carnegie Mellon Athletics Advisory Council is to provide a mechanism for communication and to promote activity between student-athletes, the athletics department, and the campus community.
The functions of the Carnegie Mellon Athletics Advisory Council include promoting communication between athletics, administration, students, and faculty; disseminating information regarding relevant topics in the realm of athletics; providing feedback and insight into athletics and academic issues; generating student-athlete voice within the athletics program involving all teams; soliciting student-athlete response to conference and NCAA legislation; organizing community service projects; creating a vehicle for student-athlete representation for campus committees; and promoting a positive student-athlete image on campus.
The Carnegie Mellon Athletics Advisory Council consists of two representatives from each of our 17 varsity programs.
The Student Athlete Handbook is a resource that provides information and guidelines for student-athletes at Carnegie Mellon University.
Students can share information about the Athletics Advisory Council through various channels such as Facebook, Twitter, and email. They can also print out the information for others to read.
The purpose of soliciting student-athlete response to conference and NCAA legislation is to gather feedback from student-athletes regarding proposed changes or updates in athletic regulations, allowing them to have a voice in the decision-making process.
The Athletics Advisory Council at Carnegie Mellon University organizes community service projects, which are activities that involve giving back to the local community.
The Athletics Advisory Council plays an important role in promoting a positive student-athlete image on campus by encouraging and facilitating activities that showcase the achievements, values, and contributions of student-athletes to the university community.
The Athletics Advisory Council provides representation for student-athletes by serving as a platform where they can voice their opinions, concerns, and ideas. It also involves all teams in discussions and decisions related to the athletics program.
 The goal of Automated audio captioning (AAC) is to describe an input audio clip using text, allowing for free-form sentences.
 State-of-the-art AAC systems rely on a sequence-to-sequence (seq2seq) backbone powered by strong models such as Transformers.
 Some methods to improve the performance of seq2seq AAC models include leveraging pretrained models, large language models (LLMs), fine-grained audio features, text embedding supervision, and data augmentation.
 BEATs is used to extract fine-grained audio features in the context of AAC models.
 Text embeddings from the INSTRUCTOR Transformer are used to provide additional supervision and infuse language-modality knowledge into BEATs audio features.
 The novel data augmentation method using ChatGPT produces caption mix-ups to increase the complexity, diversity, and amount of training data in AAC models.
 Nucleus sampling and a hybrid reranking algorithm are proposed for inference in AAC models.
 Examples of data augmentation methods used in AAC research include original mix-up, synonym substitution, and caption concatenation.
 Researchers prompt ChatGPT to mix-up the captions of two audio clips, producing natural combined captions that increase the amount, complexity, and diversity of training data.
 Nucleus sampling decoding followed by hybrid reranking led to a performance boost in AAC models.
 64x64

 The bulk composition is dominated by the contribution of the larger particles at SS of 0.1%.
 κorg was derived by subtracting the contribution of the inorganic salts (κinorg) from the κccn at SS = 0.1%.
 The uncertainty in the estimation of κorg decreases with increasing organic fraction.

 More investigations are needed to understand the impacts of these variations on CCN activity.
 Suitable κorg scheme played an important role in deriving κchem from aerosol chemical composition.
 A power fitting function κorg = 0.05×(Org/BC)0.42 was obtained.
 κorg was weakly correlated with O:C, but well correlated with the sum mass fraction of aged biomass burning OA and more oxygenated OA in total OA.
 To uncover the internal structure of a multi-participant conversation by finding all the discourse links and corresponding relations.
 Previous work either treats the task as a series of independent multiple-choice problems or restricts the encoding to only local interaction.
 The proposed method improves upon previous work from the perspectives of encoding and decoding.
 Structured encoding on the adjacency matrix followed by the matrix-tree learning algorithm.
 Structured inference using the modified Chiu-Liu-Edmonds algorithm.
 The proposed method does not rely on hand-crafted features to improve its robustness.
 The purpose of a dialogue discourse parser is to predict all the links and relations in a conversation accurately.
 Adding a dummy utterance at the beginning of the dialogue closely resembles a labeled multi-root non-projective spanning tree.
 The essential elements include the structured parameterization of the adjacency matrix, the directed version of matrix-tree theorem, and the modified directed spanning tree inference algorithm.
 The contributions include introducing structural inductive biases for encoding and decoding, jointly predicting discourse links and relations, and proposing a padding method for batchwise variable-length determinant calculation.

 The ML-SUPERB benchmark extends SUPERB to multilingual tasks.
 The most relevant layers for ASR are not the last few layers, and different languages show similar behavior in some cases.
 VoxPopuli provides lecture speech data for training.
 Larger language groups may not benefit as much from multilingual training, as shown by models like wav2vec2-large-23 and mHuBERT.
 Base models tend to generalize better to multilingual cases than their large versions, according to the text.
 The relevance of SSL model layers may be related to the speech domain, in addition to the speech task, as shown by the behavior observed in different languages.
 ML-SUPERB is a benchmark designed to guide users in using SSL representations according to their needs, including an analysis of the learned weights for layer importance.
 Mixtec represents conversational speech data among the sets.
 The learned weights for layer importance can guide users in the use of SSL representations according to their needs.

 The formulation suggests that there exists a solution for separation, which is most consistent with the linear system.
 In over-determined cases, it is possible to estimate the speaker images in an unsupervised way.
 F × (P − 1) × E × C is used because gp(c, f ) is E-tap and there is one such filter for each of P − 1 microphone pairs for each frequency and speaker.
 The blind deconvolution problem mentioned in the text is non-convex in nature and difficult to be solved without assuming any prior knowledge about the relative RIRs or the speaker images.
 The proposed system illustrated in Figure 1 is a DNN-based approach that models speech patterns through unsupervised learning for tackling the blind deconvolution problem.
 The intermediate estimate ˆZ(c) for each speaker c is obtained via complex spectral mapping, where the real and imaginary parts of the input mixture are stacked as features for the DNN to predict the RI parts of ˆZ(c).
 The mixture-constraint loss (MC) is computed by filtering the DNN estimate ˆZ(c) of each speaker c to approximate the P-channel input mixture.
 FCP is employed to estimate the relative RIR relating the ˆZ(c) to the speaker image captured at each microphone p, assuming that the speakers are non-moving.
 The actual number of filter taps (A and B) in the FCP process are set to I and J, both of which are hyper-parameters to tune.
 The weighting term used in balancing the importance of each T-F unit in relative RIR estimation is defined as ξ/(max(·))P.

 The main focus of the method is structured pruning of SSL speech models.
 Careful tuning of separate target sparsities is required to meet a particular budget, which is computationally expensive.
 The pruning target is able to regularize the training by achieving similar or better performance as the original model at low sparsities.
 The purpose of HJ-Pruning-MAC is to prune the entire model to directly meet a computational budget measured by MACs.
 The computation of MACs helps in calculating the percentage of MACs that are pruned, which is important for the method.
 The proposed pruning methods consistently outperform the baseline by reducing computation without degradation in performance.
 HJ-Pruning-MAC and HJ-Pruning-SepSize have similar performance because the CNN has much fewer parameters than Transformer.
 To select the best combination of target sparsities, a grid search is performed to identify the Pareto frontiers, which requires much more computation.
 The HJ-Pruning-MAC method is considered the best in terms of performance and complexity among the proposed methods.
 The overall trend in the results of intent classification on SLURP is very similar to that of ASR, with joint pruning methods outperforming.
 The extinction coefficient is largest in summer, followed by winter, and roughly the same in spring and autumn.
 About 0.4 km^-1 in summer, 0.35 km^-1 in winter, and 0.3 km^-1 in spring/autumn.
 Aerosol particles are more likely to absorb moisture and grow under high temperature and humidity conditions in summer.
 Due to buildings being heated during autumn and winter, leading to higher emissions of pollutants and higher aerosol mass concentrations.
 Highest in summer, followed by spring and autumn, and smallest in winter.
 Frequent dust events in spring result in high aerosol transport to high altitudes.
 In spring, turbulent motion transports aerosol particles to 0.5-1 km height during boundary layer development, with extinction coefficient gradually increasing until noon.
 In winter, the boundary layer height is relatively low, leading to higher extinction coefficient below 0.5 km due to pollutant emissions.
 As the sun sets, aerosols in the range 0.5-1.5 km above ground surface are depressed to lower altitudes, reducing the extinction coefficient.
 Some aerosols are retained in the residual layer, resulting in a relatively high extinction coefficient in that range.
 The main focus of the text is on reproducing Whisper-style training using an open-source toolkit and publicly available data.
 OpenAI Whisper model was trained on 680k hours of supervised speech data.
 Researchers face challenges in comprehending the underlying mechanisms, lacking access to training dynamics, and not having access to the complete model development pipeline.
 The purpose of presenting the OWSM model is to reproduce Whisper-style training using open-source tools and publicly available data, and to promote open science by releasing scripts, models, and training logs.
 Large-scale Transformers have garnered significant attention in natural language processing (NLP).
 Self-supervised learning techniques have demonstrated impressive achievements in the domain of speech processing.
 OWSM supports any-to-any speech translation as opposed to solely any-to-English translation.
 The potential risk is data leakage, as users are deprived of knowledge regarding the actual training data.
 The multitask data format used by OWSM includes tasks such as language identification, multilingual automatic speech recognition, and any-to-any speech-to-text translation.
 OWSM supports more translation directions, whereas Whisper can only perform any-to-English translation.

 The two significant challenges are understanding queries in any language and retrieving relevant passages from a collection of documents in multiple languages as well as generating appropriate responses in the same language.
 Previous works have used a retriever-reader approach, specifically the multilingual DPR (mDPR) model for retrieving documents from a corpus, and a multilingual reader based on multilingual T5 for generating suitable responses in the target language.
 Passage retrieval in conversational question answering presents new challenges as each question must be interpreted within the context of the ongoing dialogue.
 The mDPR model employs a bi-encoder architecture, utilizing a pre-trained multilingual model to encode questions and passages independently.
 The study considers Language-Agnostic BERT Sentence Embedding (LaBSE) and XLM-RoBERTa (XLM-R) for multilingual sentence embeddings.
 ChatGPT is used for query rewriting to summarize the conversational history more concisely and use transfer learning to generalize to French and Vietnamese rewritten queries.
 The main finding is that for the examples examined, query rewriting did not significantly improve performance over the original queries.
 The limitation is that the query rewriting observations are based on a sample size of 2000, leading to limited generalizability of findings.
 Converting the query and dialogue context history into more concise and informative questions was postulated to be advantageous for improving the efficiency of the retriever module.
 Using Fusion-in-Decoder (FiD) along with the mT5 model was found to improve the overall reader performance in terms of F1, BLEU, and Rouge-L scores.

The Tartan Leaders of Tomorrow (TLT) program aims to develop leaders, mentor students and teach values that will inspire lives of vigor, balance and greatness. It is designed as a complement to the student-athlete’s education at Carnegie Mellon University.
The TLT program aims to teach interpersonal, communication and leadership skills. These skills will embolden student-athletes to lead and excel on the court, in the pool, on the track, on the field of play, as well as in the classroom.
All student-athletes regardless of their prior engagement are presented with opportunities to engage with the TLT. This means that any student athlete at Carnegie Mellon University can join this program.
No, the Tartan Leaders of Tomorrow (TLT) program is not an accredited part of the University's official curriculum.
Student-athletes must complete a set of requirements in order to complete the Tartan Leaders of Tomorrow program. These requirements have not been specified.
Student-athletes who have questions or need further information about the Tartan Leaders of Tomorrow (TLT) program should contact Andrew Girard or Kim Kelly.
The mission of the athletic department at Carnegie Mellon University is to develop leaders, mentor students and teach values that will inspire lives of vigor, balance and greatness.
The Tartan Leaders of Tomorrow (TLT) program provides diverse opportunities to build character, teach motivation and foster collaboration among student-athletes.
The skills learned in the Tartan Leaders of Tomorrow (TLT) program will propel a graduate from the program into the workplace and beyond.

 The interactive behaviors condition performed comparably to the non-interactive condition for visual properties like transparency and size.
 Interacting with objects enables the robot to observe them from various angles, enhancing its ability to predict object shape compared to merely observing from a top angle.
 The full MOSAIC framework demonstrated robust performance in the fetch object task, relying solely on unified representations without additional learning.
 The results underscore the adaptability and applicability of unified representations across diverse tasks, including those involving natural language instructions.
 Considering the transfer of unified representations across different robot morphologies is mentioned as an exciting direction for future research.
 One limitation mentioned is that for the fetch object task, the evaluation was done using a zero-shot transfer condition rather than a learning-based approach to find the target object.
 In future work, the authors plan to explore learning-based policies for solving the fetch object task, potentially increasing the versatility and adaptability of their framework.
 The authors showcased the effectiveness of unified representations in tasks such as category recognition, using a simple linear probe setup.
 Foundation models are being considered towards building general-purpose robots.
 One of the intentions behind introducing the MOSAIC framework was to enable robots to generate versatile, multimodal representations and leverage these across various downstream robot tasks.
 Humans tend to have better explanations of the implications of statements compared to machines.
 The gap between the majority vote and unanimously approved examples might be due to annotators having different standards for what constitutes a good explanation.
 The basic statistics of the COBRACORPUS illustrate the average length of explanations and the distribution of target groups.
 Minority or marginalized groups like LGBTQIA+, people with disabilities, and women are among the most frequently targeted groups.
 The most frequent type of offensiveness found in the COBRACORPUS is microaggressions.
 COBRACORPUS-CF is a challenge set of counterfactual context pairs that invert the offensiveness of statements, designed to examine the limits of context-aware explanations.
 One of the difficulties of collecting counterfactual data is finding statements that are contextually ambiguous and can be interpreted in different ways.
 The counterfactual contexts in COBRACORPUS-CF invert the offensiveness of the statements by presenting different contexts that change perceptions of toxicity.
 The counterfactual context pairs are classified based on the types of situations they represent, such as conversations occurring between friends, among strangers in public, at a workplace, and between family members.
 Offensive language and stereotypes might be considered more acceptable in informal settings among people who are familiar with each other, like in sports or social clubs.

 The study focuses on comparing different models for speech processing tasks using various datasets.
 The tasks evaluated include Automatic Speech Recognition (ASR), Speaker Verification (ASV), and Emotion Recognition (ER).
 LRS3-TED is chosen for ASR in the study.
 The evaluation metric used for ASR is the Character Error Rate (CER).
 AV-HuBERT performs the best for ASR and ASV tasks.
 Fusion layers are unable to effectively utilize additional lip reading information, as performance is reduced when video is provided.
 Audio-visual models may improve audio representations by utilizing information learned from visual grounding even when only audio input is available at inference.
 Intermediate-task fine-tuning with (video,text) pairs shifts AV-HuBERT Transformer layers to favor video input alone, reducing usability for audio-only and audio-visual inputs.
 Fine-tuning on AudioSet-2M brings substantial improvements to all AEC and AR datasets, and also improves ASV while maintaining ASR performance.
 For MAViL, the last three layers in the audio encoder and the last two layers in the video encoder and fusion layers are commonly more dominant.

 The TDT model learns the alignment between an input sequence and the corresponding target sequence.
 The formula for computing the alignment P (At,u|x) is α(t, u)β(t, u).
 The variable Nd denotes the number of duration tokens.
 As Nd becomes larger in the experiments, the alignment contains longer-duration tokens.
 The purpose of the FastEmit regularization method is to reduce the delay of token emission.
 A large value of λ in the FastEmit regularization method can cause the model to diverge.
 The FastEmit regularization method scales the gradients to token probabilities by 1 + λ and keeps the gradients to blank probabilities unchanged.
 The ratio of sequence lengths mentioned in the experiments is T U = 7 : 1.
 It is observed that the first few token emissions occur rapidly with a duration set Nd = 1 but are delayed with Nd = 8.
 The training strength of λ affects the delay between token emissions by reducing the delay as λ increases.

 The paper focuses on formulating a different view on training models with imprecise label information.
 The paper proposes to treat imprecise label information as the information that imposes a deterministic or statistical restriction on the actual applicable true labels.
 The inaccessible full and precise labels Y are treated as a latent variable in the model.
 The common approach used is expectation-maximization (EM).
 The proposed framework is largely agnostic to the various nature of label imprecision, with the imprecise label affecting the computation of the posterior P (Y |X, I; θt).
 The unified framework can serve as a solution towards a unified view for learning with any imprecise labels.
 The proposed unified framework outperforms previous methods for dealing with single imprecise labels and demonstrates robustness and effectiveness for mixed label settings.
 The objective of partial label learning is to learn with a candidate label set where the ground truth label is concealed in the set.
 PiCO (Wang et al., 2022a) is the method mentioned that employs class prototypes for label disambiguation.
 The proposed approach enables the learning of a noise model for noisy labels.
Scott Fahlman is interested in artificial intelligence and its application to real-world problems. His specific areas of interest include knowledge representation, planning, image processing, machine learning, massively parallel approaches to search and inference, and the development of improved learning algorithms for artificial neural networks.
Scott Fahlman's current project is Scone, an open-source knowledge representation system and inference engine that can be used as a component in a variety of knowledge-based systems.
The Office is located at 6417 —Gates & Hillman Centers.
Scott Fahlman belongs to the Computer Science Department and Language Technologies Institute.
One can contact Scott Fahlman through email at sef@cs.cmu.edu, or by phone at 412-268-2575.
The name of the open-source knowledge representation system and inference engine that Scott Fahlman is currently working on is Scone.
According to Scott Fahlman, AI can be applied in many areas including knowledge representation, planning, image processing, machine learning, massively parallel approaches to search and inference, and the development of improved learning algorithms for artificial neural networks.
Scott Fahlman works in the Computer Science Department and Language Technologies Institute.
Over the years, Scott Fahlman has worked in many areas of AI including knowledge representation, planning, image processing, machine learning, massively parallel approaches to search and inference, and the development of improved learning algorithms for artificial neural networks.
The name of the research professor emeritus at Carnegie Mellon University is Scott Fahlman.
The main focus of Scone is efficiency, scalability (up to millions of entities and statements) and ease of use.
One goal of the research on Scone is to support natural-language understanding, all the way from text or speech to a language-independent representation that we can reason about.
In the context of Scone, 'episodic' representation and reasoning means actions, events, sequences of actions, plans, goals and explanations.
The author has worked on programming languages such as Common Lisp, Dylan and Java for software-development environments.
The Language Technologies Institute is located at 5000 Forbes Avenue, Pittsburgh, PA 15213-3891.
The contact email for the Language Technologies Institute is ltiwebmaster@cs.cmu.edu.
On the Connect page, there are two options: Login and Logout.
More information about Scone can be found on the Language Technologies Institute website.
The phone number for the Language Technologies Institute is 412-268-6591.
The LTI cluster provides storage and computation for projects involving large datasets and/or lengthy computations.
Carnegie Mellon graduate students are expected to complete their degree requirements within the standard length of time for their program of study as outlined in the relevant Graduate Student Handbook.
Upon completion of the graduate program degree requirements, the degree will be certified by the student’s academic program in the semester in which the student completes the requirements.
Graduate students who consider the completion of all degree requirements in less than the standard length of time for their program may consult with their degree-granting program or department to determine if early degree certification is allowed and under what circumstances.
Some full-time master’s programs last two semesters, while doctoral programs can take several or more years to complete.
The LTI cluster provides storage and computation for projects involving large datasets and/or lengthy computations, which are often used by graduate students.
The standard length of time for a master's program varies significantly, ranging from two semesters for some full-time programs to several or more years for doctoral programs.
If a graduate student completes all degree requirements in less than the standard length of time, they may consult with their degree-granting program or department to determine if early degree certification is allowed and under what circumstances.
Students considering completing their graduate program in less time than the standard length should consult with their degree-granting program or department to determine if early degree certification is allowed and under what circumstances.
Longer-than-standard degree completion may occur due to academic interruptions in making progress toward the degree as defined by the academic program, interruptions of full-time study or progress towards the degree due to serious, documented medical issues, or other unusual or unforeseen circumstances.
Master's students who require longer than the standard time to complete their degree requirements are expected to remain in close contact with their graduate program, and will be certified at the end of the semester in which they have completed their degree requirements.
Master's students should reference CMU Policy on Master’s Student Statute of Limitations (www.cmu.edu/policies/student-and-student-life/masters-students-statute-of limitations.html) for guidelines and restrictions regarding the maximum length of time allowable for master's degree completion.
Students seeking guidance about their program of study and degree requirements should consult with their academic advisor and/or appropriate associate dean.
If a Master's student does not complete their degree requirements within the standard time limit, they may be subject to restrictions and guidelines as outlined in CMU Policy on Master’s Student Statute of Limitations.
The policy on Master's student statute of limitations provides guidelines and restrictions regarding the maximum length of time allowable for master's degree completion, ensuring that students are able to complete their degrees in a timely manner.
If there is an academic interruption or serious medical issue affecting progress towards a Master's degree, students are advised to remain in close contact with their graduate program and seek guidance from appropriate university resources.
If a student requires longer than the standard time for master's degree completion due to unforeseen circumstances, they are expected to remain in close contact with their graduate program and seek guidance from appropriate university resources.
Academic advisors and associate deans play a crucial role in guiding students about their program of study and degree requirements, providing them with necessary information and advice.
Students seeking guidance about their program of study and degree requirements should consult with their academic advisor and/or appropriate associate dean.
Students are expected to make normal progress toward their degree to graduate within the standard timeframe for their program of study. Under U.S. Federal Title IV regulations, student eligibility for federal financial aid is contingent upon enrollment in and successful completion of courses that are counted as credit towards their current degree program.
To receive the maximum amount of federal financial aid for which they may be eligible, students must enroll each semester in at least 36 units that count toward their current degree program.
International Students: Immigration status for students in F-1 and J-1 non-immigrant status is tied to making normal progress toward completing degree requirements. Therefore, F-1 and J-1 students who are considering completing their degree requirements early, anticipating longer-than-standard completion, or moving from an undergraduate to a graduate student classification (integrated undergraduate-graduate study) should consult with their designated advisor in the Office of International Education (OIE) to ensure compliance with immigration regulations.
The student must pass 120 or more course units.
A student needs to complete at least 72 units of 'LTI' courses and 24 units of 'SCS' courses.
The student must take 11-711, 11-791 (or an equivalent), and one 'Task Orientation Focus' class.
The student must complete 12 units of 11-910 Directed Research and 12 units of Open Elective.
Students must attend the LTI Colloquium (11-700) each semester.
The requirement is described elsewhere in the handbook.

Students may submit their requests for additional courses to be considered by faculty members.
Course requirements must be satisfied by actual classroom courses, not credit given for research or independent study unless approved by the Program Director in advance.

The University reserves the right to withdraw the degree promptly upon discovery of the falsification.
The University reserves the right to withdraw a degree even though it has been granted should there be discovery that the work upon which it was based or the academic records in support of it had been falsified. In such a case, withdrawal of the degree will occur promptly upon discovery of the falsification.
Each student has a faculty advisor charged with guiding the education and monitoring the progress of the student through the program. The advisor also supervises the student's directed study projects.
The faculty advisor provides career advice and ensures that every student receives necessary faculty mentoring through their personal relationship with each student.
The complete reference to this University policy is available at https://www.cmu.edu/policies/student-and-student-life/withdrawal-of-a-degree.html.
The information about advising in MLT graduate program comes from the MLT Graduate Student Handbook, specifically page 14.
The faculty advisor supervises the student's directed study projects.
Having a personal relationship with an advisor ensures that every student receives necessary faculty mentoring and career advice.
The purpose of withdrawing a degree when it has been falsified is to maintain academic integrity by ensuring that degrees are only granted based on genuine work and records.
The MLT Graduate Student Handbook provides information about advising in the program, including who is responsible for guiding each student's progress and what their role entails.
A degree that has been falsified will be withdrawn promptly upon discovery of the falsification.
During the first month of the program, students are expected to attend the LTI's Orientation (“Immigration Course,” or IC) lectures and be proactive about meeting individually with potential advisors.
After meeting with several potential advisors, each student will be asked to indicate a first, second, and third choice for advisor.
Potential advisors determine how many new students they can take.
Even students who are prefunded must attend the research talks, to become acquainted with the LTI’s research projects.
Until a student finds a specific advisor, the chair of the LTI graduate programs serves as their advisor.
The student should find another faculty member willing to serve as an advisor and then make a request to the Program Director to switch advisors. Both the new and old advisors need to agree to the change.
Forging a strong student-advisor relationship takes time, so switching advisors late in their graduate studies can be disadvantageous.
The Optional Masters’ Thesis is a possibility for students who wish to undertake an independent research project. It is optional because not all students may be interested in or ready for such a commitment.
The LTI follows the long-standing SCS policy that both the new and old advisors need to agree to the change; typically, this is not a problem.
Students can choose from several ways, including completing a Masters’ Thesis, innovative research in a research project or class project work.
No, it is optional and not required.
The two courses required are 11-928 – Masters’ Thesis I (with the chosen thesis advisor) and 11-929 – Masters’ Thesis II in the following Spring.
The deadline for submitting a thesis proposal is October 31st.
Each course counts towards 6 units of MLT-level LTI course credit.
The second course (11-929) counts towards one PhD lab requirement.
The MLT thesis may focus on either a significant research result or a significant implementation of a new technology.
Students should work with their chosen thesis advisor to define the thesis research project.
The MLT thesis culminates in an M.S. degree.
The MLT thesis committee will be composed of a thesis advisor and two additional readers, to be chosen by the student in consultation with the advisor.
The student must have prepared a written proposal of at least five pages describing the scientific thesis to be investigated, any relevant research already completed by the student, a comparison with related work by others, and a detailed description of the work to be done in the next semester. The proposal MUST be accepted by the committee by the end of October.
If the student does not have their proposal accepted by the committee by the end of October, they will not be allowed to enroll in 11-929 – Masters’ Thesis II.
The student will distribute a draft of the thesis to the committee for initial review sometime during the semester when they enroll in 11-929 – Masters’ Thesis II, typically their final semester.
The purpose of distributing a draft of the thesis early is to avoid last-minute surprises that could delay final approval of the thesis.
At least 2 out of the 3 committee members must be SCS faculty working in Language Technologies.
The written proposal prepared by the student should be at least five pages long.
The thesis advisor will guide and assist the student throughout their research process, provide feedback on their work, and help them prepare for presenting their findings.
The additional readers will review the student's proposal and draft thesis, provide feedback on their work, and help ensure that the research meets academic standards.
The final step in completing a Master's thesis is submitting the final version of the thesis document, followed by a public presentation of the work in an LTI seminar or other suitable public forum.
All information required for a public announcement must be received by the LTI graduate program administrator at least one week before the defense.
The Masters’ Thesis presentation is less rigorous than a PhD thesis defense. It must communicate the research work done, similar to a conference paper presentation.
A simple majority vote of the committee is required for approval of the thesis and presentation.
It is not required that students finish the thesis by the end of the second semester. If a student requires more time, an incomplete grade will be assessed in the Masters’ Thesis course until such time as the work and presentation are accepted.
If all other requirements for the MLT degree have been completed, a student will still be allowed to walk in Spring Commencement.
Financial support beyond the end of the semester is on a case-by-case basis and must be arranged in advance with the project supporting them.
Students are strongly encouraged to finish the thesis work within one (1) year following the semester they enroll for the first Masters’ Thesis course.
If a student requires more time to revise the thesis to the committee's satisfaction, an incomplete grade will be assessed in the Masters’ Thesis course until such time as the work and presentation are accepted.
An 'LTI course' refers to any 12-unit course with a number of 11-XXX. A 6-unit course with an 11-XXX counts as half of an LTI course.
An 'SCS course' refers to any 12-unit course with a course number indicating a unit of the School of Computer Science, including LTI. A 6-unit course with such a number counts as half of an SCS course.
LTI Focus Areas are sets of courses defined on the LTI course webpage under 'Course Categories.' If a student believes a new course should be added to a Focus Area, they should notify the Chair of the LTI Graduate Programs.
An 'LTI lab course' refers to a course in the list of lab courses defined in the LTI 'Course Categories' webpage.
Yes, students are free to take elective courses outside of SCS as long as they fulfill the requirements of their program.
The student should notify the Chair of the LTI Graduate Programs. The Chair, with advice from faculty in the appropriate area, will decide whether it should be in the Focus Area.
The Program Director approves electives that are technically outside of SCS and count towards this requirement, such as Digital Signal Processing in ECE.
A course refers to an actual classroom course, not credit given for research or independent study unless otherwise specified.
Yes, as long as they fulfill the requirements of their program and discuss any such electives in advance with their advisor.

The LTI provides a set of lectures and talks at the beginning of each Fall semester to help students learn about the work done by CMU faculty, provide an opportunity for advisors to recruit new students, and give students a good introduction to the broad range of research done at the LTI.
Students are expected to attend these lectures and treat them seriously because they provide a good introduction to the broad range of research done at the LTI.
The older name for these talks was called 'the Immigration Course (IC)', which caused confusion. The older name has been retired.
Near the end of the spring and fall semesters, students prepare a statement that describes their achievements in the current semester, and plans for the next semester. At the end of the semester, faculty evaluates each student's academic progress.
A good letter typically indicates that the student is making satisfactory progress towards completing the degree. If the student is doing exceptionally good work, a stronger adjective such as excellent might be used.
If a student seems to be having trouble, faculty determines whether the student can finish the degree and what needs to be accomplished to get back on track. This type of letter should be considered a serious warning.
If a student does not make satisfactory progress, it may affect their ability to continue in the program. However, this letter is not a permanent “black mark” on the student's record; if the student begins making satisfactory progress again, there is no official record of the letter in the student's transcript.
LTI stands for Language Technology Institute.
Evaluations are conducted at the end of each semester, both in spring and fall.
If a student seems to be having trouble, the faculty determines whether it believes that the student can finish the degree, and if so, what needs to be accomplished to get back on track. This type of letter should be considered a serious warning.
In the most serious cases, the faculty gives the student an N-1 letter that specifies a list of conditions that the student must satisfy by specific deadlines. Failure to meet all of the specified conditions may result in the student's termination from the program.
