The purpose of an N-1 letter is to specify a list of conditions that the student must satisfy by specific deadlines in order to continue their studies. Failure to meet all of these conditions may result in termination from the program.
If a student is having trouble, they should seek help and guidance from faculty members. The faculty will determine whether the student can finish the degree and what needs to be accomplished to get back on track.
The purpose of the university's grading principles is to define undergraduate and graduate grading standards, assign and change grades, provide grading options, handle drop/withdrawals, and allow course repeats.
Carnegie Mellon University offers students the opportunity to take courses for credit through a cross-registration program and through the receipt of transfer credit from other accredited institutions.
Carnegie Mellon courses and courses taken through the university's cross-registration program will have grades recorded on the transcript and be factored into the QPA. All other courses will be recorded on this transcript indicating where the course was taken, but without grade.
The university's policy includes expectations around academic integrity and provides definitions of cheating, plagiarism, and unauthorized assistance.
The purpose of the university's policy on grades for transfer courses is to define how Carnegie Mellon University transcript will include information on such courses as follows: Carnegie Mellon courses and courses taken through the university's cross-registration program will have grades recorded on the transcript and be factored into the QPA. All other courses will be recorded on this transcript indicating where the course was taken, but without grade.
Suspended students may take courses elsewhere; however, they may receive transfer credit only if their college’s and department's policies allow this.
You can find the University Policy on Academic Integrity at https://www.cmu.edu/policies/student-and-student-life/academic-integrity.html
The University Policy on Academic Integrity includes the University expectations around academic integrity and provides definitions of cheating, plagiarism, and unauthorized assistance.
QPA stands for Quality Point Average. It's a system used by the university to calculate academic performance based on letter grades and credit hours.
Cross-registration program allows students of one school within the Pittsburgh Council on Higher Education (PCHE) to take courses at another PCHE member institution.
The University expects students to uphold a high standard of honesty, respect for others’ work and ideas, and personal responsibility. This includes not cheating, plagiarizing or receiving unauthorized assistance.
The University has a disciplinary actions procedure that outlines how to investigate, report and adjudicate academic integrity policy violations. The appeals process is also part of this procedure.
Students should actively reflect on these challenges, seek support from the community and discuss their experiences to evolve high standards. The entire university community is responsible for maintaining academic integrity.
Students can find more information on the University's policy and procedures related to academic integrity by visiting https://www.cmu.edu/policies/student-and-student-life/academic-integrity.html
Plagiarism, as defined by the policy, is presenting another person's ideas, words or work as your own.
Students should uphold a high standard of honesty and respect for others’ work and ideas. They should not receive unauthorized assistance or present someone else's work as their own.
The entire university community has a responsibility to establish and maintain academic integrity. This includes students, faculty, staff, and administration working together to uphold high standards.
Unauthorized assistance refers to receiving help from someone other than your instructor or teaching assistant without their permission, especially in exams or assignments.
Cheating, as defined by the policy, involves any form of academic dishonesty that violates the principles of honesty and personal responsibility. This includes unauthorized assistance.
Carnegie Mellon University's mission statement aims to create and disseminate knowledge and art through research and artistic expression, teaching and learning and transfer to society; serve students by teaching them leadership, problem-solving skills, and the values of quality, ethical behavior, responsibility to society and commitments to work; and pursue the advantages provided by a diverse community, open to the exchange of ideas, where discovery and artistic creativity can flourish.
Carnegie Mellon University emphasizes that it is the ethical responsibility of each student to identify the conceptual sources of the work submitted. Failure to do so is dishonest and is subject to disciplinary action, including charges of cheating or plagiarism.
Carnegie Mellon has a clear and specific protocol for responding to alleged violations of academic integrity. The university's Academic Disciplinary Actions Overview for Graduate Students describes procedures for disciplinary actions against graduate students in cases of alleged violations of academic regulations, as well as the appeal process.
Students can find more information about Carnegie Mellon University's policies on academic integrity by visiting the university's website and accessing the Academic Discipline section.
Carnegie Mellon University strives to teach its students leadership, problem-solving skills, and the values of quality, ethical behavior, responsibility to society, and commitments to work.
Carnegie Mellon strives to serve the changing needs of society through its three primary goals outlined in its mission statement: creating and disseminating knowledge and art, teaching and learning, and transferring this knowledge to society.

Academic Policies 5.1.1 Duration of Study: MLT students enrolled for full-time study are expected to complete the degree in two calendar years (24 months). This includes two summers of full-time directed research.
A Masters student who uses courses taken as part of another degree program (at Carnegie Mellon or elsewhere) toward their program requirements cannot use those same courses.

The School of Computer Science has a policy that graduate students cannot take any other M.S. degree offered by the school without prior approval.
No, pass/fail grades are not permitted for courses used to satisfy a degree requirement in graduate programs at the School of Computer Science.

For an Independent Study to be counted towards a student’s coursework, it must first be approved by the MLT Program Director. The student should then work with their supervising faculty member to create a short description of the study's goals and evaluation methods.
The student must submit their Independent Study proposal to the MLT Program Director before the end of the Add period in the semester when they plan to undertake the study.
Students planning an Independent Study must ensure it is structured and scheduled in such a way that all work is finished by the end of the semester, allowing for grading.

 Negative values indicate that MERRA-2 BC column concentrations are lower than GRASP/Component BC column concentrations.
 The evaluation has not been conducted globally due to the scarcity of aerosol component measurements on extensive temporal and spatial scales.
 The study presents a quantitative evaluation of the MERRA-2 reanalysis dust and BC column concentration using independent satellite-measured aerosol component concentration retrievals.
 Several dust emission resource regions and the critical downwind dust-dominated regions are selected for comparisons.
 MERRA-2 reanalysis dust products present higher column concentration than GRASP/Component dust retrievals with relative differences of about 40~70% over African dust emission resource regions.
 The correlation coefficient varies from 0.91 to 0.80 for the temporal variation in dust column concentration over the dust emission resource regions.
 The relative differences are mostly less than 40% for Asian dust emission resource regions, even for negative values in the TAK region.
 The correlation coefficient is about 0.70~0.90 for the temporal variation in BC column concentration over the globe.
 MERRA-2 reanalysis BC products present both higher (about 80%) and lower (about -20%) column concentrations compared to GRASP/Component BC retrievals.
 The purpose is to indicate how well both MERRA-2 products and GRASP/Component retrievals can capture the temporal variations in dust and BC column concentration with a high correlation coefficient.
 The PostNet refines the predicted sequence by predicting a residual component of the target sequence.
 Transformer-TTS adopts a multi-headed self-attention mechanism by replacing the RNNs with a parallelizable self-attention structure, resulting in faster and more efficient training while maintaining high perceptual quality.
 They performed pre-training on the LJSpeech dataset, which consists of 24 hours of single-female English speech, before fine-tuning the model using a small amount of Arabic training data.
 The autoregressive models predict the target sequence iteratively, while the non-autoregressive models predict the target sequence in parallel without the need for iterative steps.
 FastSpeech2 is based on Conformer and uses a Conformer block instead of the Transformer block for the text-to-mel model.
 The duration predictor is a convolutional network that predicts the duration of each input token from the hidden representation of the encoder.
 The study used the Griffin-Lim algorithm (GL) and Parallel WaveGAN (PWG) to generate speech from the predicted mel-spectrogram.
 The audio quality was evaluated by human testers, and the word error rate (WER) and character error rate (CER) of the generated speech were also calculated using pre-trained ASR models.
 Vowelization of the input transcription is important to solve the mismatch between the input text and the output pronunciation.
 The reduction factor is a common parameter that decides the number of output frames at each time step, which is crucial for stable training especially with limited training data.

 AV-SUPERB specializes in audio-visual tasks from speech and audio processing.
 Three evaluation tracks are set up in AV-SUPERB.
 The three tracks are referred to as audio-only, video-only, and audio-visual fusion features.
 The goal of the benchmark is to provide insight on the generalization capabilities of pretrained representations.
 The upstream models referred to in the text are AV-HuBERT, RepLAI, AVBERT, MAViL, and HuBERT.
 The downstream models consist of a two-layer fully-connected network.
 Handcrafted features are used in the baselines to make a fairer comparison between audio and audio-visual features.
 Using a weighted sum of representations helps improve the performance of downstream tasks.
 The tasks focused on are audio event classification (AEC) and action recognition (AR).
 MAViL excels at audio processing tasks.
 Xrec represents the reconstructed examples for a target x.
 In Figure 22a, the normalized (cid:96)2 distance between the reconstruction and target is plotted against the loss of the reconstructed examples.
 Dividing the main loss by the support loss in Figure 22c increases the correlation between the contrastive loss and the (cid:96)2 distance.
 There is a small positive correlation between loss and (cid:96)2 distance, indicating that some reconstructions are visually similar to the target while others show notable differences.
 Using a contrastive loss filters out examples that are seen as likely under both models, making reconstructions more visually similar to the target.
 Figure 23 shows that the attack fails when the target image was not included in training, indicating that the model relies on memorization rather than generalization for correct inpainting.
 A total of 256 models were trained for each GAN architecture.
 For BigGAN architecture, the number of training steps was increased to 200,000 to enhance image fidelity, unlike the default hyper-parameters used for StyleGAN and MHGAN.
 The iteration that achieved the highest FID score on the test set was selected for each model trained on a randomly selected half of the CIFAR-10 dataset.
 Figures 24 and 25 contain additional examples extracted from GANs trained on CIFAR-10, showcasing training examples for different GAN architectures.

 The effect of different vocabulary sizes, the effect of the number of artificial terms added to the queries/documents, the usefulness of complementing existing learned sparse retrievers with the KALE vocabulary, the distribution of the generated term posting lists, and the out-of-domain performance of the proposed method.
 To assess if the vocabulary size affects the effectiveness and efficiency of the model, and to determine the optimal size for better performance.
 The authors find that combing RNN-T and AED provides a 17–22% relative improvement in word error rate over RNN-T alone on a voice search task.
 Deliberation, cascaded encoder, Y-architecture, and Universal ASR are mentioned as different techniques.
 Character-level modeling is discussed as a prominent feature, as it avoids phoneme-based modeling and pronunciation lexica.
 It is mentioned that character-level modeling is viable with classical hybrid HMM architectures and can work even without neural networks.
 Various algorithmic changes, ways to combine different E2E models, ways to incorporate context, and improved encoder and decoder architectures are discussed.
 They propose employing a multi-task learning strategy with both CTC and attention-based losses, which provides a 5–14% relative improvement in word error rate over attention-based models on specific tasks.
 Contextual biasing pertains to biasing phrases like proper nouns in a specific domain, which is important for recognizing words seen infrequently during training and improving beam search performance.
 The evolution includes moving from long short-term memory recurrent neural networks (LSTMs) to architectures like Transformers and Conformers, which have shown competitive performance.
 The training criterion to be minimized is the negative log probability of the correct transcription given the input.
 These architectures have shown better performance compared to LSTMs by leveraging convolution, self-attention, or combining self-attention with convolution.

 The inverse toxicity filter yields the strongest performance on toxicity identification.
 Data source heterogeneity is more important than data quality for downstream performance.
 The inclusion of Common Crawl, OpenWeb, and Books had the strongest positive effects on downstream performance.
 The choice of pretraining source domains impacts downstream performance as demonstrated by ablating pretraining sources from the Pile and measuring the performance change in diverse QA tasks.
 Common Crawl, OpenWeb, and Books have the strongest positive effects on downstream performance.
 The trade-off suggested in the text is that better performance on QA and toxicity identification comes at the cost of more toxic generation.
 Removing Books, CommonCrawl, and OpenWeb lead to the greatest decrease in toxicity metrics.
 Web and Books domains cause the biggest trade-off between toxic identification and generation.
 The hypothesis is that CC, OpenWeb, and Books contain extensive coverage of many topics, which is why removing the Academic-specific category of sources does not remove all relevant academic information.
 The main challenge is collecting annotated data for model training, which can be expensive, laborious, time-consuming, and error-prone.
 Factors such as lack of annotator expertise, privacy concerns, and intrinsic difficulty in ascertaining labels precisely can make collecting precise labels difficult.
 ILL is a framework for the unification of learning with various imprecise label configurations, treating precise labels as latent variables and considering the entire distribution of all possible labeling entailed by the imprecise information.
 ILL uses expectation-maximization (EM) for modeling imprecise label information by treating precise labels as latent variables and considering the entire distribution of all possible labeling entailed by the imprecise information.
 ILL can seamlessly adapt to partial label learning, semi-supervised learning, noisy label learning, and a mixture of these settings.
 ILL surpasses existing specified techniques by offering a unified framework with robust and effective performance across various challenging settings, instead of proposing specific designs for each emerging imprecise label configuration.
 Some typical mechanisms of label imprecision include partial label learning (PLL), semi-supervised learning (SSL), and noisy label learning (NLL).
 Fig. 1 illustrates the full label and imprecise label configurations, such as full label, partial label, semi-supervised, and noisy label scenarios, using an example dataset.
 Existing approaches differ substantially and are tailored to specific forms of imprecision, which may complicate the deployment in practical settings where complex annotations with multiple coexisting imprecision configurations exist.
 It is challenging to adapt previous methods to scenarios with multiple coexisting imprecision configurations, such as both noisy labels and partial labels, due to the unique assumptions and design requirements of each method.
 They show that DIFUSCO outperforms previous probabilistic NPC solvers on benchmark datasets of TSP and MIS problems with various sizes.
 Autoregressive models.
 They face high time and space complexity challenges due to their sequential generation scheme and quadratic complexity in the self-attention mechanism.
 They assume conditional independence among variables in NPC problems.
 It uses an iterative denoising scheme to generate the final heatmap.
 They progressively add Gaussian noise to the clean data in the forward process and learn to remove noises in the reverse process.
 The optimization objective is to find the optimal solution xs∗ for a given instance s by minimizing the objective function cs(x) = cost(x, s) + valid(x, s).
 x is the indicator vector for selecting a subset from N edges.
 They define a parameterized conditional distribution pθ(x|s) such that the expected cost cs(x) * p(x|s) is minimized.
 The joint distribution pθ(x0:T) = p(xT) * Π from t=1 to T pθ(xt-1|xt).

 One-dimensional logistic regression model
 Uncertainty score
 Binary prediction of whether its prediction is confidently correct or not
 Transformed with a logarithm
 As one minus the average correctness probability over all the candidates in the query set
 Enhancing model training with pseudo labels predicted by the current model on unlabeled data
 Selecting the error-prone sub-structures and including the remaining un-selected parts for training
 The cross-entropy between the output distributions predicted by the previous model and the current model being trained
 With a ratio of 1:1 in the training process
 Named entity recognition (NER), dependency parsing (DPAR), event extraction, and relation extraction
 The main objective is to see if using MO algorithms limits GI’s ability to improve apps compared to improving only a single objective, especially in cases where one improvement can enhance two objectives.
 Assessing the runtime cost of MO-GI is important to ensure that any improvements found justify the cost of running it.
 The purpose is to determine if GIDroid could offer an attractive alternative to existing state-of-the-art tools available to developers.
 Three multi-objective algorithms - NSGA-II, NSGA-III, and SPEA2 are implemented in GIDroid for Android.
 MO algorithms were chosen because sacrificing some properties may lead to better improvements in other properties, such as with the caching operators.
 Execution time is measured using Linux’s time tool, memory usage is tracked using Java Runtime’s memory allocation tracking, and bandwidth is measured using Linux’s built-in process-level network traffic tracking.
 It was necessary because most open-source Android applications lack test suites, and existing automated testing tools focus on UI testing rather than generating assertions crucial for capturing correct app behavior.
 At least 75% branch coverage was achieved for methods used in the study.
 Developers find it simpler because they already have an understanding of the application and would get many benefits from writing tests.
 The benefits of writing tests include understanding the application better, getting other benefits like improving code quality, and ensuring correct app behavior.
 The issue is that utterances in the batch may have different duration outputs, making it difficult to fully parallelize the computation.
 By selecting the minimum of predicted durations for all utterances in the batch.
 Because skipping fewer frames than the model indicates causes the model to emit previously emitted tokens instead of the next token.
 They proposed a modification to the training loss by combining TDT loss with conventional transducer loss with a sampling probability.
 The noise robustness for TDT and RNNT ASR models was compared by running inference on Librispeech test-clean augmented with noise at different signal-noise-ratios (SNRs).
 TDT models performed much better in noisy conditions than conventional transducers, both in terms of accuracy and speed.
 The sampled loss is a combination of TDT loss with conventional transducer loss with a sampling probability ω.
 The inference speed-up for TDT models with batched inference is slightly smaller than for the non-batched case.
 TDT models help avoid the issue of performance degradation that RNN-T models face when there are repetitions of the same tokens in the text sequence.
 TDT models achieved significantly lower error rates compared to conventional RNN-T models, regardless of the type of decoder used.
 The hypothesis space Hi is a subset of Huni.
 In the extreme case where the VC dimension is 0, the error ϵ will be zero.
 A higher VC dimension implies greater model flexibility and capability of the approach.
 GLoRA is evaluated on VTAB-1K benchmark comprising 19 image classification tasks clustered into three domains: Natural images, Specialized tasks, and Structured tasks.
 GLoRA is evaluated on five fine-grained visual recognition few-shot datasets: Food101, OxfordFlowers102, StandfordCars, OxfordPets, and FGVCAircraft.
 ViT-B model pre-trained on ImageNet-21K is utilized for vision experiments in GLoRA.
 The largest GLoRA model configuration has 8 and 4 LoRA dimensions in the search space.
 The added parameter flexibility allows for user-defined trainable parameter count in the final models.
 GLoRA performs competitively across datasets in contrast to prior works and tends to fail on at least one dataset.
 GLoRA pushes the state of the art in as many as 14 out of 19 datasets under VTAB-1K.

 Self-training is helpful for all the strategies, boosting performance without the need for extra manual annotations.
 The PA strategy can roughly match the performance of FA with the same amount of reading cost while labeling fewer sub-structures.
 The adaptive ratio scheme aims to analyze the effectiveness of the ratio scheme with DPAR as a case study.
 If the value of a fixed-ratio scheme is too small, its performance lags behind others with the same reading contexts due to fewer sub-structures annotated.
 The adaptive scheme provides a reasonable solution by automatically deciding the ratio according to the model performance.
 The error rates on selected sub-structures indicate the need for manual corrections.
 In the domain-transfer experiments, in addition to unlabeled in-domain data, abundant out-of-domain annotated data is assumed.
 In NER tasks, the source domain knowledge can provide extra information to boost the results, especially in early AL stages.
 A classical pipelined approach is adopted, splitting the full task into two sub-tasks: mention extraction and relation prediction.
 The results indicate that the benefits of active learning and transfer learning can be orthogonal, and combining them can lead to promising results.
 Biased meta gradients may result in training instability.
 They are designed for first-order gradients as they do not involve Hessian-vector products.
 Approximating the base Jacobian with an identity matrix.
 Deep equilibrium model setting.
 The base Jacobian does not necessarily equate with the Hessian when an adaptive optimizer is used.
 The inconsistency between assumed and actual optimizers results in an incorrect meta gradient.
 SAMA stands for Solution Algorithm for Meta-Adaptation.
 It expands the meta Jacobian term with the chain rule to address adaptive update rules.
 The update rule u reduces to an identity matrix in the case of SGD.
 Most libraries like PyTorch only have native support for basic backward functions, not customized ones required by meta gradient algorithms.

 The task token is used to distinguish between ASR (Automatic Speech Recognition) and ST (Speech Translation).
 Having a separate ST token for each target language enables translation to any language.
 The text transcription is appended either with or without utterance-level timestamps.
 Three versions have been developed: OWSM v1, v2, and v3.
 Whisper was pre-trained on 680k hours of labeled audio data sourced from the Internet.
 Each long-form utterance is limited to a maximum duration of 30 seconds.
 OWSM v3 performs 4 times downsampling, resulting in a time resolution of 20ms.
 OWSM uses a joint CTC loss for ASR targets.
 OWSM supports decoding algorithms such as greedy search, beam search, and joint CTC/attention decoding (for ASR only).
 OWSM uses the same batch size as Whisper but has a smaller number of total updates.
 The main focus of GIDroid is the multi-objective automated improvement of Android apps.
 Genetic Improvement is used as a search-based technique to navigate the space of software variants and find improved software in Android apps.
 GIDroid proposes a practical approach and the first open-source tool for multi-objective automated improvement, which includes state-of-the-art multi-objective algorithms and new mutation operators.
 Non-functional properties are important because they affect user experience, with 1/3 of user instances abandoning applications and 59% of bad reviews attributed to poor performance.
 The researchers wrote tests for 21 versions of 7 Android apps using GIDroid to improve runtime, memory, and bandwidth use, thus creating a new benchmark for performance improvements.
 The technique automatically re-discovered 64% of existing improvements in the mobile apps.
 By applying the approach to current software versions without known improvements, execution time was improved by up to 35%, and memory use was improved by up to 33%.
 Genetic Improvement relies on testing to validate patches by using a simulation-based testing framework to greatly improve the speed of search.
 Multi-objective optimization is significant as it helps consider properties other than direct targets for improvement, providing a broader view of how improvements affect an application.
 Genetic Improvement makes changes directly to the source code and uses meta-heuristics to find patches that improve software properties, while linters only identify areas that may cause performance issues without applying changes.
 The CP decomposition is a special case of the Tucker decomposition where the core tensor has only diagonal component values and the same rank for each dimension, allowing for more parameter reduction but being less expressive.
 The rank of the CP decomposition is restricted to the smallest dimension.
 CP decomposition is difficult to adjust with flexible parameter sizes because the rank is often limited to the kernel size, and the kernel size of the convolution layer is typically small compared to the number of channels.
 The Tensor-Train decomposition is another method for high-order tensors, involving a product of 3-order tensors. It provides flexible parameter reduction but cannot accelerate inference like the Tucker decomposition.
 The Tensor-Train decomposition involves N - 1 hyperparameters corresponding to the rank of N-th order tensors.
 The E2E SLU model aims to estimate semantic label sequences directly from input speech feature sequences, using tensor decomposition techniques for parameter reduction.
 The middle model is used as the seed model to miniaturize the final small model using tensor decomposition techniques, ensuring that the structural type remains the same.
 The number of nodes in the middle model and the size of the core tensor of the Tucker decomposition are determined from the given compression ratio.
 Sequential distillation is a technique used to downsize sequential models like encoder-decoder models by minimizing the KL-divergence criterion using softmax outputs with temperature hyperparameters.
 The rank is determined from the compression ratio in tensor decomposition by calculating the number of middle nodes or using specific formulas depending on the decomposition technique.

 By doubling hidden dimensions in self-attention and fully connected layers
 They do not account for factors like parallelization and techniques that reduce parameter counts

 To reduce model size
 They are integrated into the objectives of NAS and AutoML methods
 Because it is often impossible to control for the hardware systems used

 PyTorch and Chainer
 The computational graph is pre-defined, compiled, and executed inside a specialized runtime

 On NLP tasks involving long-form texts at input or output.

 It evaluates both models in a k-shot in-context learning setup.
 That Latin-script languages require substantially fewer tokens compared to other scripts.
 The proportion of the language in the pretraining data and inherent properties of the language and its writing script.
 MBR decoding is a method for choosing the outputs of a machine learning system based on the output with the lowest risk among multiple candidates, rather than the output with the highest probability.
 MBR provides reliable improvements across metrics for various tasks without requiring additional data or training.
 Despite its benefits, MBR is not frequently applied in natural language processing (NLP) works and knowledge of the method itself is limited.
 When a sample of sufficient size is taken, MBR almost uniformly outperforms beam search and single-output sampling across tasks, metrics, and datasets.
 Self-consistency, range voting, output ensembling, and some types of density estimation are modern generation techniques that can be viewed as special instances of MBR.
 The desirable output should be both high probability and relatively consistent with the rest of the outputs to minimize risk.
 Standard decoding chooses the most probable next token or performs a search over the output space, while MBR decoding chooses the output with the lowest risk among multiple candidates.
 The risk of a candidate decoding is calculated as the expected error under the probability distribution over the output space.
 The objective of MBR decoding is to find the candidate decoding that minimizes the expected error under the probability distribution.
 The risk is approximated by using a subset of the full output space instead of exact computation, typically by summing over independent samples from the probability distribution.

 To identify MRI features of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) that predict microvascular invasion (MVI) and postoperative intrahepatic recurrence in patients without peritumoral hepatobiliary phase (HBP) hypointensity.
 Microvascular invasion (MVI) is the presence of clusters of tumor cells in vessels located in the peritumoral area of the liver. It is a major risk factor for HCC recurrence after surgery.
 Peritumoral HBP hypointensity has high specificity but relatively poor sensitivity in predicting MVI.

 The aim of the study is to investigate the capability of reconstructing the 3D facial shape from voice from a geometry perspective without relying on semantic information.
 The study proposes a voice-anthropometric measurement (AM)-face paradigm, which identifies predictable facial AMs from the voice and uses them to guide 3D face reconstruction.
 The study uses anthropometric measurements (AMs) as a proxy to link the voice and face geometry.
 The approach is evaluated on a proposed dataset with ground-truth 3D face scans and corresponding voice recordings.
 The study finds significant correlations between voice and specific parts of the face geometry, such as the nasal cavity and cranium.
 The most commonly used semantic cues in previous works on voice-face matching are gender, age, and emotion.
 The study aims to explore voice-face correlations beyond easily learned semantic biases and questions if reconstructing identity-fidelity 3D face from voice is possible.
 The study aims to disable previously used semantics (gender, age, emotion) and focus solely on the voice-face correlation from a pure geometry view.
 General 3D facial shape is represented by the 3D coordinates of a number of points on its surface called vertices.
 The proposed pipeline first predicts and verifies predictable anthropometric measurements (AMs) from the voice and then utilizes AMs to guide 3D face reconstruction.
 The Pareto fronts are found in the online repository of GIDroid (2023).
 The trade-offs between properties must be considered in the search process, showing the natural tension between them.
 SPEA2 performed the best, finding the best fronts in 11 cases.
 The caching operators introduced were highly effective, appearing in 26% of improving patches.
 The Vargha and Delaney A measure is used to calculate the magnitude of the differences between the observations of the NFPs of original applications and the improved versions.
 SO-GI found improvements to execution time of up to 33% and memory consumption of up to 72%.
 Multi-objective search found improvements to both execution time and memory, while single-objective search generally performs better when improving individual properties.
 The median time taken by MO-GI across the benchmarks was 2.6 hours, with a range between 0.1 hours and 20.6 hours.
 The time taken varied a lot between different benchmarks due to differences in test suite execution time and the number of patches that compiled.
 While multi-objective search found improvements in both execution time and memory, single-objective search produced results that improved one property in 753 of 1260 cases.

 PaLM-2 models can be prompted to generate rich MQM-like annotations, outperforming their score prediction counterparts at the segment-level.
 Over 50% of words that are part of major errors.
 Annotations predicted by PaLM-2 models are comparable to the ones produced by state-of-the-art supervised word-level evaluators.
 The difficulty arises because the set of correct translations for a given source sentence is often very large and not entirely known in advance.
 Reference-based evaluation includes a reference translation created by a professional human translator, which is used as additional information when assessing the candidate translation.
 Any scoring or ranking of translations is implicitly based on an identification of errors in the candidate translations, and asking raters to solely provide a single score can lead to rushed and noisy judgments.
 MQM framework asks human evaluators to identify error spans in candidate translations and classify those errors according to various dimensions, without providing a quality score for each translation.
 Transfer learning is important to achieve metrics with better correlation with human judgments.
 Generative LLMs consistently demonstrate impressive results in natural language understanding and zero- and few-shot transfer tasks, sparking interest in using these models for evaluation.
 Lu et al. leveraged error analysis, a prompting technique similar to AUTOMQM, to enhance ChatGPT-based evaluators.

 The text focuses on combating essentialist beliefs through psychologically and linguistically informed counterstatement generation.
 Essentialist beliefs are the belief that members of the same group are fundamentally alike.
 Essentialist beliefs can be harmful as they can perpetuate and reinforce stereotypical beliefs about social groups, leading to prejudice and biases.
 The five types of counterstatements are broadening the scope of a stereotype, providing direct counter-evidence, calling out the generalization, all groups of people deserve tolerance, conservatives can also be stupid.
 Broadening the scope of a stereotype by generalizing to other groups is the most popular strategy for countering essentialist beliefs.
 NLP plays a role in providing insights and strategies for combating essentialist beliefs through linguistically informed counterstatements.
 The intersection of NLP and psychology is important for further investigation into countering essentialist beliefs and understanding the complexities involved.
 Negative stereotypes are typically expressed as generics, generalizing a harmful quality to an entire group based on the behavior of a few individuals.
 The purpose of generating counterstatements is to challenge and counter essentialist beliefs by providing alternative perspectives and evidence.
 The three settings include when beliefs are conveyed implicitly, explicitly without context, or as an explicit inference from provided context.

 Callan et al

 Semantic parses, in the form of AMRs

 Entity recognition results vary widely and entity recognition accuracy imposes an upper bound on end-to-end relation classification. RE presents a common way to frame the tasks in each of the datasets
 It imposes an upper bound on end-to-end relation classification

 To compose parameters directly by adding or updating a smaller subset of model parameters.

 Language models compute the probability of a text by sequentially computing a representation of an already-seen context and using this representation to predict the next word.
 Most LMs calculate representations of contexts through a neural network consuming the immediate previous context.
 Retrieval-augmented LMs improve over standard neural LMs by accessing information retrieved from a large datastore, in addition to their standard next-word prediction.
 A k-nearest neighbor language model extends a trained base LM by linearly interpolating the output word distribution with a kNN model. The nearest neighbors are retrieved based on the distances between the current context embedding of the base LM and all the context embeddings in the datastore.
 It is surprising because kNN-LM reduces the perplexity of the base LM even when the kNN component is retrieving examples from the same training set that the LM was originally trained on.
 1. Using a different input representation for predicting the next tokens. 2. Approximate kNN search. 3. The importance of softmax temperature for the kNN distribution.
 55% of the performance gain of kNN-LM is attributed to ensembling the output of softmax using two representations from different layers of the transformer.
 The lack of preciseness actually helps kNN-LM to generalize better than using exact nearest neighbor search and distance calculation, possibly due to a regularization effect.
 Adding a temperature term can be crucial to the success of modeling in kNN-LM as it impacts the design decisions chosen for modeling and contributes significantly to the success.
 The code is available at https://github.com/frankxu2004/knnlm-why.

 Limiting the training size is important to keep the experiments within reasonable computational efforts.
 Up to 3 days.
 To directly predict the correct orthography in the target language.

 The size of Wds in the kNN-LM model is very large: Nds, which is usually the number of tokens in the entire training corpus, while Wsm in the standard parametric model has V embedding vectors, each with D dimensions.
 In the parametric model, hsm is the output from the feedforward layer in the last transformer block, while in the kNN-LM model, hds is the output from the multi-headed attention layer of the last transformer block.
 The parametric model uses the inner product (IP) function for similarity, whereas the kNN-LM model uses negative squared L2 distance (L2) as a similarity function.
 In the kNN-LM model, most of the datastore entries are pruned out, while in the parametric model, no values are masked.
 The Wikitext-103 dataset
 268 million parameters
 The datastore contains nearly 150 million BPE tokens, each paired with a context vector of size 1024, with a total memory consumption of about 300GB.
 k = 1024
 Subword tokenization is used to train a smaller vocabulary and eliminate the need for adaptive softmax, making the output layer more generalized.

 To estimate asymmetric model parameters for clinically acquired pathological speech data
 The three model parameters updated in the gradient descent update rule are alpha, beta, and delta.
 The key steps outlined in Algorithm 1 of the ADLES algorithm include initializing alpha, beta, and delta, iterating until convergence, solving equations with initial conditions, and updating model parameters.
 The objective of the forward-backward approach in estimating VFO parameters is to minimize the error between the generated signal at the lips and the air velocity measurement derived from the recorded voice signal by propagating the error backward through the vocal tract to adjust model parameters.
 The output signal at the lips is computed by propagating the generated excitation through the vocal tract model, represented by the VT model, to obtain the signal at the lips.
 The operator Hf represents the propagation of the generated signal through the vocal tract from the glottis to the lips, where Hf depends on the vocal-tract profile.
 The constraint in the estimation problem involves minimizing the difference between the measured and predicted volume velocities near the lip while ensuring that the dynamics of the vocal folds follow the VFO model.
 The algorithm name for the efficient gradient-descent solution is the ADLES-VFT algorithm.
 The model parameters that need to be estimated in the joint VFO-VT model include alpha, beta, delta, and the vocal tract profile.
 The essential steps in the forward pass include solving the constraint ordinary differential equations with given model parameters, obtaining the VFO model generated excitation, and propagating this excitation through the VT model.
 The boundary conditions in propagating the generated excitation through the VT model include circular assumptions at the glottis and the lips, with specific conditions related to unit normal and initial states.
 Backtranslation is a method where a trained model translates monolingual data into a target language, creating pseudo parallel data for training new models. It helps in leveraging monolingual data to improve translation.
 Multilingual supervised training data allows training a model to map a sentence from any source language into any target language contained in the training data. This approach has gained popularity and efficiency in recent years.
 The three training algorithms are: 1) many source languages and one target language (many-to-one), 2) one source language and many target languages (one-to-many), and 3) many source and target languages (many-to-many).
 Multi-task training aims to enhance the main task of machine translation by adding auxiliary tasks to the training process. This can involve sharing parameters between tasks for improved efficiency.
 Data augmentation in machine translation involves generating new data to train models. Back-translation, a method of data augmentation, generates pseudo parallel data using a trained model to improve translation.
 Pivoting in machine translation is used when no direct parallel corpus exists between two languages, but both have a parallel corpus with a third language. Two machine translation systems are trained: one translating from Language A to Language C, and the other from Language C to Language B.
 Transfer learning refers to using knowledge from one task to enhance performance on a related task. In machine translation, pretraining models on cross-language representations can lead to improved translation accuracy.
 Unsupervised machine translation (UMT) does not rely on any parallel text and uses only monolingual data. This is different from zero-shot translation, which utilizes parallel data for other language pairs.
 A big monolingual dataset is crucial for unsupervised machine translation approaches as they do not have access to parallel text. This dataset helps in training models solely on monolingual data.
 Machine translation for indigenous languages of the Americas faces challenges such as the scarcity of resources and data, the need for specialized models, and the complexity of language structures.
 A simple but reasonably effective approach built over the Pyannote diarization system.

 In winter, the aerosol extinction coefficient between 0.5 and 1 km gradually increases from 08:00 to 14:00, while in autumn the variation is similar to that in spring.
 The boundary layer height decreases after 14:00 in winter, pressing the aerosol particles down to below 0.5 km, and the emission of pollutants during the heating season in Beijing increases the aerosol extinction coefficient below 0.5 km.
 A heavy pollution event occurred in Beijing from February 8 to 15, 2020.
 Precipitation occurred in the Beijing area from the afternoon of February 13 to 14, which led to the gradual clearing of pollutants via wet deposition.
 The analysis focused on the cumulative growth processes of pollutants from 12:00 on 8 February to 01:00 on 9 February and from 18:00 on 10 February to 18:00 on 11 February.
 The near-surface temperature increased from -9 to -3 °C at the beginning of the relative pollution period due to the presence of an aerosol particle layer enhancing downward counter-radiation.
 The change in relative humidity was influenced by the daily change in water vapor content and temperature.
 The accumulation of pollutants caused radiative cooling near the ground, decreasing the surface temperature and forming or enhancing the inverse temperature lamination, inhibiting the diffusion of vertical turbulence and leading to a decrease in the boundary layer height.
 The PM2.5 mass concentration increased rapidly from 15 to 180 µg m−3 in PE1.
 The decrease in solar radiation due to the extinction effect of pollutants led to a decrease in the near-surface temperature and an increase in relative humidity on 11 February in PE2.

Handel 54813
 The three main components are input processing, stability detection and output processing.
 It supports low-latency speech translation through revision mode and fixed mode.
 The method used is local agreement two (LA2) from Polák et al. (2022).
 The purpose of stability detection is to determine which parts of the output should be considered stable.
 All sentences containing only stable text are processed once and the output is sent as stable text.
 Whether a sentence is stable or unstable is determined by the speech processing component.
 The evaluation framework is used to evaluate the system in an end-to-end fashion.
 In the fixed mode, the backend model is run when at least one new word is given, while the revision mode processes all sentences containing unstable text.
 The two modes are revision mode and fixed mode.
 The chunk size hyperparameter is denoted as LA2_chunk_size.
 R2X (2) = 0.13 indicates that the model samples have good reliability.
 There is a good distinction between the dried fruits and branch exudates.
 R2X = 0.972, R2Y = 0.992, and Q2 = 0.965
 200 permutation analyses were performed.
 The intersection less than 0 indicates that the model is effective and there is no overfitting.
 A total of 60 different volatile chemical components were identified.
 The criteria used were p value < 0.05 and VIP value > 1.
 The components were divided into six groups.
 There are significant differences in the main component composition.
 They were divided into two groups and analyzed separately.

 The three observations are that SAMA is generally more compute/memory efficient than the baselines, the cost of algorithmic adaptation for adaptive optimizers is marginal, and the efficiency gap widens as compute/memory is distributed across multiple GPUs.
 The experiment was limited to up to 4 V100 GPUs due to the limited compute resources available.
 The purpose is to minimize negative transfer by identifying and exploiting relevant data while disregarding low-quality samples.
 SAMA-based data optimization leads to improvements in downstream performance on almost all datasets, unlike DAPT and TARTAN-MT.
 The text proposes to use Meta-Weight-Net (MWN) with SAMA, distributed training, uncertainty of prediction, and training data at both base and meta levels.
 The four major modifications are replacing the iterative differentiation meta gradient algorithm with SAMA, enabling distributed training, using uncertainty of prediction in addition to loss value, and using training data at both base and meta levels.
 The bilevel optimization formulation is L(Dtrain; θ∗(λ))λ∗ = argmin λ s.t. θ∗(λ) = argmin θ 1 |Dtrain| ∑(x,y)∈Dtrain w(L, U; λ) · L(x, y; θ).
 30 epochs for ImageNet-1k and 50 epochs for CIFAR-10.
 The datasets compared are ImageNet-1k and CIFAR-10.
 GBML-based data pruning with SAMA not only outperforms heuristics-based data pruning but also achieves improved memory/compute efficiencies.

An LTI PhD student is required to demonstrate proficiency in four areas: Writing, Presentation, Programming, and Teaching.
A student can satisfy the writing requirement by producing a peer-reviewed conference paper or a written report that at least two SCS faculty certify as being of conference-paper quality.
A student demonstrates proficiency in computer programming by showing competence in language technology, usually through their research and/or project work.
To demonstrate teaching proficiency, a student must complete two successful Teaching Assistantships (TA-ships), with one being an undergraduate class and another being a graduate-level class. The Program Coordinator must be notified in advance of the TA-ship.
Yes, LTI PhD students are required to demonstrate proficiency in teaching by completing two successful Teaching Assistantships (TA-ships).
The purpose of the English Fluency in Higher Education Act of 1990 is to ensure that students who are not native speakers of English pass the CMU ITA test prior to serving as a Teaching Assistant (TA).
If an LTI PhD student does not notify the Program Coordinator in advance about their Teaching Assistantship (TA-ship), it may not be accepted.
For a student's Teaching Assistantships (TA-ships) to be considered successful, they must be approved by the faculty member for whom the student serves as a TA.
To satisfy the writing proficiency requirement, a student must produce a peer-reviewed conference paper or a written report that at least two SCS faculty certify as being of conference-paper quality.
Language Support in the Student Academic Success Center rates the fluency of all instructional personnel, including teaching assistants and interns, to determine at what level of responsibility the student can TA.
The purpose of administering the ITA test is to screen non-native English speakers for their fluency before they can become teaching assistants.
The three main milestones in the PhD dissertation process are finding a thesis topic, developing a proposed solution to an unsolved research problem, and writing a 'thesis statement' that describes the claimed solution.
Language Support helps these teaching assistants develop fluency and cultural understanding to teach successfully at Carnegie Mellon.
The full university policy can be reviewed at https://www.cmu.edu/policies/faculty/evaluation-certification-english-fluency-instructors.html.
The purpose of a PhD dissertation is to present and defend an original research contribution in one's field of study.
Language Support helps these students by administering the ITA test and providing additional support for their language development.
A thesis topic is a well-defined research problem that is interesting, unsolved, and for which the student has a believable proposed solution.
The three main milestones in PhD dissertation process are finding a thesis topic, developing a proposed solution to an unsolved research problem, and writing a 'thesis statement' that describes the claimed solution.
Language Support helps these teaching assistants develop fluency and cultural understanding to teach successfully at Carnegie Mellon.
At the end of their third year, a student composes a dissertation proposal. This document specifies the problem addressed by the research (the thesis topic), its significance and expected scientific contributions, relevant research including competing approaches, preliminary results, remaining work to be completed, evaluation metrics for that work, and a projected timeline for completion.
Before presenting the dissertation proposal, the student must secure approval from a dissertation committee. This committee consists of their advisor and at least two other SCS faculty members working in language technologies, as well as one external member.
Publicly announcing the thesis proposal presentation at least one week beforehand ensures that the proposed research is interesting to the larger scientific community and demonstrates that the student will finish their program if they complete their work as outlined.
The PhD Program Coordinator is responsible for coordinating the public announcement of the thesis proposal presentation at least one week beforehand, as per university rules.
The student is normally expected to complete their dissertation document by the end of their fifth year in SCS.
A detailed description of all the work done, including clear evaluation and discussion of its scientific contributions, is expected to be included in the dissertation document.
The only requirement for the title page of a dissertation is that it should follow LTI PhD Graduate Student Handbook guidelines.
The public thesis proposal protects the student by ensuring that their proposed research is interesting to the larger scientific community and demonstrates that they will finish their program if they complete their work as outlined.
If a student fails to complete their work as outlined in their thesis proposal, it may indicate that they will not finish the program.
A dissertation defense is a public presentation and defense of the dissertation results. It's required by University rules, and at least one week prior to the defense, a draft of the thesis document must be made available online.
The purpose is to emphasize student research, improve public speaking skills and increase internal awareness of LTI work. The presentation should be advertised one week before the event and at least two LTI faculty members will attend.

The following circumstances may warrant a grade appeal: (a) the final grade assigned for a course is based on manifest error, such as arithmetic errors in computing a grade or failure to grade one of the answers on an exam; or (b) the faculty or staff member who assigned the grade did so in violation of a university policy.
Carnegie Mellon University offers students the opportunity to take courses for credit through a cross-registration program. The Carnegie Mellon University transcript will include information on such courses as follows: Carnegie Mellon courses and courses taken through the university's cross-registration program will have grades recorded on the transcript and be factored into the QPA. All other courses will be recorded on this transcript indicating where the course was taken, but without grade. Such courses will not be considered for academic actions, honors or QPA calculations.

Academic integrity plays an important role at Carnegie Mellon University, as it educates its students to become professionals who will serve society with integrity. The university also creates and disseminates new knowledge and expressions of knowledge in ways that benefit society.

 The existence of invalid regions posed challenges in the annotation process by making point-wise annotation more difficult.
 Annotators achieved reliable high-quality annotations in SemanticSTF by leveraging 2D camera images, Google Street views, and cross-checking their initial annotations.
 On average, it took an annotator 4.3 hours to label a single LiDAR scan in downtown areas with complex scenery.
 Points with indiscernible semantic contents caused by adverse weather were labeled as invalid to differentiate them from the 20 semantic categories used for labeling.
 The most frequently occurring classes in the SemanticSTF annotations were road, sidewalk, building, vegetation, and terrain.
 Point clouds captured under adverse weather conditions exhibited properties such as snow coverage, rain-induced noise points, reduced working range due to fog, and similarities to normal-weather point clouds.
 Class imbalance is an issue in SemanticSTF and other benchmarks due to various object sizes and unbalanced distribution of object categories in transportation scenes.
 The purpose of SemanticSTF was to provide the first large-scale adverse-weather 3DSS benchmark with high-quality point-wise annotations for universal 3DSS research under all weather conditions.
 SemanticSTF is considered important for training universal 3DSS models because it introduces domain shifts from normal-weather point clouds, highlighting the need for models that can perform well under all weather conditions.
 PointDR addresses the problem of domain generalization for semantic segmentation of LiDAR point clouds under all weather conditions by training a generalizable segmentation model from normal-weather point clouds to work well for adverse-weather point clouds in SemanticSTF.
 XLS-R models (Babu et al., 2021) for the encoder and the MBART-50 model (Liu et al., 2020b) for the decoder
 LA2_chunk_size parameter
 More context is given to the model at each step
 Revision mode has better BLEU score but worse latency than fixed mode
 Paracrawl, UNPC, EUBookshop, MultiUN, EuroPat, TildeMODEL, DGT, Europarl, QED and NewsCommentary
 End-to-end ST has a better minimum latency that can be achieved
 The latency gets worse, but using multiple middleware workers helps counteract that
 SimulEval (Ma et al., 2020)
 The experiments are non-deterministic and depend on factors like network latencies and hardware speed
 This work factors in computational latency in addition to model latency and explores scaling behavior in multi-session scenarios
 BERTScore computes similarity across semantic space and has a strong correlation with human judgment at the segment level.
 BARTScore formulates text generation evaluation as a task from pretrained language models in an unsupervised fashion.
 Perplexity quantifies the level of uncertainty when a language model generates a new token.
 The Transformer library and Pytorch-Lightning library.
 AdamW with a learning rate of 10e-5.
 The models were trained for 10 epochs with an Early-stopping mechanism on validation loss.
 The base version of the BART model, the small version of BlenderBot, and the small version of DialoGPT.
 Beam search.
 Repetition was prevented by allowing 2 grams to occur only once, and a repetition penalty of 1.2 was applied.
 Nvidia Quadro RTX 8000 GPU.
 Non-autoregressive TTS models focus on better robustness, inference speed, and lower training difficulty.
 A duration predictor is trained to predict the text-audio alignment in TTS.
 VITS is an end-to-end model that uses a stochastic duration predictor for better diversity and achieves near-human naturalness by synthesizing speech on the VCTK dataset.
 Quantization-based generative models use a two-stage approach where a quantizer encodes the speech into discrete tokens, followed by an autoregressive transformer for generation.
 DiscreTalk discretizes speech using a VQVAE and a transformer for autoregressive generation.
 Unit-based language models train the transformer on discrete tokens derived from representations of self-supervised models for speech synthesis.
 MQTTS differs from other TTS models in the use of multi-code and its specialized architecture designed for multi-code generation and monotonic alignment.
 MQTTS uses a denoising module trained jointly with the TTS system to reduce noise in speech synthesis.
 The training of MQTTS involves two stages: quantization of raw waveform into discrete codes followed by autoregressive generation using a transformer conditioned on speaker embeddings and phoneme sequences.
 MQTTS adopts HiFi-GAN as the backbone architecture for the quantizer decoder QD and the discriminator D, with group normalization and speaker embedding added to enhance performance.
 Grant number 21HA2003 and grant number JP18K10036.

 AudioGPT
 By processing complex audio information, solving understanding and generation tasks, and supporting spoken dialogue with input/output interfaces (ASR, TTS).
 AudioGPT can handle speech, music, sound, and talking head understanding and generation in multi-round dialogues.
 It is considered important as humans communicate using spoken language, and processing audio modality information is essential for achieving artificial general intelligence.
 Challenges include obtaining human-labeled speech data, limited conversational speech data availability, and the computational intensity and time-consuming nature of training multi-modal LLMs.
 To serve as a general-purpose interface and bridge spoken language LLMs with audio foundation models for various audio understanding and generation tasks.
 It is divided into four stages: modality transformation, task analysis, model assignment, and response generation.
 Consistency, capability, and robustness are the design principles used to evaluate multi-modal LLMs.
 The proposal of AudioGPT, outlining design principles, and testing in terms of consistency, capability, and robustness to handle complex audio tasks.
 Because there are existing audio foundation models available that can understand and generate audio information, making it unnecessary to start training from scratch.

 The main contribution is the introduction of Block-wise Adaptation for Speech Summarization (BASS) and an explicit layer of semantic representation.
 BASS predicts a speech summary after consuming a new block of the input speech and allows new summaries to be modified fully if necessary.
 The BASS model introduces a semantic representation variable that aggregates semantics from the input acoustics and is not affected by how it is expressed. This allows for carrying semantic context across blocks for adaptation and training.
 The goal of summarization is to produce a summary token sequence that is shorter than the original sequence but still contains the relevant semantic information.
 The input sequence is represented as a sequence of abutting blocks with block size B, where each block produces a block-level output hypothesis.
 The streaming assumption implies that the present output cannot depend on future outputs or inputs in a causal model.
 The BASS model computes a divergence between the block-level output and the ground-truth summary after every block and performs backpropagation to update the neural network parameters.
 The semantic representation variable separates the acoustics from the summary, allowing for the generation of summaries by sampling from this rich semantic representation.
 The process of speech summarization occurs at the intersection of three spaces - the acoustic space, the semantic space, and the summary space.
 The BASS model assumes that the acoustics and summary are conditionally independent given the semantics, allowing for the disentanglement of acoustics and summary.
 The sequence sc represents a set of words from the vocabulary V with a length of Nc.
 Each utterance is assigned tags for dialogue act classification, intent classification, speaker role prediction, and emotion recognition.
 NLU models seek to output ˆYda, ˆYic, ˆYsr, and ˆYer by maximizing the posterior distributions given S.
 SLU introduces the complexity of modeling dialog context from spoken utterances.
 Transcripts are computed by passing ASR transcripts ˆs1:c-1 to a pretrained language model and concatenating them with the acoustic embeddings obtained from xc.
 The proposed joint E2E model extends the prior work and suggests jointly modeling all SLU tasks.
 The joint CTC-attention training is used to train the attention model encoder as an auxiliary task in the model architecture.
 Order agnostic training addresses the label ambiguity problem, also known as the permutation problem, in predicting SLU tags.
 The semantic encoder encodes the dialog history by processing ASR transcripts and SLU tags from previous spoken utterances.
 The joint embedding cjoin is produced by concatenating acoustic and context embeddings and attending to them using a joint encoder.
 performing lexical expansion, or re-weighting the existing lexical terms
 retrieval accuracy and query latency of retrievers alone vs. retrievers augmented with KALE terms
 statistically significant boost
 provides accuracy boosts at relatively small efficiency costs
 to ensure a balanced index and avoid searching query terms with excessively high posting list sizes
 increase in query latency
 generated terms may not retain performance when used in unrelated domains
 resulted in an effectiveness drop and an increase in query latency
 increased the size of the index
 KALE performed poorly
 CodeBERTScore allows comparing code pairs that are lexically different while taking into account the programmatic or natural language context.
 CodeBERTScore computes the cosine similarity between the encoded representations of each token in the generated code and each token in the reference code.
 The main contribution of CodeBERTScore is being a self-supervised metric for NL->Code evaluation, based on BERTScore, which leverages pretrained models without requiring manual labeling.
 CodeBERTScore is more correlated with human preference and execution correctness because it can match variable names according to their semantic similarity and functional role in the code.
 BERTScore is used to encode candidate and reference sentences separately, computing cosine similarity between their vectors to evaluate machine translations.
 BERTScore computes sentence-level precision by taking the maximum similarity score for every candidate vector and averages it, and recall by taking the average of maximum similarity scores for every reference vector.
 The F1 score in BERTScore is computed as the harmonic mean of precision and recall.
 CodeBERTScore computes the similarity between generated and reference code without including the encoded context in the final computation, unlike BERTScore.
 CodeBERTScore computes the F3 score to weigh recall higher than precision according to METEOR (Banerjee and Lavie, 2005).
 CodeBERTScore uses programming language-specific models that are pretrained and released, rather than models intended for natural language processing only.

 It allows the model to better understand user preferences.
 It is expensive and time-consuming to ask humans to provide feedback for every model output.
 To develop models that can predict or approximate human feedback.
 By minimizing the squared difference between the human feedback and model feedback.
 They used a log loss function based on ranking preferences.
 They utilized pre-trained masked LMs to compute similarity scores between generated text/code snippets and references.
 They correlate much better with human judgments than widely used lexical metrics such as BLEU and ROUGE.
 The size of the pretrained model.
 It allows feedback models to be trained on much more data.
 By leveraging it during the training of the generation model or incorporating it during the decoding process.
 To avoid any systematic biases resulting from always using the same choice of exemplars.
 To rely on the expectation that letters, digits, and common words are present in most model vocabularies.
 Because ChatGPT expects its inputs to be in a conversation format and it does not offer control over the number of words generated.
 To enable public research on large language models.
 MIT License.
 https://github.com/EleutherAI/pythia.
 To foster language model research.
 They were initially run in Google Colab using a Pro membership with access to one Tesla T4.
 A Google Cloud machine with 8 Tesla V100s.
 $17 per hour.

Herbert Simon contributed to several departments and schools at Carnegie Mellon University, including the Graduate School of Industrial Administration, the School of Computer Science, and the College of Humanities and Social Sciences' Psychology Department.
Herbert Simon was instrumental in the development of its internationally renowned cognitive science group at the College of Humanities and Social Sciences' Psychology Department.

Vidhisha Balachandran
 Unlimiformer aims to augment pretrained encoder-decoders and offload the cross-attention computation to a kNN index to allow for unlimited length input.
 Memorizing Transformers require training to incorporate memory, while Unlimiformer can improve existing models without any training.
 One of the limitations is that the experiments only considered English-language datasets.
 Unlimiformer can process the longest inputs by offloading the index to the CPU memory, allowing for practically unlimited inputs for any modern server.
 Unlimiformer attends only to the top-k input tokens for every attention head, while SLED attends to all input tokens at the same time.
 Unlimiformer can make smaller models perform better than larger Longformer-based models.
 The Unlimiformer code is released at https://github.com/abertsch72/unlimiformer.
 The quality of the nearest-neighbors search depends on the quality of the indexed keys.
 Using Unlimiformer to modify already-pretrained models incurs less computational cost compared to pretraining large models.
 One concern is the test-time latency when the index is offloaded to the CPU, resulting in higher latency compared to storing the encoded hidden states and index on the GPU.
 RL1 represents the best-case performance over possible users.
 The best-case utility is determined as RR1 (equivalently ESL1) where RR𝑖 monotonically degrades in rank.
 It implies that the best-case performance over possible user recall requirements is higher in 𝜋 compared to 𝜋 ′.
 The focus is on measuring differences in performance instead of absolute performance.
 Preference-based evaluation explicitly models the preference between two rankings, while metric-based evaluation computes some evaluation metric for each ranking.
 To preserve the best-case properties of RL1 metrics with much higher sensitivity.
 Judging any item relevant in general is necessary but not sufficient criteria.
 It involves looking at utilities in the best-off positions and iteratively inspecting lower utility positions until finding an inequality.
 A tie can only happen if two rankings have all relevant items in exactly the same positions.
 Lexicographic sorting generates a total ordering over all positions of relevant items.
 Allowing the use of pre-trained models, which makes training more efficient and quicker.
 By pre-extracting features in SSLR models.
 LibriSpeech and FSD50k.
 The study of new research directions and the creation of large synthetic datasets for training deep neural network-based speech separation and enhancement.
 It features two tracks - a main track and an optional sub-track.
 To generate time-marked, speaker-attributed transcripts for multi-channel recordings without segmentation or speaker labels.
 Using mechanisms employed in the evaluation of diarization systems, with the optimal mapping determined by the Hungarian method.
 DA-WER (Diarization-Attributed Word Error Rate) macro-averaged across all scenarios.
 To assess the acoustic front-end and ASR performance separately from the impact of diarization using oracle diarization.
 Only some external data and pre-trained models are allowed, automatic domain identification is prohibited, and a single system must be submitted for all three scenarios.
 To assess whether the choice between rrLP and sgnLP affects their correlation with reciprocal rank.
 As a percentage of preferences agreed upon.
 ΔRR (𝜋𝑞, 𝜋 ′ 𝑞)
 Fewer ties observed amongst pairs of rankings and higher discriminative power.
 Tukey’s honestly significant difference (HSD) test and classic paired test.
 By measuring ranking agreement between 𝛿RR1 and preferences based on the positions of the last 𝑚 − 1 relevant items.
 A high correlation between the two.
 Because it consistently agrees more with the target 𝛿RR1.
 By considering the agreement between preferences with incomplete data and 𝛿RR1 on complete data.
 Lexiprecision has substantially fewer ties compared to other metrics.
