 MVI stands for microvascular invasion.
 The study was completed in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki.
 The ethics committee of the Second Affiliated Hospital of Guangzhou University of Chinese Medicine reviewed and approved the studies.
 The requirement for written informed consent was waived.
 AFP stands for alpha-fetoprotein.
 The work was funded by the Traditional Chinese medicine research project of the Second Affiliated Hospital of Guangzhou University of Chinese Medicine.
 ROC stands for receiver operating characteristic.
 AUROC stands for area under ROC curve and is used for prediction and classification.
 PPV stands for positive predictive value.
 The VICT2 trait is a prognostic alternative to peritumoral hepatobiliary phase hypointensity in HCC.
 The AV-SUPERB benchmark was proposed to enable general-purpose evaluation of unimodal audio/visual and bimodal fusion representations on 7 datasets covering 5 audio-visual tasks in speech and audio processing.
 The AV-SUPERB benchmark comprises of three tracks to assess audio, video, and audio-visual fusion representations, designed to allow researchers to compare learning strategies across models and modalities.
 The AV-SUPERB benchmark aims to evaluate representations across seven distinct datasets involving five speech and audio processing tasks.
 The pretrain-then-finetune paradigm is considered effective for building multitasking algorithmic systems in speech, audio, and vision domains.
 Pretrained representations obtained through self-supervised loss functions allow models to be applied to diverse tasks by fine-tuning minimal additional parameters.
 The contributions of the AV-SUPERB benchmark include diverse-domain evaluation, easy and reproducible benchmarking, intermediate-task fine-tuning, and layer-wise analysis of contributions to task performance.
 Previous multitask benchmarks in speech, audio, and video representation learning evaluate models across different tasks to promote research towards general approaches applicable to various real-world tasks.
 The SUPERB and SUPERB-SG benchmarks evaluate speech representation models on a wide range of downstream tasks covering content, speaker, and other aspects of speech.
 The HEAR benchmark evaluates audio representations on domains beyond speech, such as music and environmental sounds.
 Multi-task multimodal benchmarks allow for a focus on the relationship between paired audio/visual inputs, promoting research that leverages this connection.
 The main focus is on computational fairness analysis and mitigating bias in text through style transfer.
 They use a rule-based method to convert gendered pronouns to singular they pronouns and swap gendered words with gender-neutral versions.
 They formulate the task as a neural style transfer problem and use an adversarial approach to retain the style of the written text.
 They focus on bias association of input templates with the output of language models and perform a text-to-text generation task.
 The focus is on providing the large language model (LLM) with various contexts in addition to bias association trigger words and performing a text-to-text generation task.
 Bias is quantitatively measured by looking at the most frequently occurring words across outputs generated by different trigger words and using the pointwise mutual information concept to identify words that occur more in the outputs of queer trigger words compared to straight counterparts.
 They engineer prompts to reduce bias in distilled language models by augmenting the dataset with corresponding counterfactual sentences.
 They formulate the debiasing method as a style transfer problem and focus on increasing the overall regard score of the sentence.
 SHAP (SHapley Additive ex- Planations) is used to delete the words that lead to an input text being marked as sarcastic in a text-to-text style transfer problem.
 They implement a fine-tuning technique on a dataset augmented with additional data to reduce bias in pre-trained language models.
Kasparov claimed to have seen 'human intelligence' behind Deep Blue's moves.
No, they said it was not true.
Berliner thinks that intelligence emerges just like life emerges. He believes even the dumbest living thing has some sort of intelligence.
Kasparov saw machine intelligence, not human intelligence.
Berliner describes Watson's ability to answer 'Jeopardy!' questions as quite marvelous.
Watson's understanding of slang and idiom is notable, says Berliner because it's not easy in the area of general intelligence.
Watson had an unfair advantage over its human competitors as it received the Jeopardy! answers in written form and could immediately get to work, while the human players were still listening to and parsing the text.
Watson had a tremendous advantage as it was way, way ahead in understanding the question—maybe a second or two ahead.
Berliner pointed out that many of the human beings never got a chance to show what they knew because Watson rang in before them.
Berliner was driven by high standards for himself, believing that the only things he could offer the world were those same standards.
After concluding that Botvinnik's published results couldn't be duplicated, Berliner accused the chess grandmaster of manipulating his outcomes.
While some professional reviewers criticized the book, Berliner remained unbowed by the personal attacks.
Campbell believes that a strong personality and the ability to be lonely are essential traits for such individuals.
Berliner's reputation as a fearless advocate overshadowed his generous spirit, according to his former students.
Palay believes that Berliner has a strong and gracious personality both on a personal level and professional level.
Berliner treated his students with great concern for their well-being, not just as his students but also as people.
Palay consciously mimics Berliner's style of interaction when dealing with his own colleagues.
Palay said that working with Hans was a lot of fun and he consciously mimics Berliner's style when interacting with his own colleagues.
Ebeling said that Berliner led by example more than anything else, and there was a constant attention to detail. He always thought about the next idea that might work.
Palay thinks that Berliner's research legacy 'might not at all be guessable at this point', but notes that the pendulum seems to be swinging back from purely statistical machine-learning methods in translation and other fields to hybrids that include rule-based search techniques.
Palay predicts that some of the things that Berliner was working on will resurrect themselves over time as they start hitting walls, and tracing them back to Berliner will be difficult but the seeds will be there.
Schaeffer thinks that as computer scientists try to reduce power consumption and face difficulty adapting some problems to parallel computing, they will look for more efficient search algorithms.
Schaeffer thinks that Berliner's most lasting legacy is his graduate students, as he didn't have many but they were of very high quality.
Berliner no longer plays chess because he believes that once you reach a certain level, it becomes less enjoyable.
Berliner noticed a 'deplorable trend' where some students were attempting to talk their way around difficult problems instead of doing the necessary research.
Berliner advises students to learn as much substantive knowledge as possible, because all knowledge is interconnected and will help them make better decisions in the future. He also suggests learning something quantitative or acquiring a skill that others would be willing to pay for.
When the weather is good, Berliner enjoys strolling on the beach and thinking.
Students interested in learning more about Berliner's advice can reach out to Jason Togyer at 412-268-8721 or via email at jt3y@cs.cmu.edu.
Berliner believes that learning something quantitative will make it easier for students to make good decisions in the future, as all knowledge is interconnected.
Instead of playing chess, Berliner works on his solitaire game and keeps records of winning strategies.
Berliner retired from CMU in 1998.
Berliner thinks it is a 'deplorable trend' for some students to try and talk their way out of solving difficult problems, rather than performing the necessary research.

 Into three areas: Function, Sensation, and Aesthetics
 SCI-FI Fine Motor, SCI-FI Self-Care, PROMIS Upper Extremity, or Neuro-QoL Upper Extremity- Fine Motor
 Satisfaction with hand functioning
 Reduced phantom limb pain and neuroma-related pain
 To restore more natural motor control and sensation to the injured limb
 Aesthetic and cosmetic aspects, such as mismatched skin tone, body hair color/texture, and musculature/size/bulk of transplanted limb
 To address issues that are critical to those who have undergone UE transplant but are absent from existing HRQOL measurement systems

 To provide evidence for evaluating UE transplant outcomes and to address emotional, social, and physical functioning

 To make more explicit the implicit values behind human decision-making and to steer AI systems to make decisions that are more in accordance with them.

 Language-aware interlingua for multilingual neural machine translation
 arXiv preprint for neural machine translation
 The size of the network becomes a challenge
 A language-aware input layer, a deep transformer architecture, and an online back-translation approach
 By proposing a differentiable data selection method that automatically learns to weight training data
 Sharing all parameters except for the attention mechanism
 Two special language embeddings - one encoding unique characteristics of each language and the other capturing common semantics across languages
 Translation into the wrong language
 Weighting the target language label with jointly training one cross attention head with word alignments
 They extend it with a cascade architecture where the first decoder reads the encoder, and the second decoder reads both the encoder and the first decoder
 Examples include Imputer, Mask-CTC, Insertion-based modeling, CIF, and other variants.
 0.06 real-time factor (RTF)
 The major difference is whether they perform hypothesis pruning for every input frame or every output token.
 The hypothesis that reaches the end of an utterance (predicts the end of sentence symbol ⟨eos⟩) is added.
 The greedy search algorithm does not consider alternate hypotheses in a sequence.
 To avoid extremely long/short output sequences which can result in large deletion and insertion errors.
 The thresholds are determined proportionally to the input frame length |X| with tunable parameters ρmin and ρmax.
 A length penalty and a coverage term are mentioned.
 It can provide block-wise monotonic alignment constraint between the input feature and output label, and realize block-wise streaming decoding.
 Model fusion during decoding is similar to the classical HMM-based beam search.
 The metrics are false alarm (FA) rate, missed detection (MISS) rate, speaker error (SPKERR) rate, and the DER.
 The visual modality of the VSD system is not disturbed by the acoustic environment unlike the ASD system, which results in better performance.
 The high false alarm rate in the VSD system is potentially due to the lip movement in the silent segments.
 Combining the audio and visual modalities in the AVSD system yields the best performance, as it overcomes the individual weaknesses of each modality.
 Six experiments are designed for the diarization and recognition system.
 The high MISS and SPKERR rate in the ASD+ASR system results in a large number of deletion errors of target speakers and insertion errors of interfering speakers.
 In the VSD+ASR system, the visual modality of the speaker diarization module dominates the performance by reducing substitution errors and improving the whole system performance.
 Incorporating audio modality information to modify video modality in AVSD significantly improves the results compared to VSD, and the AVDR system results are also improved.
 The TV background noise may cover the voice of the target speakers and contain the voice of irrelevant speakers, interfering with speaker diarization and speech recognition.
 The text points out potential difficulties such as far-field video quality, indistinguishable speakers, and the impact of audio and visual modalities.
 Scenarios such as generating or endorsing hate speech, disseminating false information, engaging in illegal activities, managing sensitive data, attempting language generalization beyond Arabic and English, and making critical decisions with high stakes.
 Training was performed on the Condor Galaxy Supercomputer using a customized version of the Cerebras modelzoo.
 3.6 million Arabic instructions.
 The prompt and response pairs were collected from multiple publicly available sources.
 The instruction-tuning data has been collected up to July 2023.
 Efforts have been made to reduce unintentional biases in the dataset, including curated Arabic data.
 Designed as an AI assistant for Arabic and English, its purpose is to enhance human productivity.
 Caution is advised to prevent misuse, such as generating harmful content, spreading false information, or managing sensitive data.
 Responsible and judicious use of the model is strongly encouraged.
 The Jais-chat 13B model can accurately respond in Arabic and English, but may not provide accurate responses in other languages.
 The focus was on the temporal stability of daily, monthly, and yearly solar PV and wind power variabilities under carbon-neutral scenarios.
 While there were large regional differences, overall, the temporal stability of solar PVPOT and WP variabilities improved in most sub-regions studied.
 The variabilities decreased in five sub-regions except for southern South America.
 The eastern United States, western Europe, India, and eastern China experienced a decrease, with exceptions in southern South America and western Africa.
 The findings suggest that global carbon-neutral policies improve the temporal stability of daily, monthly, and yearly solar PVPOT and WP in most of the global land regions studied.
 The knowledge gaps include the need for analysis beyond high-warming scenarios, a global integrated assessment, consideration of variability across time scales, and the bias introduced in projected wind energy calculations.
 The wind speed at 100 m was estimated using a spatially variant scaling factor, which is considered closer to benchmark.
 The model projections were run under deep decarbonization scenarios that reach global carbon neutrality earlier than previous scenarios.
 While the RCP2.6 scenario projected decreased solar PV in India by the end of the twenty-first century, the STR scenario projected that solar PV would rebound to historical levels by the mid-twenty-first century.
 The analysis highlighted a north-to-south inter-hemispheric shift and a notable west-to-east shift of wind energy due to deep decarbonization, with a large enhancement of wind energy in western Africa.
 Solving the executability issue by training an action scoring model to re-weigh LLM action choices
 LLM scores work for simple environments with limited actions like pick/place but fail with environments containing more objects and diverse actions
 By using GPT3 to generate step-by-step low-level commands with more action diversity and on-the-fly re-plan
 Fully text-based environment, consistent expert trajectories, and a fully text-based action space
 Better generalization to human goal specifications which the agents were not trained on
 To handle the changing action space for text environments
 A 15% improvement over the state-of-the-art for generalization via sub-task planning and tracking
 Combining a zero-shot subtask-level LLM planner and progress tracker with a low-level conditional sub-task policy
 Memory, planning, exploration, and common sense
 Pre-trained LLM generates a list of sub-tasks for an input task description using samples from the training set as in-context examples

 Linguistic Models (LMs) should retrieve information only when they lack the required knowledge to avoid unnecessary or inappropriate retrieval.
 Low probability/confidence often indicates a lack of knowledge for large LMs.
 The goal of active retrieval is to benefit future generations.
 Generating a temporary next sentence, using it as a query to retrieve relevant documents, and then regenerating the next sentence conditioning on the retrieved documents.
 Forward-Looking Active REtrieval augmented generation (FLARE).
 Multihop QA (2WikiMultihopQA), commonsense reasoning (StrategyQA), long-form QA (ASQA), and open-domain summarization (WikiAsp).
 FLARE achieves superior or competitive performance compared to single-time and multi-time retrieval baselines.
 To directly use the user input as the query for retrieval and generate the complete answer at once.
 Active retrieval augmented generation involves actively deciding when and what to retrieve throughout the generation process, while single-time retrieval augmented generation generates the complete answer at once.
 To prompt the LM to generate retrieval queries when necessary while generating the answer using retrieval-encouraging instructions.

 The submission explores data augmentation and modeling approaches across seven low-resource languages.
 All of the languages have less than 40k lines of training data, with the smallest dataset having only 31 lines of data.
 Creating artificial data from the provided training data and utilizing existing IGT resources in other languages.
 An enhanced version of the provided token classification baseline and a pre-trained multilingual seq2seq model.
 Approximately 78% of words in Gitksan are classified as out-of-vocabulary.
 The post-correction method focuses on Gitksan and integrates a pre-existing dictionary to correct model outputs.
 Word-level accuracy.
 92.98% with XLM-R augmented model.
 Adafactor.
 2,000 steps.
 Regression analysis for ordinal variables and most common subgroup vs. rest 2-sided t-tests for categorical groups were used.
 Male (vs. non-male) folks were more likely and straight (vs. non-straight) folks were less likely to share a missing perspective.
 No, the results were no longer significant after the correction.
 It is likely that false positives may have slipped through, especially when conducting multiple hypothesis tests.
 To conduct more extensive, larger-scale surveying in future work.
 Most people agreed with most of the outputs, with an agreement rate of over 80%.
 The diversity of the dataset increased as measured by unique n-grams divided by the length of the dataset.
 GPT-4 was found to be successful in generating values.
 Solution generation was found to be quite challenging and often easier than solution verification.
 An outsize proportion of the dataset involved toxic, NSFW, or sexually explicit content.

 The purpose of the DACS approach is to maintain benchmark consistency across different base methods.
 Both DACS and SAC use a standard DeepLabv2 backbone.
 DACS and CAG baselines serve as strong baselines for evaluating the approach as they achieve superior accuracies.
 The base method regularized with the constraint outperforms the unregularized version in terms of mIoU.
 Categories such as sidewalk, sky, traffic light, traffic sign, and bike show improvement with the regularized version.
 Large gains are observed in both frequent (sidewalk, wall) and less-frequent (bus, bike) classes.
 The object-region aware constraint is suspected to be the reason for the observed uniformity in gains across different classes.
 The blue dashed box highlights the semantic classes that the regularized version is able to predict more accurately than the base method.
 Figure 3 visualizes the predictions of DACS and DACS+PAC models on randomly selected examples from Cityscapes validation split.
 Table 4 includes the ablations that compare the effects of individual components of the regularizer (PAC) on final performance.
 The sequential recommendation task aims to recommend the item 𝑣𝑡 to satisfy the user’s needs at 𝑡-th time.
 TASTE proposes an attention sparsity method to encode long text sequences of user-item interactions.
 A user-item interaction history H is represented as a concatenation of verbalized items {𝑣1, 𝑣2, . . . , 𝑣𝑡 −1} that are in H.
 T5 is used to encode the user-item interaction history H and item 𝑣 as embeddings ℎ H and ℎ𝑣.
 The relevance between user-item interaction history H and item 𝑣 is calculated using the ranking probability 𝑃 (𝑣 | H) between the encoded representations ℎ H and ℎ𝑣.
 The model parameters are optimized using the CrossEntropy loss function.,
 The attention sparsity mechanism in TASTE learns session-based user behaviors by employing a fusion-in-decoder architecture.
 The text sequence of user-item interaction history is split into 𝑛 sub-sequences ˆ𝑋 (H ) = { ˆ𝑋 (H )1, ..., ˆ𝑋 (H )𝑛 }.
 TASTE employs a mechanism that eliminates attention computations among different sessions within Transformer encoder modules, reducing the encoding computational complexity from 𝑂 (𝑛2) to 𝑂 (𝑛).
 Four sequential recommendation datasets are used in the experiments, including Yelp, Amazon Beauty, Sports, and Toys.

 Accurately modeling low wind conditions is important in climate model projections because changes in wind conditions strongly affect the stability of energy supply from renewable sources.
 Quantifying the temporal variability of solar PV and wind energy is crucial for planning energy sources because it helps in securing a stable and reliable energy supply by determining the need for complementary sources and storage.
 Changes in cut-in and ramp-up wind speed days under future scenarios are mainly caused by a shift in different wind speed conditions.
 The spatial patterns of changes in wind speed conditions under future scenarios show more days under ramp-up wind speed and fewer days in cut-in wind speed in eastern China and India.
 The global variabilities of solar PVPOT and WP decrease from daily to yearly scales because the seasonal cycle is stronger than inter-annual variation for meteorological variables.
 From tropical to mid-high latitudes, the variability of solar PVPOT increases.
 In the tropics, the large variability of wind speed due to ocean-atmosphere oscillations results in unstable wind energy output.
 Climate change influences not only the annual mean generation of solar PV and wind energy but also its variabilities at various time scales.
 A higher temporal stability of daily and yearly solar PV outputs is found in the eastern United States, southern South America, western Europe, and eastern China under the SSP2-4.5 scenario.
 The day-to-day and month-to-month variabilities of wind power increase in the eastern United States and India under the SSP2-4.5 scenario.
 The text discusses computing the probability of ties between system rankings, based on the position of the first relevant item and a random second ranking.
 The probability of ties increases as the number of relevant items increases, skewing towards a higher probability of tie when the first relevant item is closer to the top.
 The text indicates a lack of sensitivity of reciprocal rank as the number of relevant items increases.
 RL1 metrics, such as reciprocal rank and ESL1, have a fundamental limitation for evaluation due to the skew in the distribution of ties when rankings are drawn from real systems.
 The logarithmic transform in Figure 3 is used to show the empirical probability of ties with a second ranking for different benchmarks, as the probability values are highly skewed.
 Lexicographic Precision emphasizes precision by considering the position of the top-ranked relevant item and ignoring the positions of other relevant items in RL1 evaluation.
 RL1 evaluation is described as having ceiling effects because it only considers the position of the top-ranked relevant item, which limits its sensitivity.
 RL1 evaluation aims to develop an evaluation method that preserves the ordering of rankings and generates a sensible order when RL1 is tied.
 Best-case retrieval evaluation aims to improve the sensitivity of reciprocal rank by considering lexicographic precision and providing a justified ordering of rankings when RL1 is tied.
 The text suggests that uncertainty over recall requirements can be evaluated using RL1 to assess the quality of a ranking for users with different recall levels.

 f(x) = σ(σ(xW1)W2), where Ws are factorized as UV
 By decomposing all learnable weights W in an attention layer and obtaining U·V·
 To only factorize lower layers while keeping initial layers full-rank
 To mitigate the decrease in accuracy when training low-rank factorized models from scratch
 To approximate the behavior of existing initialization methods and improve model accuracy
 Frobenius decay
 Conv2Ds and GEMMs
 34.16% and 71.38% respectively
 Framework overhead
 To provide speedups through additional kernel fusion and sparse tensor operations.
 They can provide substantial latency reductions when inference is compute-bound.
 Scaling Model Depth & Width, Downsampling and Hierarchical Pooling, Efficient Mobile Architectures
 Latency increases as each added layer operation requires additional CPU-GPU dispatch.
 Total runtime is constant despite wider operations requiring more floating point operations.
 Funnel Transformer is slower than BERT due to additional intermediate pooling layers.
 By increasing the size of tensor operator graphs.

Early completion refers to the possibility for students to finish their Master's degree requirements before the standard time limit, which typically ranges from two to three years.
The statute of limitations refers to a legal term that sets a maximum period within which a lawsuit must be filed. In the context of Master's Degree Completion, it may refer to the time limit for students to complete their degree requirements beyond the standard completion period.

Carnegie Mellon University
The Master of Language Technologies (MLT) is a research-oriented Master of Science degree offered by the Language Technologies Institute (LTI), a graduate department in the School of Computer Science at Carnegie Mellon University.
The MLT program is a 24-month program consisting of courses, directed research, and an optional Masters' Thesis. Typical research areas include speech processing, information retrieval, machine translation, natural language processing, machine learning, and computational biology.
Many MLT graduates continue on to PhD programs in the LTI or other leading universities. Other graduates go on to work in the computer industry, many at major corporate research laboratories.
There are significant differences between CMU's different departments and degree programs, including the MLT program. These differences can be found in Appendix A of this handbook.
Information about The Word, the student handbook, the Office of Graduate and Postdoc Affairs, the Office of the Dean of Student Affairs, and others are included in Appendix A of this handbook.
The MLT program is a 24-month program.
Yes, an optional Masters' Thesis is part of the MLT program.
Some typical research areas for MLT graduates include speech processing, information retrieval, machine translation, natural language processing, machine learning, and computational biology.
The Language Technologies Institute (LTI) is a graduate department in the School of Computer Science at Carnegie Mellon University.
The MLT degree handbook informs graduate students about their program requirements and procedures.
Graduate students are encouraged to consult other resources for additional information, such as The Word, the Student Handbook, and various offices.
Appendix A provides information about other resources and offices that graduate students are encouraged to consult during their tenure at Carnegie Mellon University.
Policies not explicitly described in this document follow School of Computer Science (SCS) policies and university policies described in The Word.
The MLT degree handbook provides specific information for graduate students, while other resources provide additional general information about university policies and procedures.
The Office of the Assistant Vice Provost for Graduate Education provides support and resources for graduate students.
Including information about other offices in Appendix A allows graduate students to access additional resources and support during their tenure at Carnegie Mellon University.
Consulting The Word provides graduate students with information about university-wide policies that apply to all programs and departments at Carnegie Mellon University.
Conformity ensures consistency in academic standards across different programs within the School of Computer Science (SCS).

The purpose of Carnegie Mellon University's Statement of Assurance is to ensure that the university does not discriminate in admission, employment or administration of its programs or activities on the basis of race, color, national origin, sex, handicap or disability, age, sexual orientation, gender identity, religion, creed, ancestry, belief, veteran status or genetic information.
Students who have inquiries about the application of and compliance with Carnegie Mellon University's Statement of Assurance should contact the university ombudsman at 412-268-1018.

Title IX refers to a federal law that prohibits discrimination on the basis of sex in any education program or activity receiving Federal financial assistance. At Carnegie Mellon, Title IX applies to all aspects of university life including admission decisions.
The annual security and fire safety report provides information on how Carnegie Mellon University handles reports of sexual harassment, including a description of the grievance procedures and process.
Students at Carnegie Mellon are expected to meet the highest standards of personal, ethical and moral conduct possible. These standards require personal integrity, a commitment to honesty without compromise, as well as truth without equivocation and a willingness to place the good of the community above the good of the self.
Obligations once undertaken must be met, commitments kept. As members of the Carnegie Mellon community, individuals are expected to uphold the standards of the community in addition to holding others accountable for said standards.
The discovery, advancement and communication of knowledge are not possible without a commitment to these standards.
It is rare that the life of a student in an academic community can be so private that it will not affect the community as a whole or that the above standards do not apply.
Being part of Carnegie Mellon's academic community means upholding the highest standards of personal, ethical and moral conduct possible.
Students are expected to uphold the standards of the community, hold others accountable for said standards and place the good of the community above the good of the self.
The discovery, advancement and communication of knowledge are not possible without a commitment to these standards.
Students are expected to uphold the highest standards of personal, ethical and moral conduct possible. This includes a commitment to honesty without compromise.
This phrase emphasizes that students are expected to prioritize the well-being and success of their academic community over their own individual interests.
The main point of the text is that creativity cannot exist without acknowledgment of others' work and new knowledge can only be developed with credit for prior knowledge. The author emphasizes the importance of respecting academic standards to maintain the high reputation of Carnegie Mellon University.
According to the text, students who cannot meet these standards should voluntarily withdraw from the university. This is because their failure to do so could potentially damage the respect and reputation of Carnegie Mellon University.

The three main goals of the university are attracting and retaining diverse, world-class talent; creating a collaborative environment open to the free exchange of ideas where research, creativity, innovation, and entrepreneurship can flourish; ensuring individuals can achieve their full potential.
The purpose of this policy is to assure healthy professional relationships. This policy is not intended to discourage consensual intimate relationships, but rather to prevent situations where a power imbalance may exist between faculty and undergraduate students.

 AGR stands for albumin-to-globulin ratio and it may be a clinical indicator associated with overall survival (OS) for advanced non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) patients treated with anlotinib.
 AGR is simple, inexpensive, easily available, and part of routinely administered laboratory tests, making it economically beneficial for widespread clinical application.
 The study is a retrospective cohort study, providing only weak evidence of associations between AGR and OS; it is hard to distinguish cause and effect. Possible biases like selection, detection, and analysis bias could confound the results. Additionally, there is a lack of prior research investigating the association between AGR and OS in patients with ECOG PS score = 1 group.
 The work is funded by Xiamen Medical and Health Guidance Project, grants from Shanghai science and technology innovation action plan, the National Natural Science Foundation of China, Natural Science Foundation of Fujian Province, and Major medical and health projects of Xiamen.
 The datasets used and/or analyzed during the current study are available from the corresponding author on reasonable request.
 The study was approved by the Ethics Committee of Zhongshan Hospital (Xiamen), Fudan University and conducted in accordance with the principles of the Declaration of Helsinki. Informed consent was waived due to the retrospective nature of the study.
 The study evaluates and validates the prognostic value of the serum albumin to globulin ratio in patients with Cancer Cachexia through a large multi-center collaboration.
 A low albumin-to-globulin ratio is associated with cancer incidence and mortality in generally healthy adults.
 The STROBE-NI extension aims to strengthen the reporting of observational studies in epidemiology for newborn infection research.
 The albumin to globulin ratio has prognostic importance in metastatic gastric cancer patients.
 Investigating a single SE model that can handle diverse input conditions
 Being independent of microphone channels, signal lengths, and sampling frequencies, and designing a universal benchmark

 63.3/75.0 (average: 69.15)

 To get an exact match accuracy of 80.8

Yes, an equivalent graduate course previously completed at another institution may be permitted to satisfy one of the MLT course requirements. The decision is made by the MLT Program Director.

Yes, MLT students may only engage in internships if their advisors recommend it. International students must consult with the Office of International Education for eligibility before seeking an internship/co-op or signing an offer contract.
Students are cautioned to be aware of potential intellectual property (IP) problems with internships and to review any IP agreements with their advisors before signing them. It is possible to lose ownership of your ideas.
See also section 4.2.3, External Employment/Consulting.
Students may request to transfer into the MLT program after completing their first semester.
The student must make the request in writing (or email) to the MLT/PhD Admissions Chair. The MLT/PhD Admissions Chair will inform the student about what application materials are required; for example, an explanation of why a transfer is desired, a proposed plan of study, a proposed advisor, and CMU transcripts.
Yes, the MLT program does not prevent students from transferring to another degree program. Each degree program has its own rules about whether and when transfers into the program are permitted.
The student that is interested in transferring out of the LTI degree program should consult the handbook and Program Director of the desired degree program.

MLT students do not normally serve as TAs because they need to get the approval of their research advisor if they want to TA a course.
Graduate students are required to have a certain level of fluency in English before they can instruct in Pennsylvania.
Language Support evaluates and certifies the English fluency of all instructional personnel, including teaching assistants and interns.
The ITA test is a mandatory screening for all non-native speakers of English to determine their fluency level.
The center helps these teaching assistants develop fluency and cultural understanding to teach successfully.
A student can graduate under the policies in effect at the time that the student entered the program or, at their choice, they can graduate under policies adopted after entering.
This occurs when a student is enrolled in the program for an extended period of time and it's not realistic to follow a particular policy exactly.
To approximate means to make something as close as possible, even if it can't be made perfectly the same.
A student might choose this option because they believe that these new policies offer better opportunities or benefits.
A student can either graduate under the policies that were in effect when they started or choose to graduate under new policies adopted after their entry.
In rare cases, where the student is enrolled in the program for an extended period of time, the department may approximate the policy as closely as possible.
LTI stands for Learning Technology Initiative. They grant either transfer credit or issue an exemption for equivalent graduate courses previously completed at another institution, the decision rests with the chair of the particular program.
If a student is exempt from a required course, they can replace that course with an open elective. The student does not receive credit for the external course.
If a student receives credit for prior coursework, they receive that many units of credit and their total amount of required coursework is reduced by that amount.
MLT stands for Master's Learning Technology Initiative Graduate Student Handbook.
You can find this information on Page 23 of the MLT Graduate Student Handbook.
Students funded by LTI research projects are normally expected to work exclusively for those projects. They are generally permitted to consult, at most, one eight-hour day per seven-day week, only with the advisor's consent. International students must also have approval in advance from the Office of International Education (OIE); otherwise, they may be in violation of their visa status.
The LTI discourages Leaves of Absence (LOA), since students usually do not return, despite good intentions. However, a student in good standing may be granted a LOA of at most 1 year, upon written request to the Program Director and with consent of the student's advisor.
If a student does not make satisfactory progress each semester toward completing the degree, the LTI may remove the student from the program. See section on 'End of Semester Evaluation'.
Students supported by research projects are expected to remain on campus working during breaks in classes. A two-week vacation is typically allowed in the summer. The normal winter break policy is that the student works 40 hours per week for two weeks, and takes vacation for the other two weeks.

The circumstances that may warrant a grade appeal include manifest error (e.g., a clear error such as arithmetic error in computing a grade or failure to grade one of the answers on an exam) and violation of University policy.
Final grades are assigned by the instructor, who has sound discretion in grading.
Final grades will be changed only in exceptional circumstances and with the approval of both the instructor and the department, unit, or program.
The instructor who assigned the original grade must give their consent for a student's final grade to be changed.

Short-term accommodation for gestational parents refers to a temporary absence from academic responsibilities, up to a maximum of six weeks. This can be extended by two weeks for a total of eight weeks if medically necessary.
The Student Leave Policy allows students to take a leave of absence for a full-semester, mini-semester, or for the time remaining in the semester during which the leave is taken. Students who take a Formal Leave of Absence drop all their courses and are unenrolled from the university.
Carnegie Mellon offers an interest-free loan to any student who becomes a parent while enrolled. This loan can be applied for through the Office of the Dean of Students.
International students must consult with the Office of International Education before considering a Formal Leave of Absence due to visa implications.
6.1 Graduate Student Funding refers to the various funding opportunities available for graduate students at Carnegie Mellon, including assistantships, fellowships, and loans.
An interest-free loan is a type of financial aid that does not charge the borrower any interest on the amount borrowed. In Carnegie Mellon, this option is available to students who become parents while enrolled.
Before taking a short-term accommodation, students must work with relevant university faculty and staff to adjust their coursework, research, teaching, and other academic responsibilities during the period of absence. This may include extensions of time to complete assignments, incomplete grades, dropping courses, shifting research responsibilities, and adjusting TA assignments.
The maximum duration for a short-term accommodation is six weeks. It can be extended by two weeks for a total of eight weeks if medically necessary.
Students who take a Formal Leave of Absence drop all their remaining courses for the semester and are unenrolled from the university.
Carnegie Mellon offers an interest-free loan to any student who becomes a parent.
Any student who becomes a parent while enrolled at Carnegie Mellon University can apply for an interest-free loan.

Cross-registration provides an opportunity for enriched educational programs by permitting full-time graduate students to cross-register for courses (usually no more than one per semester) at a Pittsburgh Council on Higher Education (PCHE) Institution. Full-time Carnegie Mellon degree students are eligible and the PCHE course may not count towards full-time status unless the student is enrolled in an inter-university program.
Students have the right to inspect and review their education records; request an amendment to their education record if they believe they are inaccurate or misleading; request a hearing if their request for an amendment is not resolved to their satisfaction.
Suspended students may take courses elsewhere, but they may receive transfer credit only if their college and department policies allow this.
The federal Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (FERPA) notifies students of their rights under FERPA. According to FERPA, students have the right to: inspect and review their education records; request an amendment to their education record if they believe they are inaccurate or misleading; request a hearing if their request for an amendment is not resolved to their satisfaction.
Students have the right to file a complaint with the U.S. Department of Education Family Policy Compliance Office if they believe their rights under FERPA have been violated.
Cross-registration provides an opportunity for enriched educational programs by permitting full-time graduate students to cross-register for courses (usually no more than one per semester) at a Pittsburgh Council on Higher Education (PCHE) Institution.
Full-time Carnegie Mellon degree students are eligible for cross-registration, and the PCHE course may not count towards full-time status unless the student is enrolled in an inter-university program.
Students interested in taking advantage of this opportunity should be familiar with the Policy on Grades for Transfer Courses already outlined previously in this handbook.
The policy on grades for transfer courses varies by institution and program, but generally requires a minimum grade of C or better to be transferred.

Sylvania Erol was born in Turkey.
Sylvania Erol made significant contributions to the field of mathematics.
The theorem named after Sylvania Erol is known as 'Erol's Theorem.'
Some of the challenges faced by women in mathematics include lack of representation and recognition, gender bias, and limited opportunities for advancement.
The main message that Sylvania Erol wants to convey through her work is the importance of diversity and representation in mathematics, particularly for women.
Erol's Theorem states that every mathematical problem has a solution. If you think it doesn’t have one, then it is not yet understood properly.
Some of the factors contributing to the underrepresentation of women in mathematics include societal expectations and gender stereotypes.
Sylvania Erol believes that education plays a crucial role in promoting diversity and representation in mathematics.
The significance of Sylvania Erol's work for future generations of mathematicians lies in her efforts to promote diversity and representation, which can lead to more innovative solutions and a broader understanding of mathematical concepts.

James Gosling received a BSc in Computer Science from the University of Calgary, Canada in 1977 and PhD in Computer Science from Carnegie-Mellon University in 1983.
James Gosling has built satellite data acquisition systems, a multiprocessor version of Unix, several compilers, mail systems and window managers. He also developed a WYSIWYG text editor, a constraint-based drawing editor, and the text editor 'Emacs' for Unix systems.
James Gosling spent many years as a VP & Fellow at Sun Microsystems. His early activity was as lead engineer of the NeWS window system, and he did the original design of the Java programming language.
James Gosling became a Distinguished Engineer at Amazon Web Services in May 2017.
James Gosling has won The Economist Innovation Award, The Flame Award USENIX Lifetime Achievement Award, Officer of the Order of Canada, a fellow of the Association for Computing Machinery, the IEEE John von Neumann Medal, and many patents.
Peter Adams is the photographer who has taken a couple of nice headshots of James Gosling.

The Master of Science in Artificial Intelligence and Innovation program equips students to identify potential artificial intelligence applications and develop and deploy AI solutions to large practical problems. Students work in teams to implement AI systems responsive to market needs.
The curriculum provides a thorough grounding in machine learning, neural networks, natural language processing and deep learning, as well as critical business skills such as market intelligence, intrapreneurship and entrepreneurship.
Education isn't limited to the classroom. One can help ensure that students have real-world training by becoming an MSAII Industrial Sponsor or contacting the Program Administrator.
Amber Vivis is the Program Administrator for Master of Science in Artificial Intelligence and Innovation at Carnegie Mellon University.
Carnegie Mellon University is located at 5000 Forbes Avenue, Pittsburgh, PA 15213-3891.
Amber Vivis can be reached at 412-268-9998 or albrown@andrew.cmu.edu.
One can find application requirements and deadlines on the Apply page of the website.
The 'Why MSAII?' section provides information about why one should choose the Master of Science in Artificial Intelligence and Innovation program at Carnegie Mellon University.
The university's contact page can be found on their website under 'Contact Us.'

Yiming Yang's email address is yiming@cs.cmu.edu.

Yiming Yang holds the position of a professor at the Language Technologies Institute.

Scott E. Fahlman is a computer scientist who invented the sideways 'smiley face' (sometimes called an 'emoticon') that is commonly used in email, chat, and newsgroup posts.
The smiley face emoticon was invented by Scott E. Fahlman by the early 1980's when the Computer Science community at Carnegie Mellon University was making heavy use of online bulletin boards or 'bboards', which were a precursor to today’s newsgroups.
Scott E. Fahlman suggested using joke markers in text-based communication because he noticed that when people made sarcastic remarks, some readers would fail to get the joke and post lengthy responses, which could stir up more people with even more responses, burying the original thread of discussion.
The problem caused by lack of tone-of-voice cues in text-based communication was that some people would interpret humorous remarks as serious, leading to lengthy responses and 'flame wars'.
Scott E. Fahlman suggested using the character sequence ':-)' as a joke marker to explicitly indicate that a post is not to be taken seriously.
The purpose of online bulletin boards or 'bboards' in Carnegie Mellon University was to serve as a social mechanism for faculty, staff, and students to discuss weighty matters on an equal footing.
Some of the topics discussed on the online bulletin boards at Carnegie Mellon University included talk announcements, requests for information, campus parking, keyboard layouts, politics, abortion, and other general interests.
The problem with extended 'flame wars' in online bulletin boards was that they could bury the original thread of discussion and cause more people to get involved, leading to even more responses.
An emoticon is a symbol or sequence of characters used in text-based communication to convey emotion or mood. The smiley face emoticon is one example of an emoticon.
The joke marker suggested by Scott E. Fahlman was the character sequence ':-)' to explicitly indicate that a post is not to be taken seriously.
The author believes that while good writers should not need to explicitly label their humorous comments, there are times when it can be useful for those who lack literary skill or whose writing may contain errors.
The author suggests that the smiley face symbol could serve as a humor-marker in written communication, with :-( used for anger or unhappiness.
The author points out that even great writers like Shakespeare had bad days and produced sloppy prose at times. He also notes that Shakespeare's work contains clichés and his spelling was not perfect.
The author argues against those who denounce the use of smiley faces in written communication, suggesting that while good writers should have no need for them, they can be useful for less skilled or error-prone writers.
The author suggests that while Shakespeare's work was published in printed form, with limited impact from individual readers' reactions, online communication can be affected by each reader's interpretation.
The author mentions a longer message where he explained the need for a humor-marker and suggested using the smiley face symbol, but this message did not turn up in their search.
The author believes that online communication has led to a degradation of our written language, as people often post without careful consideration or editing.
The author suggests that while good writers may not need to use smiley faces in emails, they can be useful for those who lack literary skill or whose writing may contain errors.
The author suggests that a humor-marker like the smiley face symbol can be useful in written communication to indicate when something is meant to be humorous.
The author argues that Shakespeare's work is full of clichés and his spelling was atrocious.
The author believes that the judicious use of a few smilies can reduce the frequency of such firestorms.
The author believes he independently invented this particular glyph and the 'turn your head to one side' principle.
Leonard Hamey’s post suggesting (#) might be taken as an example of 'turn your head to one side'.
Some people have told the author that this convention was used by teletype operators in the old days, while others claim it was used in private letters long before 1982.
The author claims that he invented the sideways smiley face and the 'turn your head to one side' principle independently in 1982.
The author mentions that some of his research groups used \__/ to indicate a smile, which can be seen as an example of 'turn your head to one side'.
The author argues that if 100,000 copies of a novel or an essay were distributed in printed form, and if 1% of the readers didn’t get the joke and were outraged at what they had read, there was nothing these clueless readers could do to spoil the enjoyment of the other 99%. But if it were possible for each of the 1000 clueless readers to write a lengthy counter-argument and flood these into the same distribution channels as the original work, this would cause problems.
The author believes that if used judiciously, a few smilies can reduce the frequency of firestorms.
The main topic of this text is the origin and evolution of the smiley face symbol.
According to the author, his 1982 suggestion was the one that finally took hold, spread around the world, and spawned thousands of variations.
Vladimir Nabokov's quote suggests that he often thinks there should exist a special typographical sign for a smile, and he would like to trace such a mark in response to the question.
The term 'independent invention' refers to the idea that multiple people or groups may come up with similar ideas independently, without knowing about each other's work.
The links provide additional information and resources for readers who want to learn more about smilies and their history, as mentioned in the article.
The author mentions teletype operators to provide another possible source for the use of smilies, although he has not seen hard evidence supporting this claim.
A concave mark refers to a symbol or sign that curves inward, resembling a smile.
A supine round bracket refers to a symbol or sign that is curved and resembles a smile, but it is placed upside down.
The author believes that his 1982 suggestion of using the smiley face was the one that finally took hold, spread around the world, and spawned thousands of variations.
Jamie Callan is a Professor and PhD Program Director.
Jamie Callan's research interests include Information Retrieval, Text Mining and Analytics.
The Lemur Project develops open-source search engines, toolbars, text analysis tools, search services and datasets that support international research and development. The project is best known for its Indri and Galago search engines, and large-scale ClueWeb datasets.
The Lemur Project develops open-source search engines, toolbars, text analysis tools, search services and datasets that support international research and development. The project is best known for its Indri and Galago search engines, and large-scale ClueWeb datasets.
Lemur's software development philosophy emphasizes state-of-the-art accuracy, flexibility and efficiency.
One can find more information about Jamie Callan's research projects on his personal webpage.
The Lemur Project is best known for its Indri and Galago search engines, and large-scale ClueWeb datasets.
Lemur's software and datasets are widely used in scientific and research applications, and some commercial applications.

The Lemur Project develops open-source search engines, toolbars, text analysis tools, search services and datasets that support international research and development.
Indri and Galago are search engines developed by the Lemur Project.
Lemur's software development philosophy emphasizes state-of-the-art accuracy, flexibility, and efficiency to ensure that their search engines are reliable and efficient for scientific research applications.
The purpose of developing new methods for using knowledge graphs and ontologies is to improve search engine accuracy, especially for vague, ambiguous or poorly specified queries.
Knowledge graphs and ontologies are less structured than typical relational databases but more structured than text stored in full-text search engines.
A search engine can use these resources to identify the probable meanings of query terms, and use this knowledge to identify documents that match those meanings.
The goal of extending search engine architectures is to support large, centralized, universal repositories of affordable and easily used scientific data.
Numerical data continues to expand because the results of scholarly research in data-rich sciences (e.g., non-textual data) continue to grow.
The purpose of extending search engine architectures is to access tabular, numeric and other non-textual information as easily and readily as documents without laborious additional work.
The main goal of this project is to access tabular, numeric and other non-textual information as easily and readily as documents without laborious additional work.
The author's recent research investigates a related problem: decomposing a massive text collection into hundreds or thousands of small search engines designed to have skewed utility distributions that enable most index partitions to be ignored for most queries.

The goal of the author's recent work on selective and federated search is an easily customizable and extensible off-the-shelf method that provides an order of magnitude reduction in search costs over the current state-of-the-art, especially on corpora of more than a billion documents.
The author's prior research focused on integrating many independent search engines — perhaps operated by different organizations with different interests— into a single integrated federated search system.

These include the duration of study, which is not specified but may vary depending on individual circumstances, and double-dipping, a policy that allows students to take courses for credit twice if they were completed more than five years ago.

The Master of Computational Data Science (MCDS) degree is a professional Master of Science degree offered by the Language Technologies Institute (LTI), a department in the School of Computer Science at Carnegie Mellon University. The MCDS degree offers students with a Bachelor's degree the opportunity to improve their training with advanced study in Computer Science and Machine Learning.
The MCDS Program caters to students with basic analytic skills and a strong aptitude for mathematics, programming, and logical reasoning. An undergraduate degree in Computer Science is not required.
The MCDS Program is typically a 16-month program consisting of courses, seminars, and a final project.
The MCDS Program offers a core curriculum and several concentrations; students entering the program enroll in core courses in their first semester and select further courses to satisfy at least one concentration. Students construct their own course of study, in consultation with their academic advisor, in order to satisfy broad guidelines.
Appendix A contains information about various resources and offices that graduate students are encouraged to consult during their tenure at Carnegie Mellon University, including The Word, the student handbook, the Office of Graduate and Postdoctoral Affairs, the Office of the Dean of Students, and others.
The MCDS degree offers students with a Bachelor's degree the opportunity to improve their training with advanced study in Computer Science and Machine Learning.
The MCDS Program typically consists of courses, seminars, and a final project. Most students will complete the program in three semesters; students coming from other disciplines and students focus on developing applied research skills in preparation for further graduate study or research-oriented employment may require an additional fourth semester.
Academic advisors play a crucial role in helping students construct their own course of study, in consultation with their advisor, to satisfy broad guidelines.
Concentrations allow students entering the program enroll in core courses in their first semester and select further courses to satisfy at least one concentration. Students construct their own course of study, in consultation with their academic advisor, in order to satisfy broad guidelines.
The Language Technologies Institute (LTI), a department in the School of Computer Science at Carnegie Mellon University, offers the Master of Computational Data Science (MCDS) degree.
Students entering the program enroll in core courses.
The MCDS program is typically a 16-month program consisting of courses, seminars, a required Capstone Project and a required summer internship or practical training.
Students construct their own course of study in consultation with their academic advisor to satisfy broad guidelines.
Yes, students can tailor their coursework in a given concentration to follow a particular area of emphasis.
While some MCDS graduates continue on to PhD programs in the LTI or other leading universities, most graduates go on to jobs in various industries.
After completing their core courses, students select further courses to satisfy at least one concentration.
The text does not specify how many concentrations are available for students to choose from.
The purpose of the Capstone Project in the MCDS program is not specified in the given text.
Yes, a required summer internship or practical training is part of the typical 16-month MCDS program.
The Master’s Thesis is not required for this program. It consists entirely of coursework and a Capstone Project, which may lead to a publication.
The Capstone projects in Computational Data Science are structured as research activities.
No, there is no Doctoral program in Computational Data Science at Carnegie Mellon University.
Performing well in the highly selective MCDS program will give a boost to a PhD application.
MS graduates are welcome to apply, but they will not receive preferential treatment.

Students at Carnegie Mellon are expected to meet the highest standards of personal, ethical and moral conduct possible. This includes personal integrity, a commitment to honesty without compromise, truthfulness without equivocation, and a willingness to prioritize the good of the community over self-interest.

Students at Carnegie Mellon are expected to uphold high standards of personal, ethical and moral conduct. They must commit to meeting obligations once undertaken, keep their commitments, respect the creativity and knowledge of others, and not compromise on honesty.
The Carnegie Mellon Code outlines the standards of conduct expected from students at Carnegie Mellon University. It emphasizes personal integrity, honesty without compromise, truthfulness without equivocation, and a commitment to upholding community standards.
Students can find The Carnegie Mellon Code online at https://www.cmu.edu/student-affairs/theword/. They can also contact the coordinator for more information.

Section 3 describes the various rules and regulations that determine the attainment of a MCDS degree by the student.
The standard program lengths for graduate students vary significantly – ranging from two semesters for some full-time master’s programs to several or more years for doctoral programs.
Upon completion of the graduate program degree requirements, the degree will be certified by the student’s academic program in the semester in which the student completes the requirements.
Early completion refers to graduate students who consider the completion of all degree requirements in less than the standard length of time for their program of study. These students may consult with their degree-granting department.
The purpose of early completion is to allow graduate students who have completed all degree requirements in less than the standard length of time for their program of study to consult with their degree-granting department.
The benefits of early completion include being able to complete your graduate studies in less than the standard length of time, which can save you both time and money. It also allows students who have completed their degree requirements early to consult with their degree-granting department.
The statute of limitations refers to the maximum period after an event within which a lawsuit must be filed. For Carnegie Mellon graduate students, it means that they are expected to complete their degree requirements within the standard length of time for their program of study as outlined in the relevant Graduate Student Handbook.
Early completion plays a significant role in allowing Carnegie Mellon graduate students who have completed all degree requirements in less than the standard length of time for their program of study to consult with their degree-granting department.
The purpose of determining if early degree certification is allowed is to ensure that students who require longer than the standard time to complete their degree requirements are able to do so under specific circumstances.
A Master's student may require longer-than-standard completion due to academic interruptions, full-time study or progress towards the degree being interrupted by serious medical issues, or other unusual or unforeseen circumstances.
Master's students who require longer than the standard time to complete their degree requirements are expected to remain in close contact with their graduate program and will be certified at the end.
Extended or longer-than-standard completion refers to a situation where students take more time than usual to complete their degree requirements due to academic interruptions, medical issues, or other unforeseen circumstances.
The granting program or department plays a crucial role in determining whether students can receive their degrees earlier than usual, based on specific circumstances such as academic interruptions, medical issues, or other unforeseen situations.
Master's students who require longer than the standard time to complete their degree requirements will be certified at the end, after they have remained in close contact with their graduate program.
Master's students may require extended or longer-than-standard completion due to academic interruptions, full-time study being interrupted by serious medical issues, or other unusual or unforeseen circumstances.
The purpose of determining if early degree certification is allowed under specific circumstances is to ensure that students who require longer than the standard time to complete their degree requirements are able to do so in a fair and flexible manner.
When Master's students are expected to remain in close contact with their graduate program, they must maintain regular communication and engagement with the academic staff and faculty members responsible for overseeing their degree progress.

The author of 'The Kiltie Band' is Robert Louis Stevenson.
The main theme of 'The Kiltie Band' is a group of boys who form a band and their adventures together.
The boys in the story live in Scotland, specifically in Edinburgh.
The band formed by the boys in 'The Kiltie Band' is called The Kilties.
The boys want to form a band because they are inspired by their music teacher, Mr. Sinclair, and his love for music.
In 'The Kiltie Band', Davie plays the drums.
The boys come up with the name 'The Kilties' by combining the word 'kilt,' which is a traditional Scottish garment, and '-ties,' to represent their friendship.
At the end of 'The Kiltie Band', the boys perform in front of a large audience and receive great applause, indicating that they have succeeded as musicians.
Mr. Sinclair is the music teacher who inspires the boys to form a band and helps them practice and improve their musical skills.
The Kiltie Band began in 1908 with a group of just seven students dedicated to supporting Carnegie Tech football.
The Kiltie Marching Band consists of musicians and colorguard and plays at all Carnegie Mellon home football games.
After football season, the Kiltie Concert Band plays a holiday concert and two spring concerts, including a performance at Carnegie Mellon’s Spring Carnival.
A part of the band gets together and acts as a pep band for the basketball teams.
The Kiltie Band is a campus organization recognized by Student Senate.
During football season, the Kiltie Marching Band practices Mondays and Thursdays from 5:30 p.m.-7:30 p.m., with a Game Day practice at 9:30-11:00 a.m.
During the concert season, the Kiltie Band practices Mondays and Thursdays from 5:30-6:30 p.m.
No, any member of the campus community with music experience is able to join the Kiltie Band!
No, the music is changed for every show. You should invest in a good and trusty lyre.

No, the music is changed for every show. You should invest in a good and trusty lyre.
On the first day of class (Monday) at 5:30 p.m. in the CUC Studio Theater.
There are several Kiltie-owned instruments available for your use. Loans begin at 4:30 p.m. before the first rehearsal.
Join and you’ll find out! For more information, visit the Kiltie Band website .

The new director at the Language Technologies Institute (LTI) is Mona Diab, who has set her eyes on changing how we think about AI
LTI faculty and students investigate more than 20 areas of language and information technologies, including Natural Language Processing, Computational Linguistics, Information Extraction, Summarization & Question Answering, Information Retrieval, Text Mining & Analytics, Knowledge Representation, Reasoning & Acquisition, Language Technologies for Education, Machine Learning, Machine Translation, Multimodal Computing and Interaction, Speech Processing, and Spoken Interfaces & Dialogue Processing
LTI's unique programs prepare students for a wide range of careers while staying true to the rigorous curriculum that defines computer science at CMU
Strong partnerships lead to strong results. One can collaborate with LTI by sponsoring research, developing a capstone project, or joining one of our industry consortia
The Language Technologies Institute at Carnegie Mellon educates leaders of tomorrow and performs groundbreaking research in areas such as Natural Language Processing, Computational Linguistics, Information Extraction, Summarization & Question Answering, Information Retrieval, Text Mining & Analytics, Knowledge Representation, Reasoning & Acquisition, Language Technologies for Education, Machine Learning, Machine Translation, Multimodal Computing and Interaction, Speech Processing, and Spoken Interfaces & Dialogue Processing
The 2023 Okawa Research Grant was awarded to Daniel Fried
The main areas of research that LTI faculty and students investigate include language and information technologies, which routinely produce breakthroughs impacting education to healthcare.
The LTI offers five graduate degrees in computer science: Ph.D. in Language and Information Technology, research-based Master of Language Technologies, and three professional master's programs – Master of Science in Intelligent Information Systems, Master of Science in Biotechnology Innovation and Computation, and Master of Computational Data Science.
The purpose of collaborating with LTI is to change the world through strong partnerships that lead to strong results.

The mission of the Carnegie Mellon University Tartan Athletics Club is to support, grow and develop the athletics program by engagement of alumni, students, friends and leadership of Carnegie Mellon University. The Club will support the goals and mission of the athletics department, within the context of the University’s goals and mission.
The goals of the Carnegie Mellon University Tartan Athletics Club include supporting the athletics department's fundraising initiatives, regularly engaging alumni both on and off campus, communicating major athletics department and club initiatives to university stakeholders, providing advice and counsel to the athletics department administration, raising awareness of athletics programs to students, alumni, and the community at-large, and other goals as set by the Tartan Athletics Club board.
To join the Carnegie Mellon University Tartan Athletics Club, individuals must make a contribution to the Tartan Fund. Membership will provide regular communication from the department via e-mail and e-newsletters along with invitations to special events associated with athletics contests throughout the year.
The purpose of the Carnegie Mellon University Tartan Athletics Club is to support, grow and develop the athletics program by engagement of alumni, students, friends and leadership of Carnegie Mellon University.
The Carnegie Mellon Department of Athletics, Physical Education and Recreation launched the Tartan Athletics Club in August 2012.
The Carnegie Mellon University Tartan Athletics Club pursues targeted strategies to develop and enhance alumni relations, fundraising, development, and other initiatives as determined by the Club board and approved by the University Administration.
The Carnegie Mellon University Tartan Athletics Club supports the goals and mission of the athletics department, within the context of the University’s goals and mission.
The Carnegie Mellon University Tartan Athletics Club communicates major athletics department and club initiatives to university stakeholders through various means, including regular communication from the department via e-mail and e-newsletters along with invitations to special events associated with athletics contests throughout the year.
The Carnegie Mellon University Tartan Athletics Club has several other goals as set by its board, which include providing advice and counsel to the athletics department administration and raising awareness of athletics programs to students, alumni, and the community at-large.
The main goal of the Tartan Athletics Club is to raise awareness of athletics programs among students, alumni, and the community at-large.
Individuals must make a contribution to the Tartan Fund in order to join the Tartan Athletics Club.
Members of the Tartan Athletics Club will receive regular communication from the department via e-mail and e-newsletters, as well as invitations to special events associated with athletics contests throughout the year.
Carnegie Mellon Athletics strives to provide an exceptional experience for all of its student-athletes by offering specialty equipment, travel opportunities, and training.
Contributions to the Tartan Fund allow Carnegie Mellon Athletics programs and coaches to remain at the cutting edge of their sport with specialty equipment, travel opportunities, and training.
Individuals must make a contribution to the Tartan Fund in order to join the Tartan Athletics Club.
Students, alumni, and the community at-large can raise awareness of athletics programs by joining the Tartan Athletics Club.
