Cognitive Tutor Authoring Tools (CTAT) is a tool developed by Carnegie Mellon University that helps in building tutors. It provides images of various tutors built with CTAT.
The new production rule system in CTAT 4.4.0 supports cognitive tutors whose production rule engines run client-side, which means use of rule-based tutors is no longer constrained by server capacity.
The release date for CMUCTAT version 4.3.0 is June 30, 2017.
Improvements include support for collaboration with HTML tutors and new actions for HTML components that allow adding and removing CSS classes through tutor-performed steps.
The JavaScript Model Tracer page describes the new production rule system in CTAT 4.4.0 that supports cognitive tutors whose production rule engines run client-side.
The Project News section provides updates on recent releases and improvements of CMUCTAT, such as the reimplementation of CTAT as a web application and the release of version 4.4.0.
The Quick Start guide provides instructions on setting up to build a CTAT tutor and downloading and installing CTAT.
Frequently Asked Questions about CMUCTAT can be found in the Google User Group for questions and help with CTAT.
The Resources section provides various resources such as a Quick Start guide, Frequently Asked Questions, Google User Group for questions and help with CTAT, Project News, and links to download and install CMUCTAT.
Improved support for collaborative tutors deployed from Tutorshop enhances the ability to build and use tutoring systems that allow multiple users to work together.
The new features in CTAT 4.3.0 include support for collaboration with HTML tutors and new actions for HTML components that allow adding and removing CSS classes through tutor-performed steps.
The changes in CTAT 4.2.0 include support for connecting the authoring tools to the web-based CTAT HTML Editor, improved support for graph editing with HTML tutor interfaces, and fixes in HTML components.
The Cognitive Tutor Authoring Tools documentation is now on this GitHub site. Some older documentation for Java and Flash tutors is still available on the old CTAT web site.
On May 10, 2017, it was announced that all new documentation for the Cognitive Tutor Authoring Tools is now on this GitHub site.
In CTAT 4.3.0, several fixes were made to support collaboration with HTML tutors and new actions for HTML components that allow adding and removing CSS classes through tutor-performed steps.
The changes in CTAT 4.2.0 include support for connecting the authoring tools to the web-based CTAT HTML Editor, improved support for graph editing with HTML tutor interfaces, and fixes in HTML components.
On January 19, 2017, CTAT 4.2.0 was released which supports the new CTAT HTML Editor that allows users to quickly build tutor interfaces.
The changes in CTAT 4.3.0 include support for collaboration with HTML tutors and new actions for HTML components that allow adding and removing CSS classes through tutor-performed steps.
On May 10, 2017, it was announced that all new documentation for the Cognitive Tutor Authoring Tools is now on this GitHub site. Some older documentation for Java and Flash tutors is still available on the old CTAT web site.
In CTAT 4.2.0, improvements were made to support graph editing with HTML tutor interfaces and fixes were done in the Authoring Tools, HTML components, and the JavaScript example tracer.
The purpose of creating a Cognitive Tutor is to help students learn by providing them with personalized feedback and guidance.
CTAT HTML Editor
The purpose of creating a Quiz in CTAT is to assess students' understanding and knowledge on specific topics.
Dynamic Interfaces
The purpose of using Formulas in CTAT is to generalize an example-tracing tutor and create more complex learning experiences.
CTAT HTML Editor
The purpose of creating an example-tracing tutor with formulas in CTAT is to create more complex learning experiences for students.
Advanced Topics
The purpose of creating a Quiz in CTAT is to assess students' understanding and knowledge on specific topics.
CTAT HTML Editor
CTAT stands for Cognitive Tutor Authoring Tools, a software toolkit designed to help educators create and deploy intelligent tutoring systems.
The basics of CTAT include creating grouping lists, multiple choice questions, drag-and-drop interfaces, and other interactive elements for educational purposes.
An example-tracing tutor in CTAT is a type of intelligent tutor that uses predefined rules to guide students through problem solving processes.
Dynamic interfaces in CTAT refer to interactive elements that can be customized and adapted based on student performance or other factors during tutoring sessions.
A formula-based example-tracing tutor uses mathematical formulas to generate problems and solutions, while a rule-based one relies on predefined rules.
Advanced topics in CTAT include configuring Eclipse for production rule editing, installing and uninstalling CTAT, HTML examples, and more.
You can deploy your tutor using CTAT by following the instructions on logging, configuring Eclipse for production rule editing, installing and uninstalling CTAT, and creating HTML examples.
Some of the interactive elements available in CTAT include grouping lists, multiple choice questions, drag-and-drop interfaces, checkboxes, radio buttons, and more.
You can create a drag-and-drop tutor interface using CTAT by building an appropriate interface with the DragNDrop component and customizing it according to your needs.
Some of the components available in CTAT for creating interactive elements include grouping components, hint buttons, chat panels, checkboxes, combo boxes, and more.

Student Awards, Faculty Awards
The main purpose of Carnegie Mellon's School of Computer Science is to train the next generation of innovators to solve real-world problems and improve the way people live and work.
Some recent achievements mentioned in the text include four SCS faculty being named 2024 Sloan Research Fellows, Carnegie Mellon University and Play Included® bringing LEGO® brick based interventions to US, Kanade receiving BBVA Foundation Frontiers of Knowledge Award for Computer Vision Legacy, Robotics Innovation Center anchoring community outreach programs in Hazelwood, CMU Robotics Institute developing a system to detect and fix problems in gas pipelines, SCS alum Blake Scholl feeling supersonic.
The School of Computer Science is located at 5000 Forbes Avenue, Pittsburgh, PA 15213.
SCS offers various computer science programs that train the next generation of innovators to solve real-world problems and improve the way people live and work.

Carnegie Mellon University does not discriminate in admission, employment or administration of its programs on the basis of race, color, national origin, sex, handicap or disability, age, sexual orientation, gender identity, religion, creed, ancestry, belief, veteran status, or genetic information.
Carnegie Mellon and the NCAA take pride in supporting all lesbian, gay, bisexual, queer and questioning, intersex, asexual and other non-heterosexual (LGBTQIA+) individuals.
Carnegie Mellon Athletics Department unequivocally supports the opportunity for transgender students to participate in intercollegiate athletics according to the NCAA process.
Carnegie Mellon believes that all people should be treated equally, and they aim to establish an inclusive culture that fosters equitable participation for student-athletes, coaches, and administrators from diverse backgrounds.
NCAA plays a significant role in shaping Carnegie Mellon University's diversity and inclusion policy, particularly regarding LGBTQIA+ individuals.
Supporting LGBTQIA+ individuals enhances excellence within learning environments and improves the learning environment for all student-athletes.
LGBTQIA+ individuals often endure social stigma and emotional trauma on the court, in the classroom, and in the workplace.
Carnegie Mellon's Athletics Department provides an inclusive and welcoming environment for individuals involved in any and all its programs.
The NCAA process allows transgender students to participate in intercollegiate athletics.

The main topic of this article is minorities in the Middle East and North Africa.
This text discusses the Middle East and North Africa.
The purpose of the article, as stated by the author, is to raise awareness about minorities in the Middle East and North Africa.
Some examples of minority groups mentioned in this text include Kurds, Berbers, and Arabs.
According to the author, these minorities face various challenges such as discrimination, marginalization, and lack of representation in politics.
The author suggests that governments should take steps to protect minority rights, promote diversity, and ensure equal opportunities for all citizens.
According to the author, it's important to discuss these issues because minorities have been historically oppressed and their rights often overlooked.
The tone of this article seems to be informative, with a hint of concern or urgency as the author emphasizes the importance of addressing these issues.
The author presents their argument by providing examples and evidence to support their claims, such as mentioning specific minority groups and discussing the challenges they face.

82481
The Carnegie Mellon Cheerleading Program is a sideline cheerleading and dance team that performs at home football games from September through November and home conference basketball games from January (after winter break) through February.
The main goal of the cheerleading program is to provide spirit at games. Members of the team will use crowd-involving chants and cheers with signs and will perform dance routines and sideline dances.
All skills regardless of experience will be re-taught starting at the most basic level to ensure proper knowledge, technique, and safety.
We do our best to accommodate busy academic schedules as well as those of other activities. That is why we have incorporated a hybrid approach with the ability to use video instruction to learn new material and to review current material in order to limit the amount of face-to-face time commitment.
The CMU Cheerleading Program welcomes all levels of experience to join! Former performers of any kind; dancers, gymnasts, figure skaters, cheerleaders, etc., or someone wanting to try something new and fun. Additionally, we welcome graduate students and semester exchange students from other CMU Campuses.
Visit our tryouts page for more information or contact Coach Kristin Kropf .
Follow us on Twitter @CMU_SpiritSquad, Like/Follow us on Facebook @CarnegieMellonCheerleading, Follow us on Instagram @carnegiemelloncheer.

GHC 4201 refers to the contact information for a specific department at Carnegie Mellon University.
MS students can access the LTI's computer cluster, which is used for course assignments, directed study projects, and/or the capstone project involving large datasets or lengthy computations.
The standard program lengths vary significantly ranging from two semesters for some full-time master’s programs to several or more years for doctoral programs.
Upon completion of the graduate program degree requirements, the degree will be certified by the student’s academic program in the semester in which the student completes the requirements.
Graduate students who consider the completion of all degree requirements in less than the standard length of time for their program of study may consult with their degree-granting program or department to determine if early degree certification is allowed and under what circumstances.
Longer-than-standard degree completion may occur due to academic interruptions in making progress toward the degree as defined by the academic program, interruptions of full-time study or progress towards the degree due to serious, documented medical issues, or other unusual or unforeseen circumstances.
GHC 4201 refers to a contact point at Carnegie Mellon University. It can be reached by calling extension 8-4231 from a campus phone or 412-268-4231 from an outside line.
The LTI’s computer cluster provides storage and computation for projects involving large datasets or lengthy computations, which can be used by MS students for course assignments, directed study projects, and/or the capstone project.
The standard length of time for a full-time master’s program can vary, but it typically ranges from two semesters.
Carnegie Mellon graduate students are expected to complete their degree requirements within the standard length of time for their program of study as outlined in the relevant Graduate Student Handbook.
A Master's student may require longer than the standard time to complete their degree due to academic interruptions in making progress toward the degree as defined by the academic program, interruptions of full-time study or progress towards the degree due to serious, documented medical issues, or other unusual or unforeseen circumstances.
Master’s students who require longer than the standard time to complete their degree requirements are expected to remain in close contact with their graduate program, and will be certified at the end of the semester in which they have completed their degree requirements.
Master's students should reference CMU Policy on Master’s Student Statute of Limitations: www.cmu.edu/policies/student-and-student-life/masters-students-statute-of limitations.html for guidelines and restrictions regarding the maximum length of time allowable for master’s degree completion.
This information comes from the MIIS Graduate Student Handbook, specifically page 11.
Master’s students who require longer than the standard time to complete their degree requirements are expected to remain in close contact with their graduate program.
At the end of the semester, Master’s students who have completed their degree requirements will be certified.
The purpose of the CMU Policy on Master’s Student Statute of Limitations is to provide guidelines and restrictions regarding the maximum length of time allowable for master’s degree completion.
Interruptions in making progress toward the degree as defined by the academic program refer to situations where a student is unable to continue their studies according to the requirements set forth by their graduate program.
Unusual or unforeseen circumstances refer to situations that are not typical or expected, and which may cause a student to require longer than the standard time to complete their degree.
The maximum time a student has to complete all requirements for a master's degree, as outlined in the Master’s Students Statute of Limitations, is seven years from original matriculation as a master’s student.
If the time-to-degree limit has lapsed, the person may resume work towards a master’s degree only if newly admitted to a currently offered master’s degree program under criteria determined by that program.
A school or college may, upon the relevant department's recommendation and with the written approval of the dean (or designate), defer the lapse for a period commensurate with the duration of that interruption.
Students seeking guidance about their program of study and degree requirements should consult with their academic advisor and/or appropriate associate dean.
Students who are pursuing a master’s degree as part-time students for all semesters of their program, as approved by their program, may also appeal to their program or department for extension of the time to degree limit.
In this context, matriculation refers to the process of becoming a master’s student.
The Master’s Students Statute of Limitations applies to all students, but it may be more restrictive in some departments, schools, or colleges.
To defer the lapse means to postpone the expiration of the time-to-degree limit for a period commensurate with the duration of an interruption.
In this context, part-time refers to students who are pursuing their master’s degree on a less than full-time basis.
Students seeking guidance about their program of study and degree requirements should consult with their academic advisor and/or appropriate associate dean.
Under U.S. Federal Title IV regulations, student eligibility for federal financial aid is contingent upon enrollment in and successful completion of courses that are counted as credit toward their current degree program. To receive the maximum amount of federal financial aid for which they may be eligible, students must enroll each semester in at least 36 units that count towards their current degree level.
International Students Immigration status for students in F-1 and J-1 nonimmigrant status is tied to making normal progress toward completing degree requirements. Therefore, F-1 and J-1 students who are considering completing their degree requirements early, anticipating longer-than-standard completion, or moving from an undergraduate to a graduate student classification (integrated undergraduate-graduate study) should consult with their designated advisor in the Office of International Education (OIE) to ensure compliance with immigration regulations.
Students should consult with their designated college liaison in The HUB regarding billing and financial aid, particularly for early completion, longer-than standard completion, or integrated undergraduate and master’s degree programs.

Students who are considering moving from an undergraduate to a graduate student classification (integrated undergraduate-graduate study) should consult with their designated advisor in the Office of International Education (OIE).
Under U.S. Federal Title IV regulations, student eligibility for federal financial aid is contingent upon enrollment in and successful completion of courses that are counted as credit toward their current degree program. If students do not enroll each semester in at least 36 units that count towards their current degree level, they may lose their eligibility for the maximum amount of federal financial aid.
The purpose of this text is to provide guidance and information about student's program of study, degree requirements, financial aid, billing, and immigration status for international students.
F-1 and J-1 students who are considering completing their degree requirements early, anticipating longer-than-standard completion, or moving from an undergraduate to a graduate student classification (integrated undergraduate-gradaduate study) should consult with their designated advisor in the Office of International Education (OIE).
The MIIS degree is offered in two options: Option 1. Standard MIIS degree (MIIS-16) - A 16-month track that is completed in three academic semesters (fall, spring, fall) and a summer internship. Option 2. MIIS: Advanced Study degree (MIIS-21) - A 21-month track that is completed in four academic semesters (fall, spring, fall, spring) and a summer internship.
MIIS: Advanced Study track offers in depth degree in one of the following areas of concentration: Human Language for Language Technologies • Language Technology Application • Machine Learning for Language Technologies
MIIS-16 students must take at least 84 units (typically 7 12-unit courses) of qualifying and elective courses that satisfy human language, machine learning, and language technology applications breadth requirements and 66 practice units for a total of 150 units to attain the Standard MIIS degree.
MIIS-21 students must take at least 108 units (typically 9 12-unit courses) of qualifying and elective courses and 66 practice units to satisfy their degree requirements, making it a total of 174 units to attain the MIIS: Advanced Study degree.
Curricular requirements ensure that MIIS students receive instruction in core intelligent information systems technologies while also allowing an opportunity to specialize in areas of personal interest. Practice requirements are opportunities to apply and hone new skills while building state-of-the-art systems. Grade requirements ensure that students have demonstrated a certain level of skill while completing degree requirements.
The total number of units required for both MIIS-16 and MIIS-21 degrees combined is 332 units.
The breadth requirements for a Standard MIIS degree include human language, machine learning, and language technology applications.
Both MIIS-16 and MIIS-21 degrees require a total of 66 practice units.
Grade requirements ensure that students have demonstrated a certain level of skill while completing degree requirements.
The MIIS: Advanced Study track is completed in four academic semesters (fall, spring, fall, spring).
MIIS-16 students must complete 72 units, typically by passing six 12-unit courses.
A qualifying master's course includes any graduate course (600-level or higher) offered by the Language Technologies Institute and any graduate course from the list of approved qualifying courses.
A free elective includes any graduate course (600-level or higher) with content relevant to the MIIS program objectives offered by the School of Computer Science, and courses approved by the student's advisor and degree Program Director.
MIIS students must demonstrate breadth by passing one course in each of the following areas: Human language, Machine learning, and Language technology applications. Additionally, MIS-21 students must take two more LTI courses (24 units total) in one of these areas.
Any graduate course (600-level or higher) offered by the Language Technologies Institute and any two graduate courses (600-level or higher) offered by departments within the SCS relevant to the MIIS degree other than LTI (Machine Learning or Computer Science departments, etc.) are approved qualifying courses.
No, a student may not use the same course to satisfy both a qualifying course requirement and an elective course requirement.
MIIS-21 students must complete 96 units, typically by passing eight 12-unit courses.
MIIS-21 students must take two more LTI courses (24 units total) in one of the following areas: Human language, Machine learning, and Language technology applications.
The department responsible for maintaining and publishing a list of courses satisfying each breadth requirement is the Language Technologies Institute.
A graduate course (600-level or higher) offered by the Language Technologies Institute is considered an approved qualifying course.
Yes, any two graduate courses (600-level or higher) offered by departments within the SCS relevant to the MIIS degree other than LTI (Machine Learning or Computer Science departments, etc.) may be counted as approved qualifying courses.
The information about the requirements for a graduate course to be considered an approved qualifying course is found in the MIIS Graduate Student Handbook, page 14.
The departments within SCS (School of Computer Science) that are relevant to the MIIS (Master's in Information Systems) degree, excluding LTI and Machine Learning or Computer Science departments, etc., are not specified.
The minimum level required for a course to be considered an approved qualifying course is 600-level or higher.
Yes, any graduate course (600-level or higher) offered by the Language Technologies Institute is considered an approved qualifying course.
The information about approved qualifying courses for MIIS (Master's in Information Systems) students can be found in the MIIS Graduate Student Handbook, page 14.
The text does not specify the maximum number of graduate courses from departments within SCS (School of Computer Science) relevant to the MIIS (Master's in Information Systems) degree that a student can count as approved qualifying courses.
The purpose of the MIIS Graduate Student Handbook is to provide information about requirements, policies, and procedures for students pursuing a Master's in Information Systems degree.

The courses offered for Master's and PhD programs in Machine Learning include 10-601, Introduction to Machine Learning (Master’s), 10-605, Machine Learning with Large Datasets, 10-701, Introduction to Machine Learning (PhD), 10-707, Advanced Deep Learning, and 10-708, Probabilistic Graphical Models.
The directed study requirement for MIIS-16 and MIIS-21 programs involves passing 24 units (typically 12 units x 2 semesters) in a structured, task-oriented form of independent study under the supervision of their advisor.
The internship requirement for MIIS-16 and MIIS-21 programs involves completing a one-semester (typically summer) internship at an organization approved by the MIIS Program Director. Students with prior professional experience may petition to waive this requirement.
A student must complete at least 66 practice-oriented course units for both MIIS-16 and MIIS-21 programs.
Students who do an internship during the summer semester are required to present their internship at a poster session at the beginning of the following Fall semester. The poster and the student’s participation in the poster session are part of the internship requirement.
Students with prior professional experience may petition the MIIS Program Director to waive the internship requirement.
Both MIIS-16 and MIIS-21 programs require 24 units (typically 12 units x 2 semesters) in directed study under the supervision of their advisor.
The courses offered for Master's program in Machine Learning include 10-601, Introduction to Machine Learning (Master’s), 10-605, Machine Learning with Large Datasets, and 10-701, Introduction to Machine Learning (PhD).
The courses offered for PhD program in Machine Learning include 10-605, Machine Learning with Large Datasets and 10-701, Introduction to Machine Learning (PhD).
Both MIIS-16 and MIIS-21 programs require a student to complete at least 66 practice-oriented course units, pass 24 units in directed study under the supervision of their advisor, and complete a one-semester internship at an organization approved by the MIIS Program Director.
Students must complete a capstone project (36 units) and a capstone planning seminar (6 units).
The capstone requirement gives students experience with collaborative, team-oriented software development; significant hands-on experience with the techniques studied in the classroom; and an opportunity to work on a large software application.
The capstone project (36 units) is a large, group-oriented demonstration of student skill in one or more areas covered by the degree. Typically, the result of the capstone project is a major software application.
The capstone project is supervised by a member of the faculty who meets with students on a weekly basis to monitor progress and provide guidance.
The capstone planning seminar organizes students into groups, defines project goals and requirements, identifies resources needed for successful completion, and must be completed in the semester prior to taking the capstone project.
Students use the Stellic Degree Audit Application to monitor progress, search for relevant courses, and share plans with advisors. They confirm enrollment status, class level, college, and department in SIO Academic Info.
Students must ensure their Enrollment Status is 'Eligible to Enroll', confirm maximum units, and check class level, college, and department. They then navigate to SIO Academic Info, select Enrollment Status and the upcoming semester, and follow 4 easy steps provided by CMU.
Students may reach out to MIIS program director Teruko Mitamura with any questions about course selection.
Undergraduate and master’s level students must follow the procedures and deadlines identified on the academic calendar. Doctoral course changes have a separate calendar.
The Transfer Courses and Pittsburgh Council on Higher Education (PCHE) section provides information about transferring courses from other institutions to MIIS.
The capstone project serves as a culminating experience for students, demonstrating their mastery of skills and knowledge gained throughout their program.
The MIIS program director assists students with course selection, providing guidance on choosing appropriate courses for their academic goals and interests.
Students should navigate to the SIO Academic Info tab, select Enrollment Status and the upcoming semester, and check for 'Eligible to Enroll' status. They also verify class level, college, and department.
Students should ensure their enrollment status is 'Eligible to Enroll', confirm maximum units allowed, check class level, college, and department. Then they navigate to SIO Academic Info, select Enrollment Status and the upcoming semester, and follow 4 easy steps provided by CMU.
The academic calendar provides deadlines and procedures for undergraduate and master’s level students to add, drop, or withdraw from courses.
Carnegie Mellon University records information on courses taken through the university's cross-registration program and transfer credit from other accredited institutions. Courses taken through the university's cross-registration program will have grades recorded on the transcript and be factored into the QPA, while all other courses will be recorded without grades.
Suspended students may take courses elsewhere but can only receive transfer credit if their college’s and department's policies allow this.
Students taking internships with units attached must provide interim and final reports on their experience, presentations in the following semester regarding their experience, assessments of how their experience relates to their course of study.
The university and LTI provide several types of support for students seeking internships. Students are responsible for identifying and applying for internships on their own.
Carnegie Mellon University's transcript records information on courses taken through the university's cross-registration program and courses taken at other accredited institutions. Courses taken through the university's cross-registration program will have grades recorded on the transcript and be factored into the QPA, while all other courses will be recorded without grades.
The inclusion of internship information in a student's academic record allows for assessments of how their experience relates to their course of study.
The QPA (Quality Point Average) is a measure used by Carnegie Mellon University to evaluate academic performance. It factors into consideration grades recorded on the transcript from courses taken at Carnegie Mellon and through cross-registration programs.
Students taking internships with units attached must provide interim and final reports on their experience, presentations in the following semester regarding their experience, assessments of how their experience relates to their course of study.
Suspended students may take courses elsewhere but can only receive transfer credit if their college’s and department's policies allow this.
The university and LTI provide several types of support for students seeking internships. Students are responsible for identifying and applying for internships on their own.
The university offers resume-writing and interviewing workshops, as well as fall and spring employment fairs.
If a student cannot find an internship, the MIIS program will arrange an on-campus internship with a university-based project. This internship may be unpaid.
International students are required to consult with the Office of International Education for eligibility before seeking an internship/co-op or signing an offer contract.
MIIS students may attend similar internship-oriented poster sessions held by other LTI professional master’s programs.
An annual poster session helps spread information from MIIS students that recently completed internships to MIIS students that will soon seek internships.
MIIS students can access the university’s Career & Professional Development Center at https://www.cmu.edu/career/. This page provides other services as well.
Section 4.10 of the MIIS Graduate Student Handbook discusses advising services for students.
The university’s Career & Professional Development Center provides various resources and services to help MIIS students prepare for internships, employment fairs, and other career opportunities.
The location of the Office of International Education at MIIS is not specified in the given text.
The faculty advisor's role includes guiding education, monitoring student progress, supervising directed study projects and providing career advice.
Advisors are chosen during the first month of the program. Students attend LTI Orientation Faculty Research Talks to meet potential advisors, who describe their interests and areas of expertise.
If a student fails to secure an advisor within the first month, the Program Director assigns an advisor to them.
Yes, students can switch advisors. They must find a new faculty member willing to serve as an advisor and then request the Program Director's approval.
The LTI follows the long-standing SCS policy that both the new and old advisors must agree to the change. This usually isn't a problem, as the new advisor has agreed beforehand.
Forming a strong student-advisor relationship takes time and effort. Switching often can disrupt this process, making it harder for the student to benefit from their advisor's guidance.
LTI Orientation is a program where faculty members describe their interests and areas of expertise. Students attend these talks, meet potential advisors, and learn about the program's expectations.
During these talks, faculty members present their interests and areas of expertise. Students attend to meet potential advisors and learn about the program's expectations.
The Program Director approves student-advisor relationships, assigns an advisor if a student doesn't find one within the first month and oversees the advising process.
Students are expected to attend these talks and treat them as seriously as a course, because they provide a good introduction to the broad range of research done at the LTI.
No, students do not have to register for the LTI Orientation Faculty Research Talks and they do not receive a grade.
The LTI Orientation Canvas course is designed to increase incoming LTI graduate students' awareness and understanding of CMU's community standards and the resources that CMU offers its students.
The program administrator enrolls MIIS students into the LTI Orientation Canvas course in early August.
All MIIS students are expected to complete all assignments by the end of their first semester in the program.

The Link
Allen Newell and Herb Simon
It serves as a link between the School of Computer Science and more than 10,000 alumni, colleagues, parents, and other friends around the world.
The history of computer science
Alan Turing, Ken Thompson, Claude Shannon, John McCarthy, and the founders of CMU's computer science department, Allen Newell and Herbert Simon.
Computer chess has been called the 'drosophila--fruitfly' of artificial intelligence research, similar to how genetics students study fruit flies due to their short life cycle.
Chess allows for a controlled domain where we can experiment with lots of issues in intelligence.
He led the team that designed Chinook, a computer checkers program
Jonathan Schaeffer is a professor of computer science and vice provost of the University of Alberta, leading the university's computer poker research.
Hans Berliner is a CMU senior research scientist who built the first game-playing computer to defeat a human champion and the first chess computer capable of playing at 'senior master' level.
Hans Berliner achieved excellence in various areas including speech, image analysis, data retrieval and was a member of the IBM Deep Blue team that defeated world chess champion Garry Kasparov.
According to Hans Berliner, computer chess was a research dead-end as far as artificial intelligence was concerned. He believes that more powerful processors and machine-learning techniques powered by statistical analysis were able to crack data-intensive problems.
Murray Campbell, one of the members of the IBM Deep Blue team, believes that Hans Berliner covered a lot of ground and achieved excellence in all areas he studied.
The Fredkin Prize in Artificial Intelligence was awarded to IBM's Deep Blue, a machine designed by three CMU alumni that defeated world chess champion Garry Kasparov.
Hans Berliner believes that computer chess was a research dead-end as far as artificial intelligence was concerned. He thinks that more powerful processors and machine-learning techniques powered by statistical analysis were able to crack data-intensive problems.
Chinook is a computer checkers program that seems unbeatable and was designed by a team led by Schaeffer. It allows for controlled domain where issues in intelligence can be experimented with.
The text suggests that researchers start with something simple and progress beyond it to tackle harder problems once they have gained a good understanding.
Schaeffer, as per the text, led the team that designed Chinook, a computer checkers program that seems unbeatable and leads the university's computer poker research.
According to Schaeffer, chess allows for a controlled domain where issues in intelligence can be experimented with and progress beyond it to tackle harder problems once they have gained a good understanding.
Hans Berliner is a computer scientist who made significant contributions to the field of artificial intelligence through his work on computer chess.
Berliner achieved excellence in all areas he covered, but it didn't lead to a huge breakthrough that allowed us to better understand human language or translation, or led to a general model of human intelligence.
Computer chess brought about a change in attitude on how we approached a large number of problems in computer science, and it led to lasting value in the field.
Berliner produced something that had lasting value and his papers contain insights, algorithms, and new ideas that aren't as common today as they should be.
Berliner's papers are still around because he never took the easy way and most scientists aren't willing to take such risks.
Emile Berliner invented the gramophone, which was a precursor to all recorded sound formats including hard drives and BluRay discs.
Thomas Edison is generally credited with the invention of recording sound, although Berliner perfected the recorded disc format which was superior to Edison's cylindrical records.
Edison's cylindrical records were difficult to manufacture and store, whereas Berliner's recorded disc format was superior in every way.
Berliner's DNA may be unique because his great-uncle Emile Berliner invented the gramophone, which took risks and led to innovative formats.
Emile Berliner invented the gramophone, also known as the phonograph.
Emile Berliner's recorded discs were superior in every way and arguably the predecessor of all formats that followed, including hard drives and BluRay discs.
Hans Berliner entered public school in Germany just as Adolf Hitler was rising to power. The first hour of each day consisted of 'religion' (meaning Christianity) and 'National Socialism', which he couldn't participate in.
Germany was a wonderful place for a child interested in science because of its inventiveness and production of high-quality goods.
Hans Berliner had a metal wind-up car that sensed when it was about to run off a ledge and automatically steered away.
While American kindergarteners were finger-painting, German kindergarteners were likely three years ahead in mathematics.
His formative years had a very positive effect on him.
He couldn't join because he was told that he was Jewish and they didn't want him.
Uncle Emile's nephew, Joseph Sanders arranged for about 10 members of their extended family to emigrate to America.
Berliner arrived in the Washington, D.C., area speaking very little English with a thick German accent.
He graduated high school with top grammar marks in his class, and years later, one of his fellow students remembered him as an 'extremely brilliant boy'.
He learned how to play chess from a teen-age friend on a rainy day at the camp.
Berliner enjoyed playing chess as it was a wonderful way for him to discipline his mind and improve his prospects in life.
He achieved master status, winning both the District of Columbia Championship and the Southern States Championship.
Chess helped Berliner to discipline his mind and think ahead. It forced him to deal with a certain level of reality, which he believed improved his prospects in life.
The atmosphere in Hitler's Germany promised nothing but despair. Berliner's parents knew it and decided to leave with their family for America.
Campbell
a very systematic approach and a lot of hard work.
Yorktown Heights, N.Y.
an analytical mind that enabled him to beat players who might very well have been more talented than him.
six or eight plies
taught by rote memorization, and as his grades plummeted, the draft beckoned.
with the German occupation forces
he kept eight games going simultaneously against one of the top German teams--and won them all.
Berliner initially planned not to return to college after his military service.
Isador Turover, a fellow European immigrant who knew Berliner through chess circles, persuaded him to finish his degree by offering him a job in his company.
Berliner changed his field of study from physics to psychology after being hired by Turover.
Berliner was informed that his skills were needed at the Naval Research Lab, leading him to work on problems in 'human engineering' or 'engineering psychology', which is now known as interface design.
Berliner won the 10th Chess Olympiad, the 1953 New York State Championship, and the 1956 Eastern States Open. He also played games blindfolded.
Berliner won his first correspondence chess championship with a margin of victory three times better than any other winner, winning 12 games out of 16 and drawing four.
Berliner remained the top-ranked U.S. correspondence chess player until 2005, even after he stopped competing.
Berliner experienced migraine headaches due to his blindfolded chess games.
Berliner's reputation grew especially strong in correspondence chess--games played through the mail--
From 1965 to 1968, Berliner was theWorld Correspondence Chess Champion.
Berliner won 12 of 16 and drew four times
He remained the top-rankedU.S. correspondence chess player until 2005, long after he stopped competing.
Nearing 40and feeling frustrated, Berliner in 1967 met future Nobel laureate and TuringAward winner Herb Simon at a technical meeting.
In 1956, Simon, associate dean of what was then known asCMU's Graduate School of Industrial Administration, had predicted (to his laterchagrin) that within 10 years a computer would become world chess champion.
Twoyears later, with Allen Newell and Cliff Shaw, Simon wrote one of the firstchess-playing programs, known as NSS.
Berliner remembers being unimpressed withNSS, which took up to an hour to make a move: 'They could play against somehuman who played even worse, but it couldn't come close to beating a rankedplayer.'
More than a decade later, Simon remained interested inchess computers.
Simon offered Berliner a job.
Berliner turned down the job initially because he wanted to be put on the student track.
Berliner joined CMU's Computer Science Department in 1969.
The founding head, Alan Perlis, was an amazing and wonderful person who had a desire for progress and truth.
All new graduate students were expected to pass a rigorous 24-hour take-home exam, the Extended Duration Qualifier.
Berliner started working on computer chess for his thesis because he was interested in it and Newell allowed him to do so.
Alan Turing proposed this idea as far back as the 1940s.
No, Alan Turing lacked a computer capable of executing his rudimentary chess program in 1950.
Alan Turing proposed this idea in the 1940s.
Logic Theorist was a program designed by Newell, Simon and Shaw in the 1950s. They used this program to prove mathematical theorems from Principia Mathematica.
Traversal refers to the process of going through each branch of a tree or graph, checking if it leads to a solution. This was used in Logic Theorist.
Researchers like Claude Shannon believed that brute-force methods, which involve calculating all known positions to solve a problem, would never work.
Chess is useful because it's bounded by rules and takes intelligence to play. It also allows progress without having to 'boil the ocean', meaning that one can focus on a specific subset of problems.
The fact that Logic Theorist generated proofs for a significant number of Principia Mathematica's theorems was considered a major achievement and widely recognized as the world's first 'artificial intelligence' program.
Logic Theorist generated a simpler proof for one of Principia Mathematica's theorems than the commonly accepted proof.
Pruning refers to the process of removing branches from a tree or graph that are not useful for solving a problem. In Logic Theorist, pruning was used to eliminate untrue hypotheses.
Brute-force methods involve calculating all known positions or possibilities to solve a problem. Researchers like Claude Shannon believed that such methods would never work due to their computational complexity.
Chess is particularly useful for AI research because it's bounded by rules, unlike more abstract problems in speech or vision.
Ebeling says that many problems in AI research rely on measurements, statistics and analysis, and results are hard to tease out.
Schaeffer adds that if a researcher is trying to build an 'intelligent' machine, and it can't even play a simple game such as chess, then clearly you have a long way to go.
During Schaeffer's studies in the 1970s, there was only one person in the entire community who was publishing about chess in high-quality scientific venues, and that was Hans Berliner.
Schaeffer says that what makes chess unique among more abstract problems is its bounded rules. It's a very challenging game, yet it's limited in nice ways.
Berliner says that with chess, you don't have to 'boil the ocean' to make progress. You can focus on an interesting subset and make some progress.
Ebeling says that it's not hard to figure out if something is working or not when playing chess. If your program doesn't win, there may be a lot of reasons why it lost, but it's hard to make excuses.
Schaeffer believes that if a researcher is trying to build an 'intelligent' machine, and it can't even play a simple game such as chess, then clearly you have a long way to go.
Berliner's students were focused on developing AI programs that could play complex games like chess, which he believed would be a good test for any intelligent machine.
Berliner's first computer program was 'J.Biit', which he wrote at IBM on his own time.
J. Biit lost to Northwestern University's Chess 3.0 in the first North American Computer Chess Championship.
Berliner's next program, called 'CAPS', remembered previous errors and learned to avoid them before beginning a new search.
Berliner believed that rule-based chess programs were not enough because they left no room for intuition or guesswork, which are important factors in human decision making.
Newell and Simon encouraged Berliner to push onward with his research by telling him that he wasn't trying hard enough and needed to make up more rules.
Berliner learned the game of backgammon from his father-in-law, which he decided to write a program for.
The initial backgammon program by Berliner would get stuck at certain points and bog down because it kept trying to optimize things that it should have forgotten about.
Berliner realized that his initial backgammon program had a problem where it would continue to optimize things even after winning, which should have triggered a change of strategy.
Berliner used fuzzy logic, a concept that was still new in the 1970s, to assign different rules 'weights' or 'application factors,' based on their relative importance at each stage of the game.
Berliner found himself pigeonholed because one of his papers on BKG was returned by an AI conference with a note from a reviewer asking why he wasn't working on chess.
Berliner tackled chess with scientific rigor because he was a scientist first and foremost, and he wanted to publish his findings in top journals and conferences.
Campbell wanted to study at CMU because of Berliner's research on chess, which he found fascinating after reading his papers.
BKG became the first computer program to beat a reigning world champion in any game when it defeated backgammon player Luigi Villa in July 1979.
Much of the work in computer chess was ad hoc because it was done by hobbyists for fun and never got published properly.
Berliner's work on chess had a scientific approach because he was a scientist who wanted to publish his findings in top journals and conferences.
In the 1970s, Berliner used fuzzy logic to assign different rules 'weights' or 'application factors,' based on their relative importance at each stage of the game.
Berliner's approach to chess was unique because he tackled it with scientific rigor, publishing his findings in top journals and conferences rather than weak mediocre conferences.
Berliner was pigeonholed because one of his papers on BKG, a program he developed to improve backgammon games, was returned by an AI conference with a note from a reviewer asking why he wasn't working on chess.
Andy Palay is a person who worked on extending the B* algorithm using a probability distribution rather than upper and lower values. He also suggested applying B* to chess.
Andy Palay used the power of computers to search in a way that was like a rational human being would search. He extended the B* algorithm using a probability distribution rather than upper and lower values.
B* is an algorithm used for searching, unlike simple A* 'best-first' searches, it is more directed towards what appear to be the most promising paths. It was extended by Andy Palay using a probability distribution rather than upper and lower values.
Palay suggested applying B* to chess because there are between 30 and 60 legal moves at any given point in a chess game, and searching for those legal moves consumed up to 75 percent of a chess computer's time. He found B* more interesting than brute-force searching.
The problem with using brute-force searching in chess is that it consumed up to 75 percent of a chess computer's time. It also requires more time than other methods.
Carl Ebeling was Palay's friend who was looking for a thesis project that involved hardware. He custom-designed a processor to generate chess moves and used 64 of these processors--one for each square of the chessboard--operating in parallel.
Carl Ebeling custom-designed a processor to generate chess moves and used 64 of these processors--one for each square of the chessboard--operating in parallel. The resulting machine, named Hitech, was used to solve chess problems.
Hitech is a machine that uses 64 processors--one for each square of the chessboard--operating in parallel. It was custom-designed by Carl Ebeling to generate chess moves.
People inside and outside CMU's CS department took turns at a third-floor lab in Wean Hall, wire-wrapping connections. There was such an enthusiasm for Hitech that I've never seen before.
Hitech's working prototype was completed in 1984.
Hitech could consider 175,000 positions per second.
In October 1985, Hitech won Pittsburgh's Gateway Open chess competition and earned the rank of 'master.'
Thompson's paper proved that chess machines improve in direct correlation with the amount of processing power they have.
After Thompson's paper, many researchers shifted their focus from creating smarter searches to faster computers because chess machines improve in direct correlation with the amount of processing power they have.
Campbell was also collaborating with fellow grad students Feng-hsiung Hsu and Thomas Anantharaman on another chess-playing computer known as ChipTest.
By 1987, ChipTest was searching 500,000 moves per second.
In 1987, ChipTest won the North American Computer Chess Championship.
ChipTest was a chess-playing computer developed by fellow grad students Feng-hsiung Hsu (CS'90) and Thomas Anantharaman (CS'86,'90).
The machine that beat Kasparov in 1997 was called Deep Blue.

In 1997, Deep Blue won the World Computer Chess Championship.

In 1987, ChipTest won the North American Computer Chess Championship.
Deep Blue was a chess-playing computer system developed by IBM.
Deep Blue had 480 special-purpose chips designed to evaluate chess moves.
Deep Blue demonstrated that brute-force computing power could crack tough problems, such as playing chess at a world-class level.
Garry Campbell, the lead developer of Deep Blue, expressed this sentiment.
Teaching a machine to learn how to play chess from scratch, like humans do, remains an unsolved challenge in artificial intelligence.

There are three types of parking available on CMU's campus: permit parking, metered parking, and hourly garage parking. Permit parking is limited and has varying rates, while metered parking requires a valid university ID to park at an expired meter.
CMU offers shuttle and escort services that operate in the evening/overnight, providing free transportation from campus to within a block of your home in Oakland, Squirrel Hill, and Shadyside neighborhoods as well as university sites outside the main campus.

The main purpose of the Center for Student Diversity & Inclusion at Carnegie Mellon University is to cultivate a strong, diverse and inclusive community capable of living out the values of the university and advancing research, creativity, learning and development that changes the world.
The Center for Student Diversity & Inclusion offers various initiatives such as first generation/first in family to attend college programs, LGBTQ+ Initiatives, race and ethnically focused programs like Inter-University Graduate Students of Color Series (SOC) and PhD SOC Network, women’s empowerment programs including Graduate Women’s Gatherings (GWGs), and transgender and non-binary student programs.

The 2023-24 Tartan Men's Track and Field season starts in Fall of 2023.
The schedule includes a total of six meets for the 2023-24 Tartan Men's Track and Field team.
The first meet of the season will be held at the Carnegie Mellon University Invitational, which takes place on September 29th and 30th.
The second meet in the schedule is called the Tartan Open, scheduled for October 14th.
The third meet of the season is hosted by Westminster College and takes place on November 4th.
The fourth meet, called the Tartan Invitational, will be held on January 27th and 28th of the following year.
The fifth meet in the schedule is hosted by Washington & Jefferson College and takes place on February 10th.
The sixth and final meet, called the Tartan Last Chance Meet, will be held on March 3rd.

The purpose of iCalendar RSS Feed is to provide a way for users to access and manage their calendar events in a structured format.
You can share an event from the iCalendar RSS Feed by clicking on the 'Share' button and selecting one of the available options: Facebook, Twitter, Email or Print.
When events are marked in bold in the Home section, they indicate that these events are related to home activities and may be of personal interest or importance.
iCalendar refers to a calendar application used for managing appointments, meetings, and events. On the other hand, an RSS Feed (Really Simple Syndication) allows users to access updates from websites in a structured format.
The 'Conference' event listed could be an upcoming conference related to iCalendar or RSS Feed, which may provide users with updates and information about these technologies.
The word 'Home' refers to events that are related to personal or home activities, which may include family gatherings, appointments, or other important dates.
The separate section for Home events allows users to easily identify and manage their personal activities and events, which may be different from work-related or other types of events.
The RSS Feed in iCalendar allows users to access and manage their calendar events in a structured format, which can be easily shared or subscribed by others.
The 'Share' button allows users to share events with others, either through social media platforms like Facebook and Twitter or by emailing it directly.

It usually takes 4-5 years to obtain the degree after completing PDEEC.
Students must demonstrate broad technical competence, continuous progress in research activities, contribute to the body of knowledge in Electrical and Computer Engineering, and have the ability to disseminate this knowledge orally and in writing.
Students must complete a minimum of 30 ECTS credits or 5 UCs (advanced courses) during their studies.
Students can demonstrate their ability to disseminate knowledge through the Practice of Teaching Support. All PDEEC students are strongly advised to complete a one-semester internship with teaching activities.
Completing a semester's worth of teaching support is equivalent to 6 ECTS credits.
Students must prepare their thesis proposal within four semesters after they are admitted into PDEEC.
The Thesis Supervision and Monitoring Committee (CAT) analyzes and makes recommendations for students' thesis proposals during a public presentation session.
The committee consists of at least three members, including the student's advisor.
The deadline for students to prepare their thesis proposal after being admitted into PDEEC is four semesters.
The Comissão de Acompanhamento Tese (CAT) is composed of at least three members, including the student's advisor.
After completing their coursework and research program, a student must prepare a written report documenting their work and explaining how it fits into the body of knowledge in EEC.
After submitting the thesis, it is presented at a public defense session. The approval is decided by majority vote from the jury appointed for this purpose.
PDEEC integrates, optionally and upon application, into one of three international collaborations: IST-EPFL Joint Doctoral Initiative; CMU-Portugal ICTI Program in Electrical and Computer Engineering; or the CMU-Portugal ICTI Program in Language Technology.
Instituto Superior Técnico started offering the doctorate degree in Electrotechnical and Computing Engineering at the end of the sixties.
The Programa Doutoral em Engenharia Electrotécnica e de Computadores (PDEEC) aims to prepare students for independent scientific work in areas covered by the Department of Electrotechnical and Computing Engineering.
The Programa Doutoral em Engenharia Electrotécnica e de Computadores (PDEEC) is designed for graduates and masters who wish to obtain a doctorate degree.
The main objective of the Programa Doutoral em Engenharia Electrotécnica e de Computadores (PDEEC) is to prepare researchers with the ability to conduct independent scientific work in areas covered by the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering.
The target audience for the Programa Doutoral em Engenharia Electrotécnica e de Computadores (PDEEC) are licentiates and masters who wish to obtain a Doctorate in Electrical and Computer Engineering with a view to an academic career and research.
Doutores em Engenharia Electrotécnica e de Computadores can work as professors in higher education, both in Portugal and abroad, guide Master's and Doctoral students, work in laboratories and research institutes, or work in industry and services, particularly in companies with research and development departments.
The official publications for the Programa Doutoral em Engenharia Electrotécnica e de Computadores (PDEEC) include the program's objectives, target audience, and potential career paths.
The purpose of the Programa Doutoral em Engenharia Electrotécnica e de Computadores (PDEEC) is to prepare students for a career in academia and research, specifically within the field of electrical and computer engineering.
Licentiates and masters who wish to pursue a Doctorate in Electrical and Computer Engineering with a view to an academic career and research can apply for the Programa Doutoral em Engenharia Electrotécnica e de Computadores (PDEEC).
After completing the Programa Doutoral em Engenharia Electrotécnica e de Computadores (PDEEC), graduates can work as professors in higher education, guide Master's and Doctoral students, work in laboratories and research institutes, or work in industry and services, particularly in companies with research and development departments.
The official publications for the Programa Doutoral em Engenharia Electrotécnica e de Computadores (PDEEC) include the program's objectives, target audience, and potential career paths.
The main objective of the Programa Doutoral em Engenharia Electrotécnica e de Computadores (PDEEC) is to prepare researchers with the ability to conduct independent scientific work in areas covered by the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering.

GSA offers an expanding suite of social programming on and off-campus to bring graduate students from different departments together and build a sense of community. They also maintain a website of graduate student resources.
The Graduate Student Lounge is on the 3rd floor of the Cohon University Center.
Students can get involved by contacting gsa@cmu.edu, stop by their office in the Cohon University Center Room 304, or become a representative for their department.
The Office of International Education (OIE) serves as the liaison to the University for all non-immigrant students and scholars, provides advising on various issues, presents programs of interest, and conducts orientation and pre-departure programs.
OIE provides many services including advising on personal, immigration, study abroad, academic, and social and acculturation issues; presenting programs of interest such as international career workshops, tax workshops, and cross-cultural and immigration workshops; providing information through email and the OIE website.
The Veterans and Military Community provides support for veteran students, including advising on personal, immigration, study abroad, academic, and social issues; presenting programs of interest such as international career workshops, tax workshops, and cross-cultural and immigration workshops.
Students can find more information on the Veterans and Military Community page of the CMU website.
Graduate students can find information about applying for veteran education benefits, campus services, veteran’s groups at CMU, and non-educational resources.
Students can file a confidential report by calling 1-844-587-0793 or visiting https://cmu.ethicspoint.com/. All submissions are reported to appropriate university personnel and handled discreetly.
The policy protects individuals who make good faith reports of suspected violations from retaliation. It also provides additional details at https://www.cmu.edu/policies/administrative-and-governance/whistleblower.html.
The hotline provides a confidential way for members of the university community to report suspected unethical activity, violations of university policy or law. It is not an emergency service and can be reached at 1-844-587-0793 or https://cmu.ethicspoint.com/. For emergencies, call University Police at 412-268-2323.

The Student Academic Success Center supports student success by providing academic coaching, subject-specific tutoring, effective communication strategies, accommodations for students with disabilities, and language support for multilingual learners. They also engage with faculty and staff to improve the coordination and professional development for academic advisors.
The University Libraries offers a wide range of information, resources, and services supporting graduate students in coursework, research, teaching, and publishing. They license and purchase books, journals, media, and other needed materials in various formats. Library liaisons, consultants, and information specialists provide in-depth and professional assistance and advice in all-things information, including locating and obtaining specific resources, providing specialized research support, and advanced training in the use and management of data.

ORIC assists researchers with human subject research, conflicts of interest, responsible conduct of research, export controls, and institutional animal care & use. It also provides consultation, advice, and review of allegations of research misconduct.
Counseling & Psychological Services provides a safe, confidential setting where students can talk privately about academic and personal concerns. It offers an initial consultation to clarify the nature of the concern, immediate support, and further options if needed. These may include referrals for counseling within CaPS or to another resource at Carnegie Mellon or in the larger Pittsburgh community.
Students can make appointments for CaPS services either in person or by telephone at 412-268-2922.
The ORIC's primary function is to support research activities by ensuring they are conducted with integrity and in accordance with federal and Pennsylvania regulations.
The website provides guidance and more general information about research activities governed by several university policies.
ORIC assists researchers with conflicts of interest, providing consultation, advice, and review of allegations of research misconduct.

LTI Ph.D. Graduate Student Handbook

Health Services provides various health-related services for students.
The intended audience for this information is graduate students of Ph.D. programs at CMU.
LTI stands for Learning Technology Initiative.
This information is relevant to the health and well-being of Ph.D. graduate students, which is an important aspect of their academic journey.
CMU stands for Carnegie Mellon University.
A Ph.D. graduate student might need to use the services provided by Health Services for various reasons, such as seeking medical attention or counseling.
University Health Services provides general medical care, allergy injections, first aid, gynecological care, and contraception as well as on-site pharmaceuticals.
The students are responsible for these fees.
University Health Services has physicians, advanced practice clinicians and registered nurses on its team.
Students can make appointments by visiting the website, walk-in or telephone (412- 268-2157).
The program offers a high level of coverage in a wide network of health care providers and hospitals.
Yes, UHS has a registered dietician and health promotion specialists on staff who assist students in addressing nutrition issues.
The university provides a wide variety of wellness, mindfulness and connectedness initiatives and resources designed to help students thrive inside and outside the classroom.
The Religious and Spiritual Life Initiatives (RSLI) program offers these initiatives.
Students should review the UHS website and their insurance plan for detailed information about the university health insurance requirement and fees.
The purpose of Campus Wellness at Carnegie Mellon University is to provide a wide variety of wellness, mindfulness and connectedness initiatives and resources designed to help students thrive inside and outside the classroom.
Carnegie Mellon is committed to creating opportunities for spiritual and religious practice and exploration. RSLI has relationships with local houses of worship from various traditions, offers programs that cross traditional religious boundaries in order to increase knowledge of and appreciation for the full diversity of worldview traditions.
RSLI staff are available to support students across the spectrum of religious and spiritual practice. They would be more than happy to help you make a connection into a community of faith during your time at CMU.
The contact information for University Police at Carnegie Mellon University is https://www.cmu.edu/police/x2323.
Students can find more information about RSLI at Carnegie Mellon University by visiting https://www.cmu.edu/wellbeing/resources/religious-spiritual/index.html.

Parking and Transportation coordinates the Shuttle Service and Escort Service provided for CMU students, faculty, and community.
You can find full information about the Shuttle & Escort Services on their website at https://www.cmu.edu/parking/transport/
The WORD is Carnegie Mellon University’s online student handbook and serves as the foundation for the department (and sometimes college) handbook.
The WORD contains university-wide academic policy information and resources, community policies and resources, and describes the university level procedures used to review possible violations of these standards. It is designed to provide all students with the tools, guidance, and insights to help you achieve your full potential as a member of the Carnegie Mellon community.
Graduate students are encouraged to bookmark this site and refer to it often.
University policies can also be found in full text at: https://www.cmu.edu/policies/
The LTI Ph.D. Graduate Student Handbook
You can find more information about the LTI Ph.D. Graduate Student Handbook on Page 49.
The WORD serves as the foundation for the department (and sometimes college) handbook, providing university-wide academic policy information and resources.
The target audience for this website appears to be high school teachers.
The main categories of content available on this website include academics, research, partnership, news, events, DEI, LTI Intranet, contact information, careers, and an application form.
The Language Technologies Institute (LTI) appears to be responsible for maintaining this website.
According to the navigation menu, the main users of this website include academics, researchers, partnership seekers, news readers, event attendees, DEI enthusiasts, LTI staff members, job applicants, and visitors.
The 'Apply' button appears to be a link for applying for jobs or academic programs at the Language Technologies Institute.
The administrative and research & technical staff members are maintained by different departments within the Language Technologies Institute (LTI).
In the 'All Staff' category, one can find administrative staff and research & technical staff members working at the Language Technologies Institute (LTI).
The search form allows users to look for specific information or people within the Language Technologies Institute by using keywords.
The main stakeholders in maintaining and updating the content of this website appear to be the administrative staff, research & technical staff members, faculty, students/alumni, and visitors.

Gesling Stadium was built in 1990 as part of the east campus project.
The playing surface at Gesling Stadium was renovated with FieldTurf in the summer of 2006 and resurfaced and rebranded in the summer of 2014.
The seating capacity of Gesling Stadium is 3,500 in the grandstands with multiple standing room viewing options available.
The track at Gesling Stadium was resurfaced in the summer of 2016.
Gesling Stadium is home to the football team in the fall.
The surface at Gesling Stadium is an infill mix of silica sand and cryogenic rubber, with a patented layering process that emulates natural grass.
The state-of-the-art 13' x 24' video scoreboard was installed in 2019 for use by varsity athletics.
No NON-CMU organized practices are allowed at Gesling Stadium.
No, pets are not allowed in Gesling Stadium.
The target audience of this website appears to be high school students, teachers and faculty members.

The name of the institute mentioned in this text is Language Technologies Institute.

The 'Apply' button leads to a page where high school students, teachers and faculty members can apply for various programs or opportunities related to Language Technologies Institute.

The name of the category where visitors can find more information is 'LTI Intranet'.

The names of the courses offered in the schedule are Sound Design, Directing, Dramaturgy, Production Management, Stage Management, Scenic Design, Carnegie Scenic, and Costume Design.
The time duration for each course varies. For example, Sound Design lasts from 06:30PM to 10:30PM, while Stage Management and Scenic Design last from 05:00PM to 06:20PM.
All these courses are held in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. The specific locations for each course can be found in the schedule provided.
Stage Management and Scenic Design both start at 05:00PM and end at 06:20PM.

The guidelines and restrictions place an upper limit on the maximum length of time allowable for master’s degree completion and certification.
Students seeking guidance about their program of study and degree requirements should consult with their academic advisor and/or appropriate associate dean.
Under U.S. Federal Title IV regulations, student eligibility for federal financial aid is contingent upon enrollment in and successful completion of courses that are counted as credit toward their current degree program.
Students must enroll each semester in at least 36 units that count toward their current degree program to receive the maximum amount of federal financial aid for which they may be eligible.
Students should consult with their designated college liaison in The HUB regarding billing and financial aid, particularly for early completion, longer-than-standard completion, or integrated undergraduate and master’s degree programs.
The policy on Master’s Student Statute of Limitations outlines guidelines and restrictions that place an upper limit on the maximum length of time allowable for master’s degree completion and certification.
The standard timeframe for completing a master's program varies by program, but students are expected to make normal progress toward their degree and graduate within this timeframe.
If a student does not complete their degree within the standard timeframe, they may face restrictions on their eligibility for federal financial aid and may need to consult with their academic advisor or appropriate associate dean regarding program of study.
Integrated undergraduate and master's degree programs are programs where students can complete both their bachelor's and master's degrees in a shorter timeframe than if they were pursuing each separately.

To receive an MCDS degree, students must have a Quality Point Average (QPA) of 3.0 and complete courses in the core curriculum, the MCDS seminar, electives, and capstone project.
The common MCDS core consists of five courses completed by all students in their first two semesters. This includes eight core and concentration courses, two 12-unit seminar courses, and two 12-unit capstone courses.
The three areas for choosing a concentration are Analytics, Systems, or Human-Centered Data Science. All students must complete at least one of these concentrations consisting of three courses.
To maintain full-time enrollment status, a student must enroll in a minimum of 36 course units per semester.
A student may not take more than 60 units per semester, without permission from their academic advisor.
Yes, all students must maintain full-time enrollment status (minimum of 36 units) in their final semester.
All MCDS students are expected to pass the 11-637 Foundations of Computational Data Science course by the end of their first semester.
Each MCDS student must pass the 11-637 Foundations of Computational Data Science course with a grade of 'B' or better.
The degree consists of two timing options based on the length of time the student spends working on the degree. The student chooses their timing at the start of the degree program (for visa requirements). Changes in timing are possible with the approval of the Director of the degree program and successful visa extension application with CMU’s Office of International Education.
All degree options consist of the same amount of coursework.
The two options for completing a degree in this program are Professional Preparation Track and Research Preparation Track.
The Professional Preparation Track is a 16-month degree consisting of study for Fall and Spring semesters, a summer internship, and Fall semester of study. Each semester consists of a minimum of 48 units of study.
Each semester in the Professional Preparation Track consists of a minimum of 48 units of study.
Students typically graduate in December after completing their 16-month degree consisting of Fall and Spring semesters, a summer internship, and Fall semester of study.
The Research Preparation Track is a 20-month degree consisting of study for Fall and Spring semesters, a summer internship, and a second year of Fall and Spring study.
Each semester in the Research Preparation Track consists of a minimum of 36 units of study.
This timing is designed for students interested in extending their time at CMU for developing applied research skills in preparation for further graduate study or research-oriented employment.
The per-semester course load is lower, but the total cost is higher since four semesters of tuition are paid for in this timing.
A typical student's study period under the Professional Preparation Track is 16 months, consisting of Fall and Spring semesters, a summer internship, and Fall semester of study.
MCDS students must complete 144 units.
There are four common core courses: Machine Learning, Cloud Computing, Interactive Data Science, and Data Science Seminar.

The three Capstone courses that all MCDS students must take are 11-634 - Capstone Planning Seminar, 11-635 - Capstone Research, and 11-632 - Data Science Capstone.
The learning outcomes of MCDS Program include designing, implementing, and evaluating analytic algorithms on sample datasets; explaining how a machine-learning model is developed for and evaluated on real world datasets; designing and executing experimental data collection and presenting resulting analyses using appropriate user experience (UX) techniques including interactive data visualizations; applying and customizing analytics, systems, and human-centered data science techniques to application-specific data science requirements and objectives; identifying tradeoffs among data science techniques (analytics, systems, and/or human-centered); survey, interpreting, and comparatively criticizing state of the art research talks and papers with emphasis on constructive improvements; organizing, executing, reporting on, and presenting a real world data science project in collaboration with other researchers/programmers.
Students electing to complete the Analytics concentration will also learn to design, implement and evaluate a software system and machine-learning model on real world datasets at real world scale; analyze and document data science requirements in different application domains and survey as well as critique state of the art solutions for those requirements.
Students electing to complete the Systems concentration will also learn to analyze and document data science requirements in different application domains; survey as well as critique state of the art solutions for those requirements.
The three Capstone courses that all MCDS students must take are 11-634 - Capstone Planning Seminar, 11-635 - Capstone Research, and 11-632 - Data Science Capstone.
