The HCDS concentration emphasizes on providing experimental evidence for design decisions and anticipating and avert structural and/or implementation problems with systems design, especially with scaling and tail distributions.
Students will learn to design, implement and evaluate a user experience prototype for clear understanding of data science solutions. They will also apply social and behavioral research methods to data science problems to understand the human aspects of data collection and analysis.
The capstone project consists of students working individually or in a team on a project that integrates their educational experience. It can be a CMU research project, an industry-sponsored project, or occasionally students define their own topics with the MCDS faculty.
Electives can be any graduate level course (numbered 600 or above) in the School of Computer Science. Students use these to enhance study in an area of interest or explore new areas.
Undergraduate courses can be any course numbered 100-599 offered by the School of Computer Science.

An independent study course allows students to cover a particular area of interest when no formal course is available in that subject area. It often offers the opportunity for research directly with a faculty member and are considered electives.
Each independent study course must be advised and approved by at least one faculty member. Agreement to supervise the course is voluntary on the part of the faculty member.
1) The student must request approval from their academic advisor and complete a proposal before the first day of classes in a given semester. 2) Enter into an agreement with the independent study supervisor that includes course expectations, including deliverables. 3) Secure the 'Independent Study Contract Form' from the MCDS administrator. 4) Complete the form, provide a brief description of the work to be done, including deliverables and how they will be graded. 5) Secure signatures of both the student and the supervisor. Return the form to the MCDS administrator in order to obtain approval for the independent study from the Director.
Independent study contracts must be submitted no later than on the last day of the first week of classes in a given semester.
No course may be used to complete two MCDS degree requirements, nor may a course satisfy requirements in two degree programs.

The student may be dismissed from the program.
They must enroll in courses as advised by their academic advisor and maintain a cumulative QPA of 3.0.
The AIV will be noted in their letter of review and may result in further academic actions.
The student will be placed on academic probation for the following semester and required to enroll in courses as advised by the academic advisor, improve his/her grades to no less than an overall 3.0 QPA in the following semester, and meet any other goal set by the advisor during that period (e.g., fulfilling a core course requirement).
The student will be considered at risk of being unable to complete the program and will be considered for dismissal. He/she will be required to meet with the program director to discuss his/her situation.
If a student's cumulative QPA remains below 3.0 in the following semester, they will be considered for dismissal from the program.
Students must maintain a cumulative QPA of 3.0 to remain in good standing with the program.

An infraction

They are encouraged to meet with their academic advisor to discuss a plan to mitigate the situation.
An instructor may award a grade of 'I' when a student has been unable to complete the work of a course, but only if the work completed up to that date is of passing quality.
The instructor must specify the requirements for completing the work and designate a default letter grade in case the student fails to complete the remaining work.
The grounds for dismissal include committing two Academic Integrity Violations deemed infractions by the MCDS committee, committing an Academic Integrity Violation where the violation is deemed sufficiently egregious as determined by the MCDS program committee, and infringing a University Policy.
They are encouraged to communicate early and often with their academic advisor for the best chances of success.
It is expected that students will complete a course during the academic semester in which the course was taken, as incomplete grades provide no undue advantage over other students.
The work completed up to that date must be of passing quality for the student to receive an incomplete grade.
An 'I' grade stands for Incomplete, which means that a student has not completed all the required course work.
If a student fails to complete the required course work by the end of an academic semester, they must finish it sooner as per the instructor's requirement.
The default letter grade designated by the instructor in case of incomplete course work is specified when awarding an 'I' grade.
Students are given until the end of the following academic semester or sooner if instructed by the teacher to complete their remaining work.
The number 20 likely represents the total amount of course work that a student needs to complete before receiving an 'I' grade, or it could be used for other purposes as per the instructor's discretion.
The term means that when an 'I' grade is awarded, the teacher specifies what letter grade will be given if the student fails to complete their remaining work.
Course work is considered completed when all assigned tasks and assignments have been finished by the student according to the instructor's requirements.
An 'I' grade may negatively impact a student's GPA and could potentially limit their access to certain programs, scholarships, or job opportunities.
The instructor plays a crucial role by specifying the requirements for completing course work and designating a default letter grade if the student fails to complete their remaining tasks.
The Registrar will automatically assign a default grade.
The default grade becomes the grade of record.
They should discuss the matter with the course instructor and provide evidence that the grade issued was incorrect.
The student should contact the program administrator to process a Change of Grade Form.
The instructor is generally considered as the final authority for a course grade.
If the requirements for the MCDS degree have not been completed when a student leaves, the degree will not be awarded.
No, completion of the MCDS degree does not insure admittance to any doctoral degree program.
Students should refer to Carnegie Mellon University's policy on intellectual property: http://www.cmu.edu/policies/documents/IntellProp.html

The highest standards of academic integrity
If a student commits a second violation, the expected penalty is dismissal from the graduate program.
Students can review the policy at https://www.cmu.edu/policies/student-and-student-life/academic-integrity.html
The purpose of the policy is to provide definitions and expectations around academic integrity, including what constitutes cheating, plagiarism, and unauthorized assistance.
The policy outlines procedures for investigating, reporting, adjudicating, and appealing academic integrity violations. The severity of these consequences can vary depending on the nature of the offense.
The policy recommends that students review the procedure outlining the investigation, reporting, adjudication, and appeal processes for academic integrity violations.
Final grades may only be changed in exceptional circumstances such as manifest error (e.g., clear errors).
The instructor and department, unit or program have the discretion to approve changes to final grades.
The policy outlines an appeal process that includes reviewing, reporting, adjudicating, and appealing academic integrity violations.
Grading is a matter of sound discretion for the instructor. Final grades are rarely changed without the consent of the instructor who assigned the grade.
The policy provides definitions and expectations around academic integrity, as well as procedures for investigating and adjudicating violations. The Word also offers additional information on the topic.

The purpose of QAAC is to create a space for LGBTQIA+ and allied varsity athletes to socialize across teams, increase allyship and awareness, and provide a platform for education and change.
Queer Athlete and Ally Collective was founded in partnership with the Carnegie Mellon University Athletics Department.
The organization provides a platform for education and change, indicating that it seeks to educate its members about LGBTQIA+ issues and promote awareness.
The three main activities of QAAC are socializing across teams, increasing allyship and awareness, and providing a platform for education.
Sharing this information through various channels allows QAAC to reach a wider audience and increase awareness about their organization and its mission.
In the context of QAAC, 'LGBTQIA+' stands for Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Transgender, Queer or Questioning, Intersex, Asexual, and Plus (representing other identities within the community).
Varsity athletes are members of QAAC, indicating that they participate in this organization as part of their commitment to promoting LGBTQIA+ awareness and allyship.
Socializing across teams means that athletes from different sports or teams within the university come together to participate in QAAC activities, fostering a sense of community and unity.
Allies are individuals who support LGBTQIA+ rights and work towards creating a more inclusive environment. In QAAC, allies can be varsity athletes or others who identify as straight but stand in solidarity with the LGBTQIA+ community.
Education and change are key components of QAAC, indicating that the organization aims to educate its members about LGBTQIA+ issues and work towards creating positive changes within the university community.
The purpose of the Core Curriculum is to prepare students to discover new AI applications and develop them into a product suitable for further development, often leading to a startup enterprise.
Students must complete 195 eligible units of study to earn the MSAII degree, including 84 units of Core Curriculum (including the 36-unit Capstone), at least 36 units of approved Electives and the LTI Practicum (3 units).
If a student fails to pass course 15-213, they must retake it during either the fall or spring semester and the units will not count towards their 192 eligible units of study.
The Core Curriculum consists of a five-course sequence based on the four main phases of innovation development: opportunity identification, opportunity development, business planning and incubation of a business with a viable product. The courses must be taken in this order: 11-651, Artificial Intelligence and Future Markets; 17-762, Law of Computer Technology; 11-690, AI Development I; 11-691, AI Development II; and 11-699, Capstone Project.
Course 17-762, Law of Computer Technology, provides a review of legal principles applicable to computer developments, including AI law and formation of startups.
The Capstone Project is a development project that students work on as part of the Core Curriculum. It involves developing a product proposal from their first semester and carrying it through for the next three semesters, leading to 11-699, the final Capstone Project.
Students must complete at least 36 units of approved Electives to earn their MSAII degree, in addition to the Core Curriculum (84 units), Knowledge Requirements (72 units) and LTI Practicum (3 units).
Students must complete a total of 195 eligible units to earn their MSAII degree, including 84 units of Core Curriculum (including the 36-unit Capstone), at least 36 units of approved Electives and the LTI Practicum (3 units).
The Knowledge Requirements are designed to provide students with a broad understanding of AI and its applications, as well as business skills necessary for developing and launching successful startups.
The LTI Practicum provides students with practical experience in applying AI technologies to real-world problems, preparing them for their future careers.
The course 17-762, Law of Computer Technology (12 units), is a review of legal principles applicable to computer developments, including AI law and formation of startups.
The course 11-695, AI Engineering (12 units), covers supervised learning, feed-forward neural networks, flow graphs, dynamic computational graphs, convolutional neural networks and recurrent neural networks.
The course 11-654, AI Innovation (12 units), teaches students how to build an enterprise either intrapreneurially or entrepreneurially by developing a business model and strategy for their team's product.
The course 11-699, Capstone Project (36 units), aims to have your team develop a working product suitable for intrapreneurial integration into a company or startup investment.
There are six rigorous courses in the Knowledge Requirements (72 units).
The course 11-601, Coding Bootcamp (12 units), teaches coding skills.
No, it is not mentioned in the text that 11-785, Deep Learning (12 units), is a prerequisite for the Capstone Project.
The two courses offered in the first fall semester are 17-762, Law of Computer Technology (12 units), and 10-601, Machine Learning (12 units).
The course 10-605, Machine Learning with Large Datasets (12 units), teaches students how to work with large datasets in machine learning.
The internship program mentioned in the text does not have a specific name, it's just referred to as 'Internship'
The course replacing 11-691, Math for Machine Learning in Fall 2019 is 10-601, Machine Learning (12 units).
The student has to complete an industry internship during the summer between the first spring and second fall semesters.
The course covering Machine Learning for Text Mining is 11-641, Machine Learning for Text Mining.
36 units are required for electives in this curriculum.
The course covering Advanced Multimodal Machine Learning is 11-777, Advanced Multimodal Machine Learning.
The student has to take a graduate-level Artificial Intelligence course in their second fall semester.
The course covering Visual Learning and Recognition is 16-824, Visual Learning and Recognition.
A graduate-level Computer Vision course requires 16-720, Computer Vision units.
The course covering Web Application Development is 17-637, Web Application Development.

The professor's research interests revolve around integrating text, image, video, and audio analysis.
The goal of the News-on-Demand application is to overcome shortfalls inherent in each component technology by combining strengths of speech recognition, natural language processing, information retrieval and interface design.
The professor wants to use large corpora of 'found data', which is easily stored and made available through the Internet or other readily accessible open sources.
The professor intends to build understanding programs that help process data from various sources, making it useful for applications such as speech recognition, image understanding, natural language processing, machine learning, and information retrieval.
The challenge is to find suitable form of data for training, learning or re-use and build mechanisms that can successfully use this data.
Speech and multimedia technology are about to make a major impact on our daily interaction with computers, making it necessary to demonstrate the advantages of integrated speech and multimedia interfaces.
The professor's research interests include improving machine learning by utilizing large corpora of 'found data' across different modalities.

The Carnegie Mellon Student-Athlete Alumni Mentoring Program aims to foster relationships between past and present student-athletes, providing guidance, wisdom, and opportunities for the current generation of Tartans.
Carnegie Mellon Athletics aims to develop leaders by providing student-athletes with skills and abilities developed as members of their intercollegiate athletics program.
The mentoring program connects world-class students and alumni in professional-based mentoring relationships, helping current student-athletes prepare for careers and providing alumni with the opportunity to stay connected with the Tartan community.
The mentoring program helps current student-athletes develop an advantage as they prepare for careers and provides them with guidance, wisdom, and opportunities.
Mentors provide student-athletes with guidance, wisdom, and opportunities as they prepare for careers.
The mentoring program provides a meaningful way for student-athlete alumni to stay connected with the Tartan community.
Sharing information about the mentoring program helps to promote it and encourage participation from both current student-athletes and alumni.
The mentoring program uses a software platform to guide connections and communication between student-athletes and alumni.
To join the mentoring program, one can click on the 'Join the Program' button and follow the instructions.

The Carnegie Mellon University Department of Athletics, Physical Education and Recreation's vision is to provide a transformative and inclusive educational experience that nurtures competitiveness, wellness, belonging and resilience, and provides students with a leadership framework to live healthy and impactful lives.
The Department of Athletics, Physical Education and Recreation aims to establish a championship Division III culture.
They complement and enhance the learning that transpires in Carnegie Mellon’s classrooms by providing a diverse recreational program offerings and opportunities.
Integrity, which is reflected as a core component of everything they do.
They use their talents to influence the world in positive ways by aligning resources — human, capital, financial — with the strategic priorities guiding a transformative student experience.
Diversity, Equity and Inclusive Excellence, which is reflected in their culture that fosters equitable participation and opportunity for individuals from different backgrounds and varied life experiences.
They aim to excel academically at a world-renowned institution and prepare students to impact the world in myriad ways.
They educate students through sport as they compete and strive for comprehensive excellence by delivering an unparalleled student-athlete experience that serves to develop the next generation of thought leaders and innovators.

The goal of the News-on-Demand application is to overcome shortfalls inherent in each component technology by combining strengths of speech recognition, natural language processing, information retrieval and interface design.
The professor wants to use large corpora of 'found data', which is easily stored and made available through the Internet or other readily accessible open sources.
The professor intends to build understanding programs that help process data from various sources, making it useful for applications such as speech recognition, image understanding, natural language processing, machine learning, and information retrieval.
The challenge is to find suitable form of data for training, learning or re-use and build mechanisms that can successfully use this data.

To build a cohesive, centralized affinity group and network of support, camaraderie and mentorship among Black and Latinx student-athletes and alumni.

Each letter in the schedule represents a day of the week: W for Monday, R for Wednesday, and F for Friday. The letters are used to indicate which days each course is offered.
The abbreviation 'MTWRF' stands for Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday. It indicates the days when each course is offered in the schedule.
This phrase means that a course will be held from 06:30 PM to 10:30 PM. The abbreviation 'TBA' stands for 'to be announced', indicating that the specific time and location of the course have not yet been determined.

You should review any IP agreements with your advisors before signing them, as it is possible to lose ownership of your ideas.

PhD students are permitted to register for 54 units of actual coursework per semester in order to encourage them to focus on research.
No, pass/fail grades are not permitted for courses used to satisfy a degree requirement. Graduate students who need additional undergraduate courses may also not elect the pass/fail option.
The handbook provides guidelines and rules for graduate students in the LTI program, including information on stipends, course load, grading options, and other important policies.
The information about maximum courseload can be found on Page 13 of the LTI PhD Graduate Student Handbook.
The purpose is to ensure that students are held accountable for their academic performance and progress towards earning their degree, as well as to maintain high standards of scholarship.
Graduate students required to take additional undergraduate courses to build up their course foundation in computer science may not elect the pass/fail option for these courses.
The decision on whether a course may be transferred is made by the PhD Program Director. The student will provide the Program Director with the syllabus of the external course, and the Program Director will use that and the student’s transcript to make the decision.
The university requires PhD students to spend at least one year of residency at Carnegie Mellon. The SCS also requires that all PhD students must take at Carnegie Mellon a minimum of 36 units of the total coursework required by their respective programs.
No, the LTI does not allow direct transfers from its master’s programs into its PhD program. Students that are already enrolled in an LTI degree program are not required to retake GRE and TOEFL exams or to produce new transcripts from other universities.
A student who is interested in transferring out of the PhD degree program should consult the handbook and Program Director of the desired degree program to learn whether transfers are permitted, and if so, how, and when to request such a transfer.

As per the Doctoral Student Status Policy, students have a maximum of ten years from their original matriculation as doctoral students to complete all requirements for the PhD degree. If required by more restrictive department or college policy, this limit may be less.
If a student fails to complete all requirements for their PhD degree within ten years (or less as per department or college policy), they may resume work towards a doctoral degree only by being newly admitted to a currently offered doctoral degree program under criteria determined by that program.
The add/drop/withdraw deadlines are found on the official Doctoral course-sections Academic Calendar.
No, doctoral, visiting and certificate students do not receive vouchers or participate in the voucher process.
The maximum time limit for completing a PhD degree is ten years from original matriculation as a doctoral student, or less if required by more restrictive department or college policy.
Students who do not meet the ten-year (or less) time-to-degree requirement can resume work towards a doctoral degree by being newly admitted to a currently offered doctoral degree program under criteria determined by that program.
The add/drop/withdraw deadlines can be found on the official Doctoral course-sections Academic Calendar.

All But Dissertation (ABD) refers to a student who has completed all coursework and comprehensive exams for their doctoral program but has not yet defended or submitted their dissertation.

The 'Grandfather' policy allows students to choose whether they want to graduate under policies in effect at the time of their entry or those adopted after entering.
Transfer credit refers to equivalent graduate courses completed at another institution that can be recognized by LTI, while a course exemption means the student has already taken an equivalent course.
The LTI may grant transfer credit or issue an exemption for equivalent graduate courses previously completed at another institution. This decision rests with the director of the particular program.
If a student is exempt from a required course, they can replace that course with an open elective. The student does not receive credit for the external course but can take any course that could normally count toward the degree in its place.
If a student receives credit for prior coursework, they receive that many units of credit. The total amount of required coursework is reduced by that amount.
Students funded by LTI research projects are expected to work primarily for those projects. Since consulting provides useful experience, students are generally permitted to consult at most.
The purpose of allowing a student to replace an exempt course with an open elective is to give them flexibility in their degree program and allow them to take courses that align more closely with their interests or career goals.
Receiving credit for prior coursework reduces the total amount of required coursework that a student needs to complete.
The decision regarding whether to grant transfer credit or issue an exemption for equivalent graduate courses previously completed at another institution rests with the director of the particular program.
Students funded by LTI research projects are generally permitted to consult at most.
External employment/consulting provides students with useful experience that can enhance their skills, knowledge, and professional network. It may also be beneficial for their future career by providing practical application of the concepts they learn in class.

The mission of the Office of Disability Resources at Carnegie Mellon University is to provide physical, digital, and programmatic access to ensure that students with disabilities have equal access to their educational experience.
Students who would like to receive accommodations can begin the process through Disability Resources' secure online portal (https://rainier.accessiblelearning.com/cmu/) or email access@andrew.cmu.edu to begin the interactive accommodation process.
Students with physical, sensory, cognitive, or emotional disabilities are encouraged to self-identify with the Office of Disability Resources and request to needed accommodations.
Students can contact access@andrew.cmu.edu or call (412) 268-6121 for any questions about accessibility.
https://www.cmu.edu/graduate/policies/appeal-grievance-procedures.html
The purpose of the Office of Disability Resources' secure online portal (https://rainier.accessiblelearning.com/cmu/) is to provide a platform for students with disabilities to request accommodations.
Students can contact access@andrew.cmu.edu or call (412) 268-6121 for any questions about accessibility.
The Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 guarantee reasonable accommodations for qualified individuals with disabilities.
The purpose of the Graduate Student Appeal and Grievance Procedures page (https://www.cmu.edu/graduate/policies/appeal-grievance-procedures.html) is to provide a framework for graduate students to appeal or file grievances related to their academic progress.
Graduate students can find the Summary of Graduate Student Appeal and Grievance Procedures on the Graduate Education Resource webpage.
Graduate students are generally expected to seek informal resolution of all concerns within the applicable department, unit, or program before invoking formal processes.
When an informal resolution cannot be reached, a graduate student who seeks further review of the matter is to follow the formal procedures outlined in the Summary of Graduate Student Appeal and Grievance Procedures.
The University prohibits sex-based discrimination, sexual harassment, sexual assault, dating/ domestic violence, and stalking. The University also prohibits retaliation against individuals who bring forward such concerns or allegations in good faith.
The University’s Sexual Misconduct Policy is available at https://www.cmu.edu/policies/administrative-and-governance/sexual-misconduct/index.html
The University’s Policy Against Retaliation is available at https://www.cmu.edu/policies/administrative-and-governance/whistleblower.html

The Consensual Intimate Relationship Policy Regarding Undergraduate Students
Consensual intimate relationships between graduate and undergraduate students are prohibited when one party has authority over the other.

All graduate students, regardless of their program, are eligible for the Emergency Student Loan.
Students may apply for the loan by visiting the Office of the Dean of Students, located in Warner Hall 321 during business hours.
The Emergency Student Loan is an interest-free and emergency-based loan that must be repaid within 30 days.
Students who find themselves in need of immediate funds for emergency situations should contact the Office of the Dean of Students.

Carnegie Mellon has a Student Health Insurance policy requiring full-time, degree seeking students to carry adequate medical insurance. Students must either purchase the plan offered by the University or an application for a waiver can be made if the student is “enrolled as the dependent, partner/spouse or principal in an employer or government-sponsored insurance plan.”
It is the responsibility of each student to make arrangements with Student Health Services to either pay for their insurance at the beginning of the semester or elect a payment plan over the course of the academic year. More information is available at the Student Health Services Web site https://www.cmu.edu/health-services/student-insurance/faqs.html
The HUB staff delivers comprehensive service and counsel to students and families regarding financial aid, billing and payment, ID cards, and registration and academic records. The Assistant Directors in The HUB serve as contacts for specific colleges and assist enrolled students with key aspects of the enrollment process.
Students can find their assigned HUB Assistant Director on their Student Information Online (SIO) Resource page.
For general questions and information, students may email The HUB or call 412-268-8186.
The HUB is located in Warner Hall, Lower Level.
Students may find more information about SIO at https://www.cmu.edu/hub/
The purpose of the Carnegie Mellon University Student Health Insurance Policy (SHIP) is to ensure that students have adequate medical insurance coverage.
If a student does not purchase or waive the required health insurance, they may be subject to penalties and fines.
The URL for the Student Health Services Web site at Carnegie Mellon University is https://www.cmu.edu/health-services/student-insurance/index.html
Student Information Online (SIO) is a secure site where students can find important, personalized information such as E-Bills and student account information, financial aid status and eligibility, grades and QPA, and course schedules.
Students can log on to SIO by going to www.cmu.edu/hub/sio and entering their Andrew User ID and password.
It's encouraged that students keep their current local address updated on SIO as this supports official living university program/department/college/university notices, the ability to facilitate wellness checks and ensures international students are in compliance with visa requirements.
Students can view various personalized information such as grades, QPA, course schedules, E-Bills and student account information, financial aid status and eligibility, housing and meal plan assignments, and more.
For international students, keeping their local address up-to-date on SIO ensures compliance with visa requirements.
Students can sign up for E-Check & E-Refund on SIO and authorize their spouses, domestic partners or other individuals to receive a copy of their E-Bill.
The LTI PhD Graduate Student Handbook was referenced to emphasize the importance of having accurate information for students.
SIO's initiative to have accurate student information supports official living university program/department/college/university notices, facilitates wellness checks and ensures compliance with visa requirements.
The URL for SIO is www.cmu.edu/hub/sio
The purpose of designating an emergency contact address is to have a relative or family friend who can be contacted in case of an emergency.
Graduate students can obtain their ID card from The HUB once they have been entered into SIO for the semester.
An Affiliate ID Card is available for spouses and partners of graduate students that allow them to access Carnegie Mellon’s campus. These cards are available through The HUB to spouses and partners of graduate students who are enrolled for the current academic year in a full-time graduate degree program.
An Affiliate ID Card is valid for one year.
Information about domestic partner registration can be found on the Office of the Dean of Students webpage: https://www.cmu.edu/student-affairs/dean/domestic-partner/
For more information about student and affiliate ID cards (spouse, domestic partners and dependent children), please visit: http://www.cmu.edu/idplus/idcards/sponsored.html.
Student cards are deactivated upon the cardholder’s separation from the university.

According to CMU policy, all units required for the PhD degree must be recorded on the transcript within ten years of the date on which the student enrolled in the program.
The maximum duration that a waiver can extend the statutory period depends on department, school or college policy. However, it cannot exceed ten years.

PCHE stands for Pittsburgh Council on Higher Education.
Cross-registration provides an opportunity for enriched educational programs by permitting full-time graduate students to cross-register for courses (usually no more than one per semester) at a Pittsburgh Council on Higher Education (PCHE) Institution.
Full-time Carnegie Mellon degree students are eligible and the PCHE course may not count towards full-time status unless the student is enrolled in an inter-university program.
Usually no more than one per semester
Students interested in taking advantage of this opportunity should be familiar with the Policy on Grades for Transfer Courses already outlined previously in this handbook.

https://www.cmu.edu/policies/student-and-student-life/privacy-rights-students.html
According to FERPA, students have the right to: inspect and review their education records; request an amendment to their education record if they believe they are inaccurate or misleading; request a hearing if their request for an amendment is not resolved to their satisfaction; consent to disclosure of personally identifiable information from their education records, except to the extent that FERPA authorizes disclosure without consent; file a complaint with the U.S. Department of Education Family Policy Compliance Office if they believe their rights under FERPA have been violated.
file a complaint with the U.S. Department of Education Family Policy Compliance Office

The School of Computer Science offers graduate application fee waivers for reasons related to financial hardship and participants of certain programs.
Up to two programs' fees can be waived by an applicant under this scheme.
An applicant who is a participant of one of the listed programs or organizations must upload appropriate documents such as receipts for registration, membership cards, certificates of participation, etc., to prove their eligibility.
No, reviewers will not have access to any information about fee waiver requests of the applicants.
After selecting your program, you are required to include evidence of participation by uploading appropriate documents such as receipts for registration, membership cards, certificates of participation, etc.
The purpose of providing fee waivers for participants of certain programs and organizations is to help those who are facing financial hardship in their application process.
The list provided does not specify how many qualifying programs and organizations there are. It only mentions a few examples, such as 'Program A' and 'Organization B', which applicants can choose from.
If an applicant doesn't find their program or organization on the list, they can still apply for a fee waiver based on financial hardship.
The School of Computer Science's policy states that reviewers will not have access to any information about fee waiver requests made by applicants.

Before founding Lycos, Michael Loren 'Fuzzy' Mauldin was a faculty member at Carnegie Mellon University.
After co-founding Conversive, Michael Loren 'Fuzzy' Mauldin went on to retire in Austin, Texas, where he currently raises cattle with his wife and continues to compete in robot battles.
Before creating the Lycos search engine, Michael Loren 'Fuzzy' Mauldin worked as a faculty member at Carnegie Mellon University.
To commercialize his product, Michael Loren 'Fuzzy' Mauldin aligned his ducks by having lawyers, accountants, and licensing agreements on hand before trying to commercialize his product.
The intellectual property entitlement split for Carnegie Mellon University is currently 50-50, meaning the inventor owns half and the school gets the other half.
Michael Loren 'Fuzzy' Mauldin competed in televised BattleBots competitions in 2000.
Michael Loren 'Fuzzy' Mauldin created the Lycos search engine from three pages of code while working as a faculty member at Carnegie Mellon in 1994.
Michael Loren 'Fuzzy' Mauldin sold his Lycos search engine to someone else after creating it from three pages of code while working as a faculty member at Carnegie Mellon in 1994.
Michael Loren 'Fuzzy' Mauldin meant that he had lawyers, accountants, and licensing agreements on hand before trying to commercialize his product.
Advantages include credibility and liquidity. Disadvantages include constant worrying about stock prices and quarterly performance.
The IPO pricing process involves determining an ideal share price range, usually between $10 to $100. In Lycos' case, it needed a minimum of $10 and a maximum of $100.
After the first day of trading, Lycos' share prices shot up to $29.
Mauldin was most proud that Lycos helped make search free for the world and showed there's money in search.
Mauldin covered topics such as debt and equity, accretion and dilution, and how a transaction affects a company's earnings per share.
Lycos went public in less than nine months after Mauldin started the process.
Mauldin claimed that Lycos had the fastest IPO ever, taking only a little over nine months from start to finish.
Mauldin sold Lycos because he predicted the internet bubble and wanted to cash in before other companies went public.
Mauldin stated that as a public company, there is constant worrying about stock prices and what will happen at the end of each quarter instead of focusing on long-term goals.
Mauldin played a significant role in Lycos, helping to guide it through its initial public offering and explaining business principles to students and faculty.
Mauldin claimed that he sold Lycos and started the frenzy of internet company IPOs in the late ‘90s.
Mauldin is proudest because his company allowed people access to information found on the other side of the world and showed that there was money in search.
Mauldin advised future entrepreneurs not only to invent something but also to get paid for taking investments, grow them as large as possible and secure both company and stockholder satisfaction.
Mauldin’s advice about startups and the IPO process is still very relevant today.
Facebook, Groupon, numerous companies worth over $100 million two years after startup and many others have succeeded by following Mauldin’s advice.
The ones that die are those that don’t adapt, as per Michael Shamos' comment.
This article was written on November 21, 2011.
The article appeared in The Tartan.
Yes, you can follow @thetartan on Twitter for the latest updates from them.

The purpose of signing in with Google is to continue using Adobe Acrobat for Google Drive.
Anyone who has a Google account can sign in with Google.
When signing in, Google will share your name, email address, language preference, and profile picture with Adobe Acrobat for Google Drive.
If you forget your email, you can use the 'Forgot email?' option to recover it.
There is a Help section provided where users can find assistance. Additionally, there are links to the Privacy and Terms policies.
In this context, 'Sign in' means logging into Adobe Acrobat for Google Drive using your Google account.
It is important to understand what data will be shared with third parties, how your information will be used, and other rules that apply when you use this app.
In this context, 'to continue' means to proceed further with using Adobe Acrobat for Google Drive after signing in.
@andrew.cmu.edu

The name of the institute mentioned in this text is Language Technologies Institute.
Under 'People', there are three main groups: Faculty, Staff and Students/Alumni. Visitors is also mentioned but it seems to be a separate category.
In the context of this text, LTI stands for Language Technologies Institute.
The search form is located under 'People' category in this website.
Under Academics, there is a sub-category named Faculty. Under Research, there is no specific sub-category mentioned but it seems to be related to Language Technologies Institute.
The 'Apply' button leads to a page where high school students, teachers and faculty members can apply for various programs or opportunities related to Language Technologies Institute.
The purpose of this website according to its menu bar appears to be a platform that provides information about Language Technologies Institute, including research, partnerships and academic programs.
The name of the category where visitors can find more information is 'LTI Intranet'.

The purpose of the University Police Department at Carnegie Mellon University is to provide police patrols and call response, criminal investigations, fixed officer and foot officer patrols, event security, and crime prevention and education programming as well as bicycle and laptop registration.
The entrance of the University Police Department at Carnegie Mellon University is located on Filmore Street.
The University Police Department offers various services for crime prevention and education programming, including bicycle registration, laptop registration, and fingerprint services.
Graduate students can obtain a copy of the annual campus security and fire safety report by contacting the University Police Department at 412-268-6232.
The annual campus security and fire safety report can be accessed online at https://www.cmu.edu/police/annualreports/
Parking and Transportation provides the Shuttle Service and Escort Service for CMU students, faculty, and community. The Shuttle & Escort website has full information about these services, stops, routes, tracking, and schedules.
More detailed information about the Shuttle Service and Escort Service provided by Parking and Transportation can be found on the Shuttle & Escort website.
The purpose of publishing an annual campus security and fire safety report at Carnegie Mellon University is to describe the university’s security, alcohol and drug, sexual assault, and fire safety policies and contain statistics about the number and type of crimes committed on the campus and the number and cause of fires in campus residence facilities during the preceding three years.
Graduate students, faculty members, and staff at Carnegie Mellon University can obtain a copy of the annual campus security and fire safety report.
Shuttle and Escort Services Parking and Transportation coordinates the Shuttle Service and Escort Service provided for CMU students, faculty, and community.
You can find full information about these services, stops, routes, tracking and schedules on the Shuttle & Escort website.
The WORD is Carnegie Mellon University’s student online handbook and is considered a supplement to the department (and sometimes college) handbook.
The WORD contains campus resources and opportunities, academic policy information and resources, community standards information and resources. It is designed to provide all students with the tools, guidance, and insights to help you achieve your full potential as a member of the Carnegie Mellon community.
Information about graduate student handbook, LTI PhD Graduate Student Handbook, and Statement of Assurance is included in The WORD. It also contains university policies.
You can find full text of the University policies at http://www.cmu.edu/policies/
Graduate students are encouraged to bookmark this site and refer to it often.
The purpose of The WORD is to provide all students with the tools, guidance, and insights to help you achieve your full potential as a member of the Carnegie Mellon community.
Carnegie Mellon Vision, Mission represents the vision and mission statement of Carnegie Mellon University.

The CMU Soccer Field was constructed in the summer of 2010.
The field uses FieldTurf, which allows for a year-round space for the campus community.
The CMU Soccer Field is adjacent to Gesling Stadium.
During the construction, the hammer/discus circle and shot put area used by the track and field teams were relocated.
Yes, the field has lighting which allows for the continuation of evening soccer games and intramural activities.
The seating capacity of the CMU Soccer Field is 250 people, with standing room along the landscaped brick wall.
To use the space, one must have a valid CMU ID.
You can view space availability by using the recreation policy.
The information about the field can be shared through Facebook, Twitter, Email or Print.

The two reasons for which a student can appeal their grade are (a) an arithmetic error in computing a grade or failure to grade one of the answers on an exam
The faculty or staff member who assigned the grade did so in violation of a University policy.
An arithmetic error in computing a grade refers to any mistake made while calculating or adding up scores, which can lead to incorrect grades being assigned.
Yes, a student can appeal their grade if they believe the faculty or staff member who assigned the grade did so in violation of a University policy.
The purpose of appealing a grade is to correct any errors that may have occurred during grading, such as arithmetic mistakes or violations of University policies.
Yes, a student can appeal their grade if they believe there was an arithmetic error in computing a grade or failure to grade one of the answers on an exam.
A student who wants to appeal their grade should follow the University's appeals process, which includes submitting a written request within 10 days of receiving the grade.
A student has 10 days from when they receive their grade to submit a written appeal.
Yes, a student can appeal their grade if they believe the faculty or staff member who assigned the grade did so in violation of a University policy.
The Technical Opportunities Conference occurs every September.
Curricular Practical Training (CPT) is employment that is an integral part of an established curriculum and is directly related to the student’s major area of study.
All international students are required to apply for CPT.
You can visit the Office of International Education (OIE) link below to learn more about the CPT process: http://www.cmu.edu/oie/forstu/jobs.html
All international students are required to apply for CPT.
The purpose of Technical Opportunities Conference is one of the main recruiting events each year.

Full-time employment refers to working for a company or organization on a permanent basis, typically for 40 hours per week.

Enrollment Services at Carnegie Mellon University provides official letters of enrollment, transcripts and verification.
Students can request an enrollment verification online through The HUB via the link: http://www.cmu.edu/hub/transcripts/verifications/enrollment.html
The university has a detailed policy on grading principles for students taking courses, covering aspects such as assigning and changing grades, grading options, drop/withdrawals and course repeats. It also defines undergraduate and graduate grading standards.
Students can review the university's grading policies here: https://www.cmu.edu/policies/student-and-student-life/grading.html
Carnegie Mellon University records the grades of cross-registration program and its own courses on transcript, but not those from other accredited institutions. However, such courses are recorded without grades.
Students can find the university's policy here: https://www.cmu.edu/policies/student-and-student-life/transfer-credit-evaluation-and-assignment.html
Academic integrity means adhering to proper conduct and avoiding cheating, plagiarism or other forms of dishonesty.
The university expects students to maintain academic integrity by avoiding cheating, plagiarism or other forms of dishonesty.
https://www.cmu.edu/policies/student-and-student-life/transfer-credit-evaluation-and-assignment.html
Academic Integrity
Students are expected to actively reflect on these challenges and if the community supports them.
High standards can provide many opportunities for evolution if students actively reflect on these challenges
3.7.1 Expectations Regarding Proper Conduct
In the midst of self-exploration, the high demands of a challenging academic environment can create situations where some students have difficulty exercising good judgment.

The purpose of reviewing the University’s Academic Disciplinary Actions procedures is to understand the process for investigating, reporting, and adjudicating violations of the University Policy on Academic Integrity.
Carnegie Mellon's Academic Disciplinary Actions Overview for Graduate Students describes procedures and the appeal process for disciplinary actions against graduate students in cases of alleged academic integrity violation.
More information on disciplinary actions can be found at https://www.cmu.edu/student-affairs/theword/acad_standards/creative/disciplinary.html.
The university has a very clear and specific protocol for responding to alleged violations of academic integrity. This protocol outlines the process for investigating, reporting, and adjudicating violations of the University Policy on Academic Integrity.
Carnegie Mellon's Academic Disciplinary Actions Overview is intended for graduate students.
The text suggests that students at Carnegie Mellon University should review the University’s Academic Disciplinary Actions procedures.
The purpose of the appeal process in academic integrity violations is to allow students who believe they have been wrongly accused or penalized for an alleged violation to challenge the decision.
Information on disciplinary actions against graduate students in cases of alleged academic integrity violation can be found at https://www.cmu.edu/student-affairs/theword/acad_standards/creative/disciplinary.html.
The protocol for responding to alleged academic integrity violations is significant because it provides a clear and specific process that must be followed when investigating, reporting, adjudicating, and appealing such violations.
MCDS implements the above policy’s option of 'conven[ing] a disciplinary hearing according to the procedures of the department/program'. They have adopted the following hearing procedure and 'two strikes' rule.
The 'two strikes' rule in MCDS means that if a student has two incidents of academic dishonesty, they will be subject to disciplinary action.
MCDS follows the procedures of the department/program in handling academic integrity violations. They have adopted a hearing procedure and 'two strikes' rule.
The purpose of the 'two strikes' rule in MCDS is to ensure that students who have repeatedly violated academic integrity policies are subject to disciplinary action.
MCDS means that when there is an incident of academic dishonesty, they will follow the specific procedures set forth by the student’s department or program in handling such incidents.
The consequence for a student who violates MCDS's policy on academic integrity can be disciplinary action, including but not limited to being subject to 'two strikes'. The specific consequences depend on the procedures of the department/program.
Departments and programs play a crucial role in handling academic integrity violations at MCDS. They set forth specific procedures for such incidents, which are followed by MCDS.
MCDS handles repeated instances of academic dishonesty through their 'two strikes' rule. If a student has two incidents, they will be subject to disciplinary action.
The policy on academic integrity at MCDS involves convening a disciplinary hearing according to the procedures of the department/program, and implementing a 'two strikes' rule.
The purpose of this policy is to ensure that academic integrity violations are handled fairly and consistently, with each incident being treated seriously.
The MCDS program committee reviews the situation and decides whether it's an infraction. A first offense may lead to dismissal, while a second one always results in dismissal.
The MCDS program reserves the right to withdraw the degree granted even after it has been awarded, upon discovery of the falsification.
Full-time MCDS students are expected to finish in three semesters (16 months), including a summer internship.
No, without prior approval, students cannot use courses taken for another degree to satisfy requirements in the MCDS program.
No, graduate students are not permitted to take pass/fail or audit options for courses that fulfill their degree requirements.
M.S. students cannot use courses taken as part of another degree towards their MCDS program without prior approval.
Full-time MCDS students usually finish in three semesters (16 months), including a summer internship.
A second infraction will always lead to dismissal from the program, with no exceptions.
No, double-dipping is not allowed in the MCDS program unless approved beforehand.
Students must petition for transfer credit by providing the Program Director with the prior course syllabus and other details that may be required by the Director in order to make a decision.
All MS students are required to take a minimum of 96 units of coursework at CMU.
Yes, international students are required to consult with the Office of International Education for eligibility before seeking an internship/co-op or signing an offer contract.
Students should work proactively with prospective employers to arrange interview travel in a way that minimizes the impact on their final semester course work.
Students should review any IP agreements with their academic advisor before signing them.

The Eberly Center for Teaching Excellence & Educational Innovation is located at 13 Eberly Center.
The Eberly Center offers a wide variety of confidential, consultation services and professional development programs to support graduate students as teaching assistants or instructors of record during their time at Carnegie Mellon University and as future faculty members at other institutions.
Eberly’s goal is to disseminate evidence-based teaching strategies in ways that are accessible and applicable across a variety of teaching contexts.
The phrase 'across a variety of teaching contexts' means that Eberly’s goal is to disseminate evidence-based teaching strategies in ways that are applicable and useful for teachers regardless of their specific role or the type of institution they may be working at.
Evidence-based teaching strategies refer to instructional methods and techniques that have been proven effective through research and data, rather than relying solely on intuition or personal experience.
The purpose of professional development programs offered by Eberly is to support graduate students and future faculty members in their teaching roles, providing them with evidence-based strategies that can improve student learning outcomes.
Confidential consultation services refer to one-on-one meetings or discussions between a teacher and an expert in teaching, where the teacher can seek advice on specific issues related to their teaching practice without fear of judgment or negative consequences.
The Eberly Center offers campus-wide Graduate Student Instructor Orientation events and our Future Faculty Program, both of which are designed to help participants be effective and efficient in their teaching roles. The center also assists departments in creating and conducting customized programs to meet the specific needs of their graduate student instructors.
The Graduate Student Assembly represents and advocates for the diverse interests of all graduate students at CMU. It is composed of representatives from different graduate programs and departments who want to improve the graduate student experience at the different levels of the university.
GSA is funded by the Student Activities Fee from all graduate students.
GSA has made a difference and implemented steps to implement the vision laid out by its strategic plan. It offers an expanding suite of social programming on and off-campus to bring graduate students from different departments together and build a sense of community.
GSA advocates for legislative action locally and in Washington D.C. on behalf of graduate student issues and needs.
GSA hosts the Graduate Student Lounge on the 3rd floor of the Cohon University Center.
GSAs maintains a website of graduate student resources on and off-campus.
GSA relies on student feedback to improve the graduate student experience at CMU.

Graham Neubig's research interests include machine translation and natural language processing.
The Language Technologies Institute is located in the Gates & Hillman Centers at Carnegie Mellon University.
Graham Neubig's long-term research goal is to break down barriers in human communication through the development of natural language processing technologies.
Graham Neubig has focused on several aspects of language, including machine translation and natural language understanding.
The overall goal of Graham Neubig's research is to break down barriers in human communication through the development of NLP technologies.
Machine translation helps break down barriers in communication by enabling people who speak different languages to understand each other's messages.
Natural language processing plays a crucial role in human-machine communication, as it enables computers to understand and respond to human language.
Some practical systems that can be constructed using NLP technologies include machine translation software and natural language understanding systems for computers.
Human language complexity poses challenges in developing accurate algorithms or learning techniques, which are essential for constructing practical NLP systems.

Photocopiers and printers are located in GHC 5404 and GHC 6604. The School of Computer Science provides a number of black-and-white and color printers for use by students.
PhD students will be given a CS user ID. A CS user ID is required to use the LTI computer cluster, department printers, and other SCS services.
To complete the PhD in Language and Information Technologies degree, students must pass 96 units of graduate level courses, satisfy proficiencies in Writing, Presentation, Programming, and Teaching, propose, write, and defend a PhD dissertation (thesis), attend the LTI Colloquium each semester, and satisfy the Research Speaking Requirement.
The School of Computer Science has a Help Center located at 4201. They can be contacted at help@cs.cmu.edu, extension 8-4231 from a campus phone, or 412-268-4231 from an outside line.
The LTI’s computer cluster provides storage and computation for projects involving large datasets and/or lengthy computations, which can be used by PhD students for course assignments, directed study projects, and/or capstone projects.
To attain a PhD degree at CMU, students must satisfy standard degree requirements & degree which include passing 96 units of graduate level courses, satisfying proficiencies in Writing, Presentation, Programming, and Teaching, proposing, writing, and defending a PhD dissertation (thesis), attending the LTI Colloquium each semester, and satisfying the Research Speaking Requirement.
The School of Computer Science publishes a list of printers online at https://computing.cs.cmu.edu/desktop/printer-list

The authors of this research article are William A. Wulf and C. G. Bell.
This research was conducted at Carnegie-Mellon University in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania.
The project was initiated in the Summer of 1971 at Carnegie-Mellon University.
C.mmp stands for a multi-mini-processor, which was designed as part of the project to create a multi-processor computer system using minicomputer processors.
AFIPS '72 (Fall, part II) refers to the Proceedings of the December 5-7, 1972 fall joint computer conference, part II.
This research article was published on December 5, 1972.
The 'Cite' button allows users to get citation alerts when a record they have chosen has been cited. It also enables them to save the article, export it as an eReader or PDF, and create a binder.
The main topic of this research paper is the design and status of a hardware/software complex for a multi-processor computer system using minicomputer processors.
The paper briefly describes an overview (only) of the goals, design, and status of this hardware/software complex, and indicates some of the research problems raised and analytic problems solved in the course of its construction.

C.ai is a L* processor for the Department of Computer Science at Carnegie-Mellon University.

Carnegie-Mellon University ARPA Report
Price/performance comparison of C.mmp and the PDP-10
J McCredie
Price/performance comparison of C.mmp and the PDP-10
The main topic of discussion in the text is a comparison between C.mmp and PDP-10, focusing on their cost/performance advantage.
The analysis shows that a multiprocessor system like C.mmp has a cost/performance advantage of three to four times over uniprocessor systems such as the PDP-10 when similar technologies are used.
The authors address this question by discussing their design and performance analysis of partial-multiple-bus interconnection networks. This evolution from multiple-bus structures aims to improve cost-effectiveness.
The text was published in AFIPS '72 (Fall, part II): Proceedings of the December 5-7, 1972, fall joint computer conference, part II. The ISBN is 9781450379137 and the DOI is 10.1145/1480083.
Personal or classroom use of this work is permitted without fee, provided that copies are not made or distributed for profit or commercial advantage and that copies bear this notice and the full citation on the first page.
To do so requires prior specific permission and/or a fee. Request permissions from [email protected]
The sponsors for this publication are Association for Computing Machinery (ACM) and In-Cooperation Publisher.
This article was published on 5 December 1972.
The publication history includes a research-article conference and funding source. The text has not been updated since its initial publication in 1972.

The purpose of iCalendar RSS Feed is to provide a way for users to access and manage their calendar events in a structured format.
You can share an event from the iCalendar RSS Feed by clicking on the 'Share' button and selecting one of the available options: Facebook, Twitter, Email or Print.
When events are marked in bold in the Home section, they indicate that these events are related to home activities and may be of personal interest or importance.
iCalendar refers to a calendar application used for managing appointments, meetings, and events. On the other hand, an RSS Feed (Really Simple Syndication) allows users to access updates from websites in a structured format.
The 'Conference' event listed could be an upcoming conference related to iCalendar or RSS Feed, which may provide users with updates and information about these technologies.
The word 'Home' refers to events that are related to personal or home activities, which may include family gatherings, appointments, or other important dates.
The separate section for Home events allows users to easily identify and manage their personal activities and events, which may be different from work-related or other types of events.
The RSS Feed in iCalendar allows users to access and manage their calendar events in a structured format, which can be easily shared or subscribed by others.
The 'Share' button allows users to share events with others, either through social media platforms like Facebook and Twitter or by emailing it directly.
In 2014, the School of Computer Science celebrated its 25th year as a stand-alone college within Carnegie Mellon University.
Herb Simon (H’90), associate dean of the Graduate School of Industrial Administration—now known as CMU’s Tepper School of Business—established Carnegie Tech’s first Computation Center with the help of its first director, Alan Perlis (S’42).
In 1956 and 1957, Simon, Allen Newell (IA’57) and Cliff Shaw of RAND designed the Logic Theorist, a computer program that could develop proofs for theorems in much the same way a human would work.
Perlis, Simon and Newell are credited with defining the term “computer science” as “the theory and design of computers,” as well as (in Newell’s words) “the study of the phenomena arising from them.”
In 1958, Perlis began teaching the first freshman-level computer programming course in the United States at Carnegie Tech.
The IBM 650 had magnetic-drum memory and a processing speed of approximately 60 instructions per second.
In 2014, the School of Computer Science celebrated its 25th year as a stand-alone college within Carnegie Mellon University.
In 1956 and 1957, Simon, Allen Newell (IA’57) and Cliff Shaw of RAND designed the Logic Theorist, a computer program that could develop proofs for theorems in much the same way a human would work.
Carnegie Tech
In 1965
Systems and Communications Sciences
Perlis
Half of its tenured faculty members, including department head Perlis, left for other universities
Joe Traub
$5 million grant from the R.K. Mellon Foundation
1967
Mellon Institute of Science, later renamed Mellon College of Science (MCS)
Raj Reddy
Some of the large projects that emerged in the Computer Science Department at CMU included C.mmp, a shared-memory multiprocessor computer with 16 processing units, and Cm*, a 50-processor computer.
The Xerox Alto was considered a forerunner to many computing environments that followed. It featured a graphical user interface and was among the first commercially available workstations controlled with a mouse.
Reddy launched a drive for development of CMU’s own 'three-M' machine—a personal workstation with a megabyte of memory, a megapixel display and at least one million instructions per second of processing power.
An executive at Pittsburgh’s Westinghouse Electric Corp., Tom Murrin, collaborated with Jordan and Reddy to create the Robotics Institute.
The A.M. Turing Award is considered the Nobel Prize of computing. As of 2014, 12 CMU alumni or faculty have been awarded Turings.
Reddy served as the first director of the Robotics Institute, which was established in 1979.
By 1982, the Computer Science Department included more than 30 faculty members and 100 graduate students.
CSD emerged as a highly agile, interdisciplinary entity with many new faculty members taking joint appointments with other CMU departments.
Simon received the Nobel Prize in Economics for his work on decision-making theory. As the 1970s progressed, Newell became interested in human-computer interaction and began a long relationship with Xerox’s Palo Alto Research Center.
CSD emerged as a highly agile, interdisciplinary entity with many new faculty members taking joint appointments with other CMU departments.
Tom Murrin collaborated with Jordan and Reddy to create the Robotics Institute, with Reddy as its first director.
By 1982, the Computer Science Department included more than 30 faculty members and 100 graduate students.

a free-floating Department of Computer Science.
Pittsburgh Supercomputing Center was created as a joint effort between CMU, the University of Pittsburgh and Westinghouse Electric Corp. in 1986.
The School of Computer Science (SCS) was formally established on December 22, 1988.
Habermann was appointed as the first Dean of Computer Science at CMU in December 1, 1988.
Undergraduate degrees began to be offered solely in computer science during the 1989-90 academic year.
CSD professor Mary Shaw (CS’72) led the first effort to create a computer science undergraduate program.
Seven CS majors were admitted as sophomores in the 1989-90 academic year.
By 1995, there were 401 undergraduate students in the School of Computer Science.
In fall 2013, more than 600 undergraduate students made up about 37 percent of the total student enrollment at SCS.
By fall 2013, there were more than 600 master’s degree students enrolled at the School of Computer Science.
Human-Computer Interaction Institute (1993), Institute for Software Research (1999), Machine Learning Department (2006) and the Ray and Stephanie Lane Center for Computational Biology (2009)

Its graduate programs are ranked with the best in the world by a leading U.S. magazine.

RSS stands for Really Simple Syndication. In this context, it refers to a type of web feed that allows users to access updates from multiple websites in one place.

The Master of Computational Data Science (MCDS) degree
Brianna Eriksen
144 units
The MCDS program offers three majors: Systems, Analytics, and Human-Centered Data Science.
Regardless of the timing option, all MCDS students must complete a minimum of 144 units to graduate. The options include Standard Timing — a 16-month degree consisting of study for fall and spring semesters, a summer internship, and fall semester of study.
The standard timing option consists of study for fall and spring semesters, a summer internship, and fall semester of study. Each semester comprises a minimum of 48 units.
Students graduate in December.
The comprehensive curriculum equips you with the skills and knowledge to develop the layers of technology involved in the next generation of massive information system deployments and analyze the data these systems generate.
The semester-long, group-oriented capstone project provides students with hands-on experience and helps them understand how to deploy large-scale information systems.
The typical duration for an MCDS degree is 16 months.
Each semester comprises a minimum of 48 units.
Students graduate in December under Standard Timing.
The duration for an MCDS degree under Extended Timing is 20 months.
Students graduate in May under Extended Timing.
To earn an MCDS degree, students must pass courses in the core curriculum, the MCDS seminar, a concentration area and electives. They also need to complete a capstone project.
Students must complete 144 eligible units of study, including eight 12-unit courses, two 12-unit seminar courses and one 24-unit capstone course.
Students must choose at least five core courses.
Yes, any additional non-prerequisite units taken beyond the 144 units are considered electives.
The two main categories of courses included in the MCDS Course Map are Analytics and Systems.
From the Analytics category, the course name is Machine Learning. From the Systems category, the course name is Cloud Computing.
The two main categories of courses included in the MCDS Course Map are Analytics and Systems.
From the Analytics category, the course name is Computational Data Science. From the Systems category, the course name is Operating Systems or Web Applications.
The two main categories of courses included in the MCDS Course Map are Analytics and Systems.
From the Analytics category, the course name is Empirical Analysis of Interactive Systems. From the Systems category, the course name is Distributed Systems.
The application period for Fall 2024 will open on September 6, 2023.
The final application deadline for Fall 2024 is December 13, 2023 at 3:00 p.m. EST.
$100 per program, or $80 if applications are submitted before November 29, 2023 at 3:00 p.m. EST (early deadline).
Yes, fee waivers may be available in cases of financial hardship or for participants in select 'pipeline' programs. More information can be found on the School of Computer Science Fee Waiver page.
The School of Computer Science requires GRE scores that must be less than five years old, and while not required, a GRE Subject Test is recommended. The Institution Code is 2074; Department Code is 0402.
No, mailed hard versions of transcripts or test scores are not required at the time of application. If you are accepted into a program, instructions will be given on how and when to submit these materials.
$80 per program (early application deadline).
Applicants can find more information on the School of Computer Science Fee Waiver page.
Students must demonstrate English proficiency via one of the standardized tests: TOEFL, IELTS, or Duolingo.
Speaking is not scored in this test.
No, they do not issue waivers for non-native speakers of English.
No, no amount of educational experience in English will result in a test waiver.
The minimum TOEFL score is 100 (Reading, Listening, Speaking, Writing scores all 25 or above).
The minimum IELTS score is 7.5 (Reading 7 or above, Listening 7 or above, Speaking 7.5 or above, Writing 6.5 or above).
The minimum DuoLingo score is 120 (Literacy 115 or above, Comprehension 125 or above, Production 100 or above, Conversation 105 or above).
Their scores will not be accepted regardless of whether they have previously studied in the U.S.
Applicants are required to submit scores from an English proficiency exam taken within the last two years.
The requirements include official transcripts from each university you have attended, a short video about yourself and your interest in the MCDS program, a current resume, a statement of purpose, three letters of recommendation, an official award letter if receiving outside funding, and no incomplete applications.
The MSAII program combines a rigorous AI and machine learning curriculum with real-world team experience to identify an AI market niche, develop a responsive product, focus on both intrapreneurship and entrepreneurship, equipping graduates to either begin a startup or develop a new organization within an existing company.
For specific application/admissions questions, please contact Jennifer Lucas or Caitlin Korpus.
You can view the MCDS Handbook for a complete breakdown of the MCDS program and its policies, including information about internships.
The core program lasts four semesters and leads to a capstone project, focusing on both intrapreneurship and entrepreneurship.
Students will gain critical practical skills such as making persuasive technical presentations, assembling development teams, and evaluating the potential of new market ideas.
The Master of Science in Artificial Intelligence and Innovation (MSAII) program is a successor to the M.S. in Biotechnology, Innovation and Computing (MSBIC).
For more on the MSAII program, contact Jennifer Lucas or Caitlin Korpus.
Any outside funding you are receiving must be accompanied by an official award letter.
To earn an MSAII degree, you must pass courses in the Core Curriculum, Knowledge Requirements and Electives. You also need to complete a capstone project as part of the Core Curriculum.
You must complete 192 eligible units of study, including 84 units of Core Curriculum (including the 36-unit Capstone), 72 units of Knowledge Requirements and at least 36 units of approved Electives.
The MSAII degree generally takes four semesters. Here's a breakdown: Semester One - Artificial Intelligence and Future Markets, Law of Computer Technology; Semester Two - Coding Bootcamp, Machine Learning AI Engineering; Semester Three - Machine Learning with Large Datasets, Cloud Computing*; Semester Four - Software Engineering for Startups*, AI Innovation, Natural Language Processing, Applied Machine Learning, Web Application Development*, Deep Learning.
For more information on the MSAII program curriculum and requirements, see the program website .
Carnegie Mellon's School of Computer Science has a centralized online application process. Applications and all supporting documentation for fall admission to any of the LTI's graduate programs must be received by the application deadline.
The final application deadline for Fall 2024 is December 13, 2023 at 3:00 p.m. EST.
$100 for one program, $80 if application is submitted before November 29, 2023 at 3PM EST (early deadline).
Yes, fee waivers are available.
The final application deadline for the School of Computer Science is December 13, 2023 at 3:00 p.m. EST.
$100
Yes, there is an early deadline. If you submit your application before November 29, 2023 at 3PM EST, the cost to apply will be $80.
Fee waivers may be available in cases of financial hardship, or for participants in select 'pipeline' programs. For more information, please refer to the School of Computer Science Fee Waiver page.
The School of Computer Science requires a GPA of 3.0 or higher, GRE scores, English Language Proficiency (if studying on an F-1 or J-1 visa), unofficial transcripts from each university attended, current resume, Statement of Purpose, and three letters of recommendation.
A GPA of 3.0 or higher
Yes, English language proficiency is required for all students studying on an F-1 or J-1 visa. This is because the primary language of instruction at the School of Computer Science is English.
Students should report raw university GPA scores and NOT converted scores. Please DO NOT convert your international score to a US GPA or weighted GPA or other system.
Applicants should contact Amber Vivis for any specific application/admissions questions.
