The LT Concentration is an overview of requirements, curriculum, admission and additional information about Human language technologies.
Students must complete Principles of Imperative Computation (15-122) and Principles of Functional Programming (15-150) with an average grade of B (3.0) or better before applying to the program.
Differential and Integral Calculus (21-120), Integration and Approximation (21-122), Matrices and Linear Transformations (21-241) or Matrix Theory (21-242), Probability and Computing (15-259), Probability (21-325), Probability Theory for Computer Scientists (36-218), Introduction to Probability Theory (36-225)
The LTI prepares students for a world where human language technologies are increasingly central components of computer science.
Through directed projects
The three core courses required to complete the Language Technologies Concentration are Principles of Imperative Computation, Principles of Functional Programming, and Differential and Integral Calculus.
Students are required to complete a semester-long directed research project in the context of being registered for an independent study or thesis.
The purpose of the elective courses in the Language Technologies Concentration is to provide students with a choice of three stand-alone courses of at least 9 units each.
Some examples of elective courses that can be chosen for the Language Technologies Concentration include Human Language for Artificial Intelligence, Natural Language Processing, Machine Learning for Text and Graph-based Mining, Search Engines, Speech Processing, Machine Learning in Practice, Advanced Natural Language Processing, Machine Translation and Sequence-to-Sequence Models, Multilingual Natural Language Processing, Neural Networks for NLP, Speech Recognition and Understanding, Language and Statistics, and Multimodal Affective Computing.
The core course requirement for an undergraduate minor is Principles of Imperative Computation, and students must choose three electives from a specific set of stand-alone courses. They also need to complete a semester-long directed research project.
The four recommended courses that candidates for SCS should take are Differential and Integral Calculus, Integration and Approximation, Matrices and Linear Transformations or Matrix Theory, Probability and Computing or Probability (21-325) or Probability Theory for Computer Scientists or Introduction to Probability Theory.
The purpose of the Language Technologies Concentration in SCS is to provide students with a deep understanding and practical experience in language technologies, including human language for artificial intelligence, natural language processing, machine learning for text and graph-based mining, search engines, speech processing, machine learning in practice, advanced natural language processing, machine translation and sequence-to-sequence models, multilingual natural language processing, neural networks for NLP, speech recognition and understanding, language and statistics, and multimodal affective computing.
To complete an undergraduate minor in Language Technologies, students must take a core course and choose three electives from a specific set of stand-alone courses. They also need to do a semester-long directed research project.
The recommended courses for SCS candidates who want to complete an undergradate minor in Language Technologies include Principles of Imperative Computation, Differential and Integral Calculus or Probability and Computing or Probability (21-325) or Probability Theory for Computer Scientists or Introduction to Probability Theory.
Completing an undergraduate minor in Language Technologies provides students with a deep understanding and practical experience in language technologies, including human language for artificial intelligence, natural language processing, machine learning for text and graph-based mining, search engines, speech processing, machine learning in practice, advanced natural language processing, machine translation and sequence-to-sequence models, multilingual natural language processing, neural networks for NLP, speech recognition and understanding, language and statistics, and multimodal affective computing. This can be beneficial for students who want to pursue a career in fields related to artificial intelligence or computer science.
Students interested in earning a minor in language technologies must apply no later than September 30 of their senior year.
An admission decision will usually be made within one month after the application is submitted.
Yes, students may petition the LTI undergraduate program director to be admitted to the minor either earlier or later in their undergraduate careers.
For more information on the undergraduate minor, students should contact Carolyn Rosé .
The Language Technologies Institute is located at 5000 Forbes Avenue in Pittsburgh, PA.
The phone number to contact the Language Technologies Institute is 412-268-6591.

The purpose of the Office of Disability Resources is to encourage students to self-identify and request accommodations for their disabilities.
Students with questions about the process of requesting accommodations from the Office of Disability Resources can direct their inquiries to access@andrew.cmu.edu or call (412) 268-6121.
The Eberly Center for Teaching Excellence & Educational Innovation is located at 13 Eberly Center.
The Eberly Center offers a wide variety of confidential, consultation services and professional development programs to support graduate students as teaching assistants or instructors of record during their time at Carnegie Mellon University and as future faculty members at other institutions.
Eberly’s goal is to disseminate evidence-based teaching strategies in ways that are accessible and applicable across a variety of teaching contexts.
The phrase 'across a variety of teaching contexts' means that Eberly’s goal is to disseminate evidence-based teaching strategies in ways that are applicable and useful for teachers regardless of their specific role or the type of institution they may be working at.
Evidence-based teaching strategies refer to instructional methods and techniques that have been proven effective through research and data, rather than relying solely on intuition or personal experience.
The purpose of professional development programs offered by Eberly is to support graduate students and future faculty members in their teaching roles, providing them with evidence-based strategies that can improve student learning outcomes.
Confidential consultation services refer to one-on-one meetings or discussions between a teacher and an expert in teaching, where the teacher can seek advice on specific issues related to their teaching practice without fear of judgment or negative consequences.
The Eberly Center offers campus-wide Graduate Student Instructor Orientation events and our Future Faculty Program, both of which are designed to help participants be effective and efficient in their teaching roles. The center also assists departments in creating and conducting customized programs to meet the specific needs of their graduate student instructors.
The Graduate Student Assembly represents and advocates for the diverse interests of all graduate students at CMU. It is composed of representatives from different graduate programs and departments who want to improve the graduate student experience at the different levels of the university.
GSA is funded by the Student Activities Fee from all graduate students.
GSA has made a difference and implemented steps to implement the vision laid out by its strategic plan. It offers an expanding suite of social programming on and off-campus to bring graduate students from different departments together and build a sense of community.
GSA advocates for legislative action locally and in Washington D.C. on behalf of graduate student issues and needs.
GSA hosts the Graduate Student Lounge on the 3rd floor of the Cohon University Center.
GSAs maintains a website of graduate student resources on and off-campus.
GSA relies on student feedback to improve the graduate student experience at CMU.

The purpose of the Carnegie Mellon University Athletics Hall of Fame is to recognize, celebrate and memorialize the contributions of student-athletes, administrators, coaches and supporters, and preserve the history of the intercollegiate athletics program.
The Carnegie Mellon University Athletics Hall of Fame was established in November 2018.
Inductees will be selected by a committee comprised of Carnegie Mellon University staff, faculty, a board of trustee member, coaches and a student representative.
The committee will endeavor to induct not less than 15 individuals for induction in its first year.
Not less than 6 individuals are to be inducted in any year thereafter, subject to the discretion of the Nominating Committee.
The below will set forth the criteria for selection to the Athletics Hall of Fame.
Nominations can be made by filling out a form on the official website or through other means as determined by the Nominating Committee.
The announcements were made on October 31st, 2018 (for the 2019 class), November 4th, 2020 (for the 2021 class) and November 5th, 2021 (for the 2022 class).
People can share the announcement through Facebook, Twitter or email.
The main goal of the Doctoral Program in Information Science and Technology is to provide students with advanced scientific training in the field of Information Science and Technology, as well as research methods, so they can conduct high-quality autonomous research in various contexts.
Admission is open to Portuguese bachelor graduates with a final grade of at least 16 (out of 20) whose degree was obtained in the scope of the legislation previous to Law 49/2005 of 30 August, as well foreign applicants with equivalent qualifications. Additionally, holders of a Master's degree or equivalent qualification that demonstrably possess an Information Science and Technology academic background can apply.
The adequacy of the academic background of applicants with a Master's degree or equivalent qualification that demonstrably possess an Information Science and Technology academic background will be assessed by the scientific commission of Informatics Engineering.
Exceptionally, the Scientific Council of FCTUC may, upon proposal of the scientific commission of Informatics Engineering, accept the application of candidates holding a scientific, academic or professional curriculum that attests their ability to complete this cycle of studies.
Candidates should check the admission requirements available on this site, in addition to the information provided here.
The legislation previous to Law 49/2005 of 30 August refers to the legislation that was in effect before this law came into force.
The purpose of exploring interdisciplinary spaces in Information Science and Technology is to identify opportunities for conducting research projects with high scientific potential and impact.
The program aims to help students enter international research networks.
The Scientific Council of FCTUC may accept applications from candidates with a scientific, academic or professional curriculum that demonstrates their ability to complete this cycle of studies.
The goals include research, technological development and innovation in institutions of higher education (academic staff at universities and polytechnic institutes), State Laboratories and Associated Laboratories.
The mode of study for this program is face-to-face.
Teaching and evaluation are conducted in both English and Portuguese.
Assessment is an integral part of teaching to evaluate students' competencies, critical thinking skills, problem-solving abilities, written and oral presentation skills. Grading is based on a scale from 0 to 20 with a passing grade of 10.
Students can only register for exams they are currently enrolled in, as per article 4 of the University of Coimbra Pedagogical Policy.
Assessment items may include oral and written exams, practical work, individual and group projects that require an oral defense, as well as class participation.
The final grade is determined by considering the relative weight of each assessment item according to a formula published in the course outline, under article 7 of the UC Pedagogical Policy.
Students who do not achieve a passing grade will have to retake the exam or repeat the course, as per article 7 of the UC Pedagogical Policy.
The main objective is for students to acquire in-depth knowledge in Information Science and Technology, develop abilities that enable them to conduct scientific research autonomously, become acquainted with the scientific literature, contribute to advancing the state of the art in their specific domain, possess advanced knowledge in other Information Science and Technology domains, particularly Informatics (the main scientific area), and be able to formulate relevant research questions, identify or develop appropriate abstractions and methodologies for solving problems, judge the merits and shortcomings of solutions found, and communicate results effectively.
A successful student should possess advanced knowledge in Informatics (the main scientific area), be able to formulate relevant research questions, identify or develop appropriate abstractions and methodologies for solving problems, judge the merits and shortcomings of solutions found, and communicate results effectively.
After completing their thesis, students should be able to formulate relevant research questions, identify or develop appropriate abstractions and methodologies for solving problems, judge the merits and shortcomings of solutions found, and communicate results effectively.
Students should become acquainted with the scientific literature and contribute to advancing the state of the art in their specific domain, particularly Informatics (the main scientific area).
Students need advanced knowledge in other Information Science and Technology domains, particularly Informatics (the main scientific area), to be able to formulate relevant research questions, identify or develop appropriate abstractions and methodologies for solving problems, judge the merits and shortcomings of solutions found, and communicate results effectively.
Students need to be able to formulate relevant research questions, identify or develop appropriate abstractions and methodologies for solving problems, judge the merits and shortcomings of solutions found, and communicate results effectively.
Students need to be able to convey and discuss their research results orally and in writing to both peers and non-experts.
Students need to be able to judge the merits and shortcomings of the solutions found, both in absolute terms and in comparison with alternative solutions.
Students need to be able to identify, make use of, and/or develop appropriate theoretical and experimental abstractions and methodologies.
The three levels of skills that students must develop according to the text are instrumental, personal and systemic.
The main objectives of the program in two phases are to acquire knowledge and develop instrumental and personal skills during the Doctoral Course, while also developing systemic skills through the preparation of the Thesis.
The course coordinator for this program is Henrique Santos do Carmo Madeira.
According to the text, the shortcomings of the solutions found can be judged in absolute terms and in comparison with alternative solutions.
Students convey and discuss their research results orally and in writing, both within a peer group and to non-experts in an international context.
The systemic skills that students must develop according to the text include autonomy in learning, creativity, a concern with quality, self-criticism and self-evaluation abilities.
The ECTS Departmental Coordinator for this program is Paula Alexandra Gomes da Silva.
The objectives of the Doctoral Course include acquiring knowledge in a specific domain, developing analysis and synthesis skills, written and oral communication skills, organizing, planning and making decisions.
The degree of fulfilment of these objectives is measured through monitoring the results of their work including success in the Doctoral Course and scientific articles published throughout the Thesis, as well as student surveys.
Henrique Santos do Carmo Madeira

Dr. Clarke is a co-founder of the conference on Computer Aided Verification (CAV) and served on its steering committee for many years.
Dr. Clarke is the former editor-in-chief of Formal Methods in Systems Design.
He served on the editorial boards of Distributed Computing, Logic and Computation, and IEEE Transactions in Software Engineering.
He received a Technical Excellence Award from the Semiconductor Research Corporation in 1995.
He was a co-recipient of the ACM Kanellakis Award for the invention of symbolic model checking.
He received an Allen Newell Award for Excellence in Research from the Carnegie Mellon Computer Science Department.
Dr. Clarke served on its steering committee for many years, but it doesn't specify his current role or if he still serves there.
The Semiconductor Research Corporation recognized Dr. Clarke's work by awarding him a Technical Excellence Award in 1995.
The ACM Kanellakis Award recognizes significant contributions to computer science, and Dr. Clarke received it for his invention of symbolic model checking.
Edmund M. Clarke is a Professor Emeritus in the Computer Science Department at Carnegie Mellon University.
He received his Ph.D. from Cornell University.
The conference he co-founded is called Computer Aided Verification (CAV).
He received the Franklin Institute Bower Award and Prize for Achievement in Science.
His research interests include hardware and software verification and automatic theorem proving.
He taught at Duke University and Harvard Universities before joining CMU in 1982.

He became a University Professor at Carnegie Mellon University in 2008.

Edmund Melson Clarke was born on July 27, 1945.
He received a BA from the University of Virginia in 1967.
Edmund Melson Clarke studied under Robert Constable at Cornell University.
Clarke currently works at Carnegie Mellon University, where he is the FORE Systems University Professor of Computer Science and Professor of Electrical and Computer Engineering.
Clarke’s career has focused on mathematical reasoning about computer systems, with an emphasis on reasoning about the reliability of those systems.
It is necessary but very hard because a computer system executes simple operations that can occur in a staggering number of different orders. This makes it impossible for the designer to envision every possible sequence and predict its consequences.
The worst consequence if a program executes an incorrect sequence is that it could cause injury or loss of life.
Every one of those sequences, no matter how infrequently executed, must be correct because if a program executes an incorrect sequence at the very least it will waste a user’s time.
He received an MA from Duke University in 1968.
Describing sequences of operations in computer systems can be difficult due to multiple programs running simultaneously and the many possible execution orderings.
Tony Hoare was one of the first researchers who developed logical forms better-suited to describing computer systems, including Hoare’s logic that could prove every possible execution would only execute an acceptable sequence of operations.
Clarke's early research strengthened the foundations of Hoare’s logic and extended his method, making it applicable to smaller systems.
Hoare's method for verifying system performance worked well for smaller systems but became close to impossible to apply to larger, more complex ones due to the sheer number of possible execution orderings.
In 1977, Amir Pnueli introduced temporal logic, an alternative logic for verifying computer systems that allows explicit reasoning about time.
Temporal logic allowed researchers to express statements such as 'This condition will remain true until a second condition becomes true', making it possible to verify that systems perform according to specification every time, no matter the circumstances.
The dream of early researchers was to develop powerful and effective methods for reasoning about all possible orderings of a system, which remained unfulfilled despite advancements like Hoare's logic and temporal logic.
The term 'multiple programs running simultaneously' refers to a feature of modern computer hardware where multiple software applications or processes can run at the same time, which presents challenges for system verification.
Formal logic is a branch of mathematics that studies logical reasoning and its expression in systems. It was initially thought to be sufficient to describe every possible sequence and ensure correctness, even for simultaneously-running programs.
Amir Pnueli
Temporal logic can be directly checked by machine, whereas Hoare’s logic requires the designer to consider every detail of both the system and the argument about the system’s correctness.
They realized that a program could exhaustively construct every possible sequence of actions a system might perform, and for every action it could evaluate a property expressed in temporal logic. If the program found the property to be true for every possible action in every possible sequence, this proved the property for the system.
Jean-Pierre Queille and Joseph Sifakis
When it detects a problem in a system design, the checker prints out an example sequence of actions that gives rise to the problem. Initial designs always get some details wrong.
The error traces provided by model checking are invaluable for designers, because they precisely locate the source of the problems.
Pnueli’s logic could be implemented in a computer program. The responsibilities could be divided: the designer focused on specifying the system, while the software ensured that the proposed system would always perform correctly.
Temporal logic allows explicit reasoning about time. It is possible to express statements such as, 'This condition will remain true until a second condition becomes true' in it.
One of the great strengths of the model checking approach is that when it detects a problem in a system design, the checker prints out an example sequence of actions that gives rise to the problem.
Early model checkers required explicitly computing every possible configuration of values a program might assume, which led to an explosive growth in the number of states. This rapid growth is called the state space explosion.
The 1981 paper [2] demonstrated that model checking was possible in principle, but its application to practical systems was severely limited due to the number of states to search.
One limitation of early model checkers was their ability to handle large amounts of data. The number of possible states grows at an explosive speed, which made it difficult for them to verify that a required property was true for every state.
The state space explosion refers to the rapid growth in the number of possible states as more data is manipulated. This makes it difficult for model checkers to verify that a required property is true for every state.
The error traces provided by model checking are invaluable for designers because they precisely locate the source of problems. This helps them understand where their designs went wrong and how to fix these issues.
One example given in the text that requires 7 storage locations is a program that counts the millimeters of rain at a weather station each day of the week. Each location needs to be big enough to hold the largest rain level expected in a single day.
This simple program has 10^21 possible states, which is slightly less than the number of stars in the observable universe. This is due to the fact that it needs to store each day's rain level for every day of the week.
In this context, 'practical systems' refers to computer programs or designs that are large enough to handle significant amounts of data and complex operations. These systems require more advanced model checking techniques than those used for small systems.
The rapid growth in the number of possible states as systems become more complex.
Because it could only handle small systems due to the state space explosion.
They observed that a single memory location can represent many potential states, but only one at a time.
It dramatically reduced storage required to represent state spaces by tersely encoding multiple states while permitting efficient computation of formulas in temporal logic.
They demonstrated flaws in the design of an IEEE standard for interconnecting computer components by exhaustively checking every possible case.
It allowed for the discovery and consideration of potential errors in rare cases that had been previously overlooked.
A type of system that uses an encoding to represent many potential states with a single value, allowing for efficient computation and reduced storage requirements.
It allowed for the representation of much larger systems without an exponential increase in memory usage or computational time, making it feasible for practical-sized systems.
State space explosion refers to the rapid growth of possible states as a system becomes more complex. This makes it difficult for early model checkers, which were designed for small systems, to handle larger ones efficiently.
Model checking is used to verify designs for integrated circuits, computer networks, and software.
The use of model checkers has substantially improved the reliability and safety of the systems upon which modern life depends.
Model checkers have been used to analyze systems whose state space (10 120) is substantially larger than the number of atoms in the observable universe.
It is becoming particularly important in the verification of software designed for recent generations of integrated circuits, which feature multiple processors running simultaneously.
The author of this text is Ted Kirkpatrick

To apply for something related to the Language Technologies Institute
The primary areas of language technologies investigated at the Language Technologies Institute include Natural Language Processing and Computational Linguistics, Information Retrieval, Text Mining and Analytics, Information Extraction, Summarization and Question Answering, Speech Processing, Spoken Interfaces and Dialogue Processing, Multimodal Computing and Interaction, Language Technologies for Education, Machine Translation, Machine Learning, Computational Biology, Knowledge Representation, Reasoning and Acquisition, Knowledge Representation and Reasoning.
Some research projects conducted at the Language Technologies Institute include AIDA/OPERA: Hypothesis-Based Reasoning Based on Integrated Cross-Media Data, Unsupervised Transcription of Early Modern Documents, ARIEL: Analysis of Rare Incident-Event Languages Modeling Lexical Borrowing to Bridge the 'Linguistic Divide' in Natural Language Processing, DialPort: Enabling Spoken Dialog Research with Real Data BIGDATA: Large-Scale Transductive Learning from Heterogeneous Data Sources, Monitoring Parking Space Availability, Effective Exploitation of Related Domain Knowledge for Large-Scale Sensor Data.
The Language Technologies Institute is located at 5000 Forbes Avenue, Pittsburgh, PA 15213-3891. Their phone number is 412-268-6591 and their email address is ltiwebmaster@cs.cmu.edu.
The contact details of the Language Technologies Institute include a phone number (412-268-6591) and an email address (ltiwebmaster@cs.cmu.edu).
Some research projects conducted at the Language Technologies Institute related to Natural Language Processing include AIDA/OPERA: Hypothesis-Based Reasoning Based on Integrated Cross-Media Data, Modeling Lexical Borrowing to Bridge the 'Linguistic Divide' in Natural Language Processing.
Some research projects conducted at the Language Technologies Institute related to Machine Learning include AIDA/OPERA: Hypothesis-Based Reasoning Based on Integrated Cross-Media Data, BIGDATA: Large-Scale Transductive Learning from Heterogeneous Data Sources.
Some research projects conducted at the Language Technologies Institute related to Computational Biology include BIGDATA: Large-Scale Transductive Learning from Heterogeneous Data Sources.
Some research projects conducted at the Language Technologies Institute related to Knowledge Representation and Reasoning include AIDA/OPERA: Hypothesis-Based Reasoning Based on Integrated Cross-Media Data, Modeling Lexical Borrowing to Bridge the 'Linguistic Divide' in Natural Language Processing.
Some research projects conducted at the Language Technologies Institute related to Spoken Interfaces and Dialogue Processing include DialPort: Enabling Spoken Dialog Research with Real Data.
Some research projects conducted at the Language Technologies Institute related to Multimodal Computing and Interaction include DialPort: Enabling Spoken Dialog Research with Real Data.
Graham Neubig's long-term research goal is to break down barriers in human-human or human-machine communication through the development of natural language processing (NLP) technologies.
Graham Neubig's research interests include Machine Translation, Natural Language Processing, and Spoken Language Processing.
Graham Neubig's office is located in the Gates & Hillman Centers at Office: 5409.
Graham Neubig belongs to the Language Technologies Institute.
One can contact Graham Neubig through email at gneubig@cs.cmu.edu.
Graham Neubig has focused on several aspects of language that both make it interesting as a scientific subject, and hold potential for the construction of practical systems.
Graham Neubig is an Associate Professor at Carnegie Mellon University.
Advances in core NLP technology can help improve the accuracy with which we can analyze, translate, generate, or reply to textual inputs.
The overall goal of Graham Neubig's research is to break down barriers in human-human or human-machine communication through the development of natural language processing (NLP) technologies.
The researcher's main focus is on advances in core NLP technology, models of language associated with other modalities, and learning from naturally occurring data.
The researcher has worked extensively with speech and is interested in associations between natural language and other types of information such as source code.
The researcher holds a Master of Science in Intelligent Information Systems.

Students have the right to review and request amendment of their education record if they believe it is inaccurate or misleading. They can also request a hearing if their request for an amendment is not resolved to their satisfaction.
Students have the right to consent to disclosure of personally identifiable information from their education records, except for cases where FERPA authorizes disclosure without consent.
Students can file a complaint with the U.S. Department of Education Family Policy Compliance Office.

The CPDC is a centralized career center staffed by seasoned professionals who provide career exploration, experiential learning, and networking opportunities for students and alumni.
The CPDC is located on the Lower Level of the University Center.
CMU's career and professional development model is grounded in discipline-specific career development, experiential learning, and employer relations shaped by strong connections with the university's seven academic colleges.
The CPDC's success is founded upon a solid understanding of career and professional development theory, integration of technology, and an unwavering commitment to providing personalized attention towards meeting the unique individual needs of students, alumni, and employers.

A full schedule of programs can be found at http://www.cmu.edu/graduate/.

The Division of Student Affairs includes Athletics, Physical Education and Recreation, Career and Professional Development Center (CPDC), Center for Student Diversity and Inclusion, Cohon University Center, Counseling & Psychological Services (CaPS), Dining Services, Office of Community Standards and Integrity (OCSI), Office of Student Leadership, Involvement, and Civic Engagement (SLICE), and University Health Services (UHS).

The Center supports and connects historically underrepresented students, including those who are first in their family to attend college. The mission of The Office of Disability Resources at Carnegie Mellon University is to provide physical, digital, and programmatic access to ensure that students with disabilities have equal access to their educational experience. They work to ensure that qualified individuals receive reasonable accommodations as guaranteed by the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973.
Students who would like to receive accommodations can begin the process through Disability Resources' secure online portal or email access@andrew.cmu.edu to begin the interactive accommodation process.
The Office of Disability Resources supports students with physical, sensory, cognitive, or emotional disabilities.
Students can get more information about the accommodation process by emailing access@andrew.cmu.edu or calling (412) 268-6121.

The Graduate Student Assembly (GSA) represents and advocates for the diverse interests of all graduate students at CMU. It is composed of representatives from different graduate programs and departments who work to improve the graduate student experience at various levels of the university. GSA passes legislation, allocates student activities funding, advocates for legislative action locally and in Washington D.C., and acts on behalf of all graduate student interests.
The Graduate Student Assembly (GSA) is funded by the Student Activities Fee from all graduate students at Carnegie Mellon University.
The Graduate Student Assembly has made a difference in implementing its strategic plan, advocating for graduate student issues and needs at various levels of the university.

The purpose of the Carnegie Mellon Ethics Hotline is to confidentially report suspected unethical activity, violations of university policy, or violations of law. Topic areas for reporting may include academic and student life, bias reporting, discriminatory harassment/sexual misconduct/Title IX, employee misconduct, employment related issues, environmental health and safety/pandemic safety, financial matters, health and wellness, information systems and data privacy, public safety & criminal activity, research & intellectual property.

LTI faculty and students investigate more than 20 areas of language and information technologies, including Natural Language Processing, Computational Linguistics, Information Extraction, Summarization & Question Answering, Information Retrieval, Text Mining & Analytics, Knowledge Representation, Reasoning & Acquisition, Language Technologies for Education, Machine Learning, Machine Translation, Multimodal Computing and Interaction, Speech Processing, and Spoken Interfaces & Dialogue Processing
LTI's unique programs prepare students for a wide range of careers while staying true to the rigorous curriculum that defines computer science at CMU

The Language Technologies Institute at Carnegie Mellon educates leaders of tomorrow and performs groundbreaking research in areas such as Natural Language Processing, Computational Linguistics, Information Extraction, Summarization & Question Answering, Information Retrieval, Text Mining & Analytics, Knowledge Representation, Reasoning & Acquisition, Language Technologies for Education, Machine Learning, Machine Translation, Multimodal Computing and Interaction, Speech Processing, and Spoken Interfaces & Dialogue Processing
The 2023 Okawa Research Grant was awarded to Daniel Fried
The main areas of research that LTI faculty and students investigate include language and information technologies, which routinely produce breakthroughs impacting education to healthcare.
The LTI offers five graduate degrees in computer science: Ph.D. in Language and Information Technology, research-based Master of Language Technologies, and three professional master's programs – Master of Science in Intelligent Information Systems, Master of Science in Biotechnology Innovation and Computation, and Master of Computational Data Science.
The purpose of collaborating with LTI is to change the world through strong partnerships that lead to strong results.

Emergency Loans are interest-free and emergency-based loans available to all students regardless of their program. They can be repaid within 30 days and are offered through the Office of the Dean of Student Affairs.
Graduate students may apply for the loan by visiting the Student Affairs Office, Warner Hall 301 or calling (412) 268-2075 to schedule an appointment.
Emergency Support Funding is available for graduate students who find themselves in need of immediate funds for emergency situations. They should contact the Office of the Dean of Students to inquire about the types of funding available.

Student Information Online (SIO) is a secure site where students can find important, personalized information such as E-Bills and student account information, financial aid status and eligibility, grades and QPA, and course schedules.
Students can update their own contact information as well as that of their spouse or domestic partner. They can also sign up for E-Check & E-Refund and authorize others to receive a copy of their E-Bill.
The information about Student Information Online (SIO) can be found on page 32 of the MIIS Graduate Student Handbook.
E-Bill refers to an electronic bill that is sent by the institution to students for their tuition and other fees. It can be accessed through Student Information Online (SIO).
QPA stands for Quality Point Average, which is a system used to calculate the academic performance of students based on their grades.
Students themselves or their spouses/domestic partners can authorize others to receive a copy of the E-Bill.
Signing up for E-Check & E-Refund allows students to receive their refunds electronically, which can be more convenient and faster than receiving a paper check.
SIO helps manage students' financial aid status by providing information about their eligibility for financial aid and the amount they are entitled to receive.

IDPlus stands for Identity Plus, which is an online service provided by Carnegie Mellon University that allows students and affiliates to manage their personal information and access various services.
According to the text, students have the right to inspect and review their education records; request an amendment if they believe them inaccurate or misleading; request a hearing for unresolved requests; consent to disclosure of personally identifiable information from their education records except where FERPA authorizes it; file a complaint with the U.S. Department of Education Family Policy Compliance Office if they feel their rights under FERPA have been violated.
The federal act referred to in the text is the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (FERPA).
No, according to this university policy, students cannot give consent for disclosure of personally identifiable information from their education records unless it is authorized by FERPA.
If a student believes that their request for an amendment to their education record has not been resolved satisfactorily, they have the right to file a hearing.
The purpose of this university policy is to notify students about their rights under FERPA and inform them that they can inspect, amend, consent or file a complaint regarding their education records.
If a student believes that their rights under FERPA have been violated, they can file a complaint with the U.S. Department of Education Family Policy Compliance Office.
The university policy serves as a guide for how students can access, amend and control their education records while ensuring that FERPA regulations are followed.
The purpose of requesting an amendment to one's education record, according to this university policy, is to correct inaccuracies or misleading information.
FERPA allows disclosure of personally identifiable information from a student's education records without their consent.

No, CMU Alert is not just for students. It sends voice and/or text messages to registered phones in the event of a campus emergency that threatens public safety or during tests of the system.
Students can register for CMU Alert through the website.
The MIIS Graduate Student Handbook is a guide that provides information about various aspects of student life at Carnegie Mellon University. It can be found on page 38.
The tests for CMU Alert are conducted in the spring and fall semesters.
The purpose of conducting tests for CMU Alert is to ensure that the system works properly during emergencies or crises.
No, it's not mandatory. However, registering for CMU Alert is highly recommended as it helps in receiving important alerts during emergencies.

The purpose of the Center for Student Diversity & Inclusion at Carnegie Mellon University is to cultivate a strong, diverse and inclusive community capable of living out values such as diversity and inclusion. The center offers resources to enhance an inclusive and transformative student experience in dimensions such as access, success, campus climate and intergroup dialogue.
The Center for Student Diversity & Inclusion offers various initiatives including First generation/first in family to attend college programs, LGBTQ+ Initiatives, Race and ethnically focused programs such as Inter-University Graduate Students of Color Series (SOC) and PhD SOC Network, Women’s empowerment programs like Graduate Women’s Gatherings (GWGs), etc.

The purpose of A.1.5 Assistance for Individuals with Disabilities at Carnegie Mellon University is to provide assistance and resources for individuals with disabilities.
The mission of the Office of Disability Resources at Carnegie Mellon University is to provide physical, digital, and programmatic access to ensure that students with disabilities have equal access to their educational experience. The office works to ensure that qualified individuals receive reasonable accommodations as guaranteed by the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973.
Students who would like to receive accommodations can begin the process through Disability Resources' secure online portal or email access@andrew.cmu.edu to begin the interactive accommodation Process.
Students with physical, sensory, cognitive, or emotional disabilities are encouraged to self- identify with the Office of Disability Resources and request needed accommodations.
Any questions about the process can be directed to access@andrew.cmu.edu, or call (412) 268- 6121.

The Language Technologies Master's program (MLT) is a unique, research-oriented program that prepares students for careers in academia or industry.
The MLT program immerses students in two full years of research, with an even split during the academic year between coursework and research with a faculty advisor. Your summers will be devoted entirely to research.
Many MLT grads continue on to pursue their doctorates at CMU and other top universities, while others find fulfilling careers at companies that value research and rapid innovation.
The curriculum provides a unified vision of very large information systems while preparing you for a professional career at leading IT, software services and social media companies.
As part of the MCDS program, you'll belong to many communities, at CMU and in Pittsburgh, that offer countless opportunities for growth and engagement.
The Language Technologies Institute is a world leader in the areas of speech processing, language processing, information retrieval, machine translation, machine learning, and computational biology.
Students learn what makes our program a world-leader in the field of language technologies, and how they can apply it.
Carnegie Mellon University is located in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania.
The Read More button allows readers to learn more about Why MLT?
The main purpose of the MCDS program, as stated in the text, is to ensure that students have real-world training they need to be successful in industry.
The text mentions countless opportunities for growth and engagement as part of the MCDS program, including belonging to many communities at CMU and in Pittsburgh.
A team of students from the Language Technologies Institute recently earned top honors for their performance in the BioASQ 2016 Biomedical Semantic Question Answering challenge.
A Carnegie Mellon system designed to rapidly answer questions, even some seemingly off the wall, received the highest score by far in the LiveQA evaluation track at the Text Retrieval Conference (TREC 2015).
The Contact Us Master of Language Technologies is located at 5000 Forbes Avenue, Pittsburgh, PA 15213-3891.

The abbreviation 'LTI' stands for Language Technologies Institute.

The purpose of iCalendar RSS Feed is to provide a way for users to access and manage their calendar events in a structured format.
You can share an event from the iCalendar RSS Feed by clicking on the 'Share' button and selecting one of the available options: Facebook, Twitter, Email or Print.
When events are marked in bold in the Home section, they indicate that these events are related to home activities and may be of personal interest or importance.
iCalendar refers to a calendar application used for managing appointments, meetings, and events. On the other hand, an RSS Feed (Really Simple Syndication) allows users to access updates from websites in a structured format.
The 'Conference' event listed could be an upcoming conference related to iCalendar or RSS Feed, which may provide users with updates and information about these technologies.
The word 'Home' refers to events that are related to personal or home activities, which may include family gatherings, appointments, or other important dates.
The separate section for Home events allows users to easily identify and manage their personal activities and events, which may be different from work-related or other types of events.
The RSS Feed in iCalendar allows users to access and manage their calendar events in a structured format, which can be easily shared or subscribed by others.
The 'Share' button allows users to share events with others, either through social media platforms like Facebook and Twitter or by emailing it directly.

The Communication Support program offers several modes of support, including One-on-one Communication Tutoring (in-person or synchronous Zoom meeting), Video Response (asynchronous feedback within 5 days of scheduled appointment), Group Appointments for peer reviews and collaborative presentation strategies, Workshops on various topics to learn research-backed communication strategies, and Resources such as handouts and videos that explain specific communication strategies.
The purpose of Language and Cross-Cultural Support at Carnegie Mellon is to help international students, non-native speakers of English who have attended high school or undergraduate programs in the U.S., hone their language and cross-cultural skills for academic and professional success.

Students can find information about academic policies and resources in The WORD by visiting the following link: http://www.cmu.edu/student-affairs/theword/
The WORD includes information about University-wide academic policies and resources, community policies and resources, and procedures for reviewing possible violations of these standards.
Graduate students should refer to The WORD often because it provides them with the tools, guidance, and insights they need to achieve their full potential as members of the Carnegie Mellon community.
The purpose of the Human Subjects in Research section in The WORD is to provide guidelines and policies for research involving human subjects.
The MLT Graduate Student Handbook is a resource that provides guidelines and policies for graduate students in the Master of Language Teaching (MLT) program. It can be found on page 46.
The WORD covers a wide range of topics, including but not limited to: Carnegie Mellon Vision, Mission Statement of Assurance, Carnegie Mellon Code Academic Standards, Policies and Procedures, Educational Goals, Academic Disciplinary Actions Overview, Statement on Academic Integrity, Standards for Academic & Creative Life, Assistance for Individuals with Disabilities, Master’s Student Statute of Limitations, Conduct of Classes, Copyright Policy, Cross-college & University Registration, Doctoral Student Status Policy, Evaluation & Certification of English Fluency for Instructors, Final Exams for Graduate Courses, Grading Policies, Intellectual Property Policy, Privacy Rights of Students, and Student’s Rights.
The purpose of The WORD in Carnegie Mellon University is to serve as the foundation for department and sometimes college handbooks, providing students with information about university-wide academic policies and resources.
Some of the procedures used to review possible violations of standards at CMU include those described in The WORD, which serves as the foundation for department and sometimes college handbooks.
The URL of the Shuttle & Escort Service website is https://www.cmu.edu/parking/shuttle/index.html

Boss is a Chevy Tahoe with over 500,000 lines of code to autonomously navigate in town and in traffic.
Defensive driving skills allow Boss to avoid crashes.
Tartan Racing technology enables Boss to follow rules of the road.
Boss uses perception, planning and behavioral software to reason about traffic and take appropriate actions while proceeding safely to a destination.
Active safety can play a huge role in countering accidents from cell phone usage, drowsiness and drinking.
Boss uses Tartan Racing technology to find a spot and park in a parking lot.
The human payoffs for Urban Challenge technology include improved safety, and enhanced driving experience.
High-level route planning determines the best path through a road network. Motion planning requires consideration of the static and dynamic obstacles detected by perception, as well as lane and road boundary information, parking lot boundaries, stop lines, speed limits, and similar requirements.
Boss uses Tartan Racing technology to follow vehicles at a safe distance.

The deadline for making changes to an online application submitted for most programs at the School of Computer Science is Dec. 13, 2023, at 3 p.m. EST.
If all your supporting documents do not arrive by the established deadline, they may not be considered in the review of your application. It is your responsibility to make certain that your application is complete and that the required materials reach us by the set deadline.
Yes, you can still submit your application even if you haven't received all of your letters of recommendation. We prefer that your recommenders submit their letters by the application deadline, but it is okay if they arrive a few days late.
Most programs at the School of Computer Science only have fall admission. However, there are exceptions. Please refer to our Graduate Admissions Overview page for more information.
Yes, you can reapply if you were not admitted last year. However, you must complete a new application and upload all the required materials again.
The admissions requirements vary by program and are determined by each program's home department. Please refer to our Graduate Admissions Overview page or contact your desired program directly for more information.
For most programs, you can make changes to your submitted application up until Dec. 13, 2023, at 3 p.m. EST. However, if you have applied to the Language Technologies programs or M.S. in Machine Learning or Robotics programs, you cannot make revisions to your application after it has been submitted.
You will receive an email notification once we have received and processed all materials. You may also log into our online system to view the status of your application.
If you forget to submit a required document or form, please contact us as soon as possible. We may be able to accommodate late submissions on a case-by-case basis.

Their concern was not having an undergraduate program, as they had a surplus of graduate students.
They felt that CSD’s needs were not adequately represented in MCS.
Creating another department about to become a college made them angry.
University politics are like sibling rivalry on steroids.
Allen Newell deserves most of the credit.
Simon was already connected to the rest of the school and didn't care whether computer science was a department or a school.
Allen had a careful, logical-thinking and great statesman like Benjamin Franklin.
Ninety percent of the maneuvering was done by Allen Newell.
Allen Newell
He became an administrator to get separated from his research obligations.
Angel Jordan
He put across the spin-out over the objections of many people.
Pat Crecine
He created the College of Computing, which was more or less a replica of what they were doing at Carnegie-Mellon.
He said that it's always secondary to the science and if you go after institutions, you don’t get any science done.

Shaw
The Carnegie Plan says, in substance, that an undergraduate education should include durable education in the ideas of the field. It should teach critical thinking … Yes, it should teach you some of the current skills, but to justify its place in the curriculum, any course needs to have durable intellectual content that will outlast a couple of changes in technology.

The main topic discussed in this text is the potential of computer science to transform the world 10 or 20 years from now.
Shaw mentions two main challenges: doing more research that directly connects with how people use their computers and helping individuals control their own computing. He also highlights electronic medical records as a big opportunity, but notes an impediment is data interchange.
Scott identifies two key areas: managing and securing distributed computing facilities (like the cloud) and integrating computer resources into teaching. He believes these issues have not been fully resolved.
The term 'HCII' refers to the School of Computer Science at Carnegie Mellon University, where researchers are working on usable security.
Shaw believes that many individuals struggle with managing their own personal computers and preventing infections, despite the prevalence of these issues.
Shaw mentions electronic medical records as a significant area where computer science could make an impact. However, he notes that data interchange remains a challenge.
Scott sees the potential for distributed facilities in computing like the cloud as a significant opportunity, but also acknowledges challenges such as ensuring security and operational efficiency.
Scott believes that producing well-designed courses with remote interaction on computers and integrating these into academic degrees needs further development.
Reddy speculates about a 10 or 20-year timeline for potential transformations in the field of computer science.
The main topic of the text is the democratization of computing and how it affects computer science.
Reddy said 'In the old days, a few people used to know a lot of things'.
The Simon Initiative is an opportunity for deeper science and higher-level vision in computer science.
The text is attributed to SIEWIOREK.
According to Reddy, democratization of computing means that everyone can have access to advanced computing at a fraction of the cost.

The MIIS degree stands for Master of International Studies.
Contact information about MIIS can be found in section 1.2, titled 'MIIS Contact Information'.
The university policies and expectations for students at Carnegie Mellon University can be found in section 1.3, titled 'University Policies and Expectations'.
The Carnegie Mellon University Statement of Assurance can be found in section 1.4, titled 'Carnegie Mellon University Statement of Assurance'.
The Carnegie Mellon Code can be found in section 1.5, titled 'The Carnegie Mellon Code'.
The main office of the Language Technologies Institute can be found in section 2.1, titled 'Main Office'.
Photocopies and Printers provide photocopying and printing services for Master’s students. This information can be found in section 2.3, titled 'Computers for Master’s Students'.
The academic calendar for Master’s degree completion can be found in section 2.4, titled 'Academic Calendar'.
The standard degree requirements and certification process for Master’s students can be found in section 3.1, titled 'Standard Degree Requirements & Degree Certification'.
Early completion options for a Master’s degree can be found in section 3.1.2, titled 'Early Completion'.
Extended or longer-than-standard completion options can be found in section 3.1.3, titled 'Extended or Longer-than-Standard Completion'.
Additional guidance for students can be found in section 3.1.4, titled 'Additional Guidance for Students'.
The purpose of Early Completion and Extended or Longer-than-Standard Competition is to provide students with additional guidance in their studies.
MIIS offers a degree in Program options.
The curricular requirements for students at MIIS include Curricular Requirements, Practice Requirements, Grade Requirements, Process for Appealing Final Grades, Approved Qualifying Courses, Breadth Courses: Human Language, and Breadth Courses: Language Technology Applications.
The breadth courses offered at MIIS include Breadth Courses: Machine Learning, Breadth Courses: Human Language, and Breadth Courses: Language Technology Applications.
Internships play a significant role in the MIIS program as they provide students with practical experience in their field of study.

LTI Orientation
16
The University Policy on Grades for Transfer Courses states that students must earn a grade of 'C-' or better in order to have their course(s) transferred.
The procedures for Drop/Add/Withdraw involve filling out a form and getting it signed by an advisor or department head, then submitting it to the Registrar's Office.
Academic Integrity at MIIS means that students must submit their own work and not cheat or plagiarize in any form. They are also expected to maintain the highest standards of honesty, respect for others' intellectual property, and ethical behavior.
Double-dipping refers to a situation where students take two courses that cover similar material in order to receive credit twice. This policy prohibits such actions and requires students to choose one course.
The Duration of Study policy states that full-time undergraduate programs typically take 4 years, while part-time programs can take up to 6 years. Graduate programs usually last between 1 and 2 years.
The Deferral policy allows students who have completed their coursework but not yet graduated to delay graduation for up to one year. This can be done only once per student.
The Independent Studies policy allows students who cannot find a course that meets their needs or interests to propose an individualized study plan with a faculty advisor. This requires approval from both the department and the Registrar's Office.
The Maximum Course Load policy states that students can take up to 18 credits per semester, while the Minimum Course Load policy requires full-time undergraduates to enroll in a minimum of 12 credits.
The Pass/Fail Grades policy allows students to choose this option for up to two courses during their undergraduate studies. If a student passes, they receive credit but no letter grade; if they fail, they do not receive any credit.
The Transfer Credit policy allows students to earn credits from courses taken elsewhere and apply them towards their degree requirements. However, only courses with a grade of 'C-' or better are eligible.
The three sections in chapter 5 of the text are Maximum and Minimum Course Loads, Pass/Fail Grades, Transfer Credit.
According to the text, students can transfer into the MIIS program.
In LTI academic policies, 'Grandfather' policy refers to a specific rule or regulation that is not changed over time for those who were already enrolled when it was established.
According to the text, transfer credit refers to credits earned at another institution that can be applied towards a student's degree requirements. Course exemption, on the other hand, allows students to skip certain courses if they have already taken and passed similar ones elsewhere.
The text does not provide a specific policy on external employment or consulting for LTI students. It only mentions that such activities are subject to approval by the student's academic advisor.
Satisfactory progress in CMU academic policies refers to maintaining a certain level of performance and completing coursework within the specified time frame. The exact criteria may vary depending on individual programs or departments.
The text mentions two breaks: Winter break and Summer break, both of which are part of the academic calendar at CMU.
The two types of breaks mentioned in this section are winter and summer breaks.
CMU provides assistance to individuals with disabilities through its Academic Policies, specifically the policy of Assistance for Individuals with Disabilities.
The purpose of the Graduate Student Appeal and Grievance Procedures is to provide a process for graduate students to appeal decisions or file grievances.
According to CMU's Consensual Intimate Relationship Policy Regarding Undergraduate Students, romantic or sexual relationships between faculty and undergraduates are strictly prohibited.
CMU has a policy that requires all employees to provide documentation for their identity and eligibility to work in the United States.
CMU has a Childbirth/Maternity Accommodation Protocol that provides various types of accommodations to support students during pregnancy and after giving birth.
The purpose of the Policy Against Sexual Harassment and Sexual Assault is to ensure that all members of the university community are treated with respect, dignity, and equality.
This section covers various financial issues related to graduate students at CMU, including employment eligibility verification, childbirth/maternity accommodations, and consensual intimate relationships.
The two types of breaks mentioned in this section are winter and summer breaks.
The three main categories of funding mentioned in section 6 are Graduate Student Funding, University Financial Aid, and Health Insurance.
The purpose of Emergency Loans according to section 6.4 is to provide financial assistance in emergencies for students who need immediate help.
The Office of the Dean of Students Emergency Support Funding provides financial assistance to students in emergencies.
Under Additional University Resources section 7, several resources are mentioned including The HUB Student Services Center, Student Information Online (SIO), ID Cards, Transcripts, Pittsburgh Council on Higher Education (PCHE) and Cross-registration, Student Privacy Rights and FERPA, Professional Development, University Libraries, Computing Services.
The purpose of The HUB Student Services Center according to section 7.1 is to provide a central location for students to access various student services.
According to section 7.2, Student Information Online (SIO) provides students with access to their academic records and financial aid information.
The purpose of ID Cards according to section 7.3 is for identification purposes, as well as access to certain facilities and services.
According to section 7.4, Transcripts provide a record of a student's academic performance and courses taken.
The purpose of Pittsburgh Council on Higher Education (PCHE) and Cross-registration according to section 7.5 is to allow students to take courses at other participating institutions.
FERPA stands for Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act. According to section 7.6, this act protects students' privacy by regulating access to their education records.
According to section 7.7, the university offers various professional development opportunities for students.

The main purpose of the MIIS Graduate Student Handbook is to inform graduate students about their program requirements and procedures.
Yes, each department at CMU has its own handbook for graduate students to inform them of the specific policies, procedures, and requirements for their program.
MIIS graduate students can also consult The Word, the Student Handbook, the Office of Graduate and Postdoc Affairs, the Office of the Dean of Student Affairs, and others as mentioned in Appendix A of this handbook.
Including information about other resources in Appendix A of the MIIS Graduate Student Handbook ensures that students have access to a comprehensive list of available resources and offices they can consult during their tenure at Carnegie Mellon University.
CMU's different departments have significant differences in their philosophical approaches, procedures, policies, and regulations.
The purpose of having a handbook for each department at CMU is to inform graduate students about their program requirements, procedures, and policies.
The MIIS Graduate Student Handbook provides written access to standard information outlined below, including policies, procedures, and requirements for the Master of Science in Intelligent Information Systems (MIIS) degree.
Having a separate handbook for each department at CMU ensures that students have access to specific information about their program requirements, procedures, and policies.
