The swimming and diving pool was constructed in 1996.
The main pool, which is an 8-lane, 25-yard long pool.
The dive pool is used for lap swimming, swimming lessons, and programming.
Only those with a valid CMU ID can use the space. Only CMU ID holders can use the pool and athletic facilities.
The balcony was added in 2015 which seats up to 200 people.
The lap pool is for lap swim ONLY.
For recreation hours, visit the aquatics page.
The cool-down area is for swimmers to relax after their workout.
The dive pool has two one-meter and two three-meter diving boards.
The LTI Ph.D. Graduate Student Handbook
Page 12
LTI Ph.D.
91
To provide guidelines and expectations for students pursuing advanced degrees.
Graduate students who are part of the LTI Ph.D program
The exact meaning is not clear from the given text, but it could be an abbreviation or acronym.
No, the given text does not mention anything about admission requirements.
It provides guidelines and expectations for students pursuing advanced degrees, helping them navigate their academic journey more effectively.
Office locations for faculty, staff, and Ph.D. students can be found on the LTI website.
Yes, most Ph.D. students in residence on the Pittsburgh campus are given an office in which to study and do research.
Offices are assigned by the LTI’s Office Manager (see Section 1.2, Department Personnel, for contact information).
Mailboxes and office supplies are in GHC 5404.
The use of a photocopier or printer requires you to log in with your CMU ID card.
The machines in GHC 5404 and GHC 6604 are the most convenient.
Ph.D. students are responsible for having their own laptop computers to support their education and research.
Many Ph.D. advisors also provide access to computer clusters, cloud computing, or other resources to support computationally-intense research.
The LTI's computer cluster provides storage and computation for projects involving large datasets and/or lengthy computation.
Ph.D. advisors provide access to computer clusters, cloud computing, or other resources.
All CMU students have an Andrew id, while Computer Science students also have a CS id that provides access to SCS-specific resources.
Ph.D. students receive two types of user ids (Andrew and CS) for access to different sets of resources, ensuring they have necessary access.
The LTI cluster provides storage and computation for projects involving large datasets and/or lengthy computations.
CS ids are being phased out very slowly, so it is likely that you will need both types of user id (Andrew and CS).
Ph.D. students can find information in the LTI Ph.D. Graduate Student Handbook, specifically on Page 13.
Ph.D. students are given access to the LTI’s computer cluster on an as-needed basis for course assignments, directed study projects, and/or capstone projects.
Having a CS id provides access to SCS-specific resources that are not available with an Andrew id alone, enabling more comprehensive research.
The LTI cluster provides storage and computation for projects involving large datasets and/or lengthy computations, which can be used in some course assignments.
The contact information for the School of Computer Science Help Center is help@cs.cmu.edu or 412-268-4231 from an outside line (M-F, 9am-5pm).
To complete the Ph.D. in Language and Information Technologies degree, students must pass at least 96 units of graduate level courses, satisfy proficiencies in Writing, Presentation, Programming, and Teaching; propose, write, and defend a Ph.D. dissertation (thesis); attend the LTI Colloquium each semester; and satisfy the Research Speaking Requirement.
To complete the course requirements, students must pass 96 or more units of graduate courses. They need to take at least 72 units of “LTI” courses and 24 units of “SCS” courses, have at least one class in each “LTI Focus Area”, and take at least two labs, in two different research areas.
Unless approved by the Program Director in advance, students must satisfy their course requirements through actual classroom courses. They cannot receive credit for research or independent study.
An 'LTI course' is any 12-unit course with a number of 11-XXX. A 6-unit course with 11-XXX counts as one-half of an LTI course.
A 'course' means an actual classroom course, not credit given for research or independent study. Note that the LTI allows any one MLD (10-XXX) graduate course to count as an 'LTI course'.
Students must satisfy proficiencies in Writing, Presentation, Programming, and Teaching as part of their Ph.D. degree.
The LTI Colloquium (11-700) is a semester event that students are required to attend as part of their Ph.D. degree.
The Research Speaking Requirement is one of the requirements for completing the Ph.D. in Language and Information Technologies degree, where students must present their research to an audience.
The term 'LTI Focus Areas' refers to specific areas of study within the Language and Information Technologies program, which students must have at least one class in each.
An LTI course is a 12-unit course with a number of 11-XXX, or a 6-unit course with 11-XXX that counts as one-half of an LTI course.
In this context, 'course' refers to an actual classroom course and not credit given for research or independent study.
Yes, any one MLD (10-XXX) graduate course can count as an 'LTI course'.
An SCS course is any 12-unit course with a number indicating it belongs to the School of Computer Science, while a regular 12-unit course does not have this specific designation.
No, 'course' in this context refers to actual classroom courses and not credit given for research or independent study.
The School of Computer Science is a unit within the university that offers courses related to computer science.
An LTI course requires 12 units, as stated in the text.
The recommendation allows students to have more flexibility in their course selection and potentially fulfill requirements for both LTI courses and other programs.
A unit of the School of Computer Science refers to a department or program within the school that offers courses related to computer science.
Sets of courses defined on the LTI course webpage under “Course Categories”.
The Ph.D. Program Director, with advice from faculty in the appropriate area.
A course belonging to that LTI Focus Area, as listed on the LTI’s “Course Categories” webpage.
Only courses with a grade of B (3.0) or higher are counted as satisfying a degree requirement.
Students must demonstrate their mastery in four areas: Writing, Presentation, and Programming.
By producing a peer-reviewed conference paper or an equivalent written report that at least two SCS faculty certify as being of conference-paper quality.
By giving an oral presentation of a conference paper, or an equivalent oral presentation that at least two SCS faculty certify as being of conference-talk quality.
By demonstrating competence in computer programming of language technology, usually through their research and/or project work.
Courses in the list of lab courses defined on the LTI’s “Course Categories” webpage.
The two ways to satisfy the Presentation requirement according to the LTI Ph.D. Graduate Student Handbook are by giving an oral presentation of a conference paper that at least two SCS faculty certify as being of conference-talk quality, and demonstrating competence in computer programming of language technology through research and/or project work.
The purpose of the LTI Ph.D. Graduate Student Handbook is to provide guidelines and requirements for students pursuing a Ph.D. in Language Technology at SCS.
You can find information about Presentation requirement on Page 15 of the LTI Ph.D. Graduate Student Handbook.
The significance of SCS faculty certification in satisfying the Presentation requirement is that it ensures that the oral presentation meets a certain standard and quality, as determined by two SCS faculty members.
Computer programming of language technology involves demonstrating competence in using programming skills to develop or improve software related to language processing and understanding, which is often a part of the student's research and/or project work.
According to the LTI Ph.D. Graduate Student Handbook, an oral presentation is considered 'of conference-talk quality' when it meets a certain standard and level of professionalism that would be expected in presentations at academic conferences.
The LTI Ph.D. Graduate Student Handbook provides guidelines, requirements, and expectations for students who are pursuing a Ph.D. in Language Technology at SCS.
The purpose of research and/or project work in satisfying the Programming requirement is to demonstrate competence in using programming skills to develop or improve software related to language processing and understanding, which is often a part of the student's Ph.D. studies.
The two requirements for students pursuing a Ph.D. in Language Technology at SCS, as stated in the LTI Ph.D. Graduate Student Handbook, are satisfying the Presentation requirement by giving an oral presentation of a conference paper that at least two SCS faculty certify as being of conference-talk quality, and demonstrating competence in computer programming of language technology through research and/or project work.
Two successful Teaching Assistantships (TA-ships) are required, typically one for an undergraduate class and one for a graduate-level class. One of these may be in some form of pre-approved 'alternate service', such as an SCS ‘v-unit’.
Graduate students are required to have a certain level of fluency in English before they can instruct, as mandated by the English Fluency in Higher Education Act of 1990. The full university policy can be reviewed at: https://www.cmu.edu/policies/faculty/evaluation-certification-english-fluency-instructors.html
Language Support in the Student Academic Success Center rates the fluency of all instructional personnel to determine at what level of responsibility they can serve as TA. They also administer the International Teaching Assistant (ITA) Test, a mandatory screening test for non-native speakers.
Language Support in the Student Academic Success Center helps these TAs develop fluency and cultural understanding to teach successfully. More information can be found on their website: https://www.cmu.edu/student-success/
The process of completing a Ph.D. dissertation has three important milestones: proposal, research and writing, and final submission.
The Ph.D. dissertation is the defining feature of a Ph.D. degree.
Two (2) successful Teaching Assistantships (TA-ships), as determined by the faculty member for whom the student serves as TA.
The ITA test is a mandatory screening test for any non-native speaker of English to evaluate their fluency before they can serve as teaching assistants.
The TA-ship may not be accepted.
The Ph.D. dissertation
During the third year of their Ph.D.
The student will specify the problem they are addressing (the thesis topic), its significance, competing approaches, preliminary results, remaining work to be done, evaluation metrics for that work.
A thesis statement describes the claimed solution to the research problem that is the thesis topic when the dissertation is finished.
Near the end of the third year
The student will specify other relevant research, including competing approaches.
The thesis topic typically develops from the directed research that the student has been carrying out with their advisor, and it should be interesting and unsolved.
Evaluation metrics are used to assess the work that still must be completed.
The thesis topic typically develops from the directed research that the student has been carrying out with their advisor.
The projected timeline for completion of a PhD in SCS involves securing approval for a dissertation committee, presenting the proposal to the scientific community, and submitting the thesis document at the end of the fifth year. The student must also publicly announce the time and place of their thesis defense one week before it occurs.
A public thesis proposal protects the student by ensuring that their proposed research is interesting to the larger scientific community and demonstrates that they will finish the program if the work is completed as outlined.
The dissertation document should include a detailed description of all the work done, including a clear evaluation and discussion of its scientific contributions. The only format requirement is that the title page should be suitable to be issued as an LTI Technical Report.
University rules require that the time and place of the dissertation defense be publicly announced at least one week before it occurs. This should also be coordinated with Ph.D. Program Coordinator.
At the time of public announcement, a draft of the thesis document must be made available online.
SCS ensures that students meet their research speaking requirement by requiring them to present their work in a public forum, such as at conferences or seminars.
The Ph.D. Program Coordinator plays an important role in ensuring that students meet all requirements for their degree, including coordinating public announcements and ensuring timely completion of thesis defense.
Securing approval from at least two other SCS faculty members working in language technologies ensures that the student's research aligns with their area of expertise and receives valuable feedback.
The external member provides an outside perspective on the student's work, ensuring that it meets high standards of scientific rigor and contributes to the broader field.
At the time of the public announcement, a draft of the thesis document must be made available online.
All LTI Ph.D. students are required to complete an annual oral presentation at the LTI to emphasize student research, improve public speaking skills and increase internal awareness of LTI work.
At least two LTI faculty members will attend the presentation, including the research advisor. The public may also be invited.
The advisor's role is to guide the education and monitor the progress of the student through the program, as well as supervise the student's directed research.
An LTI Ph.D. student must complete one annual oral presentation by the end of May.
The purpose of providing written feedback after a student's oral presentation is to help refine speaking skills with respect to talk structure, content, and delivery.
The thesis proposal and defense each count towards this requirement.
At least two LTI faculty members, including the research advisor, will convene to provide written feedback.
The Program Director of graduate programs receives a copy of the written feedback provided after a student's oral presentation.
Students are expected to select their advisors during the first month of the program.
Until a student finds a specific advisor, the Program Director of the LTI graduate programs serves as their advisor.
Students are expected to attend the LTI's Orientation lectures, where faculty describe their interests and areas of expertise. They should also be proactive about meeting individually with potential advisors.
Students indicate a first, second, and third choice for advisor after meeting with several potential advisors. The potential advisors determine how many new students they can take and indicate their preferences. Finally, the entire LTI faculty meets as a 'Matching Committee' to determine the best set of matches.
Yes, it is possible for students to change advisors. They should find another faculty member willing to serve as an advisor and then make a request to the Program Director to switch advisors.
During these lectures, faculty describe their interests and areas of expertise. Students are expected to attend these lectures as part of the matching process.
Choosing an advisor carefully ensures that the student receives necessary faculty mentoring and career advice. It also helps in forming a strong student-advisor relationship, which takes time.
The Program Director of the LTI graduate programs serves as the advisor until a student finds a specific one.
The student should find another faculty member willing to serve as an advisor and then make a request to the Program Director to switch. Both the new and old advisors need to agree to the change.
Students are expected to attend the orientation lectures and treat them as seriously as a standard course because they provide an introduction to the broad range of research done at the LTI.
The original name for these talks was 'the Immigration Course (IC)', which aimed to orient newly-arrived students into the CMU environment.
The purpose of End of Semester Evaluation is for faculty members to evaluate each student's academic progress and provide a letter at the end of the semester.
Students are expected to prepare a statement that describes their achievements during the current semester and plans for the next semester.
The student's advisor serves as the student's advocate during the end-of-semester evaluation process.
LTI Orientation provides an opportunity for advisors to recruit new students and helps them learn about the work done by CMU faculty.
The name 'Immigration Course (IC)' was used to signify that these talks help orient newly-arrived students into the CMU environment.
The primary purpose of LTI Orientation is to provide an opportunity for advisors to recruit new students and help them learn about the work done by CMU faculty.
A student's statement should include their achievements during the current semester and plans for the next semester.
A good letter typically indicates that the student is making satisfactory progress towards completing their degree.
Letters indicating trouble from faculty should be considered as serious warnings. They are not permanent 'black marks' on the student's record, but if the student begins making satisfactory progress again, there is no official record of the letter in their transcript.
In serious cases, if a faculty gives an 'N-1' letter to a student, it specifies a list of conditions that the student must satisfy by specific deadlines. Failure to meet all these specified conditions may result in the student's termination from the program.
Yes, students can take elective courses outside of SCS at Carnegie Mellon or cross-registered at the University of Pittsburgh. However, they must fulfill their program requirements as described above and discuss any such electives in advance with their advisor.
Students interested in taking recommended electives outside the SCS should pay attention to issues like whether these courses count towards 'SCS' course requirements, need advance approval for any courses not covered by their normal tuition (e.g., summer courses), and discuss with their advisor.
Yes, recommended electives outside of the SCS can count towards the 'SCS' course requirement. However, students need approval from their program director for these courses.
Typical choices might include ECE courses for Speech students, Pitt Linguistics courses, or Statistics courses.
Students interested in taking recommended electives outside the SCS should have a discussion with their advisor to ensure they fulfill all requirements and understand any potential issues.
The purpose of an 'N-1' letter is to specify a list of conditions that the student must satisfy by specific deadlines. Failure to meet all these specified conditions may result in the student's termination from the program.
If a student fails to meet all the specified conditions in an 'N-1' letter, it may result in their termination from the program.
The purpose of this text is to inform students about issues they should consider when taking recommended electives outside the SCS, such as getting approval for non-covered courses and understanding grading policies.
The consequences of taking an outside course that does not meet the minimum 'B' grade requirement for Ph.D. is unclear from this text.
Students can use courses that satisfy LTI Ph.D. requirements for one M.S. degree, the most common choice being the LTI's Master of Language Technologies (MLT) degree due to similar requirements.
Yes, according to this text, students interested in taking recommended electives outside the SCS should pay particular attention to getting approval for these courses.
The grading of outside courses is the responsibility of the department offering the course, but the LTI's Minimum Course Grade Policy still applies.
Students should consider getting approval for non-covered courses and understanding grading policies, as mentioned in the text.
The text does not provide clear information about whether a student can use an M.S. degree from another department to satisfy LTI Ph.D. requirements.
According to this text, courses that satisfy LTI Ph.D. degree requirements may also be used to satisfy requirements for one M.S. degree.
The text states that students interested in taking recommended electives outside the SCS should pay particular attention to getting approval from their Program Director.
Students interested in an M.S. degree other than the MLT degree should discuss their plans with their Ph.D. advisor due to the additional courses and project work that may be involved.
Carnegie Mellon’s Grading policy offers details concerning university grading principles for students taking courses and covers the specifics of assigning and changing grades, grading options, drop/withdrawals, and course repeats. It also defines the undergraduate and graduate grading standards.
The following circumstances are the unusual exceptions that may warrant a grade appeal: (a) the final grade assigned for a course is based on manifest error (e.g., a clear error such as arithmetic error in computing a grade or failure to grade one of the answers on an exam), or (b) the faculty or staff member who assigned the grade did so in violation of a university policy.
See the university’s Summary of Graduate Student Appeal and Grievance Procedures web page information. https://www.cmu.edu/student-affairs/theword/academic/appeal-of- for more grades-and-academic-actions.html
https://www.cmu.edu/policies/student-and-student-life/transfer-credit-evaluation-and-assignment.html
The purpose of the policy is to record grades from Carnegie Mellon courses and those taken through cross-registration programs, while not considering transfer credits without grade in academic actions or QPA calculations.
PCHE stands for Pittsburgh Council on Higher Education.
Courses taken through a cross-registration program will have grades recorded on the transcript and be factored into the QPA.
QPA stands for Quality Point Average.
Transfer courses will be recorded on the transcript indicating where the course was taken, but without grade. Such courses will not be considered for academic actions or QPA calculations.
The LTI Ph.D. Graduate Student Handbook provides information about policies and procedures for graduate students at Carnegie Mellon University, including those related to transfer courses.
https://www.cmu.edu/policies/student-and-student-life/transfer-credit-evaluation-and-assignment.html
The purpose of a cross-registration program is to allow students to take courses at other accredited institutions.
Students can find information about appeal and grievance procedures on the university’s Summary of Graduate Student Appeal and Grievance Procedures web page.
The purpose of the policy is to define and outline consequences for cheating, plagiarism, and unauthorized assistance.
If a student commits a second violation while on disciplinary probation, they are dismissed from the graduate program.
The process for investigating and adjudicating violations is outlined in the procedures provided by the LTI Ph.D. Graduate Student Handbook.
Dismissal from the graduate program means that a student is no longer allowed to continue their studies in the program and must leave the university.
According to the text, one violation can lead to dismissal if it is not immediately addressed by a disciplinary hearing. If there's no immediate dismissal after the first violation, then two violations while on probation will result in dismissal.
Disciplinary probation is a status given to students who have committed their first academic integrity violation. It means that the student is under close supervision and any further violations could lead to dismissal.
If a student commits a second violation while on disciplinary probation, they are immediately dismissed from the graduate program.
The University Policy on Academic Integrity allows for convening a disciplinary hearing according to the procedures of the department/program.
The purpose of the Appeals of Course Level Action section is to provide more information about the appeal process for violations of academic integrity.
A degree can be withdrawn if it was granted based on falsified work or academic records.
Withdrawal of the degree occurs promptly upon discovery of the falsification.

A student in the program may not take more than sixty (60) units per semester without permission from the program director.
A student in the program must be registered for a minimum thirty-six (36) units per semester to be considered a full-time student.
Yes, all international students are required by US Federal law to maintain full-time status.
No, reduced course load is not permitted for MIIS students.
Failure to maintain full-time status will result in loss of a student visa (and, therefore, “permit of stay”).
No, pass/fail grades are not permitted for courses used to satisfy a degree requirement except for the 11-696 (A) Capstone Planning Seminar and 11-935 (R) LTI Practicum.
No, graduate students who are required to take additional undergraduate courses to build up the core foundations of computer science may not elect the pass/fail option for these courses.
Yes, an equivalent graduate course previously completed at Carnegie Mellon, or another institution may be permitted to satisfy one of the MIIS breadth requirements.
No, satisfying a breadth requirement with a course from another institution does not reduce the number of CMU course units that must be taken to attain the MIIS degree.
The application materials required for transfer into the MIIS program include an explanation of why a transfer is desired, a proposed plan of study, a proposed advisor, and CMU transcripts.
No, students that are already enrolled in an LTI degree program are not required to retake GRE and TOEFL/IELTS/Duolingo exams or produce new transcripts from other universities.
The MIIS program will conduct an expedited admissions process after receiving a student's request for transfer. The program will consider whether the coursework done prior to the transfer allows the student to be 'on schedule' by the end of the spring semester, so that they can participate in a capstone project with other MIIS students during the next fall semester.
Yes, MIIS students are allowed to switch tracks (MIIS-16 to MIIS-21 and vice versa) after beginning their first semester at CMU. Ideally, all switch requests should be filed within the first semester of the program.
U.S. citizens have no restrictions on how many times they can switch if it is done for a legitimate reason. To confirm the legitimacy of the reason to switch tracks, all students must seek their advisor's approval and the approval of the Director of the MIIS program.
When a student transfers out of the MIIS program, they will be subject to additional financial obligations. It is highly recommended not to switch tracks more than once as multiple track switching may negatively impact immigration records for international students.
Students who wish to transfer out of the MIIS program should follow the standard procedures for leaving CMU and their specific degree program.

The LTI grants transfer credit or issues an exemption for equivalent graduate courses previously completed at another institution.
If a student is exempt from a required course, they can replace that course with an open elective. The student does not receive credit for the external course but can take any course that could normally count toward the degree in its place.
If a student receives credit for prior coursework completed at CMU or elsewhere, they receive that many units of credit. The total amount of required coursework is reduced by that amount.

If a student is exempt from a required course due to prior courses or experience, the student can replace that course with an open elective. They do not receive any additional credit for the external course.
When a student receives transfer credit, they have completed courses at another institution that can be counted towards their degree requirements at CMU or MIIS. The total amount of required coursework is reduced by the number of units received.

Students whose anticipated delivery date is during the semester may consider taking time away from their coursework and/or research responsibilities. Any student who gives birth to a child while engaged in coursework or research is eligible to take either a short-term absence or formal leave of absence.
Students are encouraged to consult with relevant university faculty and staff as soon as possible as they begin making plans regarding time away.
Students must contact the Office of the Dean of Student Affairs to register for Maternity Accommodations. Students will complete an information form and meet with a member of the Dean’s Office staff to determine resources and procedures appropriate for the individual student.
Students in course work should consider options such as working with their course instructors to receive incomplete grades, electing to drop to part-time status or taking a full semester leave of absence.
Students engaged in research must work with their faculty to develop plans for the research for the time they are away and for resuming upon return.
Master's students who receive an academic stipend funded by Carnegie Mellon are eligible to continue to receive stipend funding for up to six (6) weeks during a Short- Term Maternity Accommodation or a Formal Leave of Absence. Continued academic stipend funding may be extended by two (2) weeks, for a total of eight (8) weeks if an absence longer than six weeks is medically necessary.
To receive this support, students must be registered with the Office of the Dean of Students.

The purpose of Academic Coaching at CMU is to provide holistic one-on-one peer support and group workshops to help students find and implement their conditions for success. It assists in improving time management, productive habits, organization, stress management, and study skills.
A student can request support through the Academic Success Center website. They will attend in-person meetings or meet using video and audioconferencing technology to provide all students with support.
Peer Tutoring offers weekly appointments in a one-on-one and small group format for students from any discipline who need assistance with a course that may not be supported by other services. Students can register online through the Student Academic Success website.
The Student Academic Success team partners with instructors and departments to identify skills or concepts that would benefit from supplemental offerings (workshops, boot camps) to support students’ academic success and learning. They are eager to help convene and coordinate outside of the classroom skill-building opportunities open to any student interested in building skill or reinforcing course concept mastery.

The purpose of the University Libraries at CMU is to support graduate students in their coursework, research, teaching, and publishing by providing access to a wide range of information resources and services.

Research activities are governed by several university policies. Guidance and more general information can be found by visiting the Research at Carnegie Mellon website.
The Office of Research Integrity & Compliance (ORIC) supports research at Carnegie Mellon University by ensuring that research is conducted with integrity and in accordance with federal and Pennsylvania regulation.
The ORIC assists researchers with human subject research, conflicts of interest, responsible conduct of research, export controls, institutional animal care & use and provides consultation, advice, and review of allegations of research misconduct.

University Health Services provides general medical care, allergy injections, first aid, gynecological care and contraception as well as on-site pharmaceuticals.
University Health Services is staffed by physicians, advanced practice clinicians, and registered nurses.
The CMU Student Insurance Plan covers most visit fees to see the physicians and advanced practice clinicians & nurse visits. Fees for prescription medications, laboratory tests, diagnostic procedures and referral to the emergency room or specialists are the student’s responsibility.

The WORD is Carnegie Mellon University’s student handbook and serves as the foundation for the department (and sometimes college) handbook.
The WORD contains university-wide academic policy information and resources, community policies and resources, and describes the university level procedures used to review possible violations of these standards.

The MIIS Graduate Student Handbook is mentioned as a resource containing all these academic policies and resources for graduate students.
The text provides information about Athletics, Physical Fitness & Recreation as a campus resource that supports student's physical fitness.
The Leonard Gelfand Center is mentioned in the text as a university resource offering assistance to individuals with disabilities.
The Bicycle/Wheeled Transportation Policy outlines rules and regulations for using wheeled vehicles on campus.
The Non-Discrimination Policy states that any form of discriminatory harassment will not be tolerated and can lead to disciplinary action.
The Missing Student Protocol outlines procedures that are followed when a student has been absent from classes or activities without notification to the university.
The Smoking Policy prohibits smoking in all indoor spaces and within 25 feet of building entrances, exits, and windows.
The On-Campus Emergencies protocol outlines procedures for responding to various types of campus emergencies, including medical and safety hazards.
The Freedom of Expression Policy states that students have the right to express their opinions freely, but this does not extend to harassment or discrimination.
The Equal Opportunity/Affirmative Action Policy states that the university is committed to providing equal opportunities for all students, regardless of their race, gender, or other characteristics.
The Alcohol and Drugs Policy outlines rules and regulations regarding the use of alcohol and drugs on campus, including penalties for violations.
The Damage to Carnegie Mellon Property protocol outlines procedures and potential consequences for students who cause damage to university property.
The Active Medical Assistance Protocol provides guidelines for how the university responds to emergency situations involving students' health and well-being.

Rick Rashid was a professor in the computer science department who hated meetings and would often 'manage by wandering the halls'.
Rick Rashid left Carnegie Mellon in 1991 and became senior vice president of research for Microsoft Corp. where he hired Rich Draves.

Jeff Eppinger says, 'Don't bet against Steve Jobs,' and I'd say, 'Don't bet against Rick Rashid.'
The working atmosphere at Microsoft Research feels very academic, according to Draves.
Rashid models Microsoft Research after Carnegie Mellon's computer science culture because he wants to find researchers who can make an impact in their fields; collaborate with others from different backgrounds; and thrive when given freedom to pursue ideas.
Rashid looks for candidates who have curiosity, are excited about computer science as a discipline, and stake out new territory intellectually.
Having the attitude of 'I'm going to keep moving and stake out new territory intellectually' is important because it ensures a long career in computer science.

Rashid seeks out researchers who are invested in the organization, not just their personal goals.

The Accent operating kernel used memory mapping to save processor time by copying only necessary data for specific operations, allowing processors to share information via secured ports.
The Accent operating kernel was tightly woven around the Three Rivers PERQ workstation, limiting its compatibility with other systems like UNIX.

Mach supported multiple threads, sharing memory but running independently. That made it easy to expand Mach to run on multiple processors or across clusters of machines. Mach's modular design also kept the kernel size small while allowing to be ported to any number of platforms.

Professor Rosé's research interests include Information Retrieval, Text Mining and Analytics, Language Technologies for Education, Natural Language Processing and Computational Linguistics, and Computer Supported Collaborative Learning/MOOCs.
Professor Rosé directs her own lab called TELEDIA.
Professor Rosé works at the Language Technologies Institute and Human-Computer Interaction Institute in the Office: 5415 —Gates & Hillman Centers.
Professor Rosé's research focuses on better understanding the social and pragmatic nature of conversation, and using this understanding to build computational systems that improve the efficacy of conversation both between people, and between people and computers.
Professor Rosé's group has published 160 peer-reviewed publications in the top venues in five fields: language technologies, learning sciences, cognitive science, educational technology and human-computer interaction.
Professor Rosé works closely with students and post-docs from the LTI (Language Technologies Institute) and the Human-Computer Interaction Institute.
Professor Rosé's research is grounded in the fields of language technologies and human-computer interaction.
Professor Rosé uses approaches from computational discourse analysis and text mining, conversational agents, and computer-supported collaborative learning to pursue her research goals.

The two thriving interrelated research areas that have been birthed and substantially contributed to by the author's research are automated analysis of collaborative learning processes and dynamic support for collaborative learning.
The primary method used in the author's work is investigating how conversation works, formalizing this understanding in models that are precise enough to be reproducible and demonstrate explanatory power.
The author uses machine learning and text mining technologies that leverage a deep understanding of conversation constructs to build computational models capable of automatically applying these constructs to naturally occurring language interactions.
The three aspects included in each project, as per the text, are basic research on discourse analysis, basic research on text classification technology for automated analysis of conversational constructs identified under research on discourse analysis, and tools to enable other researchers to do the same.
The ultimate goal of the author's approach is to build interventions with real-world benefits, after having technology in place that automatically monitors naturalistic language communication.

The Master of Science in Intelligent Information Systems is a practice-oriented, professional degree program that offers both advanced study and practical experience in the processing and analysis of unstructured and semi-structured information (such as text, image, video, speech, and audio), mining, and intelligent information technologies.
The Master of Science in Intelligent Information Systems is geared towards students who plan to begin or resume leadership careers in industry and government.
Just over half the curriculum consists of coursework; the remainder provides hands-on, direct, project-oriented experience working closely with CMU faculty to build systems and solve problems using state-of-the-art algorithms, techniques, tools, and datasets.
Students have the flexibility to create their own course of study in consultation with their advisor.
Education isn't limited to the classroom. Students can help ensure that our students have the real-world training they need to be successful in industry.
As part of the MIIS program, you'll belong to many communities, at CMU and in Pittsburgh, that offer countless opportunities for growth and engagement.
These sections provide information about how students can learn, collaborate with faculty and peers, and connect with various communities as part of their education in the Master of Science in Intelligent Information Systems program.
The 'News' section provides updates about recent achievements or events related to the Master of Science in Intelligent Information Systems program, such as students earning top honors in a question-answering competition.
The title of the article linked by the 'Read More' button is 'Why MIIS?'.
The main purpose of the MIIS program is to provide students with real-world training they need for success in industry.
As part of the MIIS program, a student will belong to many communities at CMU and in Pittsburgh that offer countless opportunities for growth and engagement.
BioASQ 2016 Biomedical Semantic Question Answering challenge is an annual competition that pushes for a solution to the information access problem biomedical experts face by posing challenges on both biomedical semantic indexing and question answering.
The CMU team, comprising Zi Yang, achieved top honors for their performance in the BioASQ 2016 Biomedical Semantic Question Answering challenge.
The LiveQA evaluation track at TREC 2015 is a competition that pushes for rapid question answering, even to seemingly off the wall questions posed to the Yahoo! Answers website.
The Carnegie Mellon system designed to rapidly answer questions received the highest score by far in the LiveQA evaluation track at the Text Retrieval Conference (TREC) 2015.
The contact information for LTI Webmaster can be found in the 'Contact Us' section of Master in Intelligent Information Systems at Carnegie Mellon University, located at 5000 Forbes Avenue, Pittsburgh, PA 15213-3891. The phone number is 412-268-9870 and the email address is ltiwebmaster@cs.cmu.edu.
In the 'Connect' section, students can choose between logging in or logging out of their account.

The Language Technologies Institute
Dr. Lori Levin's research interests include Machine Translation, Natural Language Processing and Computational Linguistics, and Corpus Annotation and Resources.
Dr. Lori Levin's work primarily focuses on the linguistic aspects of language technologies, specifically Language Technologies With Low Resources and Language Universals and Typology.
The use of typology and universals helps to develop language technologies for new languages on short timelines or in low-resource scenarios.
Dr. Lori Levin's office is located at 5717 —Gates & Hillman Centers.
Speakers of technologically poor languages may use language technologies to access information related to education, politics, business, weather and health conditions, as well as for preserving culture and maintaining community relationships.
Dr. Lori Levin's office phone number is 412-268-6193.
Less than a hundred of the more than 6,000 human languages have robust language technologies like search engines, spell checkers or speech recognition.
Dr. Lori Levin is a Research Professor in the Language Technologies Institute with an expertise in Machine Translation, Natural Language Processing and Computational Linguistics.
Low-resource scenarios for technology-rich languages like English may occur in specialized styles or subject areas, where machine learning is insufficient. In such cases, hybrids of human-engineered knowledge and machine learning can be used.
The main purpose of exploring how to use typology and universals in developing language technologies is to develop language technologies for new languages on short timelines or in low-resource scenarios.
The author suggests using a linguistic theory of construction grammar as an approach to annotation when time and data are available.
The Language Technologies Institute is located at 5000 Forbes Avenue, Pittsburgh, PA 15213-3891.
On the 'Connect' page, you can either login or logout.
Language technologies can be based on what is known about human languages in general or what is known about related languages.
The author suggests falling back on what is known about human languages in general or what is known about related languages.
Linguistic typology and universals provide expectations for what languages might be like, which can help in developing language technologies for new languages on short timelines or in low-resource scenarios.
The contact information of Language Technologies Institute includes their address at 5000 Forbes Avenue, Pittsburgh, PA 15213-3891 and phone number 412-268-6591. They can also be reached via email at ltiwebmaster@cs.cmu.edu.
Language technologies can be developed in situations with sufficient time and data, or when there is insufficient time or data to build an NLP system.

Nanostructured Materials is taught by Pistorius
The event was held in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania at A19C from 3:00 PM to 4:50 PM.
The principles of Surface Engineering and Industrial Coatings were discussed in this session.
Inspektor 27705 Nanostructured Materials was the speaker at this event.
The main points discussed included principles of Surface Engineering and Industrial Coatings, which are crucial for understanding how materials interact with their environment.
Surface engineering plays a significant role in industrial coatings as it helps to improve the durability and performance of the coated surfaces by modifying their properties at the microscopic level.
Nanostructured materials are those with structures or dimensions on the nanoscale. They have unique properties that can be manipulated in surface engineering for enhancing the performance of industrial coatings.
Surface engineering and industrial coatings play a crucial role in improving material durability by protecting them from environmental degradation, corrosion, wear, and tear.
Understanding these principles is essential for designing and developing high-performance materials that can withstand harsh environments, leading to improved product lifespan and reduced maintenance costs.
The session lasted from 3:00 PM to 4:50 PM.

The main topic of this article is 'Advanced Optimal Transport'.
The authors of this article are Y. Benamou, M. Gozlan and A. Lellouch.
Optimal transport plays a crucial role in machine learning by providing a mathematical framework for comparing two probability distributions, which can be used to solve various problems such as image registration and data analysis.
Optimal transport differs from other distance metrics like Euclidean or Manhattan distances in that it measures the distance between two probability distributions, rather than individual points. This makes it particularly useful for comparing complex data structures.
Optimal transport provides a mathematical framework that can be used in various machine learning applications, such as generative models, image processing, and anomaly detection. It allows for more sophisticated comparisons of data distributions than traditional distance metrics.
Optimal transport can be used to solve problems such as image registration, where two images need to be aligned so that corresponding points match. It can also be applied to tasks like denoising and segmentation.
The authors present a new algorithm for solving optimal transport problems, which they call the 'entropic regularization method'. This approach allows them to handle complex data distributions more effectively than previous methods.
Entropic regularization is a technique used in optimal transport that adds an entropy term to the cost function. This helps stabilize the algorithm and allows it to handle more complex data distributions.
One of the main challenges is dealing with high-dimensional data, as traditional methods can become computationally expensive and difficult to implement. Another challenge is finding a suitable regularization method that allows for more complex comparisons.
Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania

The Additive Manufacturing Laboratory takes place in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania on Monday at 10:00 AM to 11:50 AM.
The laboratory is located in PH A22.
This text discusses an Additive Manufacturing Laboratory.
The laboratory focuses on additive manufacturing.
The laboratory is held from Monday at 10:00 AM to 11:50 AM.
Additive manufacturing, also known as 3D printing, is a process of creating physical objects from digital designs by adding material layer by layer until the object is complete.
In this context, 'MW' stands for Monday with respect to the day and time of the laboratory session.
Pittsburgh is a city in western Pennsylvania, United States.
In this context, 'PH' stands for the room number where the laboratory takes place. It refers to PH A22 as the location of the Additive Manufacturing Laboratory.

The guidelines and restrictions place an upper limit on the maximum length of time allowable for master’s degree completion and certification.
Students seeking guidance about their program of study and degree requirements should consult with their academic advisor and/or appropriate associate dean.
Under U.S. Federal Title IV regulations, student eligibility for federal financial aid is contingent upon enrollment in and successful completion of courses that are counted as credit toward their current degree program.
Students must enroll each semester in at least 36 units that count toward their current degree program to receive the maximum amount of federal financial aid for which they may be eligible.
Students should consult with their designated college liaison in The HUB regarding billing and financial aid, particularly for early completion, longer-than-standard completion, or integrated undergraduate and master’s degree programs.
The policy on Master’s Student Statute of Limitations outlines guidelines and restrictions that place an upper limit on the maximum length of time allowable for master’s degree completion and certification.
The standard timeframe for completing a master's program varies by program, but students are expected to make normal progress toward their degree and graduate within this timeframe.
If a student does not complete their degree within the standard timeframe, they may face restrictions on their eligibility for federal financial aid and may need to consult with their academic advisor or appropriate associate dean regarding program of study.
Integrated undergraduate and master's degree programs are programs where students can complete both their bachelor's and master's degrees in a shorter timeframe than if they were pursuing each separately.

To receive an MCDS degree, students must have a Quality Point Average (QPA) of 3.0 and complete courses in the core curriculum, the MCDS seminar, electives, and capstone project.
The common MCDS core consists of five courses completed by all students in their first two semesters. This includes eight core and concentration courses, two 12-unit seminar courses, and two 12-unit capstone courses.
The three areas for choosing a concentration are Analytics, Systems, or Human-Centered Data Science. All students must complete at least one of these concentrations consisting of three courses.
To maintain full-time enrollment status, a student must enroll in a minimum of 36 course units per semester.
A student may not take more than 60 units per semester, without permission from their academic advisor.
Yes, all students must maintain full-time enrollment status (minimum of 36 units) in their final semester.
All MCDS students are expected to pass the 11-637 Foundations of Computational Data Science course by the end of their first semester.
Each MCDS student must pass the 11-637 Foundations of Computational Data Science course with a grade of 'B' or better.
The degree consists of two timing options based on the length of time the student spends working on the degree. The student chooses their timing at the start of the degree program (for visa requirements). Changes in timing are possible with the approval of the Director of the degree program and successful visa extension application with CMU’s Office of International Education.
All degree options consist of the same amount of coursework.
The two options for completing a degree in this program are Professional Preparation Track and Research Preparation Track.
The Professional Preparation Track is a 16-month degree consisting of study for Fall and Spring semesters, a summer internship, and Fall semester of study. Each semester consists of a minimum of 48 units of study.
Each semester in the Professional Preparation Track consists of a minimum of 48 units of study.
Students typically graduate in December after completing their 16-month degree consisting of Fall and Spring semesters, a summer internship, and Fall semester of study.
The Research Preparation Track is a 20-month degree consisting of study for Fall and Spring semesters, a summer internship, and a second year of Fall and Spring study.
Each semester in the Research Preparation Track consists of a minimum of 36 units of study.
This timing is designed for students interested in extending their time at CMU for developing applied research skills in preparation for further graduate study or research-oriented employment.
The per-semester course load is lower, but the total cost is higher since four semesters of tuition are paid for in this timing.
A typical student's study period under the Professional Preparation Track is 16 months, consisting of Fall and Spring semesters, a summer internship, and Fall semester of study.
MCDS students must complete 144 units.
There are four common core courses: Machine Learning, Cloud Computing, Interactive Data Science, and Data Science Seminar.

The three Capstone courses that all MCDS students must take are 11-634 - Capstone Planning Seminar, 11-635 - Capstone Research, and 11-632 - Data Science Capstone.
The learning outcomes of MCDS Program include designing, implementing, and evaluating analytic algorithms on sample datasets; explaining how a machine-learning model is developed for and evaluated on real world datasets; designing and executing experimental data collection and presenting resulting analyses using appropriate user experience (UX) techniques including interactive data visualizations; applying and customizing analytics, systems, and human-centered data science techniques to application-specific data science requirements and objectives; identifying tradeoffs among data science techniques (analytics, systems, and/or human-centered); survey, interpreting, and comparatively criticizing state of the art research talks and papers with emphasis on constructive improvements; organizing, executing, reporting on, and presenting a real world data science project in collaboration with other researchers/programmers.
Students electing to complete the Analytics concentration will also learn to design, implement and evaluate a software system and machine-learning model on real world datasets at real world scale; analyze and document data science requirements in different application domains and survey as well as critique state of the art solutions for those requirements.
Students electing to complete the Systems concentration will also learn to analyze and document data science requirements in different application domains; survey as well as critique state of the art solutions for those requirements.

The HCDS concentration emphasizes on providing experimental evidence for design decisions and anticipating and avert structural and/or implementation problems with systems design, especially with scaling and tail distributions.
Students will learn to design, implement and evaluate a user experience prototype for clear understanding of data science solutions. They will also apply social and behavioral research methods to data science problems to understand the human aspects of data collection and analysis.
The capstone project consists of students working individually or in a team on a project that integrates their educational experience. It can be a CMU research project, an industry-sponsored project, or occasionally students define their own topics with the MCDS faculty.

An independent study course allows students to cover a particular area of interest when no formal course is available in that subject area. It often offers the opportunity for research directly with a faculty member and are considered electives.
Each independent study course must be advised and approved by at least one faculty member. Agreement to supervise the course is voluntary on the part of the faculty member.
1) The student must request approval from their academic advisor and complete a proposal before the first day of classes in a given semester. 2) Enter into an agreement with the independent study supervisor that includes course expectations, including deliverables. 3) Secure the 'Independent Study Contract Form' from the MCDS administrator. 4) Complete the form, provide a brief description of the work to be done, including deliverables and how they will be graded. 5) Secure signatures of both the student and the supervisor. Return the form to the MCDS administrator in order to obtain approval for the independent study from the Director.
Independent study contracts must be submitted no later than on the last day of the first week of classes in a given semester.

An instructor may award a grade of 'I' when a student has been unable to complete the work of a course, but only if the work completed up to that date is of passing quality.
The instructor must specify the requirements for completing the work and designate a default letter grade in case the student fails to complete the remaining work.
The grounds for dismissal include committing two Academic Integrity Violations deemed infractions by the MCDS committee, committing an Academic Integrity Violation where the violation is deemed sufficiently egregious as determined by the MCDS program committee, and infringing a University Policy.

It is expected that students will complete a course during the academic semester in which the course was taken, as incomplete grades provide no undue advantage over other students.
The work completed up to that date must be of passing quality for the student to receive an incomplete grade.
An 'I' grade stands for Incomplete, which means that a student has not completed all the required course work.
If a student fails to complete the required course work by the end of an academic semester, they must finish it sooner as per the instructor's requirement.
The default letter grade designated by the instructor in case of incomplete course work is specified when awarding an 'I' grade.
Students are given until the end of the following academic semester or sooner if instructed by the teacher to complete their remaining work.
The number 20 likely represents the total amount of course work that a student needs to complete before receiving an 'I' grade, or it could be used for other purposes as per the instructor's discretion.
The term means that when an 'I' grade is awarded, the teacher specifies what letter grade will be given if the student fails to complete their remaining work.
Course work is considered completed when all assigned tasks and assignments have been finished by the student according to the instructor's requirements.
An 'I' grade may negatively impact a student's GPA and could potentially limit their access to certain programs, scholarships, or job opportunities.
The instructor plays a crucial role by specifying the requirements for completing course work and designating a default letter grade if the student fails to complete their remaining tasks.

The default grade becomes the grade of record.

The highest standards of academic integrity
If a student commits a second violation, the expected penalty is dismissal from the graduate program.
Students can review the policy at https://www.cmu.edu/policies/student-and-student-life/academic-integrity.html
The purpose of the policy is to provide definitions and expectations around academic integrity, including what constitutes cheating, plagiarism, and unauthorized assistance.
The policy outlines procedures for investigating, reporting, adjudicating, and appealing academic integrity violations. The severity of these consequences can vary depending on the nature of the offense.
The policy recommends that students review the procedure outlining the investigation, reporting, adjudication, and appeal processes for academic integrity violations.
Final grades may only be changed in exceptional circumstances such as manifest error (e.g., clear errors).
The instructor and department, unit or program have the discretion to approve changes to final grades.
The policy outlines an appeal process that includes reviewing, reporting, adjudicating, and appealing academic integrity violations.
Grading is a matter of sound discretion for the instructor. Final grades are rarely changed without the consent of the instructor who assigned the grade.
The policy provides definitions and expectations around academic integrity, as well as procedures for investigating and adjudicating violations. The Word also offers additional information on the topic.

The text does not provide specific details about what this curriculum change entailed, but it mentions that it happened due to insights related to critical path analysis. It seems that the change involved matching students with research advisors as soon as they arrive and expecting them to start doing research right away.
Porter Hall is mentioned in the text, but no specific location within CMU is provided. However, based on the context of the conversation, it can be inferred that Porter Hall was part of a new addition to the university and shared space with Civil Engineering.
Dan Siewiorek is mentioned in the text as Buhl University Professor of Electrical and Computer Engineering and Computer Science at CMU. No specific information about his role or accomplishments are provided, but it can be inferred that he joined the faculty in 1972.
Jordan is mentioned as a professor of electrical engineering at CMU. In 1969, they became the head of the Electrical Engineering Department.
According to Siewiorek's statement, there was a strong culture of collaboration at CMU. It is mentioned that people from different areas of expertise would collaborate on projects and create something greater than the sum of their individual contributions.
In this context, 'critical path' refers to the sequence of steps or tasks that must be completed in order for a project to finish on time. According to Shaw, it is important to start working on this path as early as possible.
The text does not provide a specific reason for the curriculum change, but it mentions that insights from critical path analysis played a role. It seems that this insight led to changes involving students and research advisors.
Porter Hall is mentioned as the location where both floors of what was then the 'new' addition were occupied by CMU. It also shared space with Civil Engineering, and it seems that students and staff from the Computation Center would intermingle with those in offices.

One idea from the Andrew project was a centralized or cloud-based system for files, which has since become widely used globally.
The high-bandwidth connection and advanced technology of the Andrew network made it an envy for other universities, attracting world-class students.

Satya's work from the Andrew days continues to influence the field, with many of his ideas becoming global solutions widely used today.

Scott believes that Computer Science needs different types of laboratories than what are called 'wet sciences' do, which suggests a need for more specialized resources.

The student-athlete named as the CMU Student-Athlete of the Week for Feb. 19 - Feb. 25 is senior men's track and field student-athlete Andrew McGovern.
The SMART Program is a proactive approach to providing varsity student-athletes with services they need to remain healthy and educated about their well-being.
Members of Health Services, Counseling and Psychological Services (CaPS) and Student Life collaborate with the Sports Medicine Staff to provide a comprehensive educational program for Carnegie Mellon University’s student-athlete population.
The four topics covered in the SMART Program's educational sessions are Nutrition, Drugs and Alcohol, Mental Health, and Sexual Assault.
The sports medicine team is committed to treating varsity student-athletes with a holistic approach by addressing mental and social factors in addition to physical symptoms of injuries.
The goal of the SMART Program is to prevent, recognize, refer and respond to potential risk tendencies that varsity student-athletes may experience in a collegiate setting. Topics include but not limited to disordered eating, substance abuse, mental wellness, sexual assault and dating violence prevention.
The SMART Program provides information and tools for varsity student athletes to make educated decisions when it comes to areas such as nutrition, drugs and alcohol, mental health, and sexual assault.
The SMART Program's team consists of members from Health Services, Counseling and Psychological Services (CaPS), Student Life, and the Sports Medicine Staff.
The purpose of the educational sessions in the SMART Program is to provide a comprehensive and multi-disciplinary educational program for Carnegie Mellon University’s student-athlete population.
A holistic approach means treating varsity student athletes by addressing mental and social factors, in addition to physical symptoms of injuries.
The main goal of the SMART program is to prevent, recognize, refer and respond to potential risk tendencies that varsity student-athletes may experience in a collegiate setting.
The SMART program covers various topics including disordered eating, substance abuse, mental wellness, sexual assault and dating violence prevention.
The team for the SMART program includes a Coordinator of Student-Athlete Wellness, Certified Athletic Trainers, Team Physicians, Director of Student Health Services, Nutritionist, Health Promotion Specialist, Director of CaPS, Athletic Director, Office of Community Standards and Integrity, and Office of Title IX Initiatives.
The seminars in the SMART program show varsity student-athletes how to deal with a wide range of issues from homework and class conflicts to drug and alcohol use, through Carnegie Mellon University’s services for athletes.
The SMART programs are considered essential because they inform athletes on potential health risks, both mental and physical, and also challenge them to discuss difficult topics with their teammates.
Kim Hochstedler from Women's Swimming and Diving participated in the CaPS session on Drugs and Alcohol.
Lisa Murphy from Women's Basketball attended a Nutrition session with food samples and another Nutrition session.
Varsity student-athletes can share the information they learned in the SMART program through Facebook, Twitter, Email or Print.
Athletics is committed to promoting environmental practices and sustainable initiatives within its office spaces and throughout its facilities.
Recycling bins for paper and plastic products are readily available in all athletic spaces and events to create a low waste environment.
The compost program exists in Athletic office areas to promote sustainable initiatives.
Vehicle idling is prohibited at all loading zones in athletic facilities to reduce waste and promote environmental practices.
Athletics uses 30% recycled paper for general purpose printing and copying.
Water fountains in athletic spaces are updated with water bottle refill stations to promote sustainable initiatives.
Athletics only purchases new appliances that are ENERGY STAR, EPEAT or CEE qualified to promote environmental practices.
All e-waste from the department is recycled by Athletics to promote sustainable initiatives.
Jason Mlodzianowski, Associate Athletics Director for Events, Facilities and Operations, should receive your green ideas to promote environmental practices.
The two actions suggested by Athletics to help promote sustainable initiatives are recycling and composting whenever possible, and turning off lights and unplugging electronics when not in use.

The purpose of the Carnegie Mellon University campus community's central gathering place, which is located in the Jared L. Cohon University Center, is to provide numerous facilities for athletics, assemblies and dining as well as lounge and retail areas.
The new 62,000 square feet expansion of the Cohon Center was opened in May 2016.
The second floor of the new expansion of the Cohon Center houses two exercise studios and a cycling studio.
The Maureen B. Cohon Cardio Fitness Center is located on the second floor of the new expansion of the Cohon Center.
To use the recreational facilities in the Cohon University Center, a valid Carnegie Mellon ID is required. Users must follow all posted rules and clean equipment when done. They should wear proper athletic attire and tennis shoes and not bring food or drink around machines or into studios.
Locker rentals and towel service is available for purchase at the Cohon University Center.
Students can find information about hours of operation for recreational facilities on the facility hours page.
According to the posted rules, chalk is not permitted in the Fitness Center.
