The author of this text is ACM.
According to the text, the person was born in 1959.
This person got their B.S. degree from Carnegie Mellon University, M.S. degree from the University of California at Berkeley, and Ph.D. degree also from the University of California at Berkeley.
This person is currently a Professor of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science at Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT).
Apart from MIT, this person also works as a professor at Weizmann Institute of Science.
The person co-leads the Cryptography and Information Security Group at MIT.
This person's current position at MIT is RSA Professor of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science.
The text mentions several honors and awards such as Bantrel Postdoctoral Fellowship, Massachusetts Institute of Technology (1983), Assistant Professor at MIT (1983-1987), Associate Professor at MIT (1987-1992), Professor of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science at MIT (1992-present), Professor of Computer Science and Applied Mathematics at Weizmann Institute of Science (1993-present).
The text does not mention the exact location, but it says that this person was born in New York City.
Shafi Goldwasser has received the IBM Young Faculty Development Award, NSF Presidential Young Investigator Award, NSF Award for Women in Science, Co-winner of SIGACT Gödel Prize twice, ACM Grace Murray Hopper Award, RSA Award in Mathematics for Outstanding Mathematical Contributions to Cryptography, Weizmann Institute Levenson Prize in Mathematics, Fellow of American Academy of Arts and Sciences, National Academy of Sciences, and National Academy of Engineering. She also received the Distinguished Alumnus Award in Computer Science and Engineering from University of California, Berkeley.
Shafi Goldwasser received the ACM Turing Award along with Silvio Micali, for transformative work that laid the complexity-theoretic foundations for the science of cryptography, and in the process pioneered new methods for efficient verification of mathematical proofs in complexity theory.
Shafi Goldwasser's research subjects include cryptography, computational complexity theory, and the science of cryptography.
Shafi Goldwasser received her Franklin Institute Benjamin Franklin Medal in Computer and Cognitive Science from the United States.
Additional materials for further study include a video interview with Shafi Goldwasser.
Shafi Goldwasser received the RSA Award in Mathematics for Outstanding Mathematical Contributions to Cryptography in 1998.
Shafi Goldwasser is a Fellow of the National Academy of Sciences since 2004.
Shafi Goldwasser received her Weizmann Institute Levenson Prize in Mathematics in 1999.
The name of Shafi Goldwasser's co-winner for SIGACT Gödel Prize twice is Silvio Micali.
Shafi Goldwasser received her ACM Grace Murray Hopper Award in 1996.
Shafi Goldwasser
Cryptography, computational complexity, computational number theory and probabilistic algorithms.
Silvio Micali
Shafi Goldwasser discovered this.
She showed how to use the theory of elliptic curves to distinguish primes from composites.
Combinatorial property testing
Probabilistically checkable proofs.
2012
ACM Turing Award Lecture Video
Shafi was born in 1959 in New York City.
Her family returned to Israel where Shafi attended grade school in Tel Aviv. Her parents were Israeli, and her joint American/Israeli citizenship presaged the two countries that would play such an important role in her research.
In high school she was especially interested in physics, mathematics and literature.
Shafi enrolled in graduate school in Computer Science at the University of California, Berkeley, without knowing what she wanted to study.
She began to see that her interests lay in theoretical areas. She soon met a group of enthusiastic young theoretical computer scientists – including Eric Bach, Faith Ellen, Mike Luby, Jeff Shallit, Vijay Vazirani and her Turing Award co-recipient Silvio Micali.
Her master's work was with Michael Powell and David Patterson, studying the optimal instruction set for the RISC architecture.
She had a summer internship at the RAND Corporation in Los Angeles. She loved living on Venice Beach, but her seduction by California wasn’t complete until she drove up the coast road one weekend and entered Berkeley for the first time.
She soon met a group of enthusiastic young theoretical computer scientists – including Eric Bach, Faith Ellen, Mike Luby, Jeff Shallit, Vijay Vazirani and her Turing Award co-recipient Silvio Micali – and she began to see that her interests lay in theoretical areas.
One computer science course that she especially remembers, taught by Jon Bentley, was an algorithms and discrete math course that she loved.
Manuel Blum
Santa Barbara
Ron Rivest, Adi Shamir and Len Adleman
A class of Manuel Blum’s
How to hide partial information in 'mental poker'
An essentially perfect way of encrypting a single bit
A 'hybrid' technique
Quadratic residuosity assumption
How to play 'mental poker' while hiding all partial information
Shafi graduated from Berkeley in 1984 and went to the Massachusetts Institute of Technology as a postdoc, then became a faculty member. She was appointed as the RSA Professor of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science in 1997.
Shafi began a parallel career as a Professor of Computer Science and Applied Mathematics at the Weizmann Institute of Science in Israel in 1992.
Shafi, with her husband and computer scientist Nir Shavit and their two sons, somehow divide their time between the two institutes, spending about three years at a time in each country.
It was an exciting time when Shafi came to M.I.T because she joined a group with similar research interests: Micali had arrived, and Benny Chor, Oded Goldreich, Ron Rivest and Mike Sipser were there.
With Goldreich and Micali [ 4 ], Shafi investigated whether the notion of a pseudorandom number generator could be generalized so that one could generate exponentially many bits (or equivalently, a function) pseudorandomly.
They also showed how to provably transform a pseudorandom number generator into a pseudorandom function generator. These ideas had applications to the (then) new field of Learning Theory, providing examples of things that cannot be learned.
This definition was in itself important, and it is why we understand today what it means for a block cipher such as AES to be secure.
Shafi's research had applications to the (then) new field of Learning Theory.
Their ideas provided examples of things that cannot be learned.
An interactive proof, as defined by Shafi and Micali, is a process in which a prover convinces a verifier of the correctness of a mathematical proposition with overwhelming probability if and only if the proposition is correct.
The first ACM SIGACT Gödel Prize was awarded to Shafi, Micali (and later Rackoff) for their work on interactive proofs and zero-knowledge proofs.
The main idea behind 'no knowledge' in interactive proofs, as suggested by Shafi and Micali, is that the verifier should not gain any new information about why a statement is true during an interaction with the prover.
The first example of zero-knowledge interactive proofs was given by Shafi using quadratic residuosity.
Goldwasser recalls introducing zero-knowledge proofs with Micali.
The interactive proof notion given by Babai and Moran uses public coins, while that of Shafi and Sipser uses private coins. However, they later proved that the two notions are equivalent.
Michael Sipser suggested the name 'interactive proof', and he also worked with Shafi to prove that the interactive proof notion using private coins is equivalent to the one using public coins.
Shafi's work on zero-knowledge proofs led to a huge research program in the community that continues to this day, including results showing that distrusting parties can compute a function of all their inputs without learning any knowledge about other people’s inputs beyond what follows from the value of the function.
The main contribution of Shafi's work on zero-knowledge proofs was defining 'no knowledge' as simulatability, which was a very important concept in interactive proof systems.
Two or more provers who cannot talk with each other.
Two provers are sufficient.
The existence of these proofs (with certain parameters) implies a hardness of approximation result for certain NP-complete languages.
If the size of a maximum clique in a graph can be approximated within a constant factor, then all of NP can be accepted in nearly polynomial time.
Probabilistically checkable proofs, an alternative characterization of multi-prover proofs.
Johan Håstad.
The concept of a probabilistically checkable proof.
Shafi worked with Mihir Bellare, Carsten Lund and Alexander Russell.
The computational problem that quantum computers have not been able to attack yet is approximating the shortest vector size in an integer lattice. This problem forms the basis of public-key cryptography.
Shafi and Goldreich showed that it is unlikely for the approximation problem to be NP-hard by providing an especially succinct interactive proof for this problem.
Property testing is a subject introduced by Shafi, Goldreich and Dana Ron. It involves determining whether a given object (like a graph) has a certain property or if it's far from any other objects with that property after examining only a small number of locations.
Shafi, along with Yael Tauman Kalai and Guy Rothblum, introduced a practical way to delegate the computation of small-depth functions.
One example of an NP-complete property that can be tested by property testers is 3-coloring, which involves coloring a graph with three colors such that no two adjacent vertices share the same color.
The theme of approximation is present in various aspects of Shafi's work. For instance, she has worked on problems related to approximating the shortest vector size in an integer lattice and fine-tuning some PCP parameters for improved results.
Goldwasser worked with Mihir Bellare, Carsten Lund and Alexander Russell to define the concept of a probabilistically checkable proof.
Shafi's recent research primarily revolves around how to delegate computation to an untrusted 'cloud' computer, which is one of the most important areas in cryptography today.
Dr. Shafi's recent research focuses on how a user can delegate computation to a very fast but untrusted 'cloud' computer.
Dr. Shafi, along with her colleagues, proposed a practical formulation for delegating computation of small-depth functions.
The 'one-time program' model obfuscates a program so it can be executed only for a prescribed number of executions, assuming a special kind of universal secure hardware.
Dr. Shafi proposed 'token-based obfuscation' as a new paradigm for general function obfuscation.
Dr. Shafi has been focusing on protection against 'side-channel attacks', where an adversary can get information not part of the stream of bits specified by a protocol.
Dr. Shafi, along with Adi Akavia and Vaikuntanathan, had the first results on this topic.
The result from Dr. Shafi, Akavia, and Vaikuntanathan marked the start of this research effort.
Dr. Shafi's household has a total of three Gödel Prizes, which may be a record.
Dr. Shafi has become a fan and practitioner of 'Playback Theater', an improvisational interactive group experience.
Shafi is a person who has won an award.
Nir Shavit also won the Gödel Prize, which makes their household record-breaking in terms of awards won.
Playback Theater is an improvisational interactive group experience that Shafi has become a fan and practitioner of recently.

The diving event involves athletes jumping off a high platform into the water.
